text: Originating as a term in the United States in the first half of the 20th century, it became popular again in the UK in the 1950s, where it was associated with artists such as Lonnie Donegan, The Vipers Skiffle Group, Ken Colyer and Chas McDevitt.

title: Skiffle
text: Skiffle played a major part in beginning the careers of later eminent jazz, pop, blues, folk and rock musicians and has been seen as a critical stepping stone to the second British folk revival, blues boom and British Invasion of the US popular music scene.

title: Cachi Cachi music
text: Cachi Cachi music, also spelled Kachi Kachi, Kachi-Kachi and Katchi-Katchi, is a term that was coined to refer to music played by Puerto Ricans in Hawaii, when they migrated to Hawaii.

title: Cachi Cachi music
text: It is a "variation of dance music found in Hawaii".

title: Cachi Cachi music
text: Sometimes cachi cachi "involves fast, improvised solos" on the guitar.

title: Cachi Cachi music
text: The "influence on Hawai'i endures to this day in the musical form known as "cachi cachi" played on the quarto  and derivative of the Puerto Rican jibaro style."

title: Cachi Cachi music
text: "Jibaro" means peasant in Spanish.

title: Background music
text: Background music refers to various styles of music or soundscapes primarily intended to be passively listened to.

title: Background music
text: It is not meant to be the main focus of an audience, but rather to supplement that which is meant to be focused upon.

title: Background music
text: Music that is played at a low volume and is not the main focus of an audience is also referred to as background music.

title: Background music
text: Traditional examples of background music include music played at various social gatherings and music played in certain retail venues.

title: Background music
text: It is also common to employ background music in various electronic media including film, television, video games, and Internet videos such as video blogs.

title: Kantrum
text: Kantrum (Thai กันตรึม) is a type of folk music played by the Khmer in Isan, Thailand, living near the border with Cambodia.

title: Kantrum
text: It is a fast, traditional dance music.

title: Kantrum
text: In its purest form, cho-kantrum, singers, percussion and fiddles dominate the sound.

title: Kantrum
text: A more modern form using electric instrumentation arose in the mid-1980s.

title: Chillador
text: A chillador is a very small guitar-shaped fretted stringed instrument, usually with 10, 12, or 14 metal strings, in paired or tripled courses.It is played in Peru and in some border areas in Bolivia, usually has 5 courses like its cousin, the charango.

title: Chillador
text: The sort of music played on chillador it is very much like the music played on charango.

title: Chillador
text: The main difference between charango and chillador is that the charango soundbox is made of an armadillo shell while the chillador is just a little guitar.

title: Die Rhöner Säuwäntzt
text: Die Rhöner Säuwäntzt are a Skiffle-Bluesband from Eichenzell-Lütter in Hessen, Germany.

title: Die Rhöner Säuwäntzt
text: The line-up consists of Martin Caba, Christoph Günther and Christoph Leipold playing Skiffle-Blues with lyrics based on Rhön Mountains dialect and other Hessian dialects varieties.

title: Die Rhöner Säuwäntzt
text: The expression "Säuwäntzt" means pork belly and refers also to untidy or unruly children and youth.

title: Minoru Kojima
text: Minoru Kojima (born 11 October 1968) was the original guitarist for Japanese experimental punk band The Mad Capsule Markets.

title: Minoru Kojima
text: He is also known as Scene or Shin Murohime, which is apparently a conglomeration of characters from the names of different Boøwy members.

title: Minoru Kojima
text: He started The Mad Capsule Markets (which at the time was called Berrie) in 1985, with vocalist Hiroshi Kyono, in an attempt to create "loud, punk music" after becoming "bored" with music played on television and radio.

title: Minoru Kojima
text: After the release of Mad's Noël Coward "Humanity", Minoru left the band and was replaced by "support guitarist" Ai Ishigaki.

title: Minoru Kojima
text: In 1991 Minoru started Die in Cries and in 1994 became a member of The Bloody Imitation Society.

title: Minoru Kojima
text: Over the years Minoru worked with more bands and even went solo for a short time before returning to Mad to play on "Good Day" from their album "010" and playing on their "Cistm Konfliqt" tour.

title: Winston Lagoon
text: Winston Lagoon ( ) is a lagoon indenting the southeast coast of Heard Island in the southern Indian Ocean, about 1 nautical mile (1.9 km) northeast of Cape Lockyer.

title: Winston Lagoon
text: The feature is roughly portrayed on an American sealer chart of the 1860 period.

title: Winston Lagoon
text: It was sighted from the air by Lieutenant Malcolm Smith, RAAF, pilot of the ANARE (Australian National Antarctic Research Expeditions) seaplane that made the first reconnaissance flight over the island in 1948.

title: Winston Lagoon
text: Lieutenant Smith proposed that it be named Lake Winston after his wife.

title: Winston Lagoon
text: In view of his death in an aircraft accident shortly afterward, this proposal was adopted by Australian Antarctic Names and Medals Committee (ANCA) with only a change of generic term.

title: Winston Lagoon
text: Click here to see a map of Heard Island and McDonald Islands, including all major topographical features.

title: Malcolm Smith (American football)
text: Malcolm Xavier Smith (born July 5, 1989) is an American football linebacker for the San Francisco 49ers of the National Football League (NFL).

title: Malcolm Smith (American football)
text: Smith played college football at USC.

title: Malcolm Smith (American football)
text: He was drafted by the Seattle Seahawks in the seventh round of the 2011 NFL Draft.

title: Malcolm Smith (American football)
text: Smith was named the Most Valuable Player of Super Bowl XLVIII after they defeated the Denver Broncos.

title: Super Bowl XLVIII
text: Super Bowl XLVIII was an American football game between the American Football Conference (AFC) champion Denver Broncos and National Football Conference (NFC) champion Seattle Seahawks to decide the National Football League (NFL) champion for the 2013 season.

title: Super Bowl XLVIII
text: The Seahawks defeated the Broncos 43–8, the largest margin of victory for an underdog and tied for the third largest point differential overall (35) in Super Bowl history with Super Bowl XXVII (1993).

title: Super Bowl XLVIII
text: It was the first time the winning team scored over 40 points, while holding their opponent to under 10.

title: Super Bowl XLVIII
text: This became the first Super Bowl victory for the Seahawks and the fifth Super Bowl loss for the Broncos, the most of any team.

title: Super Bowl XLVIII
text: The game was played on February 2, 2014, at MetLife Stadium at the Meadowlands Sports Complex in East Rutherford, New Jersey, the first Super Bowl played outdoors in a cold-weather city and the first Super Bowl to be played on a February 2.

title: 2013 NBA Summer League
text: The 2013 NBA Summer League is a pro basketball league run by the NBA just after the 2013 NBA draft.

title: 2013 NBA Summer League
text: It gives newly drafted players a chance to test their skills against each other, and to give them a feel for professional basketball.

title: 2013 NBA Summer League
text: All 30 NBA teams participated, along with the D-League Select.

title: 2013 NBA Summer League
text: The Miami Heat were the only team to participate in both Summer Leagues.

title: 2013 NBA Summer League
text: It ran from July 7–12 in Orlando and July 12–22 in Las Vegas.

title: 2013 NBA Summer League
text: Jeremy Lamb of the Oklahoma City Thunder was named the Most Valuable Player of the Orlando Summer League.

title: 2013 NBA Summer League
text: Jonas Valančiūnas of the Toronto Raptors went on to be named the Most Valuable Player of the Las Vegas Summer League.

title: 2013 NBA Summer League
text: Ian Clark of the Golden State Warriors was named the Most Valuable Player of the Las Vegas Summer League Championship Game.

title: Steve Clark (American football)
text: Stephen Spence Clark (born August 2, 1960) is a former professional American football player who played .

title: Steve Clark (American football)
text: He also played on two state championship teams in high school which were a combined (25-1) over two years and was a five team all-American including "Parade Magazine", he was also named Most Valuable Player of the state of Utah.

title: Steve Clark (American football)
text: At the University of Utah he was named two time All-WAC defensive tackle, Defensive Most Valuable Player of the Western Athletic Conference and First Team All-American.

title: Steve Clark (American football)
text: He also played in the East-West Shrine Game and was named MVP of the Senior Bowl.

title: Steve Clark (American football)
text: After the Senior Bowl he was drafted by Don Shula and The Miami Dolphins, his second year in the NFL he played both ways in a pre-season game and Coach Shula knew he had a guy that could back up every position on the offensive and defensive line as well as long snap.

title: Steve Clark (American football)
text: He earned a starting position at right guard and played against  when the Dolphins beat the Chicago Bears on Monday Night Football to help keep the undefeated Dolphin record intact.

title: Steve Clark (American football)
text: In the NFL, he also played on two Super Bowl teams with the Miami Dolphins and was the starting right guard before being injured.

title: Steve Clark (American football)
text: Just recently Steve was named to the top 100 greatest players in the history of the University of Utah actually being named 9th best of All-Time.

title: 1959 Illinois Fighting Illini football team
text: The 1959 Illinois Fighting Illini football team was an American football team that represented the University of Illinois during the 1959 Big Ten Conference football season.

title: 1959 Illinois Fighting Illini football team
text: In their 18th year under head coach Ray Eliot, the Illini compiled a 5–3–1 record and finished in a tie for third place in the Big Ten Conference.

title: 1959 Illinois Fighting Illini football team
text: After the season, guard Bill Burrell was selected as the team's most valuable player and also received the Chicago Tribune Silver Football trophy as the Big Ten's most valuable player.

title: 103rd Grey Cup
text: The 103rd Grey Cup was a Canadian football game that was played on November 29, 2015 between the East Division champion Ottawa Redblacks and the West Division champion Edmonton Eskimos to decide the Canadian Football League (CFL) championship for the 2015 season.

title: 103rd Grey Cup
text: The game was played at Investors Group Field in Winnipeg, Manitoba.

title: 103rd Grey Cup
text: Shaw Communications was the presenting sponsor of the game; it was the first time in CFL history that the Grey Cup has been sponsored.

title: 103rd Grey Cup
text: The Eskimos won the contest 26–20 to claim their 14th Grey Cup championship in franchise history and first since 2005.

title: 103rd Grey Cup
text: Mike Reilly was named Most Valuable Player and Shamawd Chambers received the Dick Suderman Trophy as Most Valuable Canadian.

title: Richard Smith (rugby union, born 1973)
text: Richard Malcolm Smith (born 6 June 1973) is a former rugby union player who played scrum-half for Ebbw Vale RFC, Sale Sharks, Worcester Warriors, Newport RFC, Bristol Rugby, Cardiff RFC, Newbridge RFC, Merthyr RFC and Cardiff Blues.

title: Richard Smith (rugby union, born 1973)
text: He was a regular in the Wales 22 but only gained one Wales cap as he was being overlooked for Robert Howley and Rupert Moon.

title: Richard Smith (rugby union, born 1973)
text: He is well known for using the box kick to relieve the pressure posed by the opposition and to also gain territory.

title: Richard Smith (rugby union, born 1973)
text: He was a very skilful, technical and intelligent rugby player with excellent game management.

title: Kevin Durant
text: Kevin Wayne Durant (born September 29, 1988) is an American professional basketball player for the Golden State Warriors of the National Basketball Association (NBA).

title: Kevin Durant
text: He has won an NBA championship, an NBA Most Valuable Player Award, the Bill Russell NBA Finals Most Valuable Player Award, the NBA All-Star Game Most Valuable Player Award, four NBA scoring titles, the NBA Rookie of the Year Award, and two Olympic gold medals.

title: Kevin Durant
text: Durant has also been selected to seven All-NBA teams and eight NBA All-Star teams.

title: Super Bowl Most Valuable Player Award
text: The Super Bowl Most Valuable Player Award, or Super Bowl MVP, is presented annually to the most valuable player of the Super Bowl, the National Football League's (NFL) championship game.

title: Super Bowl Most Valuable Player Award
text: The winner is chosen by a fan vote during the game and by a panel of 16 football writers and broadcasters who vote after the game.

title: Super Bowl Most Valuable Player Award
text: The media panel's ballots count for 80 percent of the vote tally, while the viewers' ballots make up the other 20 percent.

title: Super Bowl Most Valuable Player Award
text: The game's viewing audience can vote on the Internet or by using cellular phones; Super Bowl XXXV, held in 2001, was the first Super Bowl with fan voting.

title: Zilpo Road
text: Zilpo Road is a National Forest Scenic Byway in the forested hills of eastern Kentucky, United States.

title: Zilpo Road
text: The nine mile byway starts south of Morehead, Kentucky and can be accessed by U.S. Highway 60.

title: Zilpo Road
text: The byway travels through the Daniel Boone National Forest and ends on the western shore of Cave Run Lake at the Zilpo Recreation Area.

title: Zilpo Road
text: It follows FSR 918, which is a two lane paved road suitable for all motor vehicles and is usually open throughout the year.

title: RISE (sculpture)
text: RISE is a concept £400,000 public art spherical metal sculpture in Belfast by Wolfgang Buttress.

title: RISE (sculpture)
text: It is 37.5 m high and 30 m wide and was constructed in early 2011 in the centre of the Broadway roundabout, at the junction of the Westlink and M1 motorway, a main gateway to the city where (as of 2009) more than 80,000 cars on average flow past it each day.

title: RISE (sculpture)
text: It is informally known as The Balls on the Falls as this junction also gives access to the Falls Road area via Broadway.

title: Peterman Hill
text: Peterman Hill is an unincorporated community located on a high ridge in Boyd County, Kentucky, on the Catlettsburg-Cannonsburg Pike (the Cannonsburg Road), three miles (5 km) west of Catlettsburg.

title: Peterman Hill
text: The road was originally known as Midland Trail and later U.S. 60 alternate until 1964 when it reverted to county maintenance.

title: Peterman Hill
text: It is now State Route 3294.

title: Arkansas Highway 113
text: Arkansas Highway 113 (AR 113 and Hwy.

title: Arkansas Highway 113
text: 113) is a north–south state highway that runs in Central Arkansas.

title: Arkansas Highway 113
text: The route runs 29.48 mi from Arkansas Highway 10 to Morrilton.

title: Arkansas Highway 113
text: This also gives access to some rural areas west of Morrilton.

title: Arkansas Highway 113
text: It runs through Pulaski, Perry, and Conway Counties.

title: Arkansas Highway 113
text: It contains no spur of business routes.

title: California State Route 266
text: State Route 266 (SR 266) is a state highway in the U.S. state of California.

title: California State Route 266
text: The route traverses Fish Lake Valley, which is part in California and part in Nevada.

title: California State Route 266
text: The route connects two Nevada state routes that traverse the Nevada portion of the valley, NV 264 and NV 266.

title: California State Route 266
text: The only connection from SR 266 to the rest of California's road network is via SR 168.

title: California State Route 266
text: Prior to 1986 the southern and northern halves of modern SR 266 had separate numerical designations.

title: California State Route 266
text: The southern portion of the highway, along with modern SR 168, dates to the auto trail era, forming part of the Midland Trail.

title: Morehead, Kentucky
text: Morehead is a home rule-class city located along US 60 (the historic Midland Trail) and Interstate 64 in Rowan County, Kentucky, in the United States.

title: Morehead, Kentucky
text: It is the seat of its county.

title: Morehead, Kentucky
text: The population was 6,845 at the time of the 2010 U.S. census.

title: Roman bridge of Salamanca
text: The Roman bridge of Salamanca (in Spanish: "Puente romano de Salamanca"), also known as Puente Mayor del Tormes is a Roman bridge crossing the Tormes River on the banks of the city of Salamanca, in Castile and León, Spain.

title: Roman bridge of Salamanca
text: The importance of the bridge as a symbol of the city can be seen in the first quartering of city's coat of arms (along with its stone bull-verraco.)

title: Roman bridge of Salamanca
text: Has been known traditionally as "puente mayor" and as "puente prinçipal" (main bridge) which gives access to the southern part of the city.

title: Roman bridge of Salamanca
text: The bridge is presented in the 21st century as a result of several restorations.

title: Roman bridge of Salamanca
text: One of the disasters that most affected it was the Flood of San Policarpo (January 26's night) of year 1626.

title: Roman bridge of Salamanca
text: It is declared Artistic Historic Monument on June 3, 1931, and Bien de Interés Cultural since 1998.

title: Roman bridge of Salamanca
text: Until the beginning of 20th century it did not lose its status as the single point of access to the city, and for many years continued to bear heavy traffic.

title: Roman bridge of Salamanca
text: From the construction of a third bridge for road traffic it remains a unique way of pedestrian and walking uses.

title: Hawks Nest, West Virginia
text: Hawk's Nest, the site of Hawks Nest State Park, is a peak on Gauley Mountain in Ansted, West Virginia, USA.

title: Hawks Nest, West Virginia
text: The cliffs at this point rise 585 ft (178 m) above the New River.

title: Hawks Nest, West Virginia
text: Located on the James River and Kanawha Turnpike (the road that served as an extension of the canal across what is now West Virginia), many early travelers on this road stopped to see the view of the river below.

title: Hawks Nest, West Virginia
text: In modern times, the Midland Trail carries U.S. Route 60 through the same general route.

title: Hawks Nest, West Virginia
text: Ample parking at the overlook in the state park provides tourists with free access to the views.

title: Hawaii Route 64
text: Route 64 is a three-mile (5 km) road that stretches from Nimitz Highway (Hawaii Route 92) to the entrance of Sand Island State Recreation Area just west of downtown Honolulu.

title: Hawaii Route 64
text: The route also goes by the street name as Sand Island Parkway.

title: Hawaii Route 64
text: The route gives access to Sand Island State Recreation Area and the U.S. Coast Guard Honolulu Branch by crossing the Kapalama Channel.

title: Glen Ferris, West Virginia
text: Glen Ferris is a census-designated place (CDP) on the western bank of the Kanawha River in Fayette County, West Virginia.

title: Glen Ferris, West Virginia
text: It is situated approximately one mile south of the town of Gauley Bridge.

title: Glen Ferris, West Virginia
text: The sole highway linking Glen Ferris to the area is U.S. Route 60, known also as the Midland Trail.

title: Glen Ferris, West Virginia
text: As of the 2010 census, its population was 203; the community had 104 housing units, 87 of which were occupied.

title: Glen Ferris, West Virginia
text: The village is roughly a mile and a half in length.

title: Glen Ferris, West Virginia
text: Glen Ferris is home to two churches, one Apostolic and one Methodist.

title: Glen Ferris, West Virginia
text: A railway owned by Norfolk Southern runs parallel to US Route 60 through the village.

title: Shane Stanley
text: Shane Stanley (born June 15, 1971 in Los Angeles) is a multi-Emmy Award-winning filmmaker and founder of Visual Arts Entertainment, a film and television production company based in Los Angeles.

title: Shane Stanley
text: Best known for executive producing "Gridiron Gang" starring Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson for Sony Pictures and directing Bret Michaels music videos supporting the hit show "Rock of Love".

title: Shane Stanley
text: Stanley, a four-time nominee, was the youngest to ever win a production Emmy Award, winning his first at sixteen and his second at nineteen for his work on The Desperate Passage Series.

title: Shane Stanley
text: Stanley made his directorial debut helming his own screenplay "A Sight for Sore Eyes" which starred Academy Award nominee Gary Busey.

title: Shane Stanley
text: Besides being honored with dozens of prestigious awards and film festival honors, the film was invited to screen at the Cannes Film Festival in 2005 and won Best Drama at the International Family Film Festival in 2006.

title: Robert Cummings
text: Charles Clarence Robert Orville Cummings, known as Bob Cummings (June 9, 1910 – December 2, 1990), was an American film and television actor known mainly for his roles in comedy films such as "The Devil and Miss Jones" (1941) and "Princess O'Rourke" (1943), but was also effective in dramatic films, especially two of Alfred Hitchcock's thrillers, "Saboteur" (1942) and "Dial M for Murder" (1954).

title: Robert Cummings
text: Cummings received five Primetime Emmy Award nominations, and won the Primetime Emmy Award for Best Actor in a Single Performance in 1955.

title: Robert Cummings
text: On February 8, 1960, he received two stars on the Hollywood Walk of Fame for his contributions to the motion picture and television industries.

title: Robert Cummings
text: The motion picture star is at 6816 Hollywood Boulevard, the television star is on 1718 Vine Street.

title: Beau Bridges
text: Lloyd Vernet "Beau" Bridges III (born December 9, 1941) is an American actor and director.

title: Beau Bridges
text: He is a three-time Emmy, two-time Golden Globe and one-time Grammy Award winner.

title: Beau Bridges
text: He is also a two-time Screen Actors Guild Award nominee.

title: Beau Bridges
text: Bridges was awarded a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame on April 7, 2003 at 7065 Hollywood Boulevard for his contributions to the television industry.

title: Beau Bridges
text: He is the son of actor Lloyd Bridges and elder brother of fellow actor Jeff Bridges.

title: Annette Bening
text: Annette Carol Bening (born May 29, 1958) is an American actress.

title: Annette Bening
text: She began her career on stage with the Colorado Shakespeare Festival company in 1980, and played Lady Macbeth in 1984 at the American Conservatory Theatre.

title: Annette Bening
text: She was nominated for the 1987 Tony Award for Best Featured Actress in a Play for her Broadway debut in "Coastal Disturbances".

title: Annette Bening
text: She is a four-time Academy Award nominee; for "The Grifters" (1990), "American Beauty" (1999), "Being Julia" (2004) and "The Kids Are All Right" (2010).

title: Annette Bening
text: In 2006, she received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.

title: Farrah Fawcett
text: Farrah Fawcett (born Ferrah Leni Fawcett; February 2, 1947 – June 25, 2009) was an American actress, model, and artist.

title: Farrah Fawcett
text: A four-time Emmy Award nominee and six-time Golden Globe Award nominee, Fawcett rose to international fame when she posed for her iconic red swimsuit poster – which became the best selling pin-up poster in history – and starred as private investigator Jill Munroe in the first season of the television series "Charlie's Angels" (1976–1977).

title: Farrah Fawcett
text: In 1996, she was ranked No. 26 on "TV Guide"'s "50 Greatest TV stars of All-Time".

title: List of stars on the Hollywood Walk of Fame
text: The following is a list of the stars' actual locations on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.

title: List of stars on the Hollywood Walk of Fame
text: The list does not include a star's name until his or her actual award ceremony, as on multiple occasions and for various reasons stars have been withdrawn prior to the award ceremony.

title: List of stars on the Hollywood Walk of Fame
text: The list should be consistent with the list on the Hollywood Walk of Fame website maintained by the Hollywood Chamber of Commerce.

title: List of stars on the Hollywood Walk of Fame
text: The stars are ordered alphabetically by surname.

title: Kevin Bacon
text: Kevin Norwood Bacon (born July 8, 1958) is an American actor and musician.

title: Kevin Bacon
text: His notable films include musical-drama film "Footloose" (1984), the controversial historical conspiracy legal thriller "JFK" (1991), the legal drama "A Few Good Men" (1992), the historical docudrama "Apollo 13" (1995), and the mystery drama "Mystic River" (2003).

title: Kevin Bacon
text: Bacon is also known for taking on darker roles such as that of a sadistic guard in "Sleepers" (1996) and troubled former child abuser in a critically acclaimed performance in "The Woodsman" (2004).

title: Kevin Bacon
text: He is equally prolific on television, having starred in the Fox drama series "The Following" (2013–2015).

title: Kevin Bacon
text: For the HBO original film "Taking Chance" (2009), Bacon won a Golden Globe Award and a Screen Actors Guild Award, also receiving a Primetime Emmy Award nomination. "

title: Kevin Bacon
text: The Guardian" named him one of the best actors never to have received an Academy Award nomination.

title: Kevin Bacon
text: In 2003, Bacon received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame for his contributions to the motion pictures industry.

title: Larry R. Williams
text: Larry Richard Williams (born October 6, 1942) is an American author, stock and commodity trader, and politician from the state of Montana.

title: Larry R. Williams
text: He is the father of four-time Academy Award and one-time Tony Award nominee actress Michelle Williams.

title: The Great Outdoors (film)
text: The Great Outdoors is a 1988 American comedy film directed by Howard Deutch, and written and produced by John Hughes.

title: The Great Outdoors (film)
text: It stars Dan Aykroyd, John Candy, Stephanie Faracy and Annette Bening in her film debut.

title: John Lithgow
text: John Arthur Lithgow ( ; born October 19 , 1945) is an American actor, musician, singer, comedian, voice actor, and author.

title: John Lithgow
text: He has received two Tony Awards, six Emmy Awards, two Golden Globe Awards, three Screen Actors Guild Awards, an American Comedy Award, four Drama Desk Awards and has also been nominated for two Academy Awards and four Grammy Awards.

title: John Lithgow
text: Lithgow has received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame and has been inducted into the American Theater Hall of Fame.

title: Joey Vera
text: Joseph "Joey" Vera (born April 24, 1963) is an American heavy metal bassist who is known as a member of the heavy metal band Armored Saint and the progressive metal band Fates Warning.

title: Joey Vera
text: In 2004-2005 he replaced Frank Bello in Anthrax as the band's bassist, but did not record with them.

title: Joey Vera
text: He was also a member of Engine, recorded with Tribe After Tribe, and appears on the OSI album "Free".

title: Joey Vera
text: His first solo album, "A Thousand Faces", was released in 1994.

title: Joey Vera
text: His current solo project, A Chinese Firedrill, released an album titled "Circles" in 2007.

title: Hurt Locker (musical)
text: Hurt Locker The Musical is a fictional musical in the 2014 Broadway premiere production of "Hedwig and the Angry Inch".

title: Hurt Locker (musical)
text: In the Broadway performance of "Hedwig and the Angry Inch" the musical opens with Hedwig explaining that the musical only ran for a single night before closing during intermission, and that she has convinced a producer to let her perform in what would otherwise be an empty stage.

title: Hurt Locker (musical)
text: Fake Playbills for the musical are used as props and are found scattered on the floor of the Belasco Theatre and contains advertisements for other fake musicals based on feature films such as "Gravity on Ice", "Container Store: The Musical", "The Entire Bible", and "SoulCycle on Broadway".

title: Hurt Locker (musical)
text: The Playbills, which describe the musical as having "explosions, negligible storytelling, camouflage and tits", also state that the musical's cast included actors such as Taye Diggs (who would go on to play the role of Hedwig in the summer of 2015) and that the music was written by Metallica and Stephen R. Schwartz, which is the real name of "Hedwig" songwriter Stephen Trask.

title: Obús
text: Obús is a Spanish heavy metal band created in Madrid in the early 80s.

title: Obús
text: They stood out because they took the risk of making a big spectacle in their concerts in order to reach to the level of other international heavy metal bands.

title: Obús
text: In addition, the lyrics they write and the feelings they transmit connect with the people that follow them.

title: Obús
text: As they said in an interview: "All our songs , some more and some less, have a meaning".

title: Obús
text: Far away from renouncing to their genre, they have always claimed that they were a heavy metal band and they even wrote a song about this genre in their first LP called"Dosis de Heavy Metal".

title: Obús
text: In 2012, because of their 30th anniversary, they did a Tour around Spain.

title: Metal Health
text: Metal Health is the third studio album by American heavy metal band Quiet Riot.

title: Metal Health
text: It was released on March 11, 1983, bolstered by the No. 5 hit "Cum On Feel the Noize" and the No. 31 hit "Metal Health".

title: Metal Health
text: "Metal Health" is notable for being the first heavy metal album to reach the top spot on the "Billboard" 200, replacing the Police's "Synchronicity" at number one in November 1983.

title: Metal Health
text: The album went on to sell more than six million copies and is considered a classic among heavy metal fans.

title: Metal Health
text: Some critics, such as AllMusic, describe it as a one-hit wonder, owing to Quiet Riot's relative lack of critical and commercial success with following albums (and subsequent disintegration) towards the end of the 1980s.

title: Metal Health
text: The title track was ranked No. 35 on VH1's 40 Greatest Metal Songs.

title: Joey Jordison
text: Nathan Jonas "Joey" Jordison (born April 26, 1975), is an American musician, songwriter, record producer and multi-instrumentalist, best known for his work as the former drummer and co-songwriter for the American heavy metal band Slipknot as well as guitarist in the American horror punk band Murderdolls.

title: Joey Jordison
text: Jordison played in Slipknot since their formation in 1995 until his departure from the band in December 2013.

title: Joey Jordison
text: He was the drummer and founder of the American heavy metal band Scar the Martyr which formed in 2013 and disbanded in 2016.

title: Joey Jordison
text: He grew up in Waukee, Iowa with his parents and two sisters, and was given his first drum kit at the age of 8.

title: Joey Jordison
text: He performed in several bands until joining in the summer of 1995 with the group The Pale Ones, which would later change their name to Slipknot.

title: Joey Jordison
text: Of Slipknot's nine-member lineup which lasted from 1999–2010, Joey was the third to join the band.

title: Black 'n Blue
text: Black 'N Blue is an American heavy metal band from Portland, Oregon.

title: Black 'n Blue
text: The current members are singer Jaime St. James, bassist Patrick Young, drummer Pete Holmes, guitarist Bob Capka, and guitarist Brandon Cook.

title: Machine Head (band)
text: Machine Head is an American heavy metal band from Oakland, California.

title: Machine Head (band)
text: Formed on October 12, 1991, the group was founded by vocalist/guitarist Robb Flynn and bassist Adam Duce.

title: Machine Head (band)
text: The current lineup of the band comprises Flynn, drummer Dave McClain, guitarist Phil Demmel and bassist Jared MacEachern.

title: Machine Head (band)
text: Machine Head is one of the pioneering bands in the new wave of American heavy metal.

title: Dan Spitz
text: Daniel Alan Spitz (born January 28, 1963) is an American musician and watchmaker best known for his work as the lead guitarist, principal songwriter and co-producer of the American heavy metal band Anthrax from 1983 to 1995 and from 2005 to 2008.

title: Dan Spitz
text: With Anthrax, Spitz was nominated for three Grammy awards and has been awarded platinum and multiple platinum RIAA certified albums for his entire Anthrax catalog of work.

title: Dan Spitz
text: Dan Spitz is the first heavy metal songwriter to have his music playing on two planets.

title: Dan Spitz
text: NASA chose his song alongside only 9 other artists such as Frank Sinatra and the Beatles to be played on the Lunar Rover Curiosity making him the first heavy metal artist to have a top 10 charting song on two planets.

title: Dan Spitz
text: Spitz also founded the Christian music group Red Lamb alongside Dave Mustaine of Megadeth as his writing partner, the first to bring autism awareness into any genre of music or music video.

title: Nu metal
text: Nu metal (also known as nü-metal and aggro-metal ) is a form of alternative metal that combines elements of heavy metal music with elements of other music genres such as hip hop, alternative rock, funk and grunge.

title: Nu metal
text: Nu metal bands have drawn elements and influences from a variety of musical styles, including multiple genres of heavy metal.

title: Nu metal
text: Nu metal rarely features guitar solos; the genre is heavily syncopated and based on guitar riffs.

title: Nu metal
text: Many nu metal guitarists use seven-string guitars that are down-tuned to play a heavier sound.

title: Nu metal
text: DJs are occasionally featured in nu metal to provide instrumentation such as sampling, turntable scratching and electronic backgrounds.

title: Nu metal
text: Vocal styles in nu metal include singing, rapping, screaming and growling.

title: Nu metal
text: Nu metal is one of the key genres of the new wave of American heavy metal.

title: Metallica
text: Metallica is an American heavy metal band based in San Rafael, California.

title: Metallica
text: The band was formed in 1981 in Los Angeles when vocalist/guitarist James Hetfield responded to an advertisement posted by drummer Lars Ulrich in a local newspaper.

title: Metallica
text: Metallica's current lineup comprises founding members Hetfield and Ulrich, longtime lead guitarist Kirk Hammett, and bassist Robert Trujillo.

title: Metallica
text: Guitarist Dave Mustaine (who went on to form Megadeth) and bassists Ron McGovney, Cliff Burton, and Jason Newsted are also former members of the band.

title: My Finale
text: "My Finale" is the hour-long season finale for season eight of the American sitcom "Scrubs".

title: My Finale
text: It was originally broadcast as episodes 18 and 19 of season eight on May 6, 2009, and was intended to be the series finale during production.

title: My Finale
text: However, the episode was billed as the "Scrubs finale" as at the time of airing it was unknown whether this would be the series finale or the season finale.

title: My Finale
text: The show ended up returning for a ninth season.

title: My Finale
text: As the show underwent many changes for the ninth and final season, this is the last episode in which all of the main cast appear as series regulars.

title: Desperate Housewives (season 2)
text: The second season of the American dramedy-mystery television series "Desperate Housewives" commenced airing in the United States on September 25, 2005 and concluded on May 21, 2006.

title: Desperate Housewives (season 2)
text: The season continues the story of the Wisteria Lane residents, while their seemingly perfect lives in the suburban neighborhood are shaken by the arrival of the mysterious Betty Applewhite.

title: Desperate Housewives (season 2)
text: Broadcast in the Sunday night time slot at 9.00 ET, the season aired twenty-four regular episodes, including a two-part season finale.

title: Desperate Housewives (season 2)
text: In addition, three clip shows were produced for the season, in order to put the previous events of the show in perspective. "

title: Desperate Housewives (season 2)
text: All the Juicy Details" aired before the eleventh episode, detailing the most memorable events of the season's first half, whereas "The More You Know, The Juicier It Gets", which aired before the twentieth episode, prepared the viewers for the highly anticipated season finale. "

title: Desperate Housewives (season 2)
text: Time to Come Clean" aired three weeks before the inception of the third season, and reviewed the previous mysteries of the series before introducing the new story lines.

title: Desperate Housewives (season 2)
text: The second season had fourteen roles receiving star billing, out of whom eleven were part of the first season's main cast.

title: Desperate Housewives (season 2)
text: The main story lines of the season were Susan Mayer's relationship with her former husband, Gabrielle Solis' upcoming motherhood, Lynette Scavo's return to work and the death of Bree Van de Kamp's husband.

title: List of Republic of Doyle episodes
text: This is a list of episodes for the Canadian crime series "Republic of Doyle".

title: List of Republic of Doyle episodes
text: The series debuted on CBC Television on January 6, 2010 with 969,000 viewers.

title: List of Republic of Doyle episodes
text: The season finale aired on April 7, 2010 and drew 1,120,000 viewers.

title: List of Republic of Doyle episodes
text: The second season debuted on January 12, 2011 with 1,038,000 viewers.

title: List of Republic of Doyle episodes
text: The second-season finale aired on April 6, 2011 and drew 1,265,000 viewers.

title: List of Republic of Doyle episodes
text: The third season debuted on January 11, 2012 with 1,361,000 viewers, and the season finale drew 968,000 viewers.

title: Human Error (House)
text: "Human Error" is the twenty-fourth episode and season finale of the third season of "House" and the seventieth episode overall.

title: The Price of Free and Fair Elections
text: "The Price of Free and Fair Elections" is the 18th episode and season finale of the third season of the American political thriller television series "Scandal", and is the 47th overall episode.

title: The Price of Free and Fair Elections
text: It aired on April 17, 2014 on ABC in the United States.

title: The Price of Free and Fair Elections
text: The episode was written by showrunner Shonda Rhimes and executive producer Mark Wilding and directed by executive producer Tom Verica.

title: The Price of Free and Fair Elections
text: The season finale was originally supposed to be the 22nd episode, but because of the show's lead Kerry Washington's pregnancy, the episode count was trimmed by ABC by four episodes, leading the season finale to be the 18th episode.

title: Robert Chase
text: Robert Chase, MBBS is a fictional character on the Fox medical drama "House".

title: Robert Chase
text: He is portrayed by Jesse Spencer.

title: Robert Chase
text: His character was a part of the team of diagnosticians who worked under Gregory House until the end of the third season when House fires him.

title: Robert Chase
text: However, he resumed work at the hospital as a surgeon, and was re-hired by House in season 6.

title: Robert Chase
text: Robert Chase is the longest-serving member of House's staff.

title: Robert Chase
text: Chase has been attracted to Allison Cameron since the beginning of the show and embarks on a romantic relationship with her in "Human Error."

title: Robert Chase
text: In "Post Mortem," he left the Diagnostic Team after realizing he was in the same position as he was 10 years earlier, unlike all of the other former members of the team.

title: Robert Chase
text: However, in the series finale, he rejoins the hospital as the new Head of Diagnostic Medicine, replacing House, who is thought to have died.

title: The Voice Portugal
text: The Voice Portugal (A Voz de Portugal in the first season) is a Portuguese reality singing competition and local version of The Voice originally broadcast as The Voice of Holland.

title: The Voice Portugal
text: It premiered on 29 October 2011, on RTP1, with the first season finale airing on February 25, 2012, crowning Denis Filipe as the winner.

title: The Voice Portugal
text: The show came back in 2014 with its second season with new judges, a new co-host, a new show name, and new "Repórteres V" (backstage hosts).

title: The Voice Portugal
text: The winner of the second season was Rui Drummond.

title: The Voice Portugal
text: RTP1 later announced the first season of "The Voice Kids Portugal" and the third season of the main show.

title: The Voice Portugal
text: The third season premiered October 11, 2015 with new judge, Aurea.

title: The Voice Portugal
text: In its third season, the show proved to be a hit and was subsequently renewed for a fourth season, which was premiered in 2016.

title: House (TV series)
text: House (also called House, M.D.) is an American television medical drama that originally ran on the Fox network for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004 to May 21, 2012.

title: House (TV series)
text: The series' main character is Dr. Gregory House (Hugh Laurie), an unconventional, misanthropic medical genius who, despite his dependence on pain medication, leads a team of diagnosticians at the fictional Princeton–Plainsboro Teaching Hospital (PPTH) in New Jersey.

title: House (TV series)
text: The series' premise originated with Paul Attanasio, while David Shore, who is credited as creator, was primarily responsible for the conception of the title character.

title: House (TV series)
text: The series' executive producers included Shore, Attanasio, Attanasio's business partner Katie Jacobs, and film director Bryan Singer.

title: House (TV series)
text: It was filmed largely in Century City.

title: Through the Looking Glass (Lost)
text: "Through the Looking Glass" is the third season finale of the ABC television series "Lost", consisting of the 22nd and 23rd episodes of the third season.

title: Through the Looking Glass (Lost)
text: It is also the 71st and 72nd episodes overall.

title: Through the Looking Glass (Lost)
text: It was written by co-creator/executive producer Damon Lindelof and executive producer Carlton Cuse, and directed by executive producer Jack Bender.

title: Through the Looking Glass (Lost)
text: When first aired on May 23, 2007, in the United States and Canada, it was watched by an average of 14 million American viewers.

title: Through the Looking Glass (Lost)
text: Like the previous two season finales, it was two hours long with advertisements, twice the length of a normal episode.

title: Through the Looking Glass (Lost)
text: It was edited into two individual episodes when released on DVD.

title: Through the Looking Glass (Lost)
text: The season finale is considered by some to be one of the best episodes of television ever broadcast.

title: Through the Looking Glass (Lost)
text: The episode garnered a number of awards and nominations, including three Primetime Emmy Awards nominations and a Directors Guild of America Award nomination.

title: Mr. Yin Presents...
text: "Mr. Yin Presents" (stylized as "Mr. Yin Presents...") is the sixteenth and final episode of the Fourth season of "Psych", and the 63rd episode in the series overall.

title: Mr. Yin Presents...
text: It premiered on March 10, 2010 on USA Network in the United States.

title: Mr. Yin Presents...
text: The episode serves as the season 4 finale and is the sequel to the third season's finale, "An Evening with Mr. Yang".

title: Mr. Yin Presents...
text: It is an important installment in one of the series' few story arcs.

title: Mr. Yin Presents...
text: A third and final installment of the Yin/Yang series, entitled "Yang 3 in 2D", aired as the fifth season finale.

title: Last Dance (Dua Lipa song)
text: "Last Dance" is a song by English singer Dua Lipa from her eponymous debut studio album (2017).

title: Last Dance (Dua Lipa song)
text: Lipa wrote the song with Stephen "Koz" Kozmeniuk and Talay Riley, with Kozmeniuk handling the song's production.

title: Last Dance (Dua Lipa song)
text: It was released on 9 February 2016 as the album's second single.

title: Last Dance (Dua Lipa song)
text: The track appears on the deluxe edition of "Dua Lipa".

title: Last Dance (Dua Lipa song)
text: It peaked at number four on the "Billboard" Twitter Emerging Artists chart, spending seven weeks on it.

title: Dua Lipa
text: Dua Lipa ( ; ] ; born 22 August 1995) is an English singer, songwriter and model.

title: Dua Lipa
text: Her musical career began at age 16, when she began covering songs by other artists on YouTube.

title: Dua Lipa
text: In 2015, she was signed with Warner Music Group, and released her first single soon after.

title: Dua Lipa
text: In December 2016, a documentary about Lipa was commissioned by "The Fader" magazine, titled "See in Blue".

title: Dua Lipa
text: In January 2017, she won the EBBA Public Choice Award.

title: Dua Lipa
text: Her self-titled debut studio album was released on 2 June 2017.

title: Dua Lipa
text: The album spawned seven singles, including the top-10 single "Be the One" and the number-one single "New Rules".

title: Lost in Your Light
text: "Lost in Your Light" is a song by English singer Dua Lipa, featuring American singer Miguel.

title: Lost in Your Light
text: The song was released on 21 April 2017 as the fifth single from Lipa's eponymous debut studio album.

title: Lost in Your Light
text: It was released as an instant-grat track to those who pre-ordered the song on the iTunes Store.

title: Lost in Your Light
text: The song was written by Lipa, Miguel, and Rick Nowels, while production was handled by Miguel and Stephen "Koz" Kozmeniuk.

title: Lost in Your Light
text: The accompanying music video, directed by Henry Schofield, was filmed in Los Angeles and premiered on 26 May 2017.

title: Be the One (Dua Lipa song)
text: "Be the One" is a song by English singer Dua Lipa from her eponymous debut studio album (2017).

title: Be the One (Dua Lipa song)
text: It was written by Lucy Taylor, Digital Farm Animals and Jack Tarrant, and produced by Digital Farm Animals.

title: Be the One (Dua Lipa song)
text: The song was released on 30 October 2015 as the album's lead single.

title: Hotter than Hell Tour (Dua Lipa)
text: Hotter than Hell Tour is the second official concert tour by English singer Dua Lipa, in support of her debut studio album "Dua Lipa" (2017).

title: Hotter than Hell Tour (Dua Lipa)
text: It is named after her hit single "Hotter than Hell".

title: Blow Your Mind (Mwah)
text: "Blow Your Mind (Mwah)" is a song by English singer Dua Lipa from her eponymous debut studio album (2017).

title: Blow Your Mind (Mwah)
text: It was released on 26 August 2016 as the album's fourth single.

title: Blow Your Mind (Mwah)
text: The song debuted at number 50 and peaked at number 30 on the UK Singles Chart; in the United States, it reached number 72 on the "Billboard" Hot 100, becoming Lipa's first song to chart in the country.

title: Blow Your Mind (Mwah)
text: It also topped the "Billboard" Dance Club Songs chart, becoming Lipa's first number-one single on that chart.

title: US and Europe Tour
text: The US and Europe Tour is the third official concert tour by English singer Dua Lipa.

title: US and Europe Tour
text: The tour supports her debut studio album "Dua Lipa" (2017).

title: US and Europe Tour
text: The tour began on 24 February 2017 in Chicago.

title: Dua Lipa (album)
text: Dua Lipa is the debut studio album by English singer Dua Lipa.

title: Dua Lipa (album)
text: It was released on 2 June 2017 by Warner Bros.

title: Dua Lipa (album)
text: Records.

title: Dua Lipa (album)
text: The lyrical themes revolve around her personal views of love, rising above, sex and self-empowerment.

title: New Rules (song)
text: "New Rules" is a song by English singer Dua Lipa from her eponymous debut studio album (2017).

title: New Rules (song)
text: The track was written by Caroline Ailin, Emily Warren and Ian Kirkpatrick, while production was handled by the latter.

title: New Rules (song)
text: It was released to contemporary hit radio in the United Kingdom on 21 July 2017 as the album's sixth single.

title: New Rules (song)
text: It impacted the same format in the United States on 22 August 2017.

title: Hotter than Hell (Dua Lipa song)
text: "Hotter than Hell" is a song by English singer Dua Lipa from her eponymous debut studio album (2017).

title: Hotter than Hell (Dua Lipa song)
text: It was written by Lipa, Adam Midgley, Tommy Baxter and Gerard O'Connell, and produced by Stephen "Koz" Kozmeniuk.

title: Hotter than Hell (Dua Lipa song)
text: The song was released on 6 May 2016 as the album's third single.

title: Hotter than Hell (Dua Lipa song)
text: "Hotter than Hell" peaked at number 15 on the UK Singles Chart, while reaching the top 20 in Australia, Belgium and the Netherlands.

title: Kamala Harris
text: Kamala Devi Harris ( , ; born October 20, 1964) is an American attorney and politician.

title: Kamala Harris
text: A member of the Democratic Party, she currently serves as the junior senator from California.

title: Kamala Harris
text: She previously served as the 32nd Attorney General of California.

title: Maryland Attorney General election, 2014
text: The Maryland Attorney General election of 2014 was held on November 4, 2014, to elect the Attorney General of Maryland.

title: Maryland Attorney General election, 2014
text: Incumbent Democratic Attorney General Doug Gansler was eligible to seek a third term in office, but instead ran unsuccessfully for the Democratic nomination for Governor of Maryland.

title: Corey Palumbo
text: Corey Lee Palumbo (born August 16, 1972) is a West Virginia State Senator representing the 17th district in the West Virginia Senate.

title: Corey Palumbo
text: A state senator since 2009, he previously served as a member of the West Virginia House of Delegates from 2003 to 2009.

title: Corey Palumbo
text: He is the son of Mario Palumbo, the 32nd Attorney General of West Virginia as well as a former five-term state senator.

title: Catherine Cortez Masto
text: Catherine Marie Cortez Masto (born March 29, 1964) is an American attorney and politician who is the junior United States Senator from Nevada.

title: Catherine Cortez Masto
text: She is a member of the Democratic Party.

title: Catherine Cortez Masto
text: She previously served as the 32nd Attorney General of Nevada from 2007 to 2015.

title: Joe Heck
text: Joseph John “Joe” Heck (born October 30, 1961) is an American politician, physician, and U.S. Army Brigadier General who had served as the U.S. Representative for Nevada's 3rd congressional district from 2011 to 2017.

title: Joe Heck
text: Heck, a member of the Republican Party, is a board-certified physician and served as a Nevada State Senator from 2004-08.

title: Joe Heck
text: He ran unsuccessfully against Democrat Catherine Cortez Masto in the general election for the open Nevada United States Senate seat in 2016.

title: Joe Heck
text: In the same year, Heck made headlines by joining a long list of Republicans who opposed the GOP nominee for President, Donald Trump.

title: List of United States Senators from Nevada
text: Nevada was admitted to the Union on October 31, 1864.

title: List of United States Senators from Nevada
text: Its current senators are Democrat Catherine Cortez Masto (Class 3) and Republican Dean Heller (Class 1).

title: Dennis Heck
text: Dennis Lynn "Denny" Heck (born July 29, 1952) is an American politician who has been the United States Representative for Washington's 10th congressional district since 2013.

title: Dennis Heck
text: Heck was previously the Democratic nominee for U.S. Representative for the 3rd district in 2010, but was defeated by Jaime Herrera Beutler (R).

title: Dennis Heck
text: In 2012 Heck ran and won in the newly created 10th district, defeating Republican Dick Muri.

title: Samuel D. Jackson
text: Samuel Dillon Jackson (May 28, 1895March 8, 1951) was a United States Senator from Indiana.

title: Samuel D. Jackson
text: Born near Zanesville, Indiana, he attended the public schools of Fort Wayne and graduated from a predecessor of the now Indiana University Robert H. McKinney School of Law in Indianapolis in 1917, gaining admission to the bar the same year.

title: Samuel D. Jackson
text: During the First World War, he served as a captain of infantry from 1917 to 1919, and engaged in the practice of law at Fort Wayne in 1919.

title: Samuel D. Jackson
text: He was prosecuting attorney of Allen County from 1924 to 1928.

title: Samuel D. Jackson
text: He ran unsuccessfully as a Democrat for election in 1928 to the Seventy-first Congress, and was attorney general of Indiana from 1940 to 1941.

title: Samuel D. Jackson
text: On January 28, 1944, he was appointed as a Democrat to the U.S. Senate to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Frederick Van Nuys and served from January 28, 1944, to November 13, 1944, when a duly elected successor qualified.

title: Samuel D. Jackson
text: Jackson was not a candidate for election to fill the vacancy, and was an unsuccessful Democratic candidate for Governor of Indiana in 1944.

title: Samuel D. Jackson
text: He resumed the practice of law, and died in Fort Wayne in 1951; interment was in Lindenwood Cemetery.

title: George Henry Williams
text: George Henry Williams (March 26, 1823April 4, 1910) was an American judge and politician.

title: George Henry Williams
text: He served as Chief Justice of the Oregon Supreme Court, was the 32nd Attorney General of the United States, and was elected Oregon's U.S. Senator, and served one term.

title: George Henry Williams
text: Williams, as U.S. Senator, authored and supported legislation that allowed the U.S. military to be deployed in Reconstruction southern states to allow for an orderly process of readmittance into the United States.

title: George Henry Williams
text: Williams was the first presidential Cabinet member to be appointed from the Pacific Coast.

title: George Henry Williams
text: As attorney general under President Ulysses S. Grant, Williams continued the prosecutions that shut down the Ku Klux Klan.

title: George Henry Williams
text: He had to contend with controversial election disputes in Reconstructed southern states.

title: George Henry Williams
text: President Grant and Williams legally recognized P. B. S. Pinchback as the first African American state governor.

title: George Henry Williams
text: Williams ruled that the "Virginius", a gun-running ship captured by Spain during the Virginius Affair, did not have the right to bear the U.S. flag.

title: George Henry Williams
text: However, he argued that Spain did not have the right to execute American crew members.

title: George Henry Williams
text: Nominated for Supreme Court Chief Justice by President Grant, Williams failed to be confirmed by the U.S. Senate primarily due to Williams' removal of A. C. Gibbs United States District Attorney at Portland, Oregon.

title: Jeff Harris (politician)
text: Jeff Harris (born October 7, 1964) is an attorney and a Missouri Democratic politician.

title: Jeff Harris (politician)
text: He represented the 23rd District of Missouri in the Missouri House of Representatives from 2003–2009 and ran unsuccessfully for the office of attorney general in 2008.

title: Jeff Harris (politician)
text: He served as Minority Floor Leader before giving up the post in order to focus more time on the attorney general race.

title: USA Drug
text: USA Drug is a convenience store and pharmacy chain in the United States that operates more than 160 stores in Arkansas, Oklahoma, Mississippi, Missouri, and Tennessee.

title: USA Drug
text: It was founded in Pine Bluff, Arkansas in 1986.

title: USA Drug
text: Its headquarters are still located in Pine Bluff with additional offices in Little Rock, Arkansas, Tulsa, Oklahoma, and Memphis, Tennessee.

title: USA Drug
text: Its parent company, Walgreens, operates Super D Drug Stores and Ikes Deep Discount Drug, both acquired in October 1997, and May's Drug, Med-X Drug, Drug Warehouse, and Drug Mart, all acquired in July 2004, as "Part of the USA Drug Family".

title: USA Drug
text: Wal-Mart and CVS/Pharmacy are two of its primary competitors.

title: USA Drug
text: The company's slogan is "America's Low Price Drug Store".

title: Perry Drug Stores
text: Perry Drug Stores was an American retail pharmacy chain founded in 1957 in the city of Pontiac, Michigan, United States.

title: Perry Drug Stores
text: At its peak in the 1980s, Perry operated more than 200 drug stores, primarily in the state of Michigan, as well as 200 Auto Works auto parts stores and fourteen A. L. Price discount health and beauty aids outlets.

title: Longs Drugs
text: Longs Drugs is an American chain with approximately 40 drug stores throughout the state of Hawaii.

title: Thrifty PayLess
text: Thrifty PayLess Holdings, Inc. was a pharmacy holding company that owned the Thrifty Drugs and PayLess Drug Stores chains in the western United States.

title: Thrifty PayLess
text: The combined company was formed in April 1994 when Los Angeles-based TCH Corporation, the parent company of Thrifty Corporation and Thrifty Drug Stores, Inc., acquired the Kmart subsidiary PayLess Drug Stores Northwest, Inc.

title: Thrifty PayLess
text: At the time of the merger, TCH Corporation was renamed Thrifty PayLess Holdings, Inc. and Thrifty operated 495 stores, PayLess operated 543 stores.

title: Leader Drug Stores
text: Leader Drug Stores is a network of over 3,100 independently owned and operated pharmacies.

title: Leader Drug Stores
text: It has a business affiliation with Cardinal Health, which sponsors the network and owns the name "Leader Drug Stores".

title: Leader Drug Stores
text: Cardinal Health also owns the franchise chain The Medicine Shoppe.

title: Leader Drug Stores
text: It operates like a retailers' cooperative, though it is not owned by its members.

title: Gray Drug
text: Gray Drug was a drugstore chain in Cleveland, Ohio.

title: Gray Drug
text: The chain began in 1912 and grew to 46 stores by 1946 and over 100 by the 1970s.

title: Gray Drug
text: Besides Ohio, stores later opened in Florida and Maryland.

title: Gray Drug
text: The chain later acquired Drug Fair in 1981, shortly before Sherwin Williams bought the chain.

title: Gray Drug
text: Gray Drug acquired several Cunningham Drug stores in 1982.

title: Hartig Drug
text: Hartig Drug Stores is a chain of pharmacy/retail stores based out of Dubuque, Iowa.

title: Hartig Drug
text: The company provides pharmacy services not only to the general public, but to area institutions as well.

title: Hartig Drug
text: Along with this pharmacy focus, Hartig Drug stores offer convenience retail items.

title: Hartig Drug
text: The company has operated for over 100 years; currently, it is the second-oldest family-run pharmacy chain in the United States.

title: Warren Bryant
text: Warren Bryant was the CEO of Longs Drugs Store Corporation out of California prior to the retail chain's acquisition by CVS/Caremark.

title: Warren Bryant
text: Hired in 2002 to Longs, he was Senior Vice President of The Kroger Company.

title: Warren Bryant
text: , a retail grocery chain, from 1999 to 2002.

title: Warren Bryant
text: Prior to that, from 1996 to 1999, he was President and Chief Executive Officer of Dillon Companies, Inc., a retail grocery chain and subsidiary of The Kroger Co.

title: Warren Bryant
text: He is also a director of OfficeMax Incorporated.

title: Cunningham Drug (U.S.)
text: Cunningham Drug was a drugstore chain based in Detroit, Michigan.

title: Cunningham Drug (U.S.)
text: Founded in October 1889 by Andrew Cunningham, the chain operated primarily within the state of Michigan, and was once the largest drugstore chain in the state.

title: Cunningham Drug (U.S.)
text: Its Michigan locations were closed and reopened in 1982 as Apex Drug, and were later sold to Perry Drug Stores.

title: Cunningham Drug (U.S.)
text: The last stores remained open in Florida until 1991, when they were sold to Walgreens.

title: Rexall
text: Rexall is a chain of American drugstores, and the name of their store-branded products.

title: Rexall
text: The stores, having roots in the federation of United Drug Stores starting in 1903, licensed the Rexall brand name to as many as 12,000 drug stores across the United States from 1920 to 1977.

title: Rexall
text: (The "Rex" in the name came from the common Rx abbreviation for medical prescriptions.)

title: Mike Dmitrich
text: Mike Dmitrich (born 1936) is an American politician and Natural Resource Consultant from Utah.

title: Mike Dmitrich
text: A Democrat, he served as a member of the Utah State Senate, representing the state's 27th senate district in Price.

title: Mike Dmitrich
text: Dmitrich served as the Minority Leader in the Utah Senate.

title: Mike Dmitrich
text: Prior to being elected to the Utah Senate Dmitrich served in the State House from 1969 to 1992.

title: Mike Dmitrich
text: He retired prior to the 2008 elections and was replaced by David P. Hinkins.

title: Maurice A. Donahue
text: Maurice A. Donahue (September 21, 1918 – January 13, 1999) is an American politician who served as President of the Massachusetts Senate from 1964 to 1971.

title: John Hoeven
text: John Henry Hoeven III (born March 13, 1957) is an American politician and the senior United States Senator from North Dakota, in office since 2011.

title: John Hoeven
text: A member of the North Dakota Republican Party, he previously served as the 31st Governor of North Dakota from December 2000 to December 2010.

title: John Hoeven
text: Hoeven was elected to the U.S. Senate in the November 2, 2010 general election.

title: John Hoeven
text: He replaced junior Senator Byron L. Dorgan, who chose not to seek re-election.

title: John Hoeven
text: Hoeven became the senior Senator in 2013 after Kent Conrad retired and was replaced by Heidi Heitkamp, who was once Hoeven's opponent for the Governor's office.

title: Anne Donahue
text: Anne de la Blanchetai Donahue is an American politician from the state of Vermont.

title: Anne Donahue
text: She has served as a Republican member of the Vermont House of Representatives since 2003, representing the Washington-2 district, which includes the Washington County towns of Berlin and Northfield.

title: Anne Donahue
text: She is also editor of "Counterpoint", a quarterly mental health publication distributed for free throughout Vermont.

title: Sue Donahue
text: Sue Donahue is an American politician.

title: Sue Donahue
text: Donahue was appointed in 2016 to serve in the Arizona State Senate representing the fifth legislative district as a member of the Republican Party.

title: Sue Donahue
text: Donahue replaced Kelli Ward who resigned to run for the United States Senate.

title: Sue Donahue
text: Donahue did not run for re-election in 2016 and was replaced by Sonny Borrelli.

title: Frank J. Donahue
text: Frank J. Donahue (1881–1979) was an American politician who served as the Massachusetts Secretary of the Commonwealth, Chairman of the Massachusetts Democratic State Committee, and as an Associate Justice of the Massachusetts Superior Court.

title: Charles Harlow
text: Charles W. Harlow (born May 25, 1942) is an American politician from Maine.

title: Charles Harlow
text: Harlow served on the Portland, Maine City Council from 1990 to 1999, including a term as ceremonial mayor from 1992 to 1993.

title: Charles Harlow
text: In 2004, Harlow was elected as a Democrat to the Maine House of Representatives from District 116.

title: Charles Harlow
text: He served until 2010, when he was replaced by his daughter, Denise Harlow.

title: Kelli Ward
text: Kelli Ward ("née" Kaznoski; born January 25, 1969) is an American politician and osteopathic physician.

title: Kelli Ward
text: A member of the Republican Party, Ward was elected in 2012 to serve in the Arizona State Senate representing the fifth legislative district.

title: Kelli Ward
text: She was unopposed for election in 2014.

title: Kelli Ward
text: While serving in office, she continued to practice medicine in the emergency departments in Lake Havasu City and Kingman, Arizona.

title: Dan Donahue
text: Daniel M. Donahue is an American politician serving in the Massachusetts House of Representatives since September 2013.

title: Dan Donahue
text: He is a Worcester resident and a member of the Democratic Party.

title: Warren Furutani
text: Warren T. Furutani (born October 16, 1947) is an American politician who served in the California State Assembly.

title: Warren Furutani
text: He is a Democrat and a fourth-generation Japanese American.

title: Warren Furutani
text: Furutani was elected in a special election in 2008.

title: Warren Furutani
text: He replaced Laura Richardson as the member of the US House of Representatives from California's 37th district.

title: Warren Furutani
text: Prior to being elected, he served on the Los Angeles Unified School District and then the Los Angeles Community College District Board of Trustees.

title: Warren Furutani
text: He was the first Asian Pacific American ever elected to the LAUSD in 1987 and became the board's president in 1991.

title: Nobody's Daughter
text: Nobody's Daughter is the fourth and final studio album by American alternative rock band Hole, released worldwide on April 27, 2010, through Mercury Records.

title: Nobody's Daughter
text: The album was originally conceived by Hole frontwoman Courtney Love as a solo project titled "How Dirty Girls Get Clean", following her poorly received solo debut "America's Sweetheart" (2004).

title: Nobody's Daughter
text: Much of the material featured on "Nobody's Daughter" originated from studio sessions for "How Dirty Girls Get Clean", which had been conceived in 2006 after a multitude of legal issues, drug addiction, and rehabilitation sentences had left Love "suicidal".

title: Nobody's Daughter
text: Love financed the making of the record herself, which cost nearly two million dollars.

title: Courtney Love filmography
text: Courtney Love is an American musician and actress who began her professional career in film in 1986 with a supporting role in Alex Cox's "Sid and Nancy" (1986); she had prior studied film with experimental director George Kuchar at the San Francisco Art Institute in 1984, and appeared in one of Kuchar's short films.

title: Courtney Love filmography
text: After pursuing music and having a successful career as the frontwoman of alternative rock band Hole, Love also had intermittent roles in films, most notably receiving critical attention for her performance as Althea Flynt in Miloš Forman's 1996 biopic "The People vs. Larry Flynt", which earned her a Golden Globe Nomination for Best Actress, as well as awards from the Boston, Chicago, New York, and Los Angeles film critics associations.

title: Courtney Love filmography
text: Love later appeared among an ensemble cast in "200 Cigarettes" (1998), as well as in a leading role in "Man on the Moon" (1999) alongside Jim Carrey, for which she received critical recognition.

title: Courtney Love filmography
text: She later appeared in several independent films and short subjects as well as the thriller "Trapped" (2002) alongside Charlize Theron and Kevin Bacon, and "Julie Johnson" (2001), for which she received an award for Best Actress at Los Angeles' gay and lesbian Outfest film festival.

title: Patty Schemel
text: Patricia Theresa Schemel (born April 24, 1967) is an American drummer and musician who rose to prominence as the drummer of alternative rock band Hole from 1992 until 1998.

title: Patty Schemel
text: In 1998, Schemel left Hole, and in the early 2000s reunited with Hole frontwoman Courtney Love during her solo career, and later drummed for Juliette and the Licks.

title: Patty Schemel
text: As of 2010, Schemel continues to play music and gives drum lessons, in addition to owning a dog daycare/boarding business.

title: Patty Schemel
text: In 2013, Schemel joined the indie rock group Upset, formed by Ali Koehler, previously of Vivian Girls and Best Coast.

title: Patty Schemel
text: She also formed a rock and roll band with her brother, Larry Schemel, called Death Valley Girls.

title: Beautiful Son
text: "Beautiful Son" is a song by American alternative rock band Hole, written collectively by frontwoman Courtney Love, lead guitarist Eric Erlandson and drummer Patty Schemel.

title: Beautiful Son
text: The song was released as the band's fourth single in April 1993 on the European label City Slang.

title: Beautiful Son
text: To coincide with the song's lyrics, Love used a photograph of her husband, Kurt Cobain, at age 7 as the single's artwork.

title: The Wolfhounds
text: The Wolfhounds are an indie pop/noise pop band formed in Romford, UK in 1985 by Dave Callahan, Paul Clark, Andy Golding, Andy Bolton and Frank Stebbing, and originally active until 1990.

title: The Wolfhounds
text: The band reformed in 2005 and continues to write, record and play live, releasing new albums in 2014 and 2016.

title: Live Through This
text: Live Through This is the second studio album by American alternative rock band Hole.

title: Live Through This
text: It was released by DGC Records on April 12, 1994, just one week after frontwoman Courtney Love's husband, Kurt Cobain, died in their home.

title: Live Through This
text: It was Hole's only album to feature bassist Kristen Pfaff before her death in June 1994.

title: Live Through This
text: Recorded in October 1993, the album marked a divergence from the band's unpolished hardcore aesthetics to more refined melodies and song structure, and features production by Sean Slade and Paul Q. Kolderie, with mixing by Scott Litt and J Mascis.

title: Live Through This
text: The album's lyrics and packaging reflect Love's preoccupation with beauty, and its songs contain repeated motifs of milk, motherhood, anti-elitism, and violence against women.

title: Live Through This
text: The album's title is derived from a quote in "Gone with the Wind".

title: Turpentine (song)
text: "Turpentine" is a song by the American alternative rock band Hole.

title: Turpentine (song)
text: It was written by vocalist and rhythm guitarist Courtney Love and lead guitarist Eric Erlandson.

title: Turpentine (song)
text: The song was one of the band's first compositions and remained unreleased for seven years before being released on the band's second EP, "The First Session" on August 26, 1997.

title: Turpentine (song)
text: Although not as well known as Hole's later songs, "Turpentine" is a notable song for the band as it is often cited as "the first Hole song."

title: Miss World (song)
text: "Miss World" is a song by American alternative rock band Hole, written by frontwoman Courtney Love and lead guitarist Eric Erlandson.

title: Miss World (song)
text: The song was released as the band's fifth single and the first from their second studio album, "Live Through This", in March 1994.

title: Softer, Softest
text: "Softer, Softest" is a song by American alternative rock band Hole, written by frontwoman Courtney Love and lead guitarist Eric Erlandson.

title: Softer, Softest
text: The song was released as the band's eighth single and fourth and final single from their second studio album, "Live Through This", in December 1995.

title: Softer, Softest
text: The single was released just as the band finished their extensive touring in 1995.

title: Courtney Love
text: Courtney Michelle Love (born Courtney Michelle Harrison; July 9, 1964) is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and visual artist.

title: Courtney Love
text: Prolific in the punk and grunge scenes of the 1990s, Love has enjoyed a career that spans four decades.

title: Courtney Love
text: She rose to prominence as the frontwoman of the alternative rock band Hole, which she formed in 1989.

title: Courtney Love
text: Love has drawn public attention for her uninhibited live performances and confrontational lyrics, as well as her highly publicized personal life following her marriage to Kurt Cobain.

title: Catching Fire
text: Catching Fire is a 2009 science fiction young adult novel by the American novelist Suzanne Collins, the second book in "The Hunger Games trilogy".

title: Catching Fire
text: As the sequel to the 2008 bestseller "The Hunger Games", it continues the story of Katniss Everdeen and the post-apocalyptic nation of Panem.

title: Catching Fire
text: Following the events of the previous novel, a rebellion against the oppressive Capitol has begun, and Katniss and fellow tribute Peeta Mellark are forced to return to the arena in a special edition of the Hunger Games.

title: Oil well fire
text: Oil well fires are oil or gas wells that have caught on fire and burn.

title: Oil well fire
text: Oil well fires can be the result of human actions, such as accidents or arson, or natural events, such as lightning.

title: Oil well fire
text: They can exist on a small scale, such as an oil field spill catching fire, or on a huge scale, as in geyser-like jets of flames from ignited high pressure wells.

title: Oil well fire
text: A frequent cause of a well fire is a high-pressure blowout during drilling operations.

title: H2O: Footprints in the Sand
text: HO: Footprints in the Sand is a Japanese adult visual novel by Makura that was released on June 23, 2006 for the PC as a DVD; a version playable on the PlayStation 2 under the title "HO +" followed on April 24, 2008 with adult content removed, but in its place will be additional scenarios and graphics not seen in the original release.

title: H2O: Footprints in the Sand
text: "HO" is Makura's first game; a sequel named "Root After and Another" was later produced in October 2007.

title: H2O: Footprints in the Sand
text: The gameplay in "HO" follows a plot line that offers pre-determined scenarios with courses of interaction, and focuses on the appeal of the three female main characters.

title: H2O: Footprints in the Sand
text: There are two modes of gameplay, the Blindness Effect and Normal Effect, where the former plays on the fact that the protagonist is blind, and the latter mode removes the added element of gameplay the Blindness Effect has.

title: H2O: Footprints in the Sand
text: The story is broken into three parts: the original introduction and meeting, following by a separation and reunion, and finally ending with the protagonist choosing one of the girls and spending the rest of the game with her.

title: To Heart 2
text: To Heart 2 (トゥハート2 , Tu Hāto 2 ) , stylized as ToHeart2, is a Japanese romance visual novel developed by Leaf and published by Aquaplus.

title: To Heart 2
text: It was first released for the PlayStation 2 on December 28, 2004 as an all-ages title, and was followed by an adult version playable on Microsoft Windows and subsequent all-ages versions for the PlayStation Portable and PlayStation 3.

title: To Heart 2
text: This deviated from the release history of the game's predecessor, "To Heart", which was originally released with adult content prior to receiving versions with such content removed.

title: To Heart 2
text: The gameplay in "To Heart 2" follows a branching plot line with multiple endings, which offers pre-determined scenarios and courses of interaction based on the player's decisions.

title: To Heart 2
text: Its story centers on the male protagonist Takaaki Kouno, and focuses on the appeal of the female main characters.

title: The Hunger Games (novel)
text: The Hunger Games is a 2008 dystopian novel by the American writer Suzanne Collins.

title: The Hunger Games (novel)
text: It is written in the voice of 16-year-old Katniss Everdeen, who lives in the future, post-apocalyptic nation of Panem in North America.

title: The Hunger Games (novel)
text: The Capitol, a highly advanced metropolis, exercises political control over the rest of the nation.

title: The Hunger Games (novel)
text: The Hunger Games is an annual event in which one boy and one girl aged 12–18 from each of the twelve districts surrounding the Capitol are selected by lottery to compete in a televised battle to the death.

title: Moon (visual novel)
text: Moon (styled as Moon.)

title: Moon (visual novel)
text: is a Japanese adult visual novel developed by Tactics, a brand of Nexton, released on November 21, 1997 playable on Windows PCs.

title: Moon (visual novel)
text: The game was described by the development team as a "Reaching the Heart AVG" (心に届くAVG , Kokoro ni Todoku AVG ) .

title: Moon (visual novel)
text: The story follows the protagonist Ikumi Amasawa, a girl who joins an organization called Fargo in the hopes of discovering why and how her mother died, who was a member of the same group.

title: Moon (visual novel)
text: The gameplay in "Moon" follows a branching plot line which offers pre-determined scenarios with courses of interaction, and focuses on the three female main characters.

title: Moon (visual novel)
text: The game ranked twice in the national top 50 for best-selling PC games sold in Japan.

title: Dōsei
text: Dōsei (同棲 , lit. "

title: Dōsei
text: Cohabitation") is a Japanese adult social simulation game developed by Tactics, a brand of Nexton.

title: Dōsei
text: It was released on May 23, 1997 for Windows PCs, the same day as "To Heart" by Leaf.

title: Dōsei
text: The gameplay in "Dōsei" follows a branching plot line which offers pre-determined scenarios with courses of interaction, and focuses on the appeal of the sole female main character Manami Minase.

title: Dōsei
text: The player assumes the role of protagonist Masaki Yamada who is living with Manami shortly after they have graduated from high school.

title: Dōsei
text: Masaki earns money at a job, and when he returns home will have sex with Manami often; this process of work in the day, and sex at night repeats many times throughout gameplay.

title: The Hunger Games: Catching Fire
text: The Hunger Games: Catching Fire is a 2013 American dystopian science fiction adventure film based on Suzanne Collins' dystopian novel, "Catching Fire" (2009), the second installment in "The Hunger Games" trilogy.

title: The Hunger Games: Catching Fire
text: The film is the sequel to "The Hunger Games" (2012) and the second installment in "The Hunger Games" film series, produced by Nina Jacobson and Jon Kilik, and distributed by Lionsgate.

title: The Hunger Games: Catching Fire
text: Francis Lawrence directed the film, with a screenplay by Simon Beaufoy and Michael Arndt.

title: The Hunger Games: Catching Fire
text: Adding to the existing cast, the supporting cast was filled out with Philip Seymour Hoffman, Jeffrey Wright, Jena Malone, Sam Claflin, Lynn Cohen, Amanda Plummer, Alan Ritchson, and Meta Golding.
