title: Ginger Rogers
text: She appeared on stage, as well as on radio and television, throughout much of the 20th century.

title: Hat Check Girl
text: Hat Check Girl is a 1932 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Lanfield and written by Barry Conners and Philip Klein.

title: Hat Check Girl
text: The film stars Sally Eilers, Ben Lyon, Ginger Rogers and Monroe Owsley.

title: Hat Check Girl
text: The film was released on October 8, 1932, by Fox Film Corporation.

title: The Big Shot (1931 film)
text: The Big Shot is a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Ralph Murphy and written by Earl Baldwin, Hal Conklin, George Dromgold, and Joseph Fields.

title: The Big Shot (1931 film)
text: The film stars Eddie Quillan, Maureen O'Sullivan, Mary Nolan, Roscoe Ates and Belle Bennett.

title: The Big Shot (1931 film)
text: The film was released on December 18, 1931, by RKO Pictures.

title: Sweepstakes (film)
text: Sweepstakes is a 1931 American pre-Code comedy film directed by Albert S. Rogell from a screenplay written by Lew Lipton and Ralph Murphy.

title: Sweepstakes (film)
text: The film stars Eddie Quillan, James Gleason, Marian Nixon, Lew Cody, and Paul Hurst, which centers around the travails and romances of jockey Buddy Doyle, known as the "Whoop-te-doo Kid" for his trademark yell during races.

title: Sweepstakes (film)
text: Produced by the newly formed RKO Pathé Pictures, this was the first film Charles R. Rogers would produce for the studio, after he replaced William LeBaron as head of production.

title: Sweepstakes (film)
text: The film was released on July 10, 1931, through RKO Radio Pictures.

title: Ladies of the Jury
text: Ladies of the Jury is a 1932 American pre-Code comedy film directed by Lowell Sherman and written by Marion Dix, Edward Salisbury Field and Eddie Welch.

title: Ladies of the Jury
text: The film stars Edna May Oliver, Jill Esmond, Ken Murray, Roscoe Ates and Kitty Kelly.

title: Ladies of the Jury
text: The film was released on February 5, 1932, by RKO Pictures.

title: Ladies of the Jury
text: It was based on the 1929 play, "Ladies of the Jury", written by John Frederick Ballard.

title: Cracked Nuts
text: Cracked Nuts is a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Edward F. Cline, from an original screenplay written by Al Boasberg and Ralph Spence.

title: Cracked Nuts
text: The film stars the comedy duo Wheeler & Woolsey (Bert Wheeler and Robert Woolsey), as well as Dorothy Lee.

title: Cracked Nuts
text: It also features Boris Karloff in a small supporting role.

title: Cracked Nuts
text: The film was one of RKO's only financial successes of the year.

title: The Half-Naked Truth
text: The Half-Naked Truth is a 1932 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Gregory LaCava and featuring Lee Tracy as a carnival pitchman who finagles his girlfriend, a fiery hoochie dancer played by Lupe Vélez, into a major Broadway revue under the auspices of an impresario portrayed by Frank Morgan.

title: The Half-Naked Truth
text: The film was released on December 16, 1932, by RKO Radio Pictures.

title: The Gay Nighties
text: The Gay Nighties is a 1933 American Pre-Code comedy film featuring Clark & McCullough and directed by Mark Sandrich.

title: Little Orphan Annie (1932 film)
text: Little Orphan Annie is a 1932 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by John S. Robertson and written by Wanda Tuchock and Tom McNamara.

title: Little Orphan Annie (1932 film)
text: It is based on the comic strip "Little Orphan Annie" by Harold Gray.

title: Little Orphan Annie (1932 film)
text: The film stars Mitzi Green, Buster Phelps, May Robson, Matt Moore and Edgar Kennedy.

title: Little Orphan Annie (1932 film)
text: The film was released on November 4, 1932, by RKO Pictures.

title: New Arrangement
text: New Arrangement is an album by Jackie DeShannon, released by Columbia Records (PC 33500) in 1975.

title: New Arrangement
text: It contains the first recording of "Bette Davis Eyes", written by Donna Weiss and Jackie DeShannon in 1974 and covered by Kim Carnes on the album "Mistaken Identity" (1981).

title: New Arrangement
text: Another song, "Boat to Sail," that features Brian Wilson and then-wife Marilyn singing backing vocals, was covered by The Carpenters in their 1976 album "A Kind of Hush".

title: Danity Kane discography
text: The discography of Danity Kane, an American R&B group, consists of two studio album, five singles, and four music videos. Danity Kane were formed in 2005 during the third season of the reality television series "Making the Band", and consisted of Aubrey O'Day, Wanita "D. Woods" Woodgett, Shannon Bex, Dawn Richard, and Aundrea Fimbres.

title: Danity Kane discography
text: The group disbanded in January 2009 during the fourth season of "Making the Band".

title: Danity Kane discography
text: The group released their self titled debut album in August 2006.

title: Danity Kane discography
text: The album reached number one on the United States "Billboard" 200 and was certified platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA).

title: Danity Kane discography
text: Danity Kane's debut single, "Show Stopper", which featured rapper Yung Joc, reached number eight on the U.S. "Billboard" Hot 100. "

title: Danity Kane discography
text: Ride for You", their second single, reached number 78 on the "Billboard" Hot 100. "

title: Danity Kane discography
text: Welcome to the Dollhouse", Danity Kane's second album, was released in March 2008.

title: Danity Kane discography
text: It reached number one on the "Billboard" 200 and was certified gold by the RIAA.

title: Danity Kane discography
text: The album's lead single, "Damaged", reached number ten on the "Billboard" Hot 100 and was certified platinum by the RIAA.

title: Danity Kane discography
text: The group's fifth single, "Bad Girl", featured Missy Elliott and reached number 110 on the "Billboard" Hot 100.

title: Bette Davis Eyes
text: "Bette Davis Eyes" is a song written and composed by Donna Weiss and Jackie DeShannon, and made popular by American singer Kim Carnes.

title: Bette Davis Eyes
text: DeShannon recorded it in 1974; Carnes's 1981 version spent nine weeks at No. 1 on the "Billboard" Hot 100 and was "Billboard"' s biggest hit of 1981.

title: You Keep Me Hangin' On
text: "You Keep Me Hangin' On" is a 1966 song written and composed by Holland–Dozier–Holland.

title: You Keep Me Hangin' On
text: It first became a popular "Billboard" Hot 100 number one hit for the American Motown group The Supremes in late 1966.

title: You Keep Me Hangin' On
text: The rock band Vanilla Fudge covered the song a year later and had a top ten hit with their version.

title: You Keep Me Hangin' On
text: British pop singer Kim Wilde covered "You Keep Me Hangin' On" in 1986, bumping it back to number one on the "Billboard" Hot 100 in June 1987.

title: You Keep Me Hangin' On
text: The single reached number one by two different musical acts in America.

title: You Keep Me Hangin' On
text: In the first 32 years of the "Billboard" Hot 100 rock era, “You Keep Me Hangin' On” became one of only six songs to achieve this feat.

title: You Keep Me Hangin' On
text: In 1996, country music singer Reba McEntire's version reached number 2 on the US "Billboard" Hot Dance Club Play chart.

title: Put a Little Love in Your Heart
text: "Put a Little Love in Your Heart" is a song originally performed in 1969 by Jackie DeShannon, who composed it with her brother, Randy Myers, and Jimmy Holiday.

title: Put a Little Love in Your Heart
text: In the US, it was DeShannon's highest-charting hit, reaching number 4 on the Hot 100 in August 1969 and number 2 on the Adult Contemporary charts.

title: Put a Little Love in Your Heart
text: In late 1969, the song reached number one on South Africa's hit parade.

title: Animal (Neon Trees song)
text: "Animal" is the lead single from Neon Trees' debut studio album, "Habits".

title: Animal (Neon Trees song)
text: It debuted in June 2010 at number 100 on the "Billboard" Hot 100 and has reached a peak of number 13 in its twenty-two week on the chart.

title: Animal (Neon Trees song)
text: In Canada, the song debuted at number 95 on the Canadian Hot 100 and has climbed to number 29.

title: Animal (Neon Trees song)
text: The song has reached number one on the "Billboard" Alternative Songs chart after 32 weeks, making "Animal" their first number-one song on a "Billboard" chart.

title: Animal (Neon Trees song)
text: This also broke the record for the longest-length of time for a song to get to the top of that list after entering.

title: Animal (Neon Trees song)
text: The song reached number two on the "Billboard" Rock Songs chart.

title: Animal (Neon Trees song)
text: In one of the music videos of the song, the band is destroying an art gallery.

title: Animal (Neon Trees song)
text: On May 22, 2011, the song won Top Alternative Song in the 2011 "Billboard" Music Awards.

title: I Got You Babe
text: "I Got You Babe" is a song written by Sonny Bono.

title: I Got You Babe
text: It was the first single taken from the debut studio album "Look at Us", of the American pop music duo Sonny & Cher.

title: I Got You Babe
text: In August 1965, their single spent three weeks at number 1 on the "Billboard" Hot 100 in the United States where it sold more than 1 million copies and was certified Gold.

title: I Got You Babe
text: It also reached number 1 in the United Kingdom and Canada.

title: I Got You Babe
text: In 1985, a cover version of "I Got You Babe" by British reggae/pop band UB40 featuring American singer Chrissie Hynde, peaked at number one in the UK Singles Chart and reached number 28 on the US "Billboard" Hot 100 chart.

title: I Got You Babe
text: A 1993 version by Cher with Beavis and Butt-Head bubbled under the Hot 100 chart.

title: Just the Two of Us (Grover Washington Jr. song)
text: "Just the Two of Us" is a 1981 R&B single written by Bill Withers, William Salter and Ralph MacDonald, which was recorded by Grover Washington Jr. and Bill Withers.

title: Just the Two of Us (Grover Washington Jr. song)
text: The song originally appeared on Washington's 1980 album "Winelight".

title: Just the Two of Us (Grover Washington Jr. song)
text: An edited version reached number two on the "Billboard" Hot 100, staying there for 3 weeks, behind "Morning Train (9 to 5)" by Sheena Easton and "Bette Davis Eyes" by Kim Carnes.

title: Just the Two of Us (Grover Washington Jr. song)
text: The song won a Grammy Award for Best R&B Song.

title: Just the Two of Us (Grover Washington Jr. song)
text: Bill Withers included the edited version on the 1981 compilation "Bill Withers' Greatest Hits" and many subsequent greatest hits collections.

title: Donna Lewis
text: Donna Lewis is a British singer-songwriter and record producer from Cardiff, Wales.

title: Donna Lewis
text: She is best known for the 1996 pop hit single "I Love You Always Forever", which peaked at number five on the UK Singles Chart, and also peaked within the top ten of the charts in Australia, Austria, Canada, France, Germany, New Zealand, Norway, and the United States.

title: Donna Lewis
text: In the latter country, "I Love You Always Forever" peaked at number two on the "Billboard" Hot 100 for nine weeks, having been held off the summit by "Macarena" by Los Del Rio.

title: Donna Lewis
text: It also became the highest-charting single on the "Billboard" Hot 100 by a Welsh artist since Bonnie Tyler topped the chart with Total Eclipse of the Heart in 1983.

title: Donna Lewis
text: Additionally, the single holds the record for being drawn for third place among songs with the longest runs at number two on the "Billboard" Hot 100 and at second for most weeks at number one on the "Billboard" Mainstream Top 40 chart.

title: Donna Lewis
text: Lewis teamed up with Richard Marx in the 1997 adult contemporary hit "At the Beginning."

title: Donna Lewis
text: In 1997, Lewis was nominated for the Brit Award for Best British Female.

title: I Love You Always Forever
text: "I Love You Always Forever" is a song by British singer Donna Lewis.

title: I Love You Always Forever
text: It was released in the United States in May 1996 as the lead single from her debut album, "Now in a Minute".

title: I Love You Always Forever
text: Inspired by the H. E. Bates novel "Love for Lydia", it peaked at number five on the UK Singles Chart.

title: I Love You Always Forever
text: Outside the United Kingdom, it peaked within the top ten of the charts in Australia, Austria, Canada, France, Germany, New Zealand, Norway, Switzerland and the United States.

title: I Love You Always Forever
text: In the latter country, the song peaked at number two on the "Billboard" Hot 100, where it remained for nine weeks during the summer of 1996, kept from number one by Los Del Rio's "Macarena".

title: I Love You Always Forever
text: Despite this, the song was number one on the Hot 100 Airplay chart for thirteen weeks and the "Billboard" Top 40 Mainstream chart for eleven weeks, becoming one of the most played songs of the 1990s.

title: I Love You Always Forever
text: The song therefore is drawn for third place among songs with the longest runs at number two on the "Billboard" Hot 100 and drawn at second for the most weeks at the "Billboard" Top 40 Mainstream chart.

title: I Love You Always Forever
text: In Australia, the single also peaked at number two on the ARIA Singles Chart.

title: I Love You Always Forever
text: In 2016, the song was covered by Australian pop singer Betty Who, peaking at number six on the ARIA Singles Chart.

title: ForPlay
text: ForPlay is the first EP by American indie rock band Saint Motel.

title: ForPlay
text: The album had a music video for every song that was also included on the CD itself.

title: Lior Goldenberg
text: Lior Goldenberg (born September 28, 1974) is a producer and mixer from Tel Aviv, Israel.

title: Lior Goldenberg
text: He currently resides in Los Angeles, California.

title: Lior Goldenberg
text: He has worked with Rancid, Macy Gray, Sheryl Crow, MxPx, Vanessa Carlton, Marilyn Manson, Andrew W.K., Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young, Alanis Morissette, Ziggy Marley, and indie bands Allen Stone, Crash Kings, Saint Motel and Wil Seabrook.

title: Lior Goldenberg
text: He works out of his private studio in Woodland Hills.

title: My Type
text: "My Type" is a song by American indie pop band Saint Motel.

title: My Type
text: It was released as the lead single from their EP of the same name in January 2014.

title: My Type
text: The song has been featured in two films, "Paper Towns" and "Mr. Right" (both 2015).

title: My Type
text: The song appeared on the soundtrack of video games "FIFA 15" and "Pro Evolution Soccer 2016".

title: Saintmotelevision
text: Saintmotelevision (stylized as saintmotelevision) is the second studio album by American indie pop band Saint Motel.

title: Saintmotelevision
text: It was released on October 21, 2016, by Elektra Records.

title: Curve Lake First Nation
text: The Curve Lake First Nation is Mississauga Ojibway First Nation located in Peterborough County of Ontario.

title: Curve Lake First Nation
text: The Curve Lake First Nation occupies three reserves; Curve Lake First Nation 35, Curve Lake 35A, and Islands in the Trent Waters Indian Reserve 36A.

title: Curve Lake First Nation
text: The last of these reserves is shared with the Hiawatha First Nation and the Scugog First Nation.

title: Curve Lake First Nation
text: The Curve Lake First Nation registered a population on these three reserves of 741, with an additional 1,050 registered band members living off-reserve.

title: Voyeur (Saint Motel album)
text: Voyeur is the debut album by American band Saint Motel, released on July 10, 2012 through OnThe Records.

title: Voyeur (Saint Motel album)
text: The album was recorded at the band's Los Angeles studio as well as Crown City Recordings.

title: Lars Stalfors
text: Lars Stalfors is an American musician, record producer, writer and mixer based in Los Angeles, CA.

title: Lars Stalfors
text: Lars’ most recent credits include Cold War Kids albums “L.A. Divine” (2017) and “Hold My Home” (2014) including the #1 alternative song “First”.

title: Lars Stalfors
text: He has also worked with and has new releases on deck with Foster the People, Electric Guest, White Lung, Antwon, HEALTH, Alice Glass, Saint Motel, Local Natives.”

title: Saint Motel
text: Saint Motel is an American indie pop band from Los Angeles, whose music has been described as everything from "dream pop" to "indie prog".

title: Saint Motel
text: The band consists of A/J Jackson (lead vocals, guitar, piano), Aaron Sharp (lead guitar), Dak Lerdamornpong (bass), and Greg Erwin (drums).

title: Curve (band)
text: Curve were an English alternative rock and electronica duo from London, formed in 1990 and split in 2005.

title: Curve (band)
text: The band consisted of Toni Halliday (vocals, occasionally guitar) and Dean Garcia (bass, guitar, drums, programming).

title: Curve (band)
text: Halliday wrote also the lyrics of their songs and they both contributed to songwriting.

title: Curve (band)
text: An important collaborator was the producer Alan Moulder, who helped them to shape their blend of heavy beats and densely layered guitar tracks set against Halliday's vocals.

title: AJ Jackson
text: A/J Jackson (born Alexander Leonard Jackson) is an American filmmaker and musician from Los Angeles, California.

title: AJ Jackson
text: He produces commercials and music videos, as well writes songs and is lead singer for the band Saint Motel.

title: AJ Jackson
text: He is known for his enthusiastic stage performances.

title: Major Boobage
text: "Major Boobage" is the third episode in season 12 of the American animated television series "South Park".

title: Major Boobage
text: The 170th episode of the series overall, it originally aired on Comedy Central in the United States on March 26, 2008.

title: Major Boobage
text: The episode was co-written by series creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone; it was the first South Park episode since 2000 not solely written by Parker, ending a streak of 120 consecutive straight solo episodes.

title: Major Boobage
text: The previous episode co-written by Stone was "The Tooth Fairy's Tats 2000".

title: South Park (season 7)
text: Season seven of "South Park", an American animated television series created by Trey Parker and Matt Stone, began airing on March 19, 2003.

title: South Park (season 7)
text: The seventh season concluded after 15 episodes on December 17, 2003, and was written and directed by Trey Parker.

title: South Park (season 8)
text: Season eight of "South Park", an American animated television series created by Trey Parker and Matt Stone, began airing on March 17, 2004.

title: South Park (season 8)
text: The eighth season concluded after 14 episodes on December 15, 2004, and was written and directed by Trey Parker.

title: South Park (season 8)
text: The season deals with various topics that were relevant at the time of release.

title: South Park (season 8)
text: The episodes portray a spectrum of topics, from effect of large scale retails corporations to immigration.

title: South Park (season 12)
text: The twelfth season of "South Park", an American animated television series created by Trey Parker and Matt Stone, began airing on March 12, 2008.

title: South Park (season 12)
text: The twelfth season concluded after 14 episodes on November 19, 2008.

title: South Park (season 12)
text: "Saturday Night Live" cast member Bill Hader is credited as a consultant starting with this season.

title: South Park (season 12)
text: Parker was the director and writer in this twelfth season.

title: South Park (season 12)
text: Stone was also the writer on the third episode of the twelfth season.

title: South Park (season 2)
text: Season two of "South Park", an American animated television series created by Trey Parker and Matt Stone, began airing on April 1, 1998.

title: South Park (season 2)
text: The second season concluded after 18 episodes on January 20, 1999; it remains the longest season of "South Park" to date.

title: South Park (season 2)
text: While most of the episodes were directed by series creator Trey Parker, Season 2 includes two episodes directed by Eric Stough.

title: South Park (season 15)
text: The fifteenth season of the American animated sitcom "South Park" began airing on Comedy Central on April 27, 2011 and ended on November 16, 2011.

title: South Park (season 15)
text: In response to reactions to the mid-season finale episode "You're Getting Old", which seemed to insinuate that creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone were wrapping up the series, Comedy Central proclaimed through the media that "South Park" was renewed for two more seasons, and the duo were signed through 2013.

title: South Park (season 15)
text: Shortly before the airing of the season finale episode "The Poor Kid", "South Park" was extended again until 2016, taking the show to 20 seasons.

title: South Park (season 15)
text: Parker was the director and writer for all episodes, and Robert Lopez was the writer in this eleventh episode for the fifteenth season.

title: South Park (season 9)
text: Season nine of "South Park", an American animated television series created by Trey Parker and Matt Stone, began airing on March 9, 2005.

title: South Park (season 9)
text: The ninth season concluded after 14 episodes on December 7, 2005.

title: South Park (season 9)
text: All of the episodes in the ninth season were written and directed by Trey Parker.

title: South Park (season 10)
text: The tenth season of "South Park", an American animated television series created by Trey Parker and Matt Stone, began airing on March 22, 2006.

title: South Park (season 10)
text: The tenth season concluded after 14 episodes on November 15, 2006.

title: South Park (season 10)
text: This is the first season in which Kenny does not die and the last season featuring Isaac Hayes (the voice of Chef) as Hayes quit the show following the backlash behind season nine's "Trapped in the Closet" episode.

title: South Park (season 10)
text: This season also had a minor controversy when the Halloween episode "Hell on Earth 2006" depicted "The Crocodile Hunter's" Steve Irwin with a stingray lodged in his chest getting thrown out of Satan's Halloween party for not being in costume.

title: South Park (season 10)
text: Episode 2 in this season is the last one with the Braniff Airlines logo.

title: South Park (season 10)
text: All the episodes in this season were written and directed by Trey Parker.

title: Funnybot
text: "Funnybot" is the second episode of the fifteenth season of the American animated television series "South Park", and the 211th episode of the series overall.

title: Funnybot
text: "Funnybot" premiered in the United States on Comedy Central on May 4, 2011, the first time a "South Park" episode has aired in May since season 10's "Tsst" in 2006.

title: Funnybot
text: "Funnybot" parodies The Comedy Awards, black comedian Tyler Perry, the Daleks from "Doctor Who", and the death of Osama bin Laden.

title: Eric Cartman
text: Eric Theodore Cartman, often referred to as just Cartman, is a main character in the animated television series "South Park", created by Matt Stone and Trey Parker, and voiced by Trey Parker.

title: Eric Cartman
text: Cartman, generally referred to by his surname, is one of four central characters in "South Park", along with his friends Stan Marsh, Kyle Broflovski, and Kenny McCormick.

title: Eric Cartman
text: Cartman first appeared, originally named Kenny, in prototypical form in a 1992 animated short "Jesus vs. Frosty", and a 1995 animated short "Jesus vs. Santa", and first appeared on television in the pilot episode of "South Park", "Cartman Gets an Anal Probe", on August 13, 1997.

title: Chestnut Hill West station
text: Chestnut Hill West station is a SEPTA Regional Rail station in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

title: Chestnut Hill West station
text: Located at 9 West Evergreen Avenue in the Chestnut Hill neighborhood, it serves the Chestnut Hill West Line.

title: Chestnut Hill West station
text: It was originally built by the Philadelphia, Germantown and Chestnut Hill Railroad between 1883 and 1884, and later acquired by the Pennsylvania Railroad.

title: Chestnut Hill West station
text: In 1918, when the line was electrified, the station was rebuilt to accommodate the upgrade.

title: List of Boston College Eagles football seasons
text: The Boston College Eagles college football team competes as part of the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) Division I Football Bowl Subdivision, representing Boston College in the Atlantic Division of the Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC).

title: List of Boston College Eagles football seasons
text: Boston College has played their home games at Alumni Stadium in Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts since 1957.

title: List of Boston College Eagles football seasons
text: Boston College claims one national championship in 1940, though the NCAA doesn't recognize it, and have played in 22 Bowl Games, winning 13.

title: List of Boston College Eagles football seasons
text: With 626 wins over 120 seasons of football, Boston College ranks 51st all-time in win-loss records in the NCAA.

title: List of Boston College Eagles football seasons
text: Boston College played as an Independent until joining the Big East Conference in 1991.

title: List of Boston College Eagles football seasons
text: Boston College later joined the Atlantic Coast Conference in 2005.

title: Chestnut Hill (Leesburg, Virginia)
text: Chestnut Hill is an 18th-century Federal-style mansion north of Leesburg in Loudoun County, Virginia, United States.

title: Chestnut Hill (Leesburg, Virginia)
text: Chestnut Hill was a home of Thomson Francis Mason (1785–21 December 1838), a prominent jurist, lawyer, councilman, judge, mayor of Alexandria, and grandson of Founding Father of the United States George Mason.

title: Chestnut Hill (Leesburg, Virginia)
text: Chestnut Hill was also a home of Mason's son, Dr. John "Frank" Francis Mason (28 August 1828–4 August 1897).

title: Chestnut Hill (Leesburg, Virginia)
text: It is located at 13263 Chestnut Hill Lane near Leesburg.

title: Old Chestnut Hill Historic District
text: The Old Chestnut Hill Historic District encompasses the historic residential heart of the Newton portion of Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts.

title: Old Chestnut Hill Historic District
text: When first listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1986, the district extended along Hammond Street, between Beacon Street and the MBTA Green Line right-of-way, and along Chestnut Hill Road between Hammond and Essex, including properties along a few adjacent streets.

title: Old Chestnut Hill Historic District
text: The district was expanded in 1990 to include more of Chestnut Hill Road and Essex Road, Suffolk Road and the roads between it and Hammond, and a small section south of the Green Line including properties on Hammond Street, Longwood Road, and Middlesex Road.

title: Old Chestnut Hill Historic District
text: A further expansion in 1999 added a single property on Suffolk Road.

title: Boston College
text: Boston College (also referred to as BC) is a private Jesuit Catholic research university located in the affluent village of Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts, United States, 6 mi west of downtown Boston.

title: Boston College
text: It has 9,100 full-time undergraduates and almost 5,000 graduate students.

title: Boston College
text: The university's name reflects its early history as a liberal arts college and preparatory school (now Boston College High School) in Dorchester.

title: Boston College
text: It is a member of the 568 Group and the Association of Jesuit Colleges and Universities.

title: Boston College
text: Its main campus is a historic district and features some of the earliest examples of collegiate gothic architecture in North America.

title: 2007 Boston College Eagles football team
text: The 2007 Boston College Eagles football team represented Boston College during the 2007 NCAA Division I FBS football season.

title: 2007 Boston College Eagles football team
text: It was Boston College's third season as a member of the Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC).

title: 2007 Boston College Eagles football team
text: The Eagles were led by Jeff Jagodzinski in his first season as Boston College head coach.

title: 2007 Boston College Eagles football team
text: Boston College has been a member of the Atlantic Coast Conference's (ACC) Atlantic Division since joining the league in 2005, after leaving the Big East Conference.

title: 2007 Boston College Eagles football team
text: The Eagles played their home games in 2007 at Alumni Stadium in Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts, which has been their home stadium since 1957.

title: Jesuit Ivy
text: "Jesuit Ivy" is the title of a commencement speech delivered at Boston College, a Jesuit university in Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts, United States.

title: Jesuit Ivy
text: The term was coined in a 1956 commencement address by then-Massachusetts Senator John F. Kennedy.

title: Jesuit Ivy
text: Speaking at the Jesuit university, he was likely making reference to the Ivy League, an athletic conference established in 1954.

title: Jesuit Ivy
text: The term "Jesuit Ivy" was somewhat of a contradiction in terms.

title: Jesuit Ivy
text: The Ivy League's members were generally Protestant-founded institutions; Boston College had itself been founded in part because Catholics were being denied admission to Harvard University in the nineteenth century.

title: Jesuit Ivy
text: The nickname suggested both Boston College's rising stature and the declining prevalence of discrimination at elite American universities.

title: Jesuit Ivy
text: Kennedy, a Catholic whose family were longtime Boston College benefactors, graduated from Harvard in 1940; as did his father in 1912, and his brothers Joe Jr, Robert and Edward in 1938, 1948 and 1956 respectively.

title: Stanford University
text: Stanford University (Stanford; officially Leland Stanford Junior University, colloquially the Farm) is a private research university in Stanford, California, adjacent to Palo Alto and between San Jose and San Francisco.

title: Stanford University
text: Stanford's undergraduate program is the most selective in America.

title: Stanford University
text: Due to its academic strength, wealth, and proximity to Silicon Valley it is often cited as one of the world's most prestigious universities.

title: Chestnut Hill Reservoir Historic District
text: The Chestnut Hill Reservoir Historic District is a historic district encompassing the Chestnut Hill Reservoir and the surrounding water works facilities which were historically used to provide fresh water to Boston, Massachusetts, and surrounding towns.

title: Chestnut Hill Reservoir Historic District
text: The district is nearly coextensive with the Chestnut Hill Reservation, a state park managed by the Massachusetts Department of Conservation and Recreation (DCR); those elements of the water works that are still required as an emergency backup are managed by the Massachusetts Water Resources Authority (MWRA).

title: Chestnut Hill Reservoir Historic District
text: The reservoir is located between Beacon Street and Commonwealth Avenue in Boston, just east of the Boston College Main Campus Historic District and the Boston-Newton city line.

title: Chestnut Hill Reservoir Historic District
text: Most of the water works facilities are also located in Boston; the terminal house of the Sudbury Aqueduct, which is part of this district, is located just over the line in Newton.

title: Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts
text: Chestnut Hill is an affluent New England village located six miles (10 km) west of downtown Boston, Massachusetts, United States.

title: Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts
text: Like all Massachusetts villages, Chestnut Hill is not an incorporated municipal entity.

title: Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts
text: Unlike most Massachusetts villages, it encompasses parts of three separate municipalities, each located in a different county: the town of Brookline in Norfolk County; the city of Boston in Suffolk County (parts of its neighborhoods of Brighton and West Roxbury), and the city of Newton in Middlesex County.

title: Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts
text: Chestnut Hill's borders are roughly defined by the 02467 ZIP Code.

title: Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts
text: Chestnut Hill is not a topographical designation; the name refers to several small hills that overlook the 135-acre (546,000 m) Chestnut Hill Reservoir rather than one particular hill.

title: Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts
text: Chestnut Hill is best known as the home of Boston College, part of the Boston Marathon route, as well as the Collegiate Gothic canvas of landscape architect Frederick Law Olmsted.

title: Arthur Rigby (actor)
text: Arthur Turner (27 September 1900 – 25 April 1971) was an English actor.

title: Arthur Rigby (actor)
text: He was best known for playing Sgt Flint on the TV series "Dixon of Dock Green", appearing in 253 episodes from 1955 to 1965.

title: Arthur Rigby (actor)
text: He also appeared with "Dixon" 's star Jack Warner in the 1949 film "The Blue Lamp", which was also the film in which the character of PC George Dixon was created.

title: Walter Reed (actor)
text: Walter Reed (born Walter Reed Smith, February 10, 1916 – August 20, 2001) was an American stage, film and television actor.

title: Walter Reed (actor)
text: He was born in Fort Ward, Washington.

title: Walter Reed (actor)
text: Following a stint as a Broadway actor, Reed broke into films in 1941.

title: Walter Reed (actor)
text: He appeared in several features for RKO Radio Pictures, including the last two "Mexican Spitfire" comedies (in which Reed replaced Buddy Rogers as the Spitfire's husband).

title: Walter Reed (actor)
text: Perhaps his most memorable role was as the spineless wagon driver husband of Gail Russell in the western "Seven Men from Now".

title: Walter Reed (actor)
text: Reed also appeared in the very first Superman theatrical feature film "Superman and the Mole Men" in 1951.

title: Brian Lane Green
text: Brian Lane Green (born March 9, 1962) is an American stage and television actor and singer.

title: Brian Lane Green
text: He is known for his stage roles throughout the country such as the title character in Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat.

title: Brian Lane Green
text: Green garnered a Tony Award nomination for his performance in the 1989 Broadway production of "Starmites".

title: Brian Lane Green
text: He also appeared as JoJo in "The Life" on Broadway.

title: Eric Thal
text: Eric Thal (born August 10, 1965) is an American film and stage actor, perhaps best known as Ariel in Sidney Lumet's "A Stranger Among Us"; Sam Nivens in "The Puppet Masters"; Samson in "Samson and Delilah"; Meade Howell in "The Wedding"; and Rick in "Six Degrees of Separation".

title: Victor Mature
text: Victor John Mature (January 29, 1913 – August 4, 1999) was an American stage, film, and television actor who starred most notably in several Biblical movies during the 1950s, and was known for his dark good looks and mega-watt smile.

title: Victor Mature
text: His best known film roles include "One Million B.C." (1940), "My Darling Clementine" (1946), "Kiss of Death" (1947), "Samson and Delilah" (1949), and "The Robe" (1953).

title: Victor Mature
text: He also appeared in a large number of musicals opposite such stars as Rita Hayworth and Betty Grable.

title: Teru Shimada
text: Teru Shimada (November 17, 1905 – June 19, 1988) was an acclaimed Japanese-American actor who was cast most famously as Mr. Osato, a SPECTRE agent in the 1967 James Bond film, "You Only Live Twice".

title: Teru Shimada
text: His film career began in 1932 with the "Night Club Lady".

title: Teru Shimada
text: He appeared with Peter Lorre in the 1939 classic "Mr. Moto's Last Warning".

title: Teru Shimada
text: Another notable role was opposite Humphrey Bogart in the 1949 film, "Tokyo Joe".

title: Teru Shimada
text: He had an uncredited role in 20th Century Fox's 1966 film "Batman" as a Japanese Delegate, and as Mr. Kurawa in Cary Grant's final film, Walk, Don't Run.

title: Teru Shimada
text: He also appeared in an episode (titled "And Five of Us are Left") of the 1960s American television series "Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea" in 1965.

title: Teru Shimada
text: That year he also made a guest appearance on "Perry Mason" as Dr. Maseo Tachikawa in "The Case of the Baffling Bug."

title: Teru Shimada
text: In 1970, he had had a leading role in an episode of "Hawaii Five-O" (titled "The Reunion").

title: Teru Shimada
text: He later retired in the mid-1970s following appearances in "Barnaby Jones" and "The Six Million Dollar Man", and died in Encino, California in 1988.

title: Elois Jenssen
text: Elois Jenssen (November 5, 1922 – February 14, 2004) was an American film and television costume designer.

title: Elois Jenssen
text: She earned Academy Awards nominations for design work in the Cecil B. DeMille production "Samson and Delilah" (1949) and for her work on the Walt Disney Studios film "Tron" (1982).

title: Ivan Samson
text: Ivan Samson (28 August 1894 – 1 May 1963) was a British stage, film and television actor.

title: Ivan Samson
text: Samson appeared regularly in West End plays and from 1920 began appearing in British silent films.

title: Ivan Samson
text: He played Viscount de Mornay in "I Will Repay" and Lord Dudley in "The Loves of Mary, Queen of Scots".

title: Ivan Samson
text: In later talkie films, Samson played roles in the literary adaptations "The Winslow Boy" (1948) and "The Browning Version" (1951).

title: Ivan Samson
text: His final film appearance was as Admiral Loddon in the 1959 film "Libel".

title: Ivan Samson
text: He also appeared in television series such as "The Teckman Biography", "Operation Diplomat" and "Dixon of Dock Green".

title: Gary Watson
text: Gary Watson (13 June 1930 in Shropshire, England) is a retired British television actor who started out as a stage actor most notably acting in Friedrich Hebbel's 1962 play "Judith" at Her Majesty's Theatre in London, England with Sean Connery.

title: Gary Watson
text: He was however best known for his appearances in British ITC productions of the 1960s including "The Avengers", "The Saint" and "Randall and Hopkirk (Deceased)" in 1969 in the last episode The Smile Behind the Veil.

title: Gary Watson
text: In 1966 he played in all 10 episodes of The Three Musketeers as Aramis starring alongside Brian Blessed and Jeremy Brett.

title: Gary Watson
text: He also appeared in the 1967 "Doctor Who" serial The Evil of the Daleks.

title: Gary Watson
text: He appeared alongside Anthony Hopkins in the 1972 Television series War and Peace.

title: Gary Watson
text: He played the semi-regular character of Det. Insp. Fred Connor in the long running BBC police drama Z-Cars between 1972 and 1974.

title: Gary Watson
text: In 1974 he played George Vavsor for 5 episodes in The Pallisers which also featured Jeremy Irons.

title: Gary Watson
text: In 1977, he played the role of Ross in the BBC series "Murder Most English" and also appeared in the 1988 BBC adaptation of Macbeth playing MacDuff.

title: Gary Watson
text: He was also much employed as a reader and narrator, featuring in dozens of commercials throughout the 1980s and 1990s, particularly noted for his work in British Transport Films, Lloyds Bank and Nescafé adverts.

title: Samson and Delilah (1984 film)
text: Samson and Delilah is a 1984 television film adaptation of the biblical story of Samson and Delilah, starring Max von Sydow, Belinda Bauer, Antony Hamilton, Daniel Stern and Victor Mature.

title: Samson and Delilah (1984 film)
text: Mature played Samson in the 1949 film and had a small cameo as the father of Antony Hamilton's Samson.

title: Samson and Delilah (1984 film)
text: This was his final acting role.

title: Samson and Delilah (1984 film)
text: Based on the novel "Husband of Delilah" by Eric Linklater, "Samson and Delilah" originally aired on ABC.

title: Iqaluit Airport
text: Iqaluit Airport (IATA: YFB, ICAO: CYFB) serves Iqaluit, Nunavut, Canada and is located adjacent to the town.

title: Iqaluit Airport
text: It is operated by the government of Nunavut.

title: Iqaluit Airport
text: It hosts scheduled passenger service from Ottawa, Montreal, Rankin Inlet and Kuujjuaq on carriers such as First Air and Canadian North, and from smaller communities throughout eastern Nunavut.

title: Iqaluit Airport
text: It is also used as a forward operating base by the CF-18 Hornet.

title: Iqaluit Airport
text: In 2011, the terminal handled more than 120,000 passengers.

title: Frobisher Bay Air Base
text: Frobisher Bay Air Base is a former United States Air Force facility adjacent to the then town of Frobisher Bay, Northwest Territories (now Iqaluit, Nunavut); 1299 mi north of Ottawa, Ontario.

title: Frobisher Bay Air Base
text: It was closed in 1963 and became a civilian airport Frobisher Bay Airport (Iqaluit Airport since 1987).

title: Lawren Harris
text: Lawren Stewart Harris, CC (October 23, 1885 – January 29, 1970) was a Canadian painter.

title: Lawren Harris
text: He was born in Brantford, Ontario, and is best known as a member of the Group of Seven who pioneered a distinctly Canadian painting style in the early twentieth century.

title: Lawren Harris
text: A. Y. Jackson has been quoted as saying that Harris provided the stimulus for the Group of Seven.

title: Lawren Harris
text: During the 1920s, Harris's works became more abstract and simplified, especially his stark landscapes of the Canadian north and Arctic.

title: Lawren Harris
text: He also stopped signing and dating his works so that people would judge his works on their own merit and not by the artist or when they were painted.

title: Lawren Harris
text: In 1969, he was made a Companion of the Order of Canada.

title: Frank Wolf (adventurer)
text: Frank Wolf (born 1970) is a Canadian adventurer, filmmaker, writer and environmentalist.

title: Frank Wolf (adventurer)
text: He is known for films, feature magazine articles, and online columns that document wilderness expeditions around the world, with a focus on the Canadian North.

title: Frank Wolf (adventurer)
text: His expeditions include being the first to canoe across Canada in one season and cycling 2,000 km in winter on the Yukon River from Dawson to Nome.

title: Frank Wolf (adventurer)
text: His films include "Wild Ones", "The Hand of Franklin", "Kitturiaq", "On the Line", "Mammalian", and "Borealis", all of which broadcast on CBC's "documentary "channel in Canada.

title: Frank Wolf (adventurer)
text: In 2012 he was named one of Canada's Top Ten Adventurers by Explore Magazine, and in 2015 he was named One of Canada's Top 100 Explorers by Canadian Geographic Magazine.

title: Selwyn Egerton Sangster
text: Selwyn Egerton Sangster, known as Canuck, was a Canadian outdoorsman and writer.

title: Selwyn Egerton Sangster
text: He lived 1883 to 1966.

title: Selwyn Egerton Sangster
text: He was a member of the Canadian North West Mounted Police, and for years attached to the Canadian Indian Service.

title: Selwyn Egerton Sangster
text: He founded a hunting and fishing outfitting organisation in the Height of Land region of North Canada.

title: Canadian North
text: Canadian North Inc. is an airline headquartered in Calgary, Alberta, Canada.

title: Canadian North
text: It operates scheduled passenger services to communities in the Northwest Territories and Nunavut.

title: Canadian North
text: Southern gateways include Edmonton and Ottawa.

title: Canadian North
text: Its main base is Edmonton Airport.

title: Nunatsiaq News
text: Nunatsiaq News (Inuktitut: ᓄᓇᑦᓯᐊᕐᒥ ᐱᕙᓪᓕᐊᔪᑦ ) is a Canadian weekly newspaper based in Iqaluit, Nunavut serving Nunavut and the Nunavik region of northern Quebec and has been in operation since 1973.

title: Nunatsiaq News
text: The paper, published every Friday by Nortext Publishing Corporation of Iqaluit and Ottawa, bears a retail price of $1.00.

title: Nunatsiaq News
text: Co-op stores in Nunavut and Nunavik distribute it to their customers for free.

title: Air Nunavut
text: Air Nunavut is an airline based in Iqaluit, Nunavut, Canada.

title: Air Nunavut
text: It is the only local and Inuit-owned air carrier in the eastern Arctic, operating MEDEVAC and charter services throughout Canada's Arctic, northern Quebec and Greenland.

title: Air Nunavut
text: Its main base is Iqaluit Airport.

title: First Air
text: Bradley Air Services Limited, operating as First Air, is an airline headquartered in Kanata, a suburb of Ottawa, Ontario, Canada.

title: First Air
text: It operates services to 34 communities in Nunavut, Nunavik, and the Northwest Territories.

title: First Air
text: The majority of its fleet is available for charters worldwide.

title: First Air
text: First Air has assisted in various humanitarian missions such as the 2010 Haiti earthquake, airlifting relief supplies and equipment.

title: First Air
text: Its main base, which includes a large hangar, cargo and maintenance facility, is located at Ottawa Macdonald–Cartier International Airport, with hubs at Iqaluit Airport, Rankin Inlet Airport and Yellowknife Airport.

title: Bernard Émond
text: Bernard Émond (born Montreal 1951) is a Québecois and Canadian director, screenwriter, novelist and essayist working in the French-language.

title: Bernard Émond
text: He studied anthropology at university and lived for several years in the Canadian north where he worked for the Inuit Broadcasting Corporation.

title: Bernard Émond
text: He began his film career making documentaries, later moving to feature-length films, all of which have been shot in Quebec.

title: Bernard Émond
text: He is noted for the humanistic, sometimes spiritual depth of his films, in particular his trilogy of feature films (2007, 2009, 2012) based on the three Christian virtues, faith, hope, and charity.

title: Bernard Émond
text: Other themes in his work include human dignity and frailty, and cultural loss.

title: Bernard Émond
text: He describes himself as an agnostic and a "conservative socialist."

title: Socialist Party of Connecticut
text: The Socialist Party of Connecticut (SPCT) is a socialist political party in the U.S. state of Connecticut.

title: Socialist Party of Connecticut
text: Founded as an affiliate of the Socialist Party of America, the party split with the SPA in 1936 and joined the Social Democratic Federation.

title: Socialist Party of Connecticut
text: In 1957, the Social Democratic Federation reunified with the Socialist Party of America.

title: Socialist Party of Connecticut
text: In 1973, the SPA voted to reform and rename itself Social Democrats, USA, which sought to reform the Democratic Party.

title: Socialist Party of Connecticut
text: The current Socialist Party of Connecticut is the state chapter of the Socialist Party USA.

title: Royal Spa Centre
text: The Royal Spa Centre is a Theatre in Leamington Spa, England.

title: Royal Spa Centre
text: The Centre was officially opened on 15 June 1972 by Anthony Eden, one time MP for Leamington and Warwick and Prime Minister of the UK.

title: Royal Spa Centre
text: It was designed by the Architect Sir Frederick Gibberd and has two Auditoria, the first of which is a traditional Theatre which can hold 667 people.

title: Royal Spa Centre
text: The second is a Cinema/Studio Theatre which holds up to 188, which shows films or used as a small theatre space.

title: Federation Party
text: The Federation Party was Fiji's first formal political party.

title: Federation Party
text: The Citizens Federation, which had won three of the four seats reserved for Indo-Fijians at the 1963 elections, decided to formalize its role as a political party, which was officially founded on 21 June 1964 with A. D. Patel as President and Sidiq Koya as Vice-President.

title: Federation Party
text: The merger took place in time for the party to participate in the 1965 constitutional conference which was called to map out a path towards independence from the United Kingdom.

title: Federation Party
text: In 1968, the Federation Party merged with the National Democratic Party to form the National Federation Party, which is now (2015) the oldest political party in Fiji still in existence.

title: Boerestaat Party
text: The Boerstaat Party (English: "Boer State Party" ) is a right wing South African political party founded on 30 September 1986 by the late Robert van Tonder.

title: Boerestaat Party
text: It was never officially registered as a political party because it was unable to rally 500 persons under one roof, a requirement under South African electoral law for official political party status.

title: Boerestaat Party
text: It was never represented in the South African Parliament, neither in the apartheid era nor after democratisation.

title: Boerestaat Party
text: In 1989, it joined the Afrikaner Weerstandsbeweging (AWB) in declaring support for Jaap Marais, the leader of the Herstigte Nasionale Party and has worked with the HNP on occasion since.

title: Boerestaat Party
text: The party was a charter member of the Afrikaner Volksfront coalition group.

title: Boerestaat Party
text: It has also operated with the paramilitary group, the "Boere Weerstandsbeweging" (Boer Resistance Movement) led by Andrew Ford.

title: Anthony Eden
text: Robert Anthony Eden, 1st Earl of Avon, (12 June 1897 – 14 January 1977) was a British Conservative politician who served three periods as Foreign Secretary and then a relatively brief term as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1955 to 1957.

title: Political party committee
text: In the United States, a political party committee is an organization, officially affiliated with a political party and registered with the Federal Elections Commission (FEC), which raises and spends money for political campaigning.

title: Political party committee
text: Political party committees are distinct from political action committees, which are formally independent of political parties and subject to different rules.

title: Royal Pump Rooms
text: The Royal Pump Rooms (signed Royal Pump Room and Baths) is a Grade II listed building on the Parade in Leamington Spa, Warwickshire, England.

title: Royal Pump Rooms
text: It was the most famous of several spa baths opened in Leamington between the late-18th and mid-19th centuries.

title: Royal Pump Rooms
text: People would travel from throughout the country, and indeed Europe, to benefit from treatments using the town's healing waters.

title: Royal Pump Rooms
text: When 'taking the waters' became less fashionable after the mid-19th century the Pump Rooms became Leamington's only surviving spa facility, later also being extended to include the town's public swimming pool.

title: Royal Pump Rooms
text: After a major redevelopment in 1997-99 the building now houses "Leamington Spa Art Gallery & Museum", a public library, a Tourist Information Centre, cafe and assembly rooms.

title: Conservative Party (UK)
text: The Conservative Party, officially the Conservative and Unionist Party, is a centre-right political party in the United Kingdom.

title: Conservative Party (UK)
text: It is currently the governing party, having been so since the 2010 general election, where a coalition government with the Liberal Democrats was formed.

title: Conservative Party (UK)
text: In 2015, the Conservatives led by David Cameron won a surprise majority and formed the first Conservative majority government since 1992.

title: Conservative Party (UK)
text: However, the 2017 snap election on Thursday 8 June resulted in a hung parliament, and the Conservatives lost their parliamentary majority.

title: Conservative Party (UK)
text: They are reliant on the support of a Northern Irish political party, the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), in order to command a majority in the House of Commons through a confidence-and-supply deal.

title: Conservative Party (UK)
text: The party leader, Theresa May, has served as both Leader of the Conservative Party and Prime Minister since 13 July 2016.

title: Conservative Party (UK)
text: It is the largest party in local government with 9,237 councillors.

title: Conservative Party (UK)
text: The Conservative Party is one of the two major contemporary political parties in the United Kingdom, the other being its modern rival, the Labour Party.

title: Conservative Party (UK)
text: The Conservative Party's platform involves support for free market capitalism, free enterprise, fiscal conservatism, a strong national defence, deregulation, and restrictions on trade unions.

title: Save Romania Union
text: The Save Romania Union (Romanian: "Uniunea Salvați România" , USR) is a political party in Romania.

title: Save Romania Union
text: The party was founded following the success of the Save Bucharest Union (USB) party in the 2016 local elections.

title: Save Romania Union
text: After being officially registered as a political party in 2016, it united with the USB and Union for Codlea parties, thus gaining most of its initial membership base from the two latter parties.

title: Save Romania Union
text: It is currently the third largest political party in Romania after the 2016 legislative elections and the only outspoken pro-LGBT party in the country.

title: Unity Party (South Ossetia)
text: The Unity Party (Ossetian: Иудзинад , Georgian: ერთიანობის , Russian: Единство ; officially, the South Ossetian Republican Political Party "Unity") is a major political party with a socially conservative ideology in South Ossetia, a partially recognized Caucasian republic, considered by most countries to be a part of Georgia.

title: Unity Party (South Ossetia)
text: The Unity Party, founded in 2003, supported former President Eduard Kokoity, and was for a decade the largest political party in South Ossetia.

title: Unity Party (South Ossetia)
text: After the 2009 elections, the party held 17 out of 34 seats in South Ossetia's parliament.

title: Unity Party (South Ossetia)
text: It is modeled after and is closely linked to the United Russia party, with which it has signed an inter-party cooperation agreement.

title: Unity Party (South Ossetia)
text: The party is a winner of the 2004 and 2009 parliamentary elections.

title: Mississippi Masala
text: Mississippi Masala is a 1991 romantic drama film directed by Mira Nair, based upon a screenplay by Sooni Taraporevala, starring Denzel Washington, Sarita Choudhury, and Roshan Seth.

title: Mississippi Masala
text: Set primarily in rural Mississippi, the film explores interracial romance between African Americans and Indian Americans in the United States.

title: Part 2, Sounder
text: Part 2, Sounder is a 1976 American drama film directed by William A. Graham.

title: Part 2, Sounder
text: It is the sequel to the 1972 Oscar-nominated film "Sounder", which in turn is based on William H. Armstrong's Newbery Award-winning novel of the same name.

title: Part 2, Sounder
text: Although Lonne Elder III and Robert B. Radnitz returned as screenwriter and producer respectively, neither Martin Ritt nor any of the cast members from the first film participated in the sequel, with the exception of Taj Mahal, who reprised his role as Ike and returned as composer.

title: Part 2, Sounder
text: According to Bob McCann, the film was "barely released."

title: Sooni Taraporevala
text: Sooni Taraporevala (born 1957) is an Indian screenwriter, photographer and filmmaker who is best known as the screenwriter of "Mississippi Masala", "The Namesake" and Oscar-nominated "Salaam Bombay" (1988), all directed by Mira Nair.

title: Howards End (film)
text: Howards End is a 1992 British romantic drama film based upon the novel of the same name by E. M. Forster (published in 1910), a story of class relations in turn-of-the-20th-century England.

title: Howards End (film)
text: The film—produced by Merchant Ivory Productions as their third adaptation of a Forster novel (following "A Room with a View" in 1985 and "Maurice" in 1987)—was the first film to be released by Sony Pictures Classics.

title: Howards End (film)
text: The screenplay was written by Ruth Prawer Jhabvala, directed by James Ivory and produced by Ismail Merchant.

title: Little Zizou
text: Little Zizou is an 2008 Indian film in Hindi, Gujarati, and English, written and directed by Sooni Taraporevala.

title: Little Zizou
text: "Little Zizou" is a fast-paced, exuberant, yet poignant comedy about how two battling Mumbai families finally come to terms.

title: Duel of Hearts
text: Duel of Hearts is a 1991 romantic television film directed by John Hough.

title: Duel of Hearts
text: Terence Feely penned the screenplay, based on the Barbara Cartland novel, "A Duel of Hearts".

title: Duel of Hearts
text: The film stars Alison Doody, Michael York, Geraldine Chaplin and Benedict Taylor.

title: The Namesake (film)
text: The Namesake is a 2006 Indian-American drama film which was released in the United States on 9 March 2007, following screenings at film festivals in Toronto and New York City.

title: The Namesake (film)
text: It was directed by Mira Nair and is based upon the novel of the same name by Jhumpa Lahiri, who appeared in the movie.

title: The Namesake (film)
text: Sooni Taraporevala wrote the screenplay.

title: The Namesake (film)
text: The film received positive reviews from American critics.

title: The Namesake (film)
text: The film stars Tabu, Irrfan Khan, Kal Penn and Sahira Nair.

title: Lone Scherfig
text: Lone Scherfig (born 2 May 1959) is a Danish film director and screenwriter who has been involved with the Dogme 95 film movement and who has been widely critically acclaimed for several of her movies, including the Oscar-nominated film "An Education" (2009).

title: Lone Scherfig
text: Scherfig's movies are generally romantic comedies, including her film "One Day" (2011), based on the David Nicholls novel.

title: Lone Scherfig
text: Through both experimenting with creative constraints and her astute attention to detail, she has come to be recognized as a blossoming talent in the film industry.

title: Parineeta (2005 film)
text: Parineeta ("The Married Woman") is a 2005 Indian musical romantic drama film adaptation of the 1914 Bengali novella, "Parineeta" by Sarat Chandra Chattopadhyay.

title: Parineeta (2005 film)
text: Directed by debutant Pradeep Sarkar, it was based upon a screenplay by the film's producer, Vidhu Vinod Chopra.

title: Parineeta (2005 film)
text: The film featured Vidya Balan (In her Bollywood Debut), Saif Ali Khan and Sanjay Dutt in the lead roles.

title: Parineeta (2005 film)
text: Raima Sen plays the supporting role of Lalita's chirpy cousin.

title: Parineeta (2005 film)
text: Sabyasachi Chakrabarty plays the pivotal role of Shekhar's father.

title: Parineeta (2005 film)
text: Diya Mirza, with a cameo appearance as Shekhar's fiancé and Rekha, with a cameo performance of a night club (Moulin Rouge) singer, are other notable performances.

title: Such a Long Journey (film)
text: Such a Long Journey is a 1998 Indo-Canadian english language film based on the novel of the same name written by Rohinton Mistry.

title: Such a Long Journey (film)
text: The film is directed by Sturla Gunnarsson with a screenplay by Sooni Taraporevala.

title: Such a Long Journey (film)
text: The film received twelve Genie Awards nominations including the Best Picture, Best Director, and Best Actor.

title: Such a Long Journey (film)
text: The film was screened at the Toronto International Film Festival.

title: Give It All
text: "Give It All" is a song by American rock band Rise Against.

title: Give It All
text: It was originally recorded for the 2004 compilation album "Rock Against Bush, Vol.

title: Give It All
text: 1", while a slightly altered version appeared on the band's third studio album "Siren Song of the Counter Culture" later that year.

title: Give It All
text: It is a hardcore punk song, with lyrics that are about "being a punk rocker in today's world," according to lead vocalist Tim McIlrath.

title: Give It All
text: It was released as "Siren Song of the Counter Culture"'s first single in October 2004.

title: Tim McIlrath
text: Timothy James "Tim" McIlrath (born November 3, 1978) is an American punk rock musician.

title: Tim McIlrath
text: He is the lead singer, rhythm guitarist, songwriter and co-founder of the American punk rock band Rise Against.

title: Tim McIlrath
text: McIlrath is known to support animal rights and actively promotes PETA with his band.

title: Tim McIlrath
text: He is also straight edge.

title: The Dwarves Must Die
text: The Dwarves Must Die is the 2004 release by the American punk band Dwarves.

title: The Dwarves Must Die
text: It is the band's first release on the "Sympathy for the Record Industry" label.

title: The Dwarves Must Die
text: There are several cameos, including Dexter Holland from The Offspring, Nash Kato from Urge Overkill, desert rock icon Nick Oliveri, Josh Freese from The Vandals, Spike Slawson from Me First and the Gimme Gimmes, gangster rapper San Quinn, DJ Marz, and even the original Space Ghost himself, Gary Owens.

title: The Dwarves Must Die
text: The rather freeform departure from the standard thrash/punk/noise sound is obvious in this release, slightly more so than in previous Dwarves productions, perhaps because they have been producing music for almost 20 years; however the original sound of the Dwarves shows clearly in several tracks.

title: Tragedy + Time
text: "Tragedy + Time" is a song by American punk rock band Rise Against.

title: Tragedy + Time
text: The song was released as the second single from their seventh album, titled "The Black Market".

title: Tragedy + Time
text: The song impacted radio on October 21, 2014.

title: Tragedy + Time
text: According to lead singer Tim McIlrath, the title of the song comes from the phrase "tragedy plus time equals comedy".

title: Tragedy + Time
text: The song is a playable track in Guitar Hero Live.

title: Spike Slawson
text: Spike Slawson is an American punk rock musician, a member of Me First and the Gimme Gimmes, Swingin' Utters, Filthy Thievin' Bastards, Re-Volts, and Uke-Hunt.

title: The Violence
text: "The Violence" is a song by American punk rock band Rise Against.

title: The Violence
text: The song was released on April 20, 2017 as the lead single from their eighth studio album, "Wolves".

title: The Violence
text: Inspired by the 2016 United States presidential election cycle, "The Violence" contains lyrics described by vocalist Tim McIlrath as being about "whether violence is an inevitability of the human condition, or whether it's a choice we make, and therefore, can reject."

title: The Violence
text: The song has charted on both Billboard's Alternative Songs chart and Mainstream Rock Songs chart.

title: Audience of One (song)
text: "Audience of One" is a song by American punk rock band Rise Against, written by the band's frontman Tim McIlrath.

title: Audience of One (song)
text: It is the second single from their 2008 album "Appeal to Reason".

title: Audience of One (song)
text: Hitting number four on the "Billboard" Alternative Songs chart, "Audience of One" is Rise Against's third-highest charting single, behind the previous single from "Appeal to Reason", "Re-Education (Through Labor)", which peaked at number three and the third single "Savior".

title: The Honor System (band)
text: The Honor System was an American punk rock band from Chicago, Illinois, formed in 1999 by Dan Hanaway and Rob DePaola, after the breakup of their previous band The Broadways.

title: The Honor System (band)
text: The band briefly featured future Rise Against frontman Tim McIlrath as a bassist.

title: The Honor System (band)
text: They broke up in 2004, leaving behind two studio albums and three EPs.

title: Help Is on the Way
text: "Help Is on the Way" is a song by American rock band Rise Against, featured on their sixth studio album "Endgame" (2011).

title: Help Is on the Way
text: Inspired by lead vocalist Tim McIlrath's visit to New Orleans, the song is about the slow response time for aid to disaster stricken areas.

title: Help Is on the Way
text: It incorporates elements of punk rock and melodic hardcore, with lyrics that allude to Hurricane Katrina and the "Deepwater Horizon" oil spill.

title: Help Is on the Way
text: "Help Is on the Way" premiered on KROQ-FM on January 17, 2011, and was later released as "Endgame"' s lead single on January 25.

title: Filthy Thieving Bastards
text: The Filthy Thieving Bastards is an American folk/punk rock group formed in 2000 in San Francisco, California.

title: Filthy Thieving Bastards
text: The band was originally a side project put together by Johnny Bonnel and Darius Koski of the Swingin' Utters.

title: Filthy Thieving Bastards
text: Spike Slawson (also from Swingin' Utters) later joined the band, along with recording engineer Randy Burk.

title: Filthy Thieving Bastards
text: Greg Lisher from Camper Van Beethoven guested on guitar for several songs on their second release.

title: Filthy Thieving Bastards
text: Their music is influenced by folk rock, Celtic rock, country music, 60's pop, and punk rock, with an acknowledged and oft-noted debt to the music of The Pogues.

title: Gigantic (2008 film)
text: Gigantic is a 2008 independent comedy film directed by Matt Aselton and starring Paul Dano, Zooey Deschanel, John Goodman, Edward Asner and Jane Alexander.

title: Gigantic (2008 film)
text: The script, written by Aselton and his college friend Adam Nagata, tells of Brian (Dano), a mattress salesman who wishes to adopt a baby from China, but finds himself sharing his passion, with the quirky, wealthy Harriet (Deschanel) when they meet in his store.

title: Gigantic (2008 film)
text: The story was based on Aselton's childhood wish for his parents to adopt a Chinese baby.

title: Gigantic (2008 film)
text: The film was shot in New York and Connecticut.

title: Gigantic (2008 film)
text: It had its world premiere at 2008's Toronto International Film Festival and was released in the United States on April 3, 2009.

title: First Monday in October (film)
text: First Monday in October is a 1981 American comedy-drama film from Paramount Pictures, produced by Paul M. Heller and Martha Scott, directed by Ronald Neame, that is based on the play of the same name by Jerome Lawrence and Robert E. Lee.

title: First Monday in October (film)

title: Cate Blanchett
text: Catherine Elise Blanchett, {'1': ", '2': ", '3': ", '4': "} ( ; born 14 May 1969) is an Australian actress and theatre director.

title: Cate Blanchett
text: She has received international acclaim and many accolades, including two Academy Awards, three Golden Globe Awards, three BAFTA Awards, six AACTA Awards, and three Screen Actors Guild Awards. Blanchett came to international attention for her role as Elizabeth I of England in Shekhar Kapur's 1998 film "Elizabeth", for which she won the BAFTA Award for Best Actress, the Golden Globe Award, and earned her first Academy Award for Best Actress nomination.

title: Cate Blanchett
text: Her portrayal of Katharine Hepburn in Martin Scorsese's 2004 film "The Aviator" brought her critical acclaim and many accolades, including the Academy Award for Best Actress in a Supporting Role, making her the only actor to win an Oscar for portraying another Oscar-winning actor.

title: Cate Blanchett
text: In 2013, she starred as Jasmine Francis in Woody Allen's "Blue Jasmine", for which she won numerous accolades including the Academy Award for Best Actress.

title: Russell Crowe filmography

title: Cantinflas
text: Mario Fortino Alfonso Moreno Reyes, known casually as Mario Moreno, and known professionally as Cantinflas (August 12, 1911 – April 20, 1993), was a Mexican comic film actor, producer, and screenwriter and an iconic figure in Mexico and Latin America.

title: Cantinflas
text: He often portrayed impoverished "campesinos" or a peasant of "pelado" origin.

title: Cantinflas
text: The character came to be associated with the national identity of Mexico, and allowed Cantinflas to establish a long, successful film career that included a foray into Hollywood.

title: Cantinflas
text: Charlie Chaplin once commented that he was the best comedian alive, and Moreno has been referred to as the "Charlie Chaplin of Mexico".

title: Cantinflas
text: To audiences in the United States, he is best remembered as co-starring with David Niven in the Academy Award winner for Best Picture film "Around the World in 80 Days", for which Moreno won a Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy.

title: Tom Cruise filmography
text: Tom Cruise is an American actor and producer who made his film debut with a minor role in the 1981 romantic drama "Endless Love".

title: Tom Cruise filmography
text: Two years later he made his breakthrough by starring in the romantic comedy "Risky Business" (1983), which garnered Cruise his first nomination for the Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy.

title: Tom Cruise filmography
text: In 1986, Cruise played a fighter pilot in the Tony Scott-directed action drama "Top Gun" (the highest-grossing film that year), and also starred opposite Paul Newman in the Martin Scorsese-directed drama "The Color of Money".

title: Tom Cruise filmography
text: Two years later he played opposite Dustin Hoffman in the Academy Award for Best Picture-winning drama "Rain Man" (1988), and also appeared in the Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Picture-winning romantic drama "Cocktail" (1988).

title: Tom Cruise filmography
text: In doing so Cruise became the first and only person as of 2014 to star in a Best Picture Oscar winner and a Worst Picture Razzie winner in the same year.

title: Tom Cruise filmography
text: His next role was as anti-war activist Ron Kovic in the drama adaptation of Kovic's memoir of the same name, "Born on the Fourth of July" (1989).

title: Tom Cruise filmography
text: For his performance Cruise received the Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Drama and his first nomination for the Academy Award for Best Actor.

title: Tom Daley
text: Thomas Robert Daley (born 21 May 1994) is a British diver.

title: Tom Daley
text: Tom Daley specialises in the 10-metre platform event and is a double World champion in the event; he won the 2009 FINA World Championionship in the individual event at the age of 15, before regaining it in 2017.

title: Tom Daley

title: Splash! (UK TV series)
text: Splash!

text: is a British television series that follows celebrities as they try to master the art of diving.

title: Splash! (UK TV series)
text: The show premiered on ITV on 5 January 2013 winning the ratings battle for its 7.15pm-8.15pm slot with an average audience of 5.6 million viewers, a network share of 23.6%, however, it was cancelled on 15 February 2014 after just two series.

title: Zoe Arancini
text: Zoe Arancini (born 14 July 1991) is an Australian club water polo player who plays driver, counter-attacker, or outside shooter.

title: Zoe Arancini
text: Several of her family members have represented her country in water polo.

title: Zoe Arancini
text: She plays club water polo in the National Water Polo League for the Fremantle Marlins, where she has won the league championship in 2005, 2007 and 2008 and is coached by her mother.

title: Zoe Arancini

title: Zoe Arancini
text: She has been included on the roster to represent the country at the 2012 Summer Olympics.

text: Life in a Tin Can is the Bee Gees' eleventh studio album (ninth worldwide), released in January 1973.

text: The Bee Gees moved their base of operations from England to Los Angeles to record "Life in a Tin Can".

title: Life in a Tin Can
text: However, it was unable to prevent a commercial decline with the album criticised for a lack of innovation.

title: Life in a Tin Can
text: It was the first Bee Gees album to bear the RSO label in the US.

title: Meech Wells
text: Meech Wells (born Cecil D. Womack, Jr.) is a music producer from the United States.

title: Meech Wells
text: He works primarily on hip hop music, and has produced or co-produced for artists Snoop Dogg and Shaquille O'Neal.

title: Meech Wells
text: Wells is also the son of Motown singer Mary Wells and musician/songwriter, Cecil Womack.

title: Meech Wells
text: Being the son of Motown legend Mary Wells may have helped jumpstart Meech Wells' career, but the West Coast rap producer quickly proved his talent and eventually aligned himself with Snoop Dogg, another relationship that definitely didn't hurt his career.

title: Meech Wells
text: Before being Snoop's producer of choice during the late 1990s and early 2000s, Wells began his career as part of a funk band called Trey Lewd that also featured Tracey Lewis, George Clinton's son; this provided him with the opportunity to work with Clinton himself.

title: Meech Wells
text: By 1993, Wells found himself working alongside producer/rapper Def Jef; the two's production on Shaquille O'Neil's "I Got Skillz" (a surprise hit single) won them instant credentials.

title: Meech Wells
text: Throughout the mid-'90s, he continued to hone his craft, working on a number of remix projects before eventually being introduced to Snoop through a friend.

title: Meech Wells
text: Before long, the two were working together as a potent duo, beginning with "Still a G Thang," one of the better songs on Snoop's Da Game Is to Be Sold, Not to Be Told.

title: Meech Wells
text: Wells produced a few No Limit songs featuring Snoop—Tru's "It's a Beautiful Thang," Silkk the Shocker's "Get It Up"—before playing a major role in bringing a West Coast sound to Snoop's Top Dogg album in 1999: "In Love With a Thug," "Better Days," "Gangsta Ride," among others.

title: Meech Wells
text: In 2000 he reprised his role as one of Snoop's producers of choice, producing tracks for Tha Eastsidaz' self-titled debut and Doggy's Angels' Pleezbalevit, as well as Snoop's own Tha Last Meal ("Go Away," "Issues").

title: Keyshia Cole
text: Keyshia Cole (born October 15, 1981) is an American singer/songwriter, record producer, business woman, and television personality.

title: Keyshia Cole
text: She was born in Oakland, California.

title: Keyshia Cole
text: Her career began when she met MC Hammer at the age of 12, and later met rapper Tupac Shakur.

title: Keyshia Cole
text: At the age of 18, she moved to Los Angeles and was later introduced to A&M Records.

title: Keyshia Cole
text: She released her debut album, "The Way It Is" (2005), which spawned five singles: "Never," "I Changed My Mind," "(I Just Want It) To Be Over," "I Should Have Cheated," and "Love."

title: Keyshia Cole
text: It was certified gold within 17 weeks, and then platinum just eight weeks later.

title: Keyshia Cole
text: The album stayed on the charts for over a year, selling over 1.6 million copies.

text: Four Rooms is a 1995 American anthology comedy film co-written and co-directed by Allison Anders, Alexandre Rockwell, Robert Rodriguez, and Quentin Tarantino, each directing a segment of it that in its entirety is loosely based on the adult short fiction writings of Roald Dahl, especially "Man from the South" which is the basis for the last one, "Penthouse - "The Man from Hollywood"" directed by Tarantino.

title: Four Rooms
text: The story is set in the fictional Hotel Mon Signor in Los Angeles on New Year's Eve.

title: Four Rooms
text: Tim Roth plays Ted, the bellhop and main character in the frame story, whose first night on the job consists of four very different encounters with various hotel guests.

title: Koh Rong Sanloem
text: Koh Rong Sanloem (Khmer: កោះរុងសន្លឹម, also "Kaoh Rong Sanloem") is an island off the coast of Sihanoukville, Cambodia, 4 km south of Koh Rong island.

title: Koh Rong Sanloem
text: It is around 9 km long (north to south), 4 km wide (east to west) and 1 km wide at its narrowest point.

title: Koh Rong Sanloem
text: Its distance from the local port of Sihanoukville is 25 km (beeline) and 23 km (beeline) from the Serendipity/Ochheuteal beach pier.

title: Koh Rong Sanloem
text: The word "Sanloem" translates to: 1.

title: Koh Rong Sanloem
text: drowsiness and to: 2.

title: Koh Rong Sanloem
text: far out and hard to discern, in a wider sense.

title: Koh Rong Sanloem
text: Inconsistencies on how to spell the island's name in its Latinized version date back to the 19th century.

title: Koh Rong Sanloem
text: The first controversial spelling variants were issued by map makers during French rule.

title: Koh Rong Sanloem
text: Alternatives have since become widespread and are in common usage.

title: Koh Rong Sanloem
text: Often confusion ensues as Google Maps offers the phonetically most consistent variant, whereas Google Search redirects to an alternative.

title: Historias de un arrabal parisino
text: Historias de un arrabal parisino ("Stories of a Parisian suburb") is the third novel by the Venezuelan Vicente Ulive-Schnell and was published by Ediciones Idea in Spain.

title: Golf Magazine

text: The magazine is for golfers of all skill levels.

title: Golf Magazine
text: Some features it includes are instruction from the top 100 teachers in America, interviews with famous golfers, tips on the best values for golf courses to go to on vacation, and an annual club test.

title: El Nuevo Cojo
text: El Nuevo Cojo Ilustrado is an American online Spanish language magazine published from Los Angeles, California.

title: El Nuevo Cojo
text: It was founded in 2003 as a free alternative webzine published monthly from Harlem, New York.

title: El Nuevo Cojo
text: Originally it was an arts and opinion magazine focused exclusively on Venezuelan culture for Venezuelans living in the United States.

title: El Nuevo Cojo
text: It also sought to be a window to the US press for Spanish-speaking immigrants by translating English articles from mainstream newspapers.

title: El Nuevo Cojo
text: The website slowly embraced a wider audience by covering general interest issues.

title: El Nuevo Heraldo
text: El Nuevo Heraldo is a Spanish-language newspaper in Brownsville, Texas, United States.

title: El Nuevo Heraldo
text: It is a sister newspaper to "The Brownsville Herald".

title: El Nuevo Heraldo
text: In 2009 the 2009 Texas Associated Press Managing Editors' annual meeting awarded the "El Nuevo Heraldo" as the best Spanish-language newspaper in the state.

title: El Nuevo Herald
text: El Nuevo Herald is a newspaper published daily in Spanish in Southeast Florida, in Florida, the United States.

title: El Nuevo Herald
text: Its headquarters is in Doral.

title: El Nuevo Herald
text: "El Nuevo Herald"'s sister paper is the "Miami Herald", also produced by the McClatchy Company.

title: Alberto Ibargüen
text: Alberto Ibargüen (born February 29, 1944) is President and CEO of the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation in Miami, Florida.

title: Alberto Ibargüen
text: He is the former publisher of "The Miami Herald" and "El Nuevo Herald" in Miami, Florida.

title: Alberto Ibargüen
text: Under his leadership, "The Miami Herald" won three Pulitzer Prizes; "El Nuevo Herald" won Spain's Ortega y Gasset Prize for excellence in journalism.

title: Golf Digest
text: Golf Digest is a monthly golf magazine published by Condé Nast Publications in the United States.

title: Golf Digest
