text: It is a generalist golf publication covering recreational golf and men's and women's competitive golf.

title: Golf Digest
text: Condé Nast Publications also publishes the more specialized "Golf for Women", "Golf World" and "Golf World Business".

title: Golf Digest
text: The magazine started in 1950, and was sold to The New York Times Company in 1969.

title: Golf Digest
text: The Times company sold their magazine division to Condé Nast in 2001.

title: Golf Digest
text: The headquarters of "Golf Digest" is in Des Moines, Iowa.

title: El Nuevo Diario
text: El Nuevo Diario is a Nicaraguan newspaper, with offices in the capital Managua.

title: El Nuevo Diario
text: "El Nuevo Diario" was cofounded in 1980 by a breakaway group of employees of "La Prensa" sympathetic to the Sandinista cause, that included 80 percent of the staff including the editor, Xavier Chamorro Cardenal and Danilo Aguirre Solís who opposed the new line of the journal.

title: El Nuevo Diario
text: As of 2006, "El Nuevo Diario" is one of the two major newspapers in Nicaragua, the other one is "La Prensa".

title: Time Inc.
text: Time Inc. is a multinational mass media corporation founded on November 28, 1922 by Henry Luce and Briton Hadden and based in New York City.

title: Time Inc.
text: It owns and publishes over 100 magazine brands, most notably its flagship "Time".

title: Time Inc.
text: Other magazines include "Sports Illustrated", "Travel + Leisure", "Food & Wine", "Fortune", "People", "InStyle", "Life", "Golf Magazine", "Southern Living", "Essence", "Real Simple", and "Entertainment Weekly".

title: Time Inc.
text: It also has subsidiaries which it co-operates with the UK magazine house Time Inc.

title: Time Inc.
text: UK, whose major titles include "What's on TV", "NME", "Country Life", and "Wallpaper".

title: Time Inc.
text: Time Inc. also co-operates over 60 websites and digital-only titles including "MyRecipes", "TheSnug", HelloGiggles, and "MIMI".

title: Team Homer
text: "Team Homer" is the twelfth episode of "The Simpsons"<nowiki>'</nowiki> seventh season.

title: Team Homer
text: It originally aired on the Fox network in the United States on January 7, 1996.

title: Team Homer
text: In the episode, Homer starts a bowling team with Moe, Apu, and Otto.

title: Team Homer
text: When Mr. Burns discovers the team was funded with his money, he insists on joining.

title: Team Homer
text: Meanwhile, Bart's "Down with homework" T-shirt incites a student riot that leads to the implementation of a uniform dress code.

title: North Boone Community Unit School District 200
text: North Boone Community Unit School District 200 is a unified school district based in the central region of the county of its namesake, Boone County; more specifically, in the village of Poplar Grove, Illinois.

title: North Boone Community Unit School District 200
text: Five of the six schools in the district are located here, with the other being eastwards in the village of Capron.

title: North Boone Community Unit School District 200
text: The community unit school district is composed of, as previously mentioned, six schools: there are three elementary schools, two middle schools, and one high school.

title: North Boone Community Unit School District 200
text: Manchester Elementary School, which serves the grades K-4 alongside Poplar Grove Elementary School, is governed by Principal Kristi Crawford; the principal of Poplar Grove Elementary School is Sharon Olds.

title: North Boone Community Unit School District 200
text: Capron Elementary School, the only school in the district located in a village other than Poplar Grove, serves not only the grades K-4, but also includes a prekindergarten program.

title: North Boone Community Unit School District 200
text: The current principal is Matt Klett.

title: North Boone Community Unit School District 200
text: All students who graduate from one of the district elementary schools will consolidate at the fifth grade in one school, called North Boone Upper Elementary School, whose principal is Mike Greenlee;all students move on to North Boone Middle School, headed by Jeremiah Auble, which educates those in grades seven and eight.

title: North Boone Community Unit School District 200
text: The last leg of education this district can provide is to those from grade nine to grade twelve; the facility is called North Boone High School, whose principal is named Jacob Hubert.

title: North Boone Community Unit School District 200
text: The current superintendent is Steven Baule.

title: North Boone Community Unit School District 200
text: The mascot of the district high school is the Viking.

title: Otto Mann
text: Otto Mann is a fictional character on the animated TV series "The Simpsons", voiced by Harry Shearer.

title: Otto Mann
text: He is the school bus driver for Springfield Elementary School.

title: Jasper County Community Unit School District 1
text: Jasper County Community Unit School District 1 is a unified school district based in Jasper County's county seat of Newton, Illinois; it is the only school district in the county and is, consequently, the main educational body in all of Jasper County, although it serves portions of Effingham County and Cumberland County as well.

title: Jasper County Community Unit School District 1
text: This school district is composed of six schools in total; four elementary schools, one junior high school, and one high school.

title: Jasper County Community Unit School District 1
text: There is also a prekindergarten program run at the high school of the district should parents wish to enroll their children early.

title: Jasper County Community Unit School District 1
text: Willow Hill Elementary School, which is located in the village of its namesake, serves only kindergarteners; its proximity to the county seat and central position in the county allows its students to dawn from all parts of the county and still have easy access to the elementary school they will attend.

title: Jasper County Community Unit School District 1
text: The principal of Willow Hill is Dave Parker.

title: Jasper County Community Unit School District 1
text: Grove Elementary School is located in Island Grove, Illinois, the highest point of elevation in the county.

title: Jasper County Community Unit School District 1
text: Grove Elementary School educates students from kindergarten to grade six, and it runs a prekindergarten program as well.

title: Jasper County Community Unit School District 1
text: Craig Carr is the principal of this school.

title: Jasper County Community Unit School District 1
text: Ste. Marie Elementary School is located in the southern Jasper County village of Ste. Marie, and serves students in grades one through six.

title: Jasper County Community Unit School District 1
text: The principal of Ste. Marie is David Parker, the principal of Willow Hill Elementary School.

title: Jasper County Community Unit School District 1
text: Newton Elementary School is located in the county seat of Newton, and serves most of west Jasper County's first through sixth graders under principal Travis Wyatt.

title: Jasper County Community Unit School District 1
text: The latter three elementary schools feed into Jasper County Junior High School and are taught in the facility during seventh and eighth grade while being supervised by Newton Elementary School principal Travis Wyatt before graduating into Newton Community High School.

title: Jasper County Community Unit School District 1
text: Students in grades nine through twelve spend their last leg of precollegiate education at this school; their principal is Ruth Kerner.

title: Jasper County Community Unit School District 1
text: The district superintendent is Ron Alburtus, and the district's mascot is the eagle.

title: 2006 Huntsville bus crash
text: The Huntsville bus crash involved a school bus carrying 40 students from Lee High School to the Huntsville Center for Technology center and occurred on November 20, 2006 on an elevated portion of Interstate 565 in Huntsville, Alabama.

title: 2006 Huntsville bus crash
text: Police stated that the bus went over the side of the road after a car driven by another Lee High student tried to swerve around the bus, causing the bus driver to swerve going over the cliff.

title: 2006 Huntsville bus crash
text: Four students were killed and 23 were injured after the bus plunged almost 40 feet.

title: 2006 Huntsville bus crash
text: The driver was ejected from the bus before it went over the side of the bridge.

title: 2006 Huntsville bus crash
text: The crash was extensively covered by CNN and "USA Today".

title: Charleston Community Unit School District 1
text: Charleston Community Unit School District 1 is a unified school district based in Charleston, the county seat of Coles County, Illinois; it was created through the consolidation of the charter school district it was formed from and over sixty-seven other school districts in the area.

title: Charleston Community Unit School District 1
text: Charleston Community Unit School District 1 is a conglomerate of six schools, with all but one located in Charleston itself: four elementary schools, one middle school, and one high school form the makeup of the district.

title: Charleston Community Unit School District 1
text: Education begins at a prekindergarten level, and those living in the Charleston area attend Mark Twain Elementary School, which prepares early youth for schooling by taking them through prekindergarten and kindergarten under the supervision of principal Terry Diss.

title: Charleston Community Unit School District 1
text: Students who live in the far east reaches of Coles County may attend Ashmore Elementary School, which is based in a northeasterly village by the same name; Ashmore's distance from the other schools permits it to educate a larger range of students for the sake of efficiency.

title: Charleston Community Unit School District 1
text: The school educates students from kindergarten through grade four, and also runs a prekindergarten program.

title: Charleston Community Unit School District 1
text: Ashmore is also governed by Terry Diss.

title: Charleston Community Unit School District 1
text: Students who graduate from Mark Twain move onwards to Carl Sandburg Elementary School, which educates those in grades one, two, and three under principal Chad Burgett.

title: Charleston Community Unit School District 1
text: At Jefferson Elementary School in Charleston, the student bodies from both Carl Sandburg Elementary School and Ashmore Elementary School are consolidated.

title: Charleston Community Unit School District 1
text: Students from grades four through six are taught in the facility under the supervision of principal Deborah Poffinbarger.

title: Charleston Community Unit School District 1
text: District students graduating from Jefferson are moved to Charleston Middle School, where they are taught as seventh and eighth graders; the school principal here is Sandy Wilson.

title: Charleston Community Unit School District 1
text: The last branch of education that Charleston's school district can provide is the education of adolescents in the grades nine through twelve at Charleston High School, which is run by principal Trevor Doughty.

title: Charleston Community Unit School District 1
text: The superintendent of the schools in the district as of the 2007-08 school year was Dr. William Hill, although is considered as an interim;lastly, the mascots of the district and its middle and high schools are the Trojans, while the mascot of Jefferson Elementary School is the bulldog.

title: Burbank School District 111
text: Burbank School District 111 is an elementary school district located in Burbank, a Chicago suburb just south of Chicago Midway International Airport in Cook County, Illinois.

title: Burbank School District 111
text: There are seven elementary schools in District 111.

title: Burbank School District 111
text: They are all kindergarten through sixth grade and located within the city of Burbank.

title: Burbank School District 111
text: The elementary schools are: Luther Burbank Elementary School under direction of principal Robert Mocek, principal Marian Stockhausen's Richard Byrd Elementary School, Jacqueline Kennedy Elementary School under direction of principal Charles Roza, principal Mark Antkiewicz's Rosa Maddock Elementary School, principal Patricia Donaghue's Frances McCord Elementary School, principal Mary Anne Sheehan's Edward J. Tobin Elementary School, which was reopened in 2007 after being rebuilt, and principal Mary Rein's Harry Fry Elementary School, which closed after the 2003-2004 school year and reopened during the 2009-2010 school year.

title: Burbank School District 111
text: Graduates from all these elementary schools move on to Liberty Junior High School, which is under direction of principal Jim Martin.

title: Burbank School District 111
text: The district superintendent is Carol Kunst.

title: Braintree Public Schools
text: The Braintree Public School District, located in Braintree, Massachusetts, includes Hollis Elementary School, Donald Ross Elementary School, Archie T. Morrison Elementary School, Liberty Elementary School, Mary E. Flaherty Elementary School (formerly Lakeside Elementary School), Highlands Elementary School, East Middle School, South Middle School, and Braintree High School.

title: Braintree Public Schools
text: Monatiquot Elementary School is now the Monatiquot School Kindergarten Center for full-day kindergarten students in Braintree.

title: The Otto Show
text: "The Otto Show" is the twenty-second episode of "The Simpsons"<nowiki>'</nowiki> third season.

title: The Otto Show
text: It first aired on the Fox network in the United States on April 23, 1992.

title: The Otto Show
text: In the episode, Bart decides that he wants to become a rock star after attending a Spinal Tap concert, so Homer and Marge buy him a guitar.

title: The Otto Show
text: He shows the guitar to Otto the bus driver, who plays it and consequently makes the children late for school.

title: The Otto Show
text: Racing to Springfield Elementary, Otto crashes the school bus and is suspended until he can get his license back.

title: The Otto Show
text: Bart, who respects Otto, invites him to move in with the Simpson family.

title: Zion Elementary School District 6
text: Zion Elementary School District 6 is an Illinois school district serving Zion, Lake County.

title: Zion Elementary School District 6
text: The school district governs seven schools.

title: Zion Elementary School District 6
text: Lakeview School is responsible for prekindergarten children, housing also the district's administrative offices.

title: Zion Elementary School District 6
text: Beulah Park Elementary School, East Elementary School, Elmwood Elementary School, Shiloh Park Elementary School and West Elementary School serve students between kindergarten and sixth grade.

title: Zion Elementary School District 6
text: Zion Elementary School District 6's sole middle school, Zion Central Middle School, serves the seventh and eighth grades.

title: Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust
text: Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust (also known as Southend University Hospital and commonly referred to as Southend Hospital) is an NHS hospital located in Westcliff-on-Sea, Southend-on-Sea, Essex, England.

title: Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust
text: Southend University Hospital has 157 consultants providing various services, and serves a catchment area with a population of about 350,000.

title: Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust
text: It has officially been designated cancer centre status, and has also gained NHS Foundation Trust status under the name Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust.

title: Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust
text: More importantly Southend University Hospital is home to Funky Towers, broadcasting across Southend and surrounding areas, 103.7 on your dial, keep it real, keep it funky.

title: Square 54 Redevelopment
text: Square 54 Redevelopment is a complex of high-rise buildings located on the main campus of The George Washington University (GW) in Washington, D.C., United States.

title: Square 54 Redevelopment
text: The new GW complex is mixed-use, with residential and office buildings and ground-level retail space along Eye Street to serve the campus and neighborhood.

title: Square 54 Redevelopment
text: The complex will be completed with three buildings, "Square 54 Residential I", "Square 54 Residential II", and "Square 54 Office".

title: Square 54 Redevelopment
text: Square 54 Residential I is expected to rise 48 m , featuring 14 floors.

title: Square 54 Redevelopment
text: Square 54 Residential II is expected to rise 44 m , featuring 12 floors.

title: Square 54 Redevelopment
text: Finally, "Square 54 Office", is expected to rise 45 m , featuring 11 floors.

title: Square 54 Redevelopment
text: Construction of every building will be completed in 2011.

title: Square 54 Redevelopment
text: Each building will be designed by the architect, Pelli Clarke Pelli Architects and Hickok Cole Architects.

title: Square 54 Redevelopment
text: The complex will replace the former George Washington University Hospital building, which was razed to make way for the construction of the Square 54 Complex.

title: MedStar Georgetown University Hospital
text: MedStar Georgetown University Hospital is one of the national capital area's oldest academic teaching hospitals.

title: MedStar Georgetown University Hospital
text: It is a not-for-profit, acute care teaching and research facility located in the Georgetown neighborhood of the Northwest Quadrant of Washington, D.C.

title: MedStar Georgetown University Hospital
text: MedStar Georgetown is co-located with the Georgetown University Medical Center and is affiliated with the Georgetown University School of Medicine.

title: MedStar Georgetown University Hospital
text: Its clinical services represent one of the largest, most geographically diverse, and fully integrated healthcare and delivery networks in the area.

title: MedStar Georgetown University Hospital
text: MedStar Georgetown is home to the internationally known Lombardi Comprehensive Cancer Center, as well as centers of excellence in the neurology, neurosurgery, psychiatry, gastroenterology, transplant and vascular surgery.

title: MedStar Georgetown University Hospital
text: Originally named Georgetown University Hospital, it became part of the MedStar Health network in 2000.

title: Brad Wenstrup
text: Brad Robert Wenstrup (born June 17, 1958) is an American politician, Army Reserve officer, and Doctor of Podiatric Medicine, who has been the U.S. Representative for Ohio 's 2 congressional district since 2013.

title: Brad Wenstrup
text: A Republican, he defeated U.S. Representative Jean Schmidt in the 2012 Republican primary election and Democrat William R. Smith in the 2012 general election.

title: Brad Wenstrup
text: Wenstrup is a colonel in the U.S. Army Reserve and an Iraq War veteran.

title: Brad Wenstrup
text: After the shooting of Congressman Steve Scalise on the morning of June 14, 2017, Wenstrup attended to the wounded congressman until he was transported to MedStar Washington Hospital Center.

title: Children's National Medical Center
text: Children’s National Medical Center (formerly DC Children’s Hospital) is ranked among the top 10 children’s hospitals in the country by "U.S. News & World Report."

title: Children's National Medical Center
text: Located just north of the McMillan Reservoir and Howard University, it shares grounds with Washington Hospital Center, National Rehabilitation Hospital, and the DC Veterans Affairs Medical Center.

title: Children's National Medical Center
text: Kurt Newman, M.D., has served as the president and chief executive officer of Children’s National since 2011.

title: Children's National Medical Center
text: Children's National is a not-for-profit institution that performs more than 450,000 visits each year.

title: Children's National Medical Center
text: Featuring 303 beds and a Level IV NICU, Children's National is the regional referral center for pediatric emergency, trauma, cancer, cardiac and critical care as well as neonatology, orthopaedic surgery, neurology and neurosurgery.

title: Medical Faculty Associates
text: The George Washington University Medical Faculty Associates is a non-profit 501(c)3 physician group practice affiliated with the George Washington University.

title: Medical Faculty Associates
text: The MFA group practice is made up of academic clinical faculty of the GW Medical School.

title: Medical Faculty Associates
text: As of 2015, the group had more than 750 physicians providing medical services to the Washington DC, Northern Virginia, and Maryland areas.

title: Medical Faculty Associates
text: The GW Medical Faculty Associates offers over 51 specialty areas of care.

title: Medical Faculty Associates
text: The organization is a partner with the George Washington University Hospital and the School of Medicine and Health Sciences.

title: George Washington University Hospital
text: The George Washington University Hospital is located in Washington, D.C. in the United States.

title: George Washington University Hospital
text: It is affiliated with the George Washington University School of Medicine and Health Sciences.

title: George Washington University Hospital
text: The current facility opened on August 23, 2002, with 371 beds in a 400,000 sq. ft. building, housing more than $45 million of medical equipment and costing over $96 million to construct.

title: George Washington University Hospital
text: The hospital is licensed by the District of Columbia Department of Consumer and Regulatory Affairs and accredited by the U.S. Joint Commission.

title: Georgetown University School of Medicine
text: Georgetown University School of Medicine, a medical school opened in 1851, is one of Georgetown University's five graduate schools.

title: Georgetown University School of Medicine
text: It is located on Reservoir Road in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington, DC, adjacent to the University's main campus.

title: Georgetown University School of Medicine
text: The School of Medicine works in association with the 609-bed Georgetown University Hospital, Washington Hospital Center, and nine other affiliated federal and community hospitals in the Washington metropolitan area.

title: Georgetown University School of Medicine
text: Georgetown is the oldest Catholic medical school in the United States.

title: MedStar Washington Hospital Center
text: MedStar Washington Hospital Center is the largest private hospital in Washington, D.C. A member of MedStar Health, the not-for-profit Hospital Center is licensed for 926 beds.

title: MedStar Washington Hospital Center
text: Health services in primary, secondary and tertiary care are offered to adult and neonatal patients.

title: MedStar Washington Hospital Center
text: It also serves as a teaching hospital for Georgetown University School of Medicine.

title: West End, Washington, D.C.
text: The West End is a neighborhood in the Northwest quadrant of Washington, D.C., bounded by K Street to the south, Rock Creek Park to the west and north, and New Hampshire Avenue and 21st Street to the east.

title: West End, Washington, D.C.
text: The West End is so named because it was the westernmost part of the original L'Enfant Plan for the city of Washington, before the annexation of Georgetown.

title: West End, Washington, D.C.
text: It is home to the embassies of Qatar and Spain as well as the Delegation of the European Union to the United States.

title: West End, Washington, D.C.
text: The George Washington University and George Washington University Hospital are on the edge of the West End, at Washington Circle.

title: Peter O'Meara (rugby union)
text: Peter O'Meara was the inaugural CEO of the Western Force rugby union team.

title: Peter O'Meara (rugby union)
text: He was appointed in March 2005 following the successful bid by RugbyWA for the right to host the fourth Australian franchise.

title: Peter O'Meara (rugby union)
text: O'Meara had previously been on the boards of the NSWRU and QRU and had moved to Western Australia in his capacity as an executive with the Commonwealth Bank.

title: Time Slave
text: Time Slave is a 1975 hybrid of historical fiction and science fiction by John Norman.

title: Time Slave
text: In this book, Norman presents his personal theories of human evolution, exemplified by the case of a modern woman sent back in time twenty thousand years or more; he mourns the loss of human evolutionary fitness and distortion of "natural" social relations which in his view occurred when farming spread, and farmers squeezed hunter/gatherers to the ecological margins.

title: Time Slave
text: "Time Slave" features Norman's social philosophy of male-dominance (as also in his "Gor" series), and expresses an unexplained connection between female sexual subordination and the speeding up of the development of space travel.

title: Gold (1974 film)
text: Gold is a 1974 thriller film starring Roger Moore and Susannah York and directed by Peter R. Hunt.

title: Gold (1974 film)
text: It was based on the 1970 novel "Gold Mine" by Wilbur Smith.

title: Gold (1974 film)
text: Moore plays Rodney "Rod" Slater, General Manager of a South African gold mine, who is instructed by his boss Steyner (Bradford Dillman) to break through an underground dike into what he is told is a rich seam of gold.

title: Gold (1974 film)
text: Meanwhile, he falls in love with Steyner's wife Terry, played by York.

title: Gold (1974 film)
text: In the United States, the film was only released as part of a double bill.

title: Peter O'Meara
text: Peter O'Meara is an award-winning Irish actor.

title: Peter O'Meara
text: Lauded for his work on the London stage he came to the screen in the groundbreaking HBO series "Band of Brothers" playing 1st Lt Norman Dike.

title: Peter O'Meara
text: He garnered a popular following on USA TV series "Peacemakers" as Det Larimer Finch bringing the science of the future to the old west opposite Tom Berenger as Marshall Jared Stone.

title: Peter O'Meara
text: For this he received the Western Heritage Bronze Wrangler award.

title: Norman Dike
text: Norman Staunton Dike, Jr. (19 May 191823 June 1989) was an officer of the United States Army who later served in the U.S. Army Reserve.

title: Norman Dike
text: During World War II he was a lieutenant and captain in the 101st Airborne Division, where one assignment was company commander of Easy Company, 2nd Battalion, 506th Parachute Infantry Regiment.

title: Norman Dike
text: After World War II, he became a lawyer and businessman and eventually became a permanent resident of Switzerland.

title: Norman Dike
text: Dike was portrayed in the HBO miniseries "Band of Brothers" by Peter O'Meara.

title: Middelharnis
text: Middelharnis has a shopping area called "D'n Diek".

title: Middelharnis
text: This shopping center settled itself on a dike which used to be the last barrier for the town from the Haringvliet.

title: Middelharnis
text: The town hosts two public and one Christian high schools.

title: Middelharnis
text: Middelharnis has an inland harbor with connection to the Haringvliet.

title: Middelharnis
text: There is also a small beach which can get very crowded in the summertime.

title: Middelharnis
text: In Middelharnis the old main street has the old municipality building.

title: Ernest Norman
text: Ernest Leland Norman (November 11, 1904 – December 6, 1971) was an American electrical engineer, clairvoyant, and spiritual leader.

title: Ernest Norman
text: A polymath, Norman dabbled in philosophy, poetry, scientific research and paranormal investigation.

title: Ernest Norman
text: Ernest Norman also co-founded of the Unarius Science of Life and the Unarius Educational Foundation, which later became known as Unarius Academy of Science.

title: Ernest Norman
text: Before starting the grassroots work for Unarius, Ernest Norman also worked for the Borderlands Sciences Research Association as a contributing editor for the Round Robin journal, and also worked as a minister for a Spiritualist church for 15 years.

title: Ernest Norman
text: Ernest Norman wrote twenty books in his lifetime that covered theoretical physics, spirituality, philosophy, theology, extraterrestrial life, sociology, and poetry.

title: Ernest Norman
text: Norman also authored articles further emphasizing the interdimensional hypothesis he was trying to teach, and answered letters from his students that have been archived at the Unarius Academy of Science.

title: Ernest Norman
text: The first book he wrote, "The Truth About Mars", gives an account where he met the Martian ambassador, a being named Nur El, and traveled to the underground cities of Mars in his astral body.

title: Ernest Norman
text: Unariuns believe he was other major figures in Earth's history, and that he was overshadowed by an Archangel named Raphiel who resides on a celestial super planet with other Archangels.

title: Ernest Norman
text: He is referred to as the Moderator, or as "Dr." Norman by his students out of respect.

title: Ernest Norman
text: A genius child prodigy, Ernest Norman never sought a doctorate through academia as he was self-taught and did not have formal schooling for many of the subjects he seemingly mastered, as he claimed his knowledge was due to his clairvoyant connection to the Masters and Higher Minds of the White Brotherhood;

title: Norman Staunton Dike
text: Norman Staunton Dike (October 22, 1862 – April 15, 1953) was a New York State Supreme Court judge from 1920-1932.

title: Norman Staunton Dike
text: He had previously worked as a lawyer, sheriff, and judge in Brooklyn, New York.

title: Norman Staunton Dike
text: He was also a prominent member of the Brooklyn social scene.

title: Oklahoma Shakespeare in the Park
text: Oklahoma Shakespeare in the Park (OSP) was founded in 1985 in Edmond, Oklahoma, USA by current Executive Director and Artistic Director Kathryn McGill (née Huey) and Jack J. O'Meara.

title: Oklahoma Shakespeare in the Park
text: With two different performing venues, the organization is dedicated to excellence in producing an eclectic range of classic plays to the entire Oklahoma City metro area and beyond.

title: Oklahoma Shakespeare in the Park
text: Oklahoma Shakespeare in the Park is a non-profit organization overseen by a Board of Directors.

title: Oklahoma Shakespeare in the Park
text: Jason Foreman serves as Board President.

title: Oklahoma Shakespeare in the Park
text: Jon Haque serves as Managing Director, Michelle Swink as PR/Marketing Associate, and Norman H. Hammon serves as Development Director.

title: Oklahoma Shakespeare in the Park
text: In 2007, it relocated to downtown Oklahoma City.

title: 1985 Dunhill Cup
text: The 1985 Dunhill Cup was the first Dunhill Cup.

title: 1985 Dunhill Cup
text: It was a team tournament featuring 16 countries, each represented by three players.

title: 1985 Dunhill Cup
text: The Cup was played 17–20 October at the Old Course at St Andrews in Scotland.

title: 1985 Dunhill Cup
text: The sponsor was the Alfred Dunhill company.

title: 1985 Dunhill Cup
text: The Australian team of David Graham, Graham Marsh, and Greg Norman beat the American team of Raymond Floyd, Mark O'Meara, and Curtis Strange in the final.

title: Pedro Alcántara Quijano Montero
text: Pedro Alcántara Quijano Montero (1878-1953) was a Colombian artist, engraver, author and set designer.

title: Pedro Alcántara Quijano Montero
text: Born in Bogota, he studied at Escuela de Bellas Artes under Recio among others.

title: Pedro Alcántara Quijano Montero
text: Later, he taught at his alma mater for more than 30 years.

title: Pedro Alcántara Quijano Montero
text: He was also a set designer for the Teatro Colón de Bogotá, and taught several generations of Colombian artists.

title: Pedro Alcántara Quijano Montero
text: He wrote several works: "Ricaurte en San Mateo", "Niño con Casco", "La misa de los conquistadores", "La Pola conducida al cadalso" and "Reyerta del 20 de julio", among others.

title: Pedro Alcántara Quijano Montero
text: He died in Bogota in 1953.

title: Peter Gallo
text: Peter Gallo (born 1959 in Rutland, VT) is an artist and writer who lives and works in Hyde Park, VT.

title: Peter Gallo
text: He received his Ph.D. and MA in Art History from Concordia University, Montreal, and has written about the intersection of biopolitics, medicalization, and artistic experience from the eighteenth to early twenty-first centuries.

title: Peter Gallo
text: He has a BA from Middlebury College, Middlebury, VT.

title: Peter Gallo
text: Additionally, the artist has been active in the Grass Roots Art and Community Efforts (GRACE) in Hardwick, VT.

title: Peter Gallo
text: He has organized numerous exhibitions including "Insider Art," (GRACE traveling exhibition, 1990), and "Our Yard in the Future: The Art of Gayleen Aiken" (Horton Gallery, 2007).

title: Peter Gallo
text: He has contributed criticism to "Art in America" and "Art New England", among others.

title: Peter Gallo
text: The artist is represented by Horton Gallery in New York City and Anthony Reynolds Gallery in London, UK.

title: Peter Gallo
text: Gallo's works have been featured in solo and group exhibitions in the United States and Europe, and are included in notable collections of contemporary art.

title: Silas Bent
text: Silas Bent IV (born May 9, 1882 in Millersburg, Kentucky – d. July 30, 1945 in Greenwich, Connecticut), son of Silas Bent III and Ann Elizabeth (Tyler) Bent was an American was a journalist, author, and lecturer.

title: Silas Bent
text: He began newspaper work in 1900 in Louisville, Kentucky, on the "Louisville Herald".

title: Silas Bent
text: After three years he moved to St. Louis and joined the staff of the St. Louis Post-Dispatch as reporter and assistant editor.

title: Silas Bent
text: He was appointed assistant professor of theory and practice of journalism at the University of Missouri School of Journalism in Columbia, Missouri when the school was opened in 1908, but resigned that position in February 1909 to return to the Post-Dispatch.

title: Silas Bent
text: Later, he did publicity work in Chicago and then spent 13 years in New York City.

title: Silas Bent
text: As a freelance writer he contributed articles to "The New York Times", "Harper's Weekly" and "The Atlantic" among others.

title: Philip Schultz
text: Philip Schultz (born 1945 in Rochester, New York) is an American poet, and the founder/director of The Writers Studio, a private school for fiction and poetry writing based in New York City.

title: Philip Schultz
text: He is the author of several collections of poetry, including "The God of Loneliness, Selected and New Poems" (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, 2010); "Failure" (Harcourt, 2007), winner of the 2008 Pulitzer Prize in Poetry; "Living in the Past" (Harcourt, 2004); and "The Holy Worm of Praise" (Harcourt, 2002).

title: Philip Schultz
text: He is also the author of "Deep Within the Ravine" Viking Penguin, 1984), which was the Lamont Poetry Selection of the Academy of American Poets; "Like Wings" (Viking Penguin, 1978, winner of an American Academy & Institute of Arts and Letters Award as well as a National Book Award nomination), and the poetry chapbook, "My Guardian Angel Stein" (1986).

title: Philip Schultz
text: His work has been published in The New Yorker, The Paris Review, Slate, Poetry magazine, The Gettysburg Review, The Southern Review, and Five Points, among others, and he is the recipient of a Fulbright Fellowship in Poetry to Israel and a 2005 Guggenheim Fellowship in Poetry.

title: Philip Schultz
text: He has also received, among others, a National Endowment for the Arts Fellowship in Poetry (1981), a New York Foundation for the Arts Fellowship in Poetry (1985), as well as the Levinson Prize from Poetry magazine.

title: Philip Schultz
text: Schultz is also the author of a memoir, "My Dyslexia", published by W.W. Norton in 2011, and a new book of poetry, "The Wherewithal" (W. W. Norton), published in February 2014.

title: Dysteleology
text: Dysteleology is the philosophical view that existence has no "telos" or final cause from purposeful design.

title: Dysteleology
text: The term "dysteleology" is a modern word invented and popularized by Ernst Haeckel.

title: Dysteleology
text: Dysteleology is an aggressive, yet optimistic, form of science-oriented atheism originally perhaps associated with Haeckel and his followers, but now perhaps more associated with the type of atheism of Richard Dawkins, Sam Harris, or Christopher Hitchens.

title: Dysteleology
text: Transcending traditional philosophical and religious perspectives, such as German idealism (including the philosophies of Hegel and Schelling) and contemporary New Age thinking, modern philosophical naturalism sees existence as having no inherent goal.

title: Na-Ga
text: Na-Ga is a male Japanese artist who is employed as a graphic designer and illustrator for the company Key known for such famous visual novels as "Kanon", "Air", and "Clannad" among others.

title: Na-Ga
text: Na-Ga has been working for Key since the production of "Air" as one of the computer graphic artists, but was able to majorly contribute to character design in Key's sixth visual novel "Little Busters!

title: Na-Ga
text: " with Itaru Hinoue, along with the later released "Little Busters!

title: Na-Ga
text: Ecstasy" and "Kud Wafter".

title: Na-Ga
text: For Key's ninth title "Rewrite", Na-Ga contributed to the game's computer graphics.

title: Na-Ga
text: Na-Ga worked in collaboration with Jun Maeda and ASCII Media Works' "Dengeki G's Magazine" to produce the mixed media projects "Angel Beats!

title: Na-Ga
text: " and "Charlotte" as the original character designer.

title: Na-Ga
text: Na-Ga once worked for the company Pearlsoft R between 1997 and 1999 where he contributed to two visual novels, "Hakanai Omoi: Anemone", and "Sweet Days", as the main artist before coming to Key.

title: Na-Ga
text: He also participates in a dōjinshi circle named "from-D".

title: Skylite
text: Skylite is a Memphis based gospel music label started by The Statesmen Quartet and The Blackwood Brothers in 1959.

title: Skylite
text: Along with The Blackwood Brothers and The Statesmen Quartet, Skylite signed, among others, The Speer Family, and the Oak Ridge Quartet (later renamed The Oak Ridge Boys).

title: Skylite
text: In 1966, the Statesmen-Blackwood team sold the record company to a group of investors led by Joel Gentry, with main offices on Music Row in Nashville, Tenn.

title: Christopher Hitchens
text: Christopher Eric Hitchens (13 April 1949 – 15 December 2011) was an Anglo-American author, columnist, essayist, orator, religious and literary critic, social critic, and journalist.

title: Christopher Hitchens
text: Hitchens was the author, co-author, editor or co-editor of over 30 books, including five collections of essays, on politics, literature and religion.

title: Christopher Hitchens
text: A staple of public discourse, his confrontational style of debate made him both a lauded intellectual and a controversial public figure.

title: Christopher Hitchens
text: He contributed to "New Statesman", "The Nation", "The Weekly Standard", "The Atlantic", "London Review of Books", "The Times Literary Supplement", "Slate", "Free Inquiry" and "Vanity Fair".

title: Emily Matchar
text: Emily Matchar (born 1982) is an American journalist and author.

title: Emily Matchar
text: Originally from Chapel Hill, North Carolina, she graduated from Harvard University in 2004.

title: Emily Matchar
text: Her work has appeared in "The Atlantic", "Salon", "The Washington Post", "Time", "The New Republic", "Gourmet", and "Outside", among others.

title: Emily Matchar
text: Her non-fiction book, "Homeward Bound: Why Women Are Embracing the New Domesticity" was a critical exploration of the cultural phenomenon of "new domesticity," the re-embrace of old-fashioned domestic arts and practices from knitting to canning to backyard chicken-raising.

title: Emily Matchar
text: It was published by Simon & Schuster in 2013 and received favorable reviews from "The New Yorker", "The New Republic", and "The Washington Post", among many others, and was given 3.5 out of 4 stars by "People Magazine".

title: Emily Matchar
text: She has made numerous appearances on TV and radio, including The Colbert Report, Good Morning America, MSNBC's The Cycle, NPR, and the BBC.

title: Menil Collection
text: The Menil Collection, located in Houston, Texas, USA, refers either to a museum that houses the private art collection of founders John de Menil and Dominique de Menil, or to the collection itself of approximately 17,000 paintings, sculptures, prints, drawings, photographs and rare books.

title: Menil Collection
text: While the bulk of the collection is made up of a once-private collection, Menil Foundation, Inc. is a tax-exempt, nonprofit, public charity corporation formed under Section 501(c)3 of the Internal Revenue Code.

title: Menil Collection
text: Additionally the Menil receives public funds granted by the City of Houston, the State of Texas, and the federal government through the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Menil Collection
text: The museum's holdings are diverse, including early to mid-twentieth century works of Yves Tanguy, René Magritte, Max Ernst, Man Ray, Marcel Duchamp, Henri Matisse and Pablo Picasso, among others.

title: Menil Collection
text: The museum also maintains an extensive collection of pop art and contemporary art from Jackson Pollock, Andy Warhol, Mark Rothko, Robert Rauschenberg, Vija Celmins and Cy Twombly, Jr., among others.

title: Menil Collection
text: Also included in the museum's permanent collection are Antiquities and works of Byzantine, Medieval and Tribal art.

title: Dwight D. Eisenhower
text: Dwight David "Ike" Eisenhower ( ; October 14, 1890 – March 28, 1969) was an American politician and Army general who served as the 34th President of the United States from 1953 until 1961.

title: Dwight D. Eisenhower
text: During World War II, he was a five-star general in the United States Army and served as Supreme Commander of the Allied Expeditionary Forces in Europe.

title: Dwight D. Eisenhower
text: He was responsible for planning and supervising the invasion of North Africa in Operation Torch in 1942–43 and the successful invasion of France and Germany in 1944–45 from the Western Front.

title: 34th Battalion (Australia)
text: The 34th Battalion was an infantry unit of 1st Australian Imperial Force (AIF), which was established in World War I for overseas service.

title: 34th Battalion (Australia)
text: Formed in Australia in 1916, the battalion fought on the Western Front before being disbanded in 1919.

title: 34th Battalion (Australia)
text: It was later re-raised as a part-time infantry battalion in the Illawarra region of New South Wales during the inter-war years.

title: 34th Battalion (Australia)
text: During World War II, the 34th was amalgamated with the 20th Battalion and undertook defensive duties in Australia before being disbanded in 1944.

title: 34th Battalion (Australia)
text: Post war, the 34th was re-formed in the early 1950s before being subsumed into the Royal New South Wales Regiment in 1960.

title: 2013 America's Cup
text: The 34th America's Cup was a series of boat races held on San Francisco Bay between the defender Oracle Team USA representing the Golden Gate Yacht Club, and the challenger Emirates Team New Zealand representing the Royal New Zealand Yacht Squadron.

title: 2013 America's Cup
text: Oracle Team USA defended the America's Cup by a score of 9 to 8.

title: 2013 America's Cup
text: Oracle had to win the last eight races to come from behind and once again win the oldest trophy in international sport.

title: 2013 America's Cup
text: Team New Zealand won the right to challenge for the cup by winning the 2013 Louis Vuitton Cup.

title: 2013 America's Cup
text: The 34th America's Cup was the longest ever cup by both number of days and races, and the first since the 25th America's Cup to feature a winner-take-all final race.

title: 34th Armoured Brigade (United Kingdom)
text: The 34th Armoured Brigade was an armoured brigade of the British Army that saw active service in the Second World War.

title: 34th Armoured Brigade (United Kingdom)
text: It was formed in 1941 as the 34th Army Tank Brigade and subsequently redesignated as the 34th Tank Brigade in February 1945 and became part of the 79th Armoured Division.

title: 34th Armoured Brigade (United Kingdom)
text: It was equipped with Churchill tanks and provided close support for assaults by the infantry.

title: 34th Armoured Brigade (United Kingdom)
text: During the fighting in North-west Europe from July 1944 to May 1945 the brigade served with both the First Canadian Army and the British Second Army.

title: 34th Armoured Brigade (United Kingdom)
text: The brigade was disbanded in early 1946.

title: Andrés Avelino Cáceres
text: Andrés Avelino Cáceres Dorregaray (November 10, 1836 – October 10, 1923) served as the President of Peru three times during the 19th century, from 1881 to 1882 as the 34th President of Peru, then from 1886 to 1890 as the 36th President of Peru, and again from 1894 to 1895 as the 38th President of Peru.

title: Andrés Avelino Cáceres
text: In Peru, he is considered a national hero for leading the resistance to Chilean occupation during the War of the Pacific (1879–1883), where he fought as a General in the Peruvian Army.

title: R Adams Cowley
text: R Adams Cowley (July 25, 1917 – October 27, 1991), the "Father of Trauma Medicine," was an American surgeon considered a pioneer in emergency medicine and the treatment of shock trauma.

title: R Adams Cowley
text: He was the founder of the United States's first trauma center at the University of Maryland, in 1958, after the US Army awarded Dr. Cowley $100,000 to study shock in people—the first award of its kind in the United States.

title: R Adams Cowley
text: The trauma unit at first consisted of two beds, and was later expanded to four beds.

title: R Adams Cowley
text: Many people called the four-bed unit the "death lab."

title: R Adams Cowley
text: Cowley was the creator of the "Golden Hour" concept, the period of 60 minutes or less following injury when immediate definitive care is crucial to a trauma patient's survival.

title: R Adams Cowley
text: He was a leader in the use of helicopters for medical evacuations of civilians, beginning in 1969, and founded the Society of Thoracic Surgeons.

title: R Adams Cowley
text: He also founded the nation's first statewide EMS system, called MIEMSS by Executive Order of Maryland's Governor Mandel, 1972, as well as the National Study Center for Trauma and EMS, enacted by Congress in 1986 and signed into law by President Ronald Reagan.

title: R Adams Cowley
text: He is also known for being one of the first surgeons to perform open-heart surgery and invented both a surgical clamp that bears his name and a prototype pacemaker that was used by Dwight D. Eisenhower.

title: David Eisenhower
text: Dwight David Eisenhower II (born March 31, 1948) is an American author, public policy fellow, professor at the University of Pennsylvania, and eponym of the U.S. Presidential retreat, Camp David.

title: David Eisenhower
text: He is the only grandson of 34th President of the United States, Dwight D. Eisenhower, and the son-in-law of the 37th President of the United States Richard Nixon.

title: Black Bat Squadron
text: Black Bats () 34th Squadron was the name of a corps of CIA reconnaissance plane pilots and crew based in Taiwan during the Cold War.

title: Black Bat Squadron
text: Citizens of the Republic of China, they flew missions over mainland China controlled by the People's Republic of China (PRC), to drop agents and gathered military signal intelligences around military sites.

title: Black Bat Squadron
text: The 34th Squadron was formed in 1953 and flew its last operational mission in 1967.

title: Black Bat Squadron
text: The squadron's emblem was a bat and seven stars and its formal name was the 34th Squadron of the ROC Air Force.

title: Black Bat Squadron
text: Unit's aircraft included the Boeing B-17G, Douglas A-26C/B-26C Invader, 7 Lockheed RB-69A, Douglas C-54, 11 Fairchild C-123B/K Provider, Lockheed C-130E Hercules, and 3 "black" Lockheed P-3A Orion (149669, 149673, 149678).

title: Black Bat Squadron
text: The P-3As and RB-69As were armed with AIM-9 Sidewinder missiles for self-defense.

title: Black Bat Squadron
text: 34th Squadron specialized in very low level air space penetration (100–200 meters altitude) to hug the ground in order to evade enemy radars and fighter interceptions.

title: Black Bat Squadron
text: Later when operating P-3A, its main mission was flying in international water, 40 miles outside of Mainland China, to collect signal intelligences.

title: 34th Street (IRT Second Avenue Line)
text: 34th Street was a local station on the demolished IRT Second Avenue Line.

title: 34th Street (IRT Second Avenue Line)
text: It had two levels.

title: 34th Street (IRT Second Avenue Line)
text: The upper level had three tracks and two side platforms and was used for the Second Avenue line trains.

title: 34th Street (IRT Second Avenue Line)
text: The lower level had two tracks and one island platform and was used by 34th Street shuttle trains.

title: 34th Street (IRT Second Avenue Line)
text: The next stop to the north was 42nd Street.

title: 34th Street (IRT Second Avenue Line)
text: The next stop to the south was 23rd Street.

title: 34th Street (IRT Second Avenue Line)
text: The next eastbound stop on the shuttle was 34th Street Ferry.

title: 34th Street (IRT Second Avenue Line)
text: The next westbound stop on the shuttle was Third Avenue.

title: 34th Street (IRT Second Avenue Line)
text: The shuttle platform closed on July 14, 1930, and the main line station closed on June 13, 1942.

title: East 34th – Campus (RTA Rapid Transit station)
text: East 34th–Campus Station is station on the RTA Rapid Transit system in Cleveland, Ohio, USA, serving the Red, Blue and Green Lines.

title: East 34th – Campus (RTA Rapid Transit station)
text: It is located just east of East 34th Street near the intersection of East 34th and Broadway, on the north side of the CSX railway tracks, and below the bridge that carries East 34th Street over the railway tracks.

title: Fortean Times
text: Fortean Times is a British monthly magazine devoted to the anomalous phenomena popularised by Charles Fort.

title: Fortean Times
text: Previously published by John Brown Publishing (from 1991 to 2001) and then I Feel Good Publishing (2001 to 2005), it is now published by Dennis Publishing Ltd.

title: Charles Fort
text: Charles Hoy Fort (August 6, 1874 – May 3, 1932) was an American writer and researcher who specialized in anomalous phenomena.

title: Charles Fort
text: The terms "Fortean" and "Forteana" are sometimes used to characterize various such phenomena.

title: Charles Fort
text: Fort's books sold well and are still in print.

title: Charles Fort
text: His work continues to inspire admirers, who refer to themselves as "Forteans", and has influenced some aspects of science fiction.

title: Bob Rickard
text: Robert "Bob" J M Rickard is the founder and editor of the UK magazine "Fortean Times: The Journal of Strange Phenomena", which debuted in 1973 under its original title "The News".

title: Bob Rickard
text: The magazine's express purpose is to continue the documentary work of Charles Fort on the strange, anomalous and unexplained.

title: Bob Rickard
text: In addition to his editorial role, Rickard has written several books and hundreds of articles on a wide range of Fortean topics.

title: Bob Rickard
text: In 1981, he was a founding member of ASSAP and is also the founder of the Charles Fort Institute.

title: Bizarre (magazine)
text: Bizarre was a British alternative magazine published from 1997 to 2015.

title: Bizarre (magazine)
text: It was published by Dennis Publishing, and was a sister publication to the "Fortean Times".

title: Super-Sargasso Sea
text: The Super-Sargasso Sea is the dimension into which lost things go, whose existence was proposed by Charles Fort, writer and researcher into anomalous phenomena.

title: Super-Sargasso Sea
text: It may be thought of as the spontaneous, anomalous teleportation of an object into another dimension.

title: Super-Sargasso Sea
text: Fort did not actually believe that it existed but, in the vein of the ancient Greek skeptics, he wished only to present a theory that was just as plausible as those in the mainstream.

title: Super-Sargasso Sea
text: The name alludes to the Sargasso Sea of the Atlantic Ocean, which lies next to the Bermuda Triangle.

title: Fortean Society
text: The Fortean Society was started in the United States in 1931 during a meeting held in the New York flat of Charles Hoy Fort in order to promote the ideas of American writer Charles Fort.

title: Fortean Society
text: The Fortean Society was primarily based in New York City.

title: Fortean Society
text: Its first president was Theodore Dreiser, an old friend of Charles Fort, who had helped to get his work published.

title: Fortean Society
text: Founding members of The Fortean Society included Tiffany Thayer, Booth Tarkington, Ben Hecht, Alexander Woollcott (and many of NYC's literati such as Dorothy Parker), and Baltimore writer H. L. Mencken.

title: Fortean Society
text: Other members included Vincent Gaddis, Ivan T. Sanderson, A. Merritt, Frank Lloyd Wright and Buckminster Fuller.

title: Fortean Society
text: The first 6 issues of the Fortean Society's newsletter "Doubt" were each edited by a different member, starting with Theodore Dreiser.

title: Fortean Society
text: Tiffany Thayer thereafter took over editorship of subsequent issues.

title: Fortean Society
text: Thayer began to assert extreme control over the society, largely filling the newsletter with articles written by himself, and excommunicating the entire San Francisco chapter, reportedly their most active, after disagreements over the society's direction, and forbidding them to use the name Fortean.

title: Fortean Society
text: During World War II, for example, Thayer used every issue of "Doubt" to espouse his politics.

title: Fortean Society
text: Particularly, he frequently expressed opposition to Civil Defense, going to such lengths as encouraging readers to turn on their lights in defiance to air raid sirens.

title: Fortean Society
text: In contrast to the spirit of Charles Fort, he not only dismissed flying saucers as nonsense, but also dismissed the atomic bomb as a hoax.

title: Vincent Gaddis
text: Vincent Hayes Gaddis (December 28, 1913 – February 26, 1997) was an American author who invented the phrase "Bermuda Triangle", which he used first in the cover article for the 1964 February issue of the magazine "Argosy".

title: Vincent Gaddis
text: He popularized many stories about anomalous and paranormal phenomena in a style similar to that of Charles Fort.

title: William R. Corliss
text: William Roger Corliss (August 28, 1926 – July 8, 2011) was an American physicist and writer who was known for his interest in collecting data regarding anomalous phenomena.

title: William R. Corliss
text: Arthur C. Clarke described him as "Fort's latter-day - and much more scientific - successor."

title: Michael D. Swords
text: Michael D. Swords is a retired professor of Natural Science at Western Michigan University, who writes about general sciences and anomalous phenomena, particularly parapsychology, cryptozoology, and ufology, editing the academic publication "The Journal of UFO Studies".

title: Michael D. Swords
text: He is a board member of the J. Allen Hynek Center for UFO Studies.

title: The Book of the Damned
text: The Book of the Damned was the first published nonfiction work of the author Charles Fort (first edition 1919).

title: The Book of the Damned
text: Concerning various types of anomalous phenomena including UFOs, strange falls of both organic and inorganic materials from the sky, odd weather patterns, the possible existence of creatures generally believed to be mythological, disappearances of people, and many other phenomena, the book is considered to be the first of the specific topic of anomalistics.

title: Chipmunks in Low Places
text: Chipmunks in Low Places is a country album written by John Boylan and Andrew Gold and performed by Alvin and the Chipmunks.

title: Chipmunks in Low Places
text: It features cover songs as well as original material.

title: Chipmunks in Low Places
text: Released on September 29, 1992, the album was certified Platinum by the RIAA, becoming the group's first platinum record and making it the Chipmunks' best-selling album.

title: Chipmunks in Low Places
text: The album reached number 21 on the "Billboard" 200, becoming their first album to chart in ten years.

title: Chipmunks in Low Places
text: The album also managed to peak at No. 6 on "Billboard"' s Top Country Albums, making it the highest peaking album for the group on the chart.

title: Martina McBride discography
text: The discography of American country artist Martina McBride consists of thirteen studio albums, one live album, four compilation albums, two video albums, three additional albums, forty five music videos, fifty one singles, sixteen other charting songs, and forty five album appearances.

title: Martina McBride discography
text: In 1991, she signed a recording contract with RCA Records, launching her debut studio album "The Time Has Come" in 1992.

title: Martina McBride discography
text: In September 1993, her second studio album "The Way That I Am" was issued.

title: Martina McBride discography
text: Its lead single "My Baby Loves Me" reached number two on the "Billboard" Hot Country Songs chart, becoming her breakthrough hit.

title: Martina McBride discography
text: The third single "Independence Day" peaked in the top twenty and became McBride's signature song.

title: Martina McBride discography
text: The song's success elevated sales of "The Way That I Am" to platinum status from the Recording Industry Association of America. "

title: Martina McBride discography
text: Wild Angels" was released in September 1995 and reached number seventeen on the "Billboard" Top Country Albums chart.

title: Martina McBride discography
text: The album's title track became McBride's first song to top the Hot Country Songs list.

title: Martina McBride discography
text: McBride's fourth studio album "Evolution" was released in August 1997 and is her best-selling album to date, certifying three times platinum in the United States.

title: Martina McBride discography
text: The album spawned six singles which all became major hits including, "A Broken Wing", "Wrong Again", and "Whatever You Say".

title: Martina McBride discography
text: After releasing a holiday album, McBride's fifth studio album "Emotion" was issued in September 1999.

title: Martina McBride discography
text: The lead single "I Love You" topped the Hot Country Songs list, while also reaching minor positions on the Adult Contemporary and "Billboard" Hot 100 charts.

title: Danity Kane discography
text: The discography of Danity Kane, an American R&B group, consists of two studio album, five singles, and four music videos. Danity Kane were formed in 2005 during the third season of the reality television series "Making the Band", and consisted of Aubrey O'Day, Wanita "D. Woods" Woodgett, Shannon Bex, Dawn Richard, and Aundrea Fimbres.

title: Danity Kane discography
text: The group disbanded in January 2009 during the fourth season of "Making the Band".

title: Danity Kane discography
text: The group released their self titled debut album in August 2006.

title: Danity Kane discography
text: The album reached number one on the United States "Billboard" 200 and was certified platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA).

title: Danity Kane discography
text: Danity Kane's debut single, "Show Stopper", which featured rapper Yung Joc, reached number eight on the U.S. "Billboard" Hot 100. "

title: Danity Kane discography
text: Ride for You", their second single, reached number 78 on the "Billboard" Hot 100. "

title: Danity Kane discography
text: Welcome to the Dollhouse", Danity Kane's second album, was released in March 2008.

title: Danity Kane discography
text: It reached number one on the "Billboard" 200 and was certified gold by the RIAA.

title: Danity Kane discography
text: The album's lead single, "Damaged", reached number ten on the "Billboard" Hot 100 and was certified platinum by the RIAA.

title: Danity Kane discography
text: The group's fifth single, "Bad Girl", featured Missy Elliott and reached number 110 on the "Billboard" Hot 100.

title: The Dance (song)
text: "The Dance" is a song written and composed by Tony Arata, and recorded by American country music singer Garth Brooks as the tenth and final track from his self-titled debut album, from which it was also released as the album's fourth and final single in April 1990.

title: The Dance (song)
text: It is considered by many to be Brooks' signature song.

title: The Dance (song)
text: In a 2015 interview with Patrick Kielty of BBC Radio 2, Brooks credits the back to back success of both "The Dance" and its follow up "Friends In Low Places" for his phenomenal success.

title: I Feel Lucky
text: "I Feel Lucky" is a song co-written and recorded by American country artist Mary Chapin Carpenter.

title: I Feel Lucky
text: It was released in May 1992 as the first single from the album "Come On Come On".

title: I Feel Lucky
text: The song reached number 4 on the "Billboard" Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart.

title: I Feel Lucky
text: The Chipettes recorded a cover of this song for the 1992 album "Chipmunks in Low Places".

title: I Feel Lucky
text: It was written by Carpenter and Don Schlitz.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: The discography of Rosanne Cash, an American singer-songwriter, consists of thirteen studio albums, six compilation albums, one tribute album, and 39 singles.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: The daughter of Johnny Cash, Rosanne Cash recorded her self-titled debut album in 1978 under the German label Ariola.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: After signing with Columbia Records in 1979, Cash's second studio album "Right or Wrong" was released.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: Its lead single "No Memories Hangin' Around" (a duet with Bobby Bare) reached the Top 20 on the "Billboard" Hot Country Songs chart.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: Cash's third studio release, "Seven Year Ache" (1981) gained major success when the title track peaked at number one on the "Billboard" Country chart, followed by "My Baby Thinks He's a Train" and "Blue Moon with a Heartache," which also reached the top spot.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: The album's follow-up effort, "Somewhere in the Stars" (1982) produced two Top 10 hits on the "Billboard" chart.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: After a 3-year hiatus, Cash issued "Rhythm & Romance" in 1985, which reached #1 on the "Billboard" Top Country Albums list.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: It spawned four Top 10 singles.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: This included the number one single, "I Don't Know Why You Don't Want Me," which won the Grammy Award for Best Female Country Vocal Performance in 1986.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: Her sixth album, "King's Record Shop" was released in 1987.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: The album peaked at number six on the country albums chart and certified gold in the United States.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: The four singles released from "King's Record Shop" all reached number one on the "Billboard" Country chart between 1987 and 1988, including a cover of Johnny Cash's "Tennessee Flat-Top Box."

title: There It Is (Shalamar song)
text: "There It Is" is a 1982 song by funk band Shalamar from their album Friends.

title: There It Is (Shalamar song)
text: It is their highest charting single in the UK, along with A Night to Remember which both reached no. 5.

title: There It Is (Shalamar song)
text: It reached no. 6 in Ireland.

title: Omarion
text: Omari Ishmael Grandberry (born November 12, 1984, known by his stage name Omarion) is an American singer, songwriter, rapper, actor and dancer.

title: Omarion
text: He is best known as being the lead singer of the American R&B boy band B2K; the group achieved success with singles like "Bump, Bump, Bump", "Uh Huh", and "Girlfriend", which all reached success on the "Billboard" Hot 100.

title: Omarion
text: After the group's disbandment, Omarion released his debut solo album, "O" (2005), which debuted atop the "Billboard" 200 and received a Grammy Award nomination for Best Contemporary R&B Album at the 48th Grammy Awards.

title: Omarion
text: His second solo album, "21" (2006), contained his second highest-charting single to date, "Ice Box", which reached the top 20 on the "Billboard" Hot 100.

title: Omarion
text: His third solo album, "Ollusion" (2010), was released on January 12, 2010, with the lead single, "I Get It In".

title: Omarion
text: His fourth solo album, "Sex Playlist" (2014), spawned the single, "Post to Be", which was certified 3x platinum and reached number 13 on the Hot 100 chart in May 2015, and became his highest charting single to date.

title: No Fences
text: No Fences is the second studio album by the American country music artist Garth Brooks.

title: No Fences
text: It was released on August 27, 1990, and reached #1 on "Billboard's" Top Country Albums chart.

title: No Fences
text: The album also reached #3 on the "Billboard" 200.

title: No Fences
text: On the latter chart it stayed in the top 40 for 126 weeks.

title: No Fences
text: No Fences remains Brooks' best-selling studio album to date with 17 million copies shipped in the US, and is the album that made him an international star.

title: No Fences
text: It was his first album issued in Europe (the original European release contained the four singles from his U.S. debut as bonus tracks).

title: No Fences
text: This was Garth's first album to have a crossover-friendly country-pop sound, which was a departure from the neotraditional country sound of his first album.

title: Friends in Low Places
text: "Friends in Low Places" is a song performed by American country pop artist Garth Brooks.

title: Friends in Low Places
text: It was released on August 6, 1990 as the lead single from his album "No Fences".

title: Friends in Low Places
text: The song spent four weeks at number one on the Hot Country Songs, and won both the Academy of Country Music and Country Music Association awards for 1990 Single of the Year.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: The discography of Rosanne Cash, an American singer-songwriter, consists of thirteen studio albums, six compilation albums, one tribute album, and 39 singles.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: The daughter of Johnny Cash, Rosanne Cash recorded her self-titled debut album in 1978 under the German label Ariola.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: After signing with Columbia Records in 1979, Cash's second studio album "Right or Wrong" was released.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: Its lead single "No Memories Hangin' Around" (a duet with Bobby Bare) reached the Top 20 on the "Billboard" Hot Country Songs chart.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: Cash's third studio release, "Seven Year Ache" (1981) gained major success when the title track peaked at number one on the "Billboard" Country chart, followed by "My Baby Thinks He's a Train" and "Blue Moon with a Heartache," which also reached the top spot.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: The album's follow-up effort, "Somewhere in the Stars" (1982) produced two Top 10 hits on the "Billboard" chart.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: After a 3-year hiatus, Cash issued "Rhythm & Romance" in 1985, which reached #1 on the "Billboard" Top Country Albums list.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: It spawned four Top 10 singles.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: This included the number one single, "I Don't Know Why You Don't Want Me," which won the Grammy Award for Best Female Country Vocal Performance in 1986.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: Her sixth album, "King's Record Shop" was released in 1987.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: The album peaked at number six on the country albums chart and certified gold in the United States.

title: Rosanne Cash discography
text: The four singles released from "King's Record Shop" all reached number one on the "Billboard" Country chart between 1987 and 1988, including a cover of Johnny Cash's "Tennessee Flat-Top Box."

title: Train discography
text: American pop rock band Train has released ten studio albums, two live albums, one video album, four extended plays, 30 singles, four promotional singles, and 26 music videos.

title: Train discography
text: The band independently released their eponymous debut studio album in 1996, two years after their formation.

title: Train discography
text: In February 1998, the band signed to Aware Records and Columbia Records and re-released the album under the two labels.

title: Train discography
text: Three singles were released from "Train"; the album's second single, "Meet Virginia", peaked at number 20 on the US "Billboard" Hot 100.

title: Train discography
text: The album peaked at number 76 on the US "Billboard" 200 and was certified platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA).

title: Train discography
text: In the period following the release of "Train", producer Brendan O'Brien started working with the band in a partnership that would last for three albums.

title: Train discography
text: The band released their second studio album "Drops of Jupiter" in March 2001; it was preceded by the release of its lead single, "Drops of Jupiter (Tell Me)".

title: Train discography
text: The single became a commercial success, peaking at number five on the US "Billboard" Hot 100 and also becoming a top ten hit in Australia, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom.

title: Train discography
text: "Drops of Jupiter (Tell Me)" also won an award for Best Rock Song at the 44th Grammy Awards.

title: Train discography
text: The album peaked at number six on the "Billboard" 200, earning a double platinum certification from the RIAA. "

title: Train discography
text: She's on Fire", the third single from "Drops of Jupiter", achieved moderate success in Australia and the UK.

title: Train discography
text: Train's third studio album, "My Private Nation", was released in June 2003.

title: Train discography
text: It peaked at number six on the "Billboard" 200 and was certified platinum by the RIAA.

title: Train discography
text: The album's first two singles, "Calling All Angels" and "When I Look to the Sky", peaked at numbers 19 and 74 respectively on the "Billboard" Hot 100.

title: Train discography
text: The band released their fourth studio album "For Me, It's You" in January 2006.

title: Train discography
text: The album peaked at number 10 on the "Billboard" 200 and spawned three singles.

title: I Love You Always Forever
text: "I Love You Always Forever" is a song by British singer Donna Lewis.

title: I Love You Always Forever
text: It was released in the United States in May 1996 as the lead single from her debut album, "Now in a Minute".

title: I Love You Always Forever
text: Inspired by the H. E. Bates novel "Love for Lydia", it peaked at number five on the UK Singles Chart.

title: I Love You Always Forever
text: Outside the United Kingdom, it peaked within the top ten of the charts in Australia, Austria, Canada, France, Germany, New Zealand, Norway, Switzerland and the United States.

title: I Love You Always Forever
text: In the latter country, the song peaked at number two on the "Billboard" Hot 100, where it remained for nine weeks during the summer of 1996, kept from number one by Los Del Rio's "Macarena".

title: I Love You Always Forever
text: Despite this, the song was number one on the Hot 100 Airplay chart for thirteen weeks and the "Billboard" Top 40 Mainstream chart for eleven weeks, becoming one of the most played songs of the 1990s.

title: I Love You Always Forever
text: The song therefore is drawn for third place among songs with the longest runs at number two on the "Billboard" Hot 100 and drawn at second for the most weeks at the "Billboard" Top 40 Mainstream chart.

title: I Love You Always Forever
text: In Australia, the single also peaked at number two on the ARIA Singles Chart.

title: I Love You Always Forever
text: In 2016, the song was covered by Australian pop singer Betty Who, peaking at number six on the ARIA Singles Chart.

title: The Definition Of...
text: The Definition Of... is the fifth studio album by American recording artist Fantasia.

title: The Definition Of...
text: It was released by RCA Records and 19 Recordings on July 29, 2016 in the United States and for online streaming worldwide on Apple Music a day earlier.

title: The Definition Of...
text: Fantasia worked with producers Ron Fair, Brian Kennedy, Neff-U, Jerome "J-Roc" Harmon and GRADES on the album.

title: The Definition Of...
text: The album featured two top ten singles on the US "Billboard" Adult R&B Songs airplay chart: "No Time for It", which peaked at number six, and "Sleeping with the One I Love" which peaked at number nine.

title: The Definition Of...
text: In order to further promote the album, Fantasia embarked on a tour with Anthony Hamilton called .

title: The Definition Of...
text: "The Definition Of..." received mixed to positive reviews from music critics.

title: The Definition Of...
text: The album peaked at number six on the US "Billboard" 200.

title: The Definition Of...
text: The album also topped that week's "Billboard" Top R&B Albums chart, and peaked at number two on the US Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums chart.

title: The Definition Of...
text: The album was also promoted with an US twelve-show tour titled The Definition Of... Tour, which started on November 16, 2016 and ended on December 4, 2016.

title: The Definition Of...
text: The third single "When I Met You" was released on January 17, 2017.

title: Thomas Rhett discography
text: American singer and songwriter Thomas Rhett has released three studio albums, one extended play and thirteen singles, including one as a featured artist.

title: Thomas Rhett discography
text: His debut album, "It Goes Like This", debuted in the top 10 of the "Billboard" 200 in 2013 and produced three number one singles on the "Billboard" Country Airplay chart.

title: Thomas Rhett discography
text: Rhett released his second album, "Tangled Up", in 2015 which peaked at number six on the "Billboard" 200.

title: Thomas Rhett discography
text: Four of the album's five singles reached number one, while the second single, "Die a Happy Man" became his first crossover success and highest-charting single on the "Billboard" Hot 100.

title: Thomas Rhett discography
text: His third album, "Life Changes", is due in 2017.

title: Thomas Rhett discography
text: Nine of Rhett's singles have received at least a Gold certification from the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA), with six going Platinum.

title: Trisha Yearwood discography
text: American country artist Trisha Yearwood has released twelve studio albums, seven compilation albums, one additional album, forty one music videos, fifty-eight singles and has appeared on twenty eight albums.

title: Trisha Yearwood discography
text: Yearwood's self-titled debut album was released in 1991, peaking at number two on the "Billboard" Top Country Albums chart and number thirty one on the Billboard 200.

title: Trisha Yearwood discography
text: It became the first debut female country album to sell one million copies, eventually certifying double platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America. "

title: Trisha Yearwood discography
text: She's in Love with the Boy" became the first female debut single since 1964 to top the "Billboard" Hot Country Singles chart.

title: Trisha Yearwood discography
text: The album would spawn an additional three singles, including "The Woman Before Me".

title: Trisha Yearwood discography
text: Her second studio album was the critically acclaimed "Hearts in Armor" (1992).

title: Trisha Yearwood discography
text: It spawned the top five country hits "Wrong Side of Memphis" and "Walkaway Joe".

title: Trisha Yearwood discography
text: Her third studio record "The Song Remembers When" (1993) enjoyed similar success while the lead single reached number two on the Billboard country chart.

title: Trisha Yearwood discography
text: A holiday album appeared before her platinum-selling fourth studio album "Thinkin' About You" (1995).

title: Trisha Yearwood discography
text: Reaching the third position of the country albums chart and the top thirty of the Billboard 200, its first two singles topped the Hot Country Singles chart.

title: Trisha Yearwood discography
text: Her sixth studio album "Everybody Knows" (1996) spawned Yearwood's fourth number one single, "Believe Me Baby (I Lied)".

title: Number 1's (Destiny's Child album)
text: Following its release, "#1's" received positive reviews from music critics who praised the included material as the highlights of the group's music career.

title: Number 1's (Destiny's Child album)
text: However, its title was dismissed as many of the songs included on the track listing hadn't reached the top position of a major record chart; it was later acknowledged by "Billboard" magazine that the title was only used as a marketing strategy.

title: Number 1's (Destiny's Child album)
text: The compilation debuted and peaked on top of the US "Billboard" 200 album chart becoming the group's second album to reach number one in that country.

title: Number 1's (Destiny's Child album)
text: It further peaked at number one in Japan and number six in the UK while also reaching the top forty in many European countries.

title: Number 1's (Destiny's Child album)
text: The compilation received seven certifications by music trade organizations in different countries across the world.

title: Number 1's (Destiny's Child album)
text: It further spawned two singles: "Stand up For Love", which failed to appear on a major music chart, and "Check on It", which reached number one on the US "Billboard" Hot 100 and the top ten on many European charts.

title: Dirt (Alice in Chains album)
text: Dirt is the second studio album by the American rock band Alice in Chains, released on September 29, 1992, through Columbia Records.

title: Dirt (Alice in Chains album)
text: Peaking at number six on the "Billboard" 200, the album was also well received by music critics.

title: Dirt (Alice in Chains album)
text: It has since been certified four-times platinum by the RIAA and gone on to sell five million copies worldwide, making "Dirt" the band's highest selling album to date.

title: Dirt (Alice in Chains album)
