text: Directed by Roger Christian and starring John Travolta, Barry Pepper and Forest Whitaker, the film depicts an Earth that has been under the rule of the alien Psychlos for 1,000 years and tells the story of the rebellion that develops when the Psychlos attempt to use the surviving humans as gold miners.

title: Avalanche (1994 film)
text: Avalanche is a 1994 CTV made-for-television disaster thriller film directed by Paul Shapiro and starring Michael Gross, Deanna Milligan, Myles Ferguson and David Hasselhoff as main characters.

title: Avalanche (1994 film)
text: The film was shot in British Columbia, Canada.

title: Natalie Gold
text: Natalie Gold is an American actress who has appeared in film, television, and stage productions, including on Broadway.

title: Natalie Gold
text: She is perhaps best known for playing Julia Harwell on the TV show "Rubicon", and she has appeared in many films including "Before the Devil Knows You're Dead", "I Don't Know How She Does It", "Love & Other Drugs".

title: Natalie Gold
text: She has performed opposite Jake Gyllenhall, Naomi Watts, Cynthia Nixon, and she has been directed by Sidney Lumet.

title: Natalie Gold
text: Gold grew up in Miami, Florida and studied theatre at the New World School of the Arts and at Emerson College.

title: Robin Hood: Men in Tights
text: Robin Hood: Men in Tights is a 1993 American musical adventure comedy film and a parody of the Robin Hood story.

title: Robin Hood: Men in Tights
text: The film was produced and directed by Mel Brooks, co-written by Brooks, Evan Chandler, and J. David Shapiro based on a story by Chandler and Shapiro, and stars Cary Elwes, Richard Lewis, and Dave Chappelle in his film debut.

title: Robin Hood: Men in Tights
text: It includes frequent comedic references to previous "Robin Hood" films (particularly "", upon which the plot is loosely structured, Disney's "Robin Hood", and the 1938 Errol Flynn adaptation, "The Adventures of Robin Hood").

title: Brothers at War
text: Brothers at War is a 2009 documentary film directed by Jake Rademacher and produced by Rademacher and Norman S. Powell.

title: Brothers at War
text: The film follows several US soldiers in the Iraq War.

title: Brothers at War
text: The film's executive producers are actor, director, and Presidential Citizens Medal recipient Gary Sinise and Secretary of Defense Medal for Outstanding Public Service recipient David Scantling.

title: Brothers at War
text: "Brothers at War" won the Best Documentary Feature Award at the 2008 GI Film Festival.

title: Brothers at War
text: The film features an original score by Lee Holdridge and an original song--"Brothers in Arms"—by John Ondrasik of Five for Fighting.

title: J. David Shapiro
text: Jake David Shapiro, also known as J. D. Shapiro (born March 18, 1969), is an American filmmaker and stand-up comedian.

title: J. David Shapiro
text: Shapiro is best known as the original screenwriter of the film "" and for writing the screenplay adaptation of L. Ron Hubbard's novel "Battlefield Earth".

title: Frithwald
text: Frithwald (Old English: "Friþuweald" or "Friðewald"; d. 762 × 764) was an Anglo-Saxon Bishop of Whithorn.

title: Frithwald
text: The version of the "Anglo-Saxon Chronicle" in the "Worcester Chronicle" says that in 735 he succeeded Pehthelm, after the latter's death, as Bishop of Whithorn.

title: Frithwald
text: The only other source for Frithwald is the entry in versions D and E of the "Anglo-Saxon Chronicle" which, "sub anno" 762, relate that:Frithwald, bishop at Whithorn, died on the Nones of May .

title: Frithwald
text:
He was consecrated at Chester on the eighteenth before the Kalends of September , in the sixth winter of Ceolwulf's kingship ; and he was bishop twenty-nine winters
"Friþuweald biscop æt Hwiterne forðferde on Nonas Maius, se wæs gehalgod on Ceastre on .

title: Frithwald
text: xviii.

title: Frithwald
text: Kalendas September þam .

title: Frithwald
text: vi.

title: Frithwald
text: wintra Ceolwulfes rices, 7 he wæs biscop .

title: Frithwald
text: xxix.

title: Frithwald
text: wintra".

title: Frithwald
text: If the Worcester source is correct, that would put his death in 764; the entry is also sometimes thought to cover the year 763.

title: Kings of the Angles
text: The Angles were a dominant Germanic tribe in the Anglo-Saxon settlement of Britain, and gave their name to the English, England and to the region of East Anglia.

title: Kings of the Angles
text: Originally from Angeln, present-day Schleswig-Holstein, a legendary list of their kings has been preserved in the heroic poems "Widsith" and "Beowulf", and the "Anglo-Saxon Chronicle".

title: The Dragon (Beowulf)
text: The final act of the Anglo-Saxon poem "Beowulf" is about the hero Beowulf's fight with a dragon, the third monster he encounters in the epic.

title: The Dragon (Beowulf)
text: On his return from Heorot, where he killed Grendel and Grendel's mother, Beowulf becomes king of the Geats and rules peacefully for fifty winters until a slave awakens and angers a dragon by stealing a jewelled cup from its lair in order to gain freedom from killing his brother.

title: The Dragon (Beowulf)
text: When the angry dragon mercilessly burns the Geats' homes and lands, Beowulf decides to fight and kill the monster personally.

title: The Dragon (Beowulf)
text: He and his thanes climb to the dragon's lair where, upon seeing the beast, the thanes flee in terror, leaving only Wiglaf to battle at Beowulf's side.

title: The Dragon (Beowulf)
text: When the dragon wounds Beowulf fatally, Wiglaf slays it.

title: Battle of Brunanburh (poem)
text: The Battle of Brunanburh is an Old English poem.

title: Battle of Brunanburh (poem)
text: It is preserved in the "Anglo-Saxon Chronicle", a historical record of events in Anglo-Saxon England which was kept from the late ninth to the mid-twelfth century.

title: Battle of Brunanburh (poem)
text: The poem records the Battle of Brunanburh, a battle fought in 937 between an English army and a combined army of Scots, Vikings, and Britons.

title: Battle of Brunanburh (poem)
text: The battle resulted in an English victory, celebrated by the poem in style and language like that of traditional Old English battle poetry.

title: Battle of Brunanburh (poem)
text: The poem is notable because of those traditional elements and has been praised for its authentic tone, but it is also remarkable for its fiercely nationalistic tone, which documents the development of a unified England ruled by the House of Wessex.

title: Widsith
text: Widsith is an Old English poem of 143 lines.

title: Widsith
text: The poem survives only in the Exeter Book, a manuscript of Old English poetry compiled in the late 10th century containing approximately one sixth of all surviving Old English poetry.

title: Widsith
text: Widsith is located between the poems "Vainglory" and "The Fortunes of Men".

title: Widsith
text: Since the donation of the Exeter Book in 1076, it has been housed in Exeter Cathedral in southwest England.

title: Widsith
text: The poem is for the most part a survey of the people, kings, and heroes of Europe in the Heroic Age of Northern Europe: see Tribes of Widsith.

title: Grendel
text: Grendel is a being originated from the Anglo-Saxon epic poem "Beowulf" (AD 700–1000), which is considered to be the oldest surviving poem in Old English.

title: Grendel
text: He is one of the poem's three antagonists (along with Grendel's mother and the dragon), all aligned in opposition against the protagonist Beowulf.

title: Grendel
text: Grendel is feared by all but Beowulf.

title: Grendel
text: Grendel is described to have descended from the lineage of the Biblical figure Cain, from Genesis 4 of the Bible, and is usually depicted as a monster or a giant, although his status as a monster, giant or some other form of supernatural being is not clearly described in the poem and thus remains the subject of scholarly debate.

title: Nowell Codex
text: The Nowell Codex is the second of two manuscripts found in the bound volume Cotton Vitellius A.xv, one of the four major Anglo-Saxon poetic manuscripts.

title: Nowell Codex
text: It is most famous as the manuscript containing the unique copy of the epic poem "Beowulf".

title: Nowell Codex
text: In addition to this, it contains first a fragment of "The Life of Saint Christopher", then the more complete texts "Wonders of the East" and "Letters of Alexander to Aristotle," and, after "Beowulf", a poetic translation of "Judith".

title: Nowell Codex
text: Due to the fame of "Beowulf", the Nowell codex is also sometimes known simply as the Beowulf manuscript.

title: Nowell Codex
text: The manuscript is located within the British Library with the rest of the Cotton collection.

title: Offa of Angel
text: Offa is a legendary king of the Angles in the genealogy of the kings of Mercia presented in the "Anglo-Saxon Chronicle".

title: Offa of Angel
text: He is the son of Wermund and the father of Angeltheow.

title: History of Herefordshire
text: The History of Herefordshire starts with a shire in the time of Athelstan (895–939), and Herefordshire is mentioned in the "Anglo-Saxon Chronicle" in 1051.

title: History of Herefordshire
text: The first Anglo-Saxon settlers, the Magonsætan, were a sub-tribal unit of the Hwicce who occupied the Severn valley.

title: History of Herefordshire
text: The Magonsætan were said to be in the intervening lands between the Rivers Wye and Severn.

title: History of Herefordshire
text: The undulating hills of marl clay were surrounded by the Welsh mountains to the west; the Malvern Hills to the east; the Clent Hills of the Shropshire borders to the north, and the indeterminate extent of the Forest of Dean to the south.

title: History of Herefordshire
text: The shire name first recorded in the "Anglo-Saxon Chronicle" was derived from "Here-ford", Old English for "Army crossing", the location for the city.

title: History of Herefordshire
text: The area was covered first by Offa of Mercia, who constructed the dyke as a boundary to keep warring tribes out of the Mercian kingdom: an early indication of the ambivalent relations with the Welsh.

title: History of Herefordshire
text: The shire as an administrative unit was developed from Alfred the Great's Burghal Hidage, and the Shire-reeve courts of the Hundred.

title: History of Herefordshire
text: King Edgar the Ætheling was a regular visitor, and founded the diocese, previously part of the see of Worcester, in 976.

title: History of Herefordshire
text: The establishment of a centre of law and justice was supported by a monastic chapter that flourished during the Tenth century Reformation.

title: History of Herefordshire
text: Hereford's geographical location at the hub of the shire allowed Anglo-Saxon ealdormen to manage affairs; and Hereford played a vital role in the Scandinavian wars until Ralph, Earl Hereford was deposed by the regal Earl Harold Godwinson.

title: Layamon's Brut
text: Layamon's "Brut (ca. 1190 - 1215), also known as The Chronicle of Britain", is a Middle English poem compiled and recast by the English priest Layamon.

title: Layamon's Brut
text: The "Brut" is 16,095 lines long and narrates the history of Britain: it is the first historiography written in English since the "Anglo-Saxon Chronicle".

title: Layamon's Brut
text: Named for Britain's mythical founder, Brutus of Troy, the poem is largely based on the Anglo-Norman "Roman de Brut" by Wace, which is in turn a version of Geoffrey of Monmouth's Latin "Historia Regum Britanniae".

title: Layamon's Brut
text: Layamon's poem, however, is longer than both and includes an enlarged section on the life and exploits of King Arthur.

title: Layamon's Brut
text: It is written in the alliterative verse style commonly used in Middle English poetry by rhyming chroniclers, the two halves of the alliterative lines being often linked by rhyme as well as by alliteration.

title: Karl Freiherr von Müffling
text: Friedrich Karl Ferdinand Freiherr von Müffling, called Weiss (12 June 177510 January 1851) was a Prussian "Generalfeldmarschall" and military theorist.

title: Karl Freiherr von Müffling
text: He served as Blücher's liaison officer in Wellington's headquarters during the Battle of Waterloo and was one of the organizers of the final victory over Napoleon.

title: Karl Freiherr von Müffling
text: After the wars he served a diplomatic role at the Congress of Aix-la-Chappelle and was a major contributor to the development of the Prussian General Staff as Chief.

title: Karl Freiherr von Müffling
text: Müffling also specialized in military topography and cartography.

title: Ardant du Picq
text: Charles Jean Jacques Joseph Ardant du Picq (19 October 1821 – 18 August 1870) was a French Army officer and military theorist of the mid-nineteenth century whose writings, as they were later interpreted by other theorists, had a great effect on French military theory and doctrine.

title: František Zach
text: František Zach (] ; Serbian: Франтишек Зах ; 1 May 1807–14 January 1892), known as Franjo Zah (Фрањо Зах), was a Czech-born soldier and military theorist, best known for being the first acting General and Chief of the General Staff of the Principality of Serbia from 1876 to 1877.

title: Graham Seton Hutchison
text: Lieutenant-Colonel Graham Seton Hutchison (1890–1946) was a Scottish First World War army officer, military theorist, author of both adventure novels and non-fiction works and fascist activist.

title: Graham Seton Hutchison
text: Seton Hutchison became a celebrated figure in military circles for his tactical innovations during the First World War but would later become associated with a series of fringe fascist movements which failed to capture much support even by the standards of the far right in Britain in the interbellum period.

title: Richard Terrin
text: Richard Terrin (January 8, 1890 – June 3, 1958) was an American lawyer, military theorist, historian, and government official known for his expertise on Asia.

title: Richard Terrin
text: After graduating from the Northwestern University School of Law, Terrin worked briefly as a prosecutor, then served in various positions with the American administration in the Philippines, most notably working as primary staff aide and legal advisor to Governor-General of the Philippines Dwight F. Davis.

title: Richard Terrin
text: During the 1930s, he worked in the US Department of War and taught at the Army War College, then moved to Kenya.

title: Richard Terrin
text: After American entry into World War II, he moved to Australia, where he worked with the American Embassy to coordinate operations and from 1945–1948, he held a position with the US administration in Japan.

title: Richard Terrin
text: After leaving Japan, he practiced law in Chicago until his retirement in 1954.

title: Richard Terrin
text: He died at his home on June 3, 1958 of natural causes.

title: Erwin Rommel
text: Erwin Rommel (15 November 1891 – 14 October 1944) was a German general and military theorist.

title: Erwin Rommel
text: Popularly known as the Desert Fox, he served as field marshal in the Wehrmacht of Nazi Germany during World War II.

title: International Stability Operations Association
text: The International Stability Operations Association (ISOA), formerly known as the International Peace Operations Association (IPOA), is a trade association founded in April 2001.

title: International Stability Operations Association
text: IPOA was created to support the private military and disaster relief industries, and is based in Washington, D.C., United States.

title: Evgeny Messner
text: Evgeny Messner (Russian: Евгений Эдуардович Месснер , German: "Eugen Messner" ; 1891–1974) was a Russian professional soldier and military theorist.

title: Evgeny Messner
text: A Russian German, he became an officer of the Imperial Russian Army.

title: Evgeny Messner
text: During the Russian Civil War he sided with the White movement and fought against the Bolsheviks, notably as the last chief of staff of Kornilov Division of the Army of General Wrangel.

title: Norbert Holm
text: Norbert Holm (16 December 1895 – 3 June 1962) was a general in the Wehrmacht of Nazi Germany during World War II.

title: Norbert Holm
text: He was a recipient of the Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross.

title: Norbert Holm
text: Following the 20 July plot, on 16 September 1944, Norbert Holm was arrested and later demoted because of his Chief of Operations association with Field Marsal Erwin Rommel.

title: Norbert Holm
text: He fought as a private in the 19th Panzer Division, and for "repeated bravery before the enemy" he was promoted to Unteroffizier in January 1945 and to Feldwebel two months before the end of the war.

title: Norbert Holm
text: He was rehabilitated in 1956.

title: Mirza Mohammad Afzal Beg
text: Mirza Mohammad Afzal Bég was a Kashmiri politician and lieutenant of the late Chief Minister of Jammu and Kashmir, Sheikh Abdullah.

title: Mirza Mohammad Afzal Beg
text: He was also the president of the Plebiscite Front and was arrested as one of the accused in Kashmir Conspiracy Case.

title: Mirza Mohammad Afzal Beg
text: In later years, he was Sheikh Abdullah's representative in talks with the Indian government in 1974, inking the 1974 Indira-Sheikh accord.

title: Mirza Mohammad Afzal Beg
text: Afzal Bég hailed from Anantnag and was the son of mirza Nizamudin Beg, brother of Mirza Ghulam Qadir Beg and nephew of the landlord, Mirza Ghulam Mohammad Bég, of Anantnag.

title: Mirza Mohammad Afzal Beg
text: He died on 11 June 1982.

title: Mirza Mohammad Afzal Beg
text: He was popularly known as 'Fakhr-e-Kashmir' (pride of Kashmir) and was the architect of the legendary 'land to the landless tiller' legislation which uplifted the masses of J&K.

title: Mirza Mohammad Afzal Beg
text: His legal acumen and genius was admired by friends and foes.

title: Mirza Mohammad Afzal Beg
text: He was also known as the brain behind Sheikh Abdullah.

title: Mirza Mohammad Afzal Beg
text: His legal acumen was lauded by the imminent legal luminary G.S. Pathak, who later became the Vice President of India, who proclaimed "Beg Sahab, you come out of politics and be a permanent part of the legal profession, you can be a jewel of any Bar" (after hearing his arguments in the Kashmir Conspiracy case).

title: Mirza Mohammad Afzal Beg
text: He was immensely popular amongst his people and was perceived as the successor to Sheikh Mohd.

title: Mirza Mohammad Afzal Beg
text: Abdullah.

title: Mirza Mohammad Afzal Beg
text: He served as the first Deputy Chief Minister of the state of J&K and was seen discharging the most important functions in the State with his sheer brilliance.

title: Mirza Mohammad Afzal Beg
text: Historians of JK Politics hold him solely for National Conference's landslide win in the 1977 assembly elections when he single-handedly ran the NC's campaign.

title: Mirza Mohammad Afzal Beg
text: He is survived by three sons and three daughters.

title: Mirza Mohammad Afzal Beg
text: His eldest son Dr Mirza Mohammad Aijaz beg is a very renowned medico and has served state government for about forty years and retired as Deputy director health services.

title: Mirza Mohammad Afzal Beg
text: He is the only son who has been residing at ancestral place throughout.

title: Mirza Mohammad Afzal Beg
text: He was never interested in politics and has got a great rapport of being pious and honest administrator and human being.

title: Mirza Mohammad Afzal Beg
text: His second son Mirza Mehboob Beg took on his father's mantle and is also a widely respected and envied politician in the state.

title: Mirza Mohammad Afzal Beg
text: The Beg family enjoys a very good rapport with the people and are widely respected for their honesty and integrity.

title: Stephen Pearton
text: Stephen Pearton is an American materials scientist and engineer and Distinguished Professor at University of Florida.

title: Stephen Pearton
text: Pearton's work focuses on the use of advanced materials in areas such as laser diodes and nanomaterial applications and similar applications.

title: Stephen Pearton
text: He is a recipient of the J.J. Ebers Award from the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, and the David Adler Lectureship from the American Physical Society.

title: Stephen Pearton
text: He is also a Fellow of multiple professional or academic societies, including the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, the American Physical Society, the Materials Research Society, and the American Vacuum Society.

title: Atul Chokshi
text: Atul Harish Chokshi (born 1958) is an Indian materials scientist, metallurgical engineer and a professor at the Department of Materials Engineering of the Indian Institute of Science.

title: Atul Chokshi
text: He is known for his studies on "high temperature deformation and failure of ceramic materials" and is an elected fellow of all the three major Indian science academies viz.

title: Atul Chokshi
text: the National Academy of Sciences, India, Indian Academy of Sciences, and Indian National Science Academy as well as the Indian National Academy of Engineering.

title: Atul Chokshi
text: The Council of Scientific and Industrial Research, the apex agency of the Government of India for scientific research, awarded him the Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar Prize for Science and Technology, one of the highest Indian science awards for his contributions to Engineering Sciences in 2003.

title: Lionel Kimerling
text: Lionel C. Kimerling is an American materials scientist, known for his work in the field of semiconductor materials and their processing.

title: Lionel Kimerling
text: As of 2016, he is the Thomas Lord Professor of Materials Science & Engineering at the Department of Materials Science & Engineering at Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).

title: Lionel Kimerling
text: He headed the Materials Physics Research Department of AT&T Bell Laboratories from 1981 to 1990.

title: Sang-Wook Cheong
text: Sang Wook Cheong is a Korean American materials scientist at Rutgers University.

title: Sang-Wook Cheong
text: He has made ground-breaking contributions to the research field of enhanced physical functionalities in complex materials originating from collective correlations and collective phase transitions such as colossal magnetoresistive and colossal magnetoelectric effects in complex oxides.

title: Sang-Wook Cheong
text: He has also made pivotal contributions to mesoscopic self-organization in solids, including the nanoscale charge stripe formation, mesoscopic electronic phase separation in mixed valent transition metal oxides, and the formation of topological vortex domains in multiferroics, which was found to be synergistically relevant to mathematics (graph theory) and cosmology.

title: Yuval Golan
text: Yuval Golan is an Israeli materials scientist who works at Ben-Gurion University of the Negev (BGU).

title: Yuval Golan
text: Golan, a professor of materials engineering, studies materials at the nanoscale level and focuses on their synthesis, characterization and applications.

title: Yuval Golan
text: Golan is the Director of the Ilse Katz Institute for Nanoscale Science and Technology, and chairman of the synchrotron committee of the Israeli Academy of Sciences and Humanities.

title: Markus J. Buehler
text: Markus J. Buehler is an American materials scientist and engineer at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).

title: Markus J. Buehler
text: He is a professor at MIT's Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, where he directs the Laboratory for Atomistic and Molecular Mechanics (LAMM).

title: Markus J. Buehler
text: Since 2013, he serves as the Head of the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering at MIT.

title: Markus J. Buehler
text: His research and teaching activities center on the application of a computational materials science approach to understand functional material properties in biological and synthetic materials, specifically focused on mechanical properties.

title: Markus J. Buehler
text: His work is highly cross-disciplinary and incorporates materials science, engineering, mathematics and the establishment of links between natural materials with the Arts through the use of category theory.

title: Rutgers University
text: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey ( ), commonly referred to as Rutgers University, Rutgers, or RU, is an American public research university and the largest institution for higher education in New Jersey.

title: Winston Wole Soboyejo
text: Winston Oluwole Soboyejo commonly known as "Wole" is an American Scientist of Yoruba Nigerian parentage.

title: Winston Wole Soboyejo
text: He is a materials scientist whose research focuses on biomaterials and the use of nanoparticles for the detection and treatment of disease, the mechanical properties of materials, and the use of materials science to promote global development.

title: Marc A. Meyers
text: Marc André Meyers is an American materials scientist, engineer and Distinguished Professor at the University of California, San Diego.

title: Marc A. Meyers
text: Meyers studies and writes about the dynamic behavior of materials, synthesis, processing, impact testing, and characterization of new materials.

title: Marc A. Meyers
text: He also studies the properties of biological materials, and in particular the protective coverings of animals.

title: Marc A. Meyers
text: Abalone shells, toucan beaks, the scales of exotic fish, feathers, piranha teeth, rabbit skin, boxfish, turtle and armadillo carapaces, and pangolin scales are some of the biological materials studied by his group.

title: Arthur Nowick
text: Arthur S. Nowick (29 August 1923 – 20 July 2010) was an American materials scientist.

title: Arthur Nowick
text: He made pioneering contributions to the study of internal friction, anelasticity, crystal defects and other subjects over a fifty-year career and helped develop materials science from a field focused on metals to one that encompasses all classes of materials.

title: Dinaric calcareous block fir forest
text: The Dinaric calcareous silver fir forests are an endemic vegetation type of the littoral Dinaric Alps, located in southeastern Europe.

title: Dinaric calcareous block fir forest
text: Pure stands of Dinaric calcareous Silver fir —"Abies alba" forests appear on limestone escarpments in the montane zones of Orjen, Velebit, Biokovo and Prenj.

title: Dinaric calcareous block fir forest
text: They comprise one of the most interesting formations of Balkan vegetation types as the forests bear several rare plants and are of striking beauty.

title: Dinaric calcareous block fir forest
text: As a highly endemic and rare vegetation type of the Dinarids it needs protection.

title: Kniphofia
text: Kniphofia , also called tritoma, red hot poker, torch lily, knofflers or poker plant, is a genus of flowering plants in the family Asphodelaceae, first described as a genus in 1794.

title: Kniphofia
text: It is native to Africa.

title: Kniphofia
text: Herbaceous species and hybrids have narrow, grass-like leaves 10 - long, while perennial species have broader, strap-shaped foliage up to 1.5 m long.

title: Kniphofia
text: All plants produce spikes of upright, brightly coloured flowers well above the foliage, in shades of red, orange and yellow, often bicoloured.

title: Kniphofia
text: The flowers produce copious nectar while blooming and are attractive to bees.

title: Kniphofia
text: In the New World they may attract sap-suckers such as hummingbirds and New World orioles.

title: Caatinga
text: Caatinga (] ) is a type of desert vegetation, which can also be called Jola Jolilo (Jou-lah-Jouh-Liloy).

title: Caatinga
text: It is the indian name for the Caatinga, and an ecoregion characterized by this vegetation in interior northeastern Brazil.

title: Caatinga
text: The name "Caatinga" is a Tupi word meaning "white forest" or "white vegetation" ("caa" = forest, vegetation, "tinga" = white).

title: Lourensford Alluvium Fynbos
text: Lourensford Alluvium Fynbos is a critically endangered vegetation type that is endemic to Cape Town.

title: Lourensford Alluvium Fynbos
text: Though closest to Fynbos, it has characteristics of both Fynbos and Renosterveld vegetation and is thus actually a unique hybrid vegetation type.

title: Desert dry wash
text: Desert dry wash is a North American desert vegetation type (or biome) occurring in the flat bottoms of canyons and drainages that lack water at or near the surface most of the year, and are subject to periodic severe flooding events.

title: Desert dry wash
text: Desert dry wash is contrasted with desert riparian vegetation, which occurs in desert canyons and drainages where there is year-round water at or near the surface.

title: Desert dry wash
text: Plants must either be able to survive the severe flooding conditions or be able to reestablish themselves before the next flooding event.

title: Desert dry wash
text: Some of these plants have evolved so that in order for their seeds to germinate, the seeds must be scarified or abraded by tumbling sand, gravel, and rocks during the flooding event.

title: Desert dry wash
text: They must then quickly send down roots deep enough to be able to tap into deep underground water reserves, in order to survive the dry period after the flooding.

title: Desert dry wash
text: Common dominant species of the desert dry wash include smoke tree ("Psorothamnus spinosus"), desert willow ("Chilopsis linearis"), catclaw ("Senegalia greggii"), cheesebush ("Ambrosia salsola"), and waterweed ("Baccharis sergiloides").

title: Baptisia
text: Baptisia (wild indigo, false indigo) is a genus in the legume family, Fabaceae.

title: Baptisia
text: They are flowering herbaceous perennial plants with pea-like flowers, followed by pods, which are sometimes inflated.

title: Baptisia
text: They are native to woodland and grassland in eastern and southern North America.

title: Baptisia
text: The species most commonly found in cultivation is "B. australis".

title: Desert riparian
text: Desert riparian is a North American desert vegetation type (or biome) occurring in the bottoms of canyons and drainages that have water at or near the surface most of the year.

title: Desert riparian
text: It is contrasted with the desert dry wash vegetation type in which water at or near the surface is lacking most of the year.

title: Desert riparian
text: The visual character is of large, lush green trees surrounded by dry desert vegetation and soil coloration.

title: Desert riparian
text: The area may be in a patch surrounding a spring (oasis), or in a strand following the course of water flow.

title: Desert riparian
text: Over 80% of known desert wildlife species use desert riparian areas.

title: Desert riparian
text: Common dominant species include Fremont cottonwood ("Populus fremontii"), Arizona ash ("Fraxinus velutina"), arroyo willow ("Salix lasiolepis"), Goodding's willow ("Salix gooddingii"), red willow ("Salix laevigata"), California fan palm ("Washingtonia filifera"), and invasive species such as salt cedar ("Tamarix ramosissima"), giant reed ("Arundo donax"), and Russian olive ("Elaeagnus angustifolia").

title: Desert riparian
text: Salt cedar is particularly causing problems for this ecosystem because it is able to extract water more efficiently than cottonwoods and willows.

title: Desert riparian
text: Many noninvasive non-native species may also be found because springs and surface water areas in the desert often were old homesites where such species were intentionally planted, such as elm, black locust, and assorted fruit trees.

title: Vegetation and slope stability
text: Vegetation and slope stability are interrelated by the ability of the plant life growing on slopes to both promote and hinder the stability of the slope.

title: Vegetation and slope stability
text: The relationship is a complex combination of the type of soil, the rainfall regime, the plant species present, the slope aspect, and the steepness of the slope.

title: Vegetation and slope stability
text: Knowledge of the underlying slope stability as a function of the soil type, its age, horizon development, compaction, and other impacts is a major underlying aspect of understanding how vegetation can alter the stability of the slope.

title: Vegetation and slope stability
text: There are four major ways in which vegetation influences slope stability: wind throwing, the removal of water, mass of vegetation (surcharge), and mechanical reinforcement of roots.

title: Vegetation classification
text: Vegetation classification is the process of classifying and mapping the vegetation over an area of the earth's surface.

title: Vegetation classification
text: Vegetation classification is often performed by state based agencies as part of land use, resource and environmental management.

title: Vegetation classification
text: Many different methods of vegetation classification have been used.

title: Vegetation classification
text: In general, there has been a shift from structural classification used by forestry for the mapping of timber resources, to floristic community mapping for biodiversity management.

title: Vegetation classification
text: Whereas older forestry-based schemes considered factors such as height, species and density of the woody canopy, floristic community mapping shifts the emphasis onto ecological factors such as climate, soil type and floristic associations.

title: Vegetation classification
text: Classification mapping is usually now done using Geographic Information Systems (GIS) software.

title: Wildfire
text: A wildfire or wildland fire is a fire in an area of combustible vegetation that occurs in the countryside or rural area.

title: Wildfire
text: Depending on the type of vegetation where it occurs, a wildfire can also be classified more specifically as a brush fire, bush fire, desert fire, forest fire, grass fire, hill fire, peat fire, vegetation fire, or veld fire.

title: Wildfire
text: Fossil charcoal indicates that wildfires began soon after the appearance of terrestrial plants 420 million years ago.

title: Wildfire
text: Wildfire’s occurrence throughout the history of terrestrial life invites conjecture that fire must have had pronounced evolutionary effects on most ecosystems' flora and fauna.

title: Wildfire
text: Earth is an intrinsically flammable planet owing to its cover of carbon-rich vegetation, seasonally dry climates, atmospheric oxygen, and widespread lightning and volcano ignitions.

title: My Own Worst Enemy (song)
text: "My Own Worst Enemy" is a song by the American rock band Lit.

title: My Own Worst Enemy (song)
text: It was released in March 1999 as the lead single from Lit's second album, "A Place in the Sun", which was also released that year.

title: My Own Worst Enemy (song)
text: The song was only moderately successful at first, reaching number 17 on the Modern Rock Tracks chart on February 27, 1999.

title: My Own Worst Enemy (song)
text: It later achieved mainstream success, peaking at number 51 on the "Billboard" Hot 100 chart and number one on the Modern Rock Tracks (also known as Alternative Songs) chart.

title: My Own Worst Enemy (song)
text: The song's success helped "A Place in the Sun" to be certified platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) on October 27, 1999 for sales of 1,300,000 copies in the United States.

title: My Own Worst Enemy (song)
text: At the 1999 "Billboard" Music Awards, "My Own Worst Enemy" won the Modern Rock Track of the Year award.

title: My Own Worst Enemy (song)
text: Its music video was filmed by Gavin Bowden in a Las Vegas bowling alley.

title: Astro Lounge
text: Astro Lounge, released in 1999, is the second full length album from the Californian rock band Smash Mouth.

title: Astro Lounge
text: It includes the single "All Star", arguably the group's most well-known song, which reached number four on the U.S. "Billboard" Hot 100.

title: Astro Lounge
text: Several other singles were released from the album, including "Waste" and "Then the Morning Comes".

title: ...To Be Loved: The Best of Papa Roach
text: ...To Be Loved: The Best of Papa Roach is the first compilation album by Californian rock band Papa Roach.

title: ...To Be Loved: The Best of Papa Roach
text: It was released on June 29, 2010.

title: ...To Be Loved: The Best of Papa Roach
text: It was the band's final album with Geffen Records, after the band left for Eleven Seven Music.

title: ...To Be Loved: The Best of Papa Roach
text: The album omits one of the band's biggest singles, "Between Angels and Insects", which was a top 20 hit in the UK.

title: ...To Be Loved: The Best of Papa Roach
text: The band members themselves asked their fans not to buy this CD (as well as expressed their resentment towards Geffen Records) because they do not endorse this release, nor would they receive royalties for its sales.

title: A Place in the Sun (Lit album)
text: A Place in the Sun is the second studio album by the American rock band Lit.

title: Zip-Lock (song)
text: "Zip-Lock" is a song by the American pop punk band Lit, released as the follow-up single to their number one rock hit "My Own Worst Enemy" from their second album, "A Place in the Sun" in 1999.

title: Zip-Lock (song)
text: While not as successful as its previous single, it was able to reach number 11 on the Modern Rock Tracks and number 34 on the Mainstream Rock Tracks.

title: Lifeline (Papa Roach song)
text: "Lifeline" is the second single from Californian rock band Papa Roach's fifth album, "Metamorphosis", and eleventh released single in total.

title: Lifeline (Papa Roach song)
text: The song was originally titled "Hanging On", and was changed to "Lifeline" after lead singer Jacoby Shaddix decided to alter the lyrics of the chorus.

title: Lifeline (Papa Roach song)
text: It was released to iTunes on January 27, 2009 and as a Hot Topic exclusive CD single on February 10.

title: Lifeline (Papa Roach song)
text: An accompanying music video was released on March 6, 2009.

title: Lifeline (Papa Roach song)
text: To launch this song in its truest form, the band filmed "Lifeline" live during "Crüe Fest".

title: Lit (album)
text: Lit is the fourth studio album by the American rock band Lit.

title: Lit (album)
text: The album was recorded at World Class Audio in Anaheim and The Pool House in Fullerton, California.

title: Between Angels and Insects
text: "Between Angels and Insects", also known by its working title of "Obsession", is the third single from Californian rock band Papa Roach's first album, "Infest", and third released single in total.

title: Between Angels and Insects
text: It is also one of the band's most well known songs.

title: Lit (band)
text: Lit is an American rock band, formed in 1995 in Fullerton, California.

title: Lit (band)
text: They are best known for their hit song "My Own Worst Enemy".

title: Time Is Running Out (Papa Roach song)
text: "Time Is Running Out" is the seventh track from Californian rock band Papa Roach's fifth album, "The Paramour Sessions".

title: Time Is Running Out (Papa Roach song)
text: The song is also available as a downloadable track for the "Rock Band" games.

title: Everybody Knows (Trisha Yearwood song)
text: "Everybody Knows" is a song written by Matraca Berg and Gary Harrison, and recorded by American country music artist Trisha Yearwood.

title: Everybody Knows (Trisha Yearwood song)
text: It was released in October 1996 as the second single from her album of the same name.

title: Everybody Knows (Trisha Yearwood song)
text: The song reached number 3 on the US "Billboard" Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart in February 1997 and number 1 on the "RPM" Country Tracks chart in Canada.

title: Between Now and Forever
text: Between Now and Forever is the second studio album by American country music artist Bryan White.

title: Between Now and Forever
text: It was released in 1996 (see 1996 in country music) on Asylum Records.

title: Between Now and Forever
text: Like his debut album "Bryan White", it was certified platinum by the RIAA for U.S. sales of one million copies.

title: Between Now and Forever
text: The album produced four singles for White on the "Billboard" Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now Hot Country Songs) charts.

title: Between Now and Forever
text: In order of release, these were "I'm Not Supposed to Love You Anymore" (number 4), "So Much for Pretending" (number 1), "That's Another Song" (number 15), and "Sittin' on Go" (number 1).

title: Between Now and Forever
text: "Sittin' on Go" was also his last Number One hit.

title: Two Car Garage
text: "Two Car Garage" is a song recorded by American country music artist B. J. Thomas.

title: Two Car Garage
text: It was released in November 1983 as the first single from his album "The Great American Dream".

title: Two Car Garage
text: The song reached #3 on the "Billboard" Hot Country Singles chart in February 1984 and #1 on the "RPM" Country Tracks chart in Canada.

title: Two Car Garage
text: The song was written J. D. Martin and Gary Harrison.

title: Bryan White
text: Bryan Shelton White (born February 17, 1974) is an American country music artist.

title: Bryan White
text: Signed to Asylum Records in 1994 at age 20, White released his self-titled debut album that year.

title: Bryan White
text: Both it and its follow-up, 1996's "Between Now and Forever", were certified platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America, and 1997's "The Right Place" was certified gold.

title: Bryan White
text: His fourth album, 1999's "How Lucky I Am", produced 2 top 40 singles, with the song "God Gave Me You" eventually becoming a big hit in the Philippines.

title: Domestic Life (song)
text: "Domestic Life" is a song written by J.D. Martin and Gary Harrison, and recorded by American country music artist John Conlee.

title: Domestic Life (song)
text: It was released in February 1987 as the first single from the album "American Faces".

title: Domestic Life (song)
text: The song reached #4 on the "Billboard" Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart.

title: Look at Me Now (Bryan White song)
text: "Look at Me Now" is a song co-written and recorded by American country music artist Bryan White.

title: Look at Me Now (Bryan White song)
text: It was released in December 1994 as the second single from the album "Bryan White".

title: Look at Me Now (Bryan White song)
text: The song reached number 24 on the "Billboard" Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart.

title: Look at Me Now (Bryan White song)
text: White wrote the song with Derek George and John Tirro.

title: Strawberry Wine (Deana Carter song)
text: "Strawberry Wine" is the title of a debut song written by Matraca Berg and Gary Harrison, and recorded by American country music artist Deana Carter.

title: Strawberry Wine (Deana Carter song)
text: It was released in August 1996 as the lead-off single from Carter's debut album "Did I Shave My Legs for This?

title: Strawberry Wine (Deana Carter song)
text: The song went on to peak at No. 1 on the Billboard Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart, and the Canadian "RPM" Country Tracks.

title: She Dreams
text: "She Dreams" is a song co-written by Tim Mensy and Gary Harrison.

title: She Dreams
text: It was originally recorded by Mensy on his 1993 album "This Ol' Heart" (produced by James Stroud), from which it was released as the third and final single.

title: She Dreams
text: It was also the final single release of his career.

title: She Dreams
text: It was recorded by American country music artist Mark Chesnutt and released in July 1994 as the lead single from the album, "What a Way to Live".

title: She Dreams
text: It peaked at number 6 on the U.S. "Billboard" Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart and at number 7 on the Canadian "RPM" Country Tracks chart.

title: Gary Harrison
text: Harrison began his career in the 1970s and has written over 300 major-label recorded songs including several number-one hits.

title: Gary Harrison
text: His songwriting credits include ; "Hey Cinderella" (recorded by Suzy Bogguss); "I Hate Everything" a number-one recording by George Strait); "I Just Wanted You to Know" (recorded by Mark Chesnutt); "I Thought It Was You" (recorded by Doug Stone); "Lying in Love with You" (recorded by Jim Ed Brown and Helen Cornelius); "Strawberry Wine" (with Matraca Berg, recorded by Deana Carter); "Wild Angels" (with Matraca Berg; recorded by Martina McBride); "Wrong Side of Memphis" (with Matraca Berg, recorded by Trisha Yearwood), and "That Train Don't Run" (recorded by Pinmonkey).

title: Gary Harrison
text: Other artists who have recorded his work include Kenny Chesney, Tim McGraw, Easton Corbin, Patty Loveless, Keith Whitley, John Michael Montgomery, Billy Ray Cyrus, Charley Pride, Anne Murray, Mindy McCready, Diamond Rio, Sammy Kershaw, Emmylou Harris, Ronnie Milsap, Highway 101, Molly Hatchet, Johnny Lee, Neal McCoy, Reba McEntire, Joe Nichols, Bob Welch, Nitty Gritty Dirt Band, Kenny Rogers, Matraca Berg, Pam Tillis, Crystal Gayle, Brenda Lee, B. J. Thomas, Alabama, Michelle Wright, Loverboy, Randy Travis, The Oak Ridge Boys, Conway Twitty, Barbara Mandrell, Lonestar, Steve Wariner, Joe Diffie, Michael Martin Murphey, Marty Balin, Cindy Alexander, Kim Carnes, Keith Stegall, Shawn Camp, Lee Greenwood, Russ Taff, George Canyon, The Kendalls, Chris LeDoux, Sylvia, Mickey Gilley, Eddy Raven, John Conlee, Bryan White, Blaine Larsen, Tammy Cochran, John Berry, Rick Trevino, Marie Osmond, Eric Heatherly, Pirates of the Mississippi, Chely Wright, and Robin Lee.

title: I Just Wanted You to Know
text: "I Just Wanted You to Know" is a song written by Tim Mensy and Gary Harrison and recorded by American country music singer Mark Chesnutt.

title: I Just Wanted You to Know
text: It was released in December 1993 as the third single from his album "Almost Goodbye".

title: I Just Wanted You to Know
text: The song reached number-one on the U.S. "Billboard" Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now Hot Country Songs) chart and on the Canadian "RPM" Country Tracks chart.

title: 1976 German Grand Prix
text: The 1976 German Grand Prix (formally the XXXVIII Großer Preis von Deutschland) was a Formula One motor race held at the Nürburgring on 1 August 1976.

title: 1976 German Grand Prix
text: It was the scene of reigning world champion Niki Lauda's near fatal accident, and the last Formula One race to be held on the Nordschleife section of the track.

title: 1976 German Grand Prix
text: The 14-lap race was the tenth round of the 1976 Formula One season and was won by James Hunt.

title: 1974 German Grand Prix
text: The 1974 German Grand Prix was a Formula One motor race held at the Nürburgring on 4 August 1974.

title: 1974 German Grand Prix
text: It was race 11 of 15 in both the 1974 World Championship of Drivers and the 1974 International Cup for Formula One Manufacturers.

title: 1974 German Grand Prix
text: It was the 36th German Grand Prix and the 33rd to be held at the Nürburgring complex of circuits.

title: 1974 German Grand Prix
text: The race was won by Swiss driver Clay Regazzoni driving a Ferrari 312B3.

title: 1974 German Grand Prix
text: Regazzoni led every lap on the way to his second Grand Prix victory, some four years after his debut victory at the 1970 Italian Grand Prix.

title: 1974 German Grand Prix
text: South African driver Jody Scheckter was second driving a Tyrrell 007 ahead of Argentine driver Carlos Reutemann (Brabham BT44).

title: 1959 German Grand Prix
text: The 1959 German Grand Prix was a Formula One motor race held at the Automobil-Verkehrs- und Übungs-Straße in West Berlin on 2 August 1959.

title: 1959 German Grand Prix
text: It was race 6 of 9 in the 1959 World Championship of Drivers and race 5 of 8 in the 1959 International Cup for Formula One Manufacturers.

title: 1959 German Grand Prix
text: It was the 21st German Grand Prix and was only the second time the race was not held at the Nürburgring.

title: 1959 German Grand Prix
text: AVUS had previously held the original German Grand Prix in 1926.

title: 1959 German Grand Prix
text: The race was held over two 30 lap heats of the eight kilometre circuit for a total race distance of 498 kilometres.

title: Christian Goethals
text: Christian Roger Xavier Marie Joseph Ghislain Goethals (4 August 1928 in Heule – 26 February 2003 in Kortrijk) was a racing driver from Belgium.

title: Christian Goethals
text: Goethals competed as an amateur in sports car races, driving a Porsche Spyder during the 1950s.

title: Christian Goethals
text: His best results were a second-place finish with his brother in the 1956 1500cc class event in Reims, and a win in the same class the following year at Forez.

title: Christian Goethals
text: Goethals acquired a Cooper-Climax and entered it in the Formula Two class of the 1958 German Grand Prix, but retired from the race.

title: Christian Goethals
text: He did not participate in another Formula One Grand Prix, and returned to sports cars, with notable finishes in 1960 of fifth in the Buenos Aires 1000 km and second in the GP de Spa.

title: Christian Goethals
text: He retired from racing later in the season.

title: Christian Goethals
text: He established a racing team called "Écurie Éperon d'Or" to participate in the 1958 German Grand Prix where he raced in a Cooper T43.

title: Klenk
text: The Klenk-Meteor was a racing car which competed in the 1954 German Grand Prix.

title: Klenk
text: The car was based on the established German marque of Veritas which was active between 1948 and 1953.

title: Klenk
text: Veritas is chiefly remembered as a manufacturer of sports cars and successful Formula Two racing cars.

title: Klenk
text: The company closed when its founder, Ernst Loof, became ill.

title: Klenk
text: He subsequently died in 1956.

title: Klenk
text: The Klenk-Meteor entered for the 1954 German Grand Prix was essentially a Veritas Formula Two car.

title: Klenk
text: The car was owned and prepared by the noted German racing driver Hans Klenk who intended to race it himself in the Grand Prix.

title: Klenk
text: However, Klenk's career as a racing driver came to an end when he suffered injuries in an accident while working as a test driver for Mercedes-Benz.

title: Klenk
text: The car was driven in the Grand Prix by another German, Theo Helfrich.

title: Klenk
text: He retired on lap 9 with engine failure.

title: Racing helmet
text: A racing helmet is a form of protective headgear worn by racing car and rally drivers.

title: Racing helmet
text: Motor racing has long been known to be an exceptionally risky sport: sudden deceleration forces on the head can easily occur if a racing car loses control at the very high speeds of competitive motor racing or the rough terrain experienced in rallying.

title: Racing helmet
text: A risk more nearly unique to motor racing is the possibility of drastically severe burns from fuel igniting when the fuel lines or fuel tank of the vehicle are jolted sufficiently to dislodge or breach them in a situation in which the driver cannot soon enough escape from his car.

title: Racing helmet
text: This happened to world champion driver Niki Lauda at the 1976 German Grand Prix race at the Nürburgring in a crash from which he barely escaped alive.

title: James Hunt
text: James Simon Wallis Hunt (29 August 1947 – 15 June 1993) was a British racing driver who won the Formula One World Championship in .

title: James Hunt
text: After retiring from racing in 1979, Hunt became a media commentator and businessman.

title: 1976 German motorcycle Grand Prix
text: The 1976 German motorcycle Grand Prix was the eleventh round of the 1976 Grand Prix motorcycle racing season.

title: 1976 German motorcycle Grand Prix
text: It took place on 29 August 1976 at the Nürburgring circuit.

title: 1976 German motorcycle Grand Prix
text: The 500cc race was known for being the distinguished Giacomo Agostini's 122nd and final victory in Grand Prix motorcycle competition, a record that still stands today.

title: 2013 German Grand Prix
text: The 2013 German Grand Prix (formally known as the Formula 1 Großer Preis Santander von Deutschland 2013) was a Formula One motor race that was held on 7 July 2013 at the Nürburgring in Nürburg, Germany.

title: 2013 German Grand Prix
text: The race was the ninth round of the 2013 season, and marked the 74th running of the German Grand Prix overall, and the 60th running of the German Grand Prix since 1950, when the racing series now known as the Formula One World Championship was created.

title: 2013 German Grand Prix
text: This is the earliest a German Grand Prix has been held in a calendar year, followed by the 1926 and the 2009 editions of the race.

title: 1984 European Grand Prix
text: The 1984 European Grand Prix was a Formula One motor race held at Nürburgring on 7 October 1984.

title: 1984 European Grand Prix
text: It was the fifteenth round of the 1984 Formula One season.

title: 1984 European Grand Prix
text: This was the first time a Formula One race was run on the new 4.54 km (2.82 mi) Nürburgring GP-Strecke and the first time F1 had returned to the 'Ring since the 1976 German Grand Prix that was held on the old 22.835 km (14.19 mi) Nordschleife circuit.

title: 2002 Asian Junior Athletics Championships
text: The 2002 Asian Junior Athletics Championships was the tenth edition of the international athletics competition for Asian under-20 athletes, organised by the Asian Athletics Association.

title: 2002 Asian Junior Athletics Championships
text: It took place from 28–31 October in Bangkok, Thailand.

title: 2002 Asian Junior Athletics Championships
text: A total of 43 events were contested, which were divided equally between male and female athletes aside from the men's 3000 metres steeplechase.

title: 1999 Asian Junior Athletics Championships
text: The 1999 Asian Junior Athletics Championships was the eighth edition of the international athletics competition for Asian under-20 athletes, organised by the Asian Athletics Association.

title: 1999 Asian Junior Athletics Championships
text: It took place from 30 September to 3 October in Singapore.

title: 1999 Asian Junior Athletics Championships
text: A total of 43 events were contested, which were divided equally between male and female athletes aside from the men's 3000 metres steeplechase.

title: 2008 Asian Junior Athletics Championships
text: The 2008 Asian Junior Athletics Championships was the 13th edition of the international athletics competition for Asian under-20 athletes, organised by the Asian Athletics Association.

title: 2008 Asian Junior Athletics Championships
text: It took place from 12–15 July at the Madya Stadium in Jakarta.

title: 2008 Asian Junior Athletics Championships
text: It was the third occasion that the Indonesian capital had hosted the event, following the inaugural edition in 1986 and the fifth hosting in 1994.

title: 2008 Asian Junior Athletics Championships
text: A total of 44 events were contested, which were divided equally between male and female athletes.

title: 3000 metres steeplechase
text: The 3000 metres steeplechase or 3000-meter steeplechase is the most common distance for the steeplechase in track and field.

title: 3000 metres steeplechase
text: It is an obstacle race over the distance of the 3000 metres, which derives its name from the horse racing steeplechase.

title: Shane Niemi
text: Shane Niemi (born June 2, 1978 in Kamloops, British Columbia) is a retired Canadian sprints athlete.

title: Shane Niemi
text: As a 17 year old he took the bronze medal in the 400 metres at the 1995 Pan American Junior Athletics Championships behind Obea Moore's still standing World Youth Best.

title: Shane Niemi
text: The same three athletes (Jerome Young in silver position) finished in the same order at the 1996 World Junior Championships in Athletics.

title: Shane Niemi
text: He returned to the 1997 Pan American Junior Athletics Championships to take the gold medal in the event.

title: Shane Niemi
text: He was not able to make the qualifying standard for the 2000 Olympics.

title: Shane Niemi
text: He ran his personal record, the Canadian record, 44.86 at the 2001 Jeux de la Francophonie (French Games) on home soil in Ottawa to take gold.

title: Shane Niemi
text: He didn't have the same magic at the home field 2001 World Championships in Athletics but the following year took silver in a tight battle at the 2002 Commonwealth Games beating the world champion Avard Moncur.

title: Shane Niemi
text: He won six straight Canadian championships between 1998 and 2003.

title: Shane Niemi
text: Unable to make the qualifying mark to the 2004 Olympics, he retired in late 2004.

title: 2010 Asian Junior Athletics Championships
text: The 2010 Asian Junior Athletics Championships was the 14th edition of the international athletics competition for Asian under-20 athletes, organised by the Asian Athletics Association.

title: 2010 Asian Junior Athletics Championships
text: It took place from 1 to 4 July 2010 at the My Dinh National Stadium in Hanoi – the first time the competition was held in Vietnam.

title: 2010 Asian Junior Athletics Championships
text: A total of 44 events were contested, which were divided equally between male and female athletes.

title: 2010 Asian Junior Athletics Championships
text: Three championship records were improved over the course of the four-day competition and numerous national junior records were also bettered.

title: 2010 Asian Junior Athletics Championships
text: The competition, including its opening and closing ceremonies, was broadcast live on Vietnamese carrier VTV3.

title: 2004 Asian Junior Athletics Championships
text: The 2004 Asian Junior Athletics Championships was the eleventh edition of the international athletics competition for Asian under-20 athletes, organised by the Asian Athletics Association.

title: 2004 Asian Junior Athletics Championships
text: It took place from 12–15 June at the Perak Stadium in Ipoh, Malaysia.

title: 2004 Asian Junior Athletics Championships
text: A total of 43 events were contested, which were divided equally between male and female athletes aside from the men's 3000 metres steeplechase.

title: 2001 Asian Junior Athletics Championships
text: The 2001 Asian Junior Athletics Championships was the ninth edition of the international athletics competition for Asian under-20 athletes, organised by the Asian Athletics Association.

title: 2001 Asian Junior Athletics Championships
text: It took place from 19–22 July in Bandar Seri Begawan, Brunei.

title: 2001 Asian Junior Athletics Championships

title: Asian Junior Athletics Championships

text: It took place from 9 to 12 June at the Sugathadasa Stadium in Colombo, Sri Lanka – the same venue hosted the 2002 Asian Athletics Championships.

text: Thirty-four nations took part in the event and over five hundred athletes participated.

title: Lu Lu (badminton)
text: Lu Lu (; born 29 September 1990) is a retired Chinese female badminton player.

title: Lu Lu (badminton)
text: In 2008, she won gold medal in the mixed team event at the World Junior Championships.

title: Lu Lu (badminton)
text: In the individual event, she won mixed doubles silver and girls' doubles bronze.

title: Lu Lu (badminton)
text: She also competed at the Asian Junior Championships, and won the girls' doubles silver medal, and gold medals in the mixed team and doubles event.

title: Lu Lu (badminton)
text: Partnered with Zhang Nan, Lu became the champion at the 2009 Philippines Open.

title: Lu Lu (badminton)
text: In 2010, she became the women's doubles runner-up at the China Masters Super Series tournament with Bao Yixin.

title: Williams sisters
text: The Williams sisters are two professional American tennis players: Venus Williams (b. 1980), a seven-time Grand Slam title winner (singles), and Serena Williams (b. 1981), twenty-three-time Grand Slam title winner (singles), both of whom were coached from an early age by their parents Richard Williams and Oracene Price.

title: Williams sisters
text: There is a noted professional rivalry between them – between the 2001 US Open and the 2017 Australian Open tournaments, they met in nine Grand Slam singles finals.

title: Williams sisters
text: They became the first two players, female or male, to play in 4 consecutive grand slam singles finals from the 2002 French Open to the 2003 Australian Open; Serena famously won all 4 to complete the first of two "Serena Slams".

title: Williams sisters
text: Between 2000 and 2016, a 17-year span, they collectively won 12 Wimbledon singles titles (Venus won 5 and Serena won 7).

title: Williams sisters
text: By winning the 2001 Australian Open women's doubles title, they became the 5th pair to complete the Career Doubles Grand Slam and the only pair to complete the Career Doubles Golden Slam.

title: Williams sisters
text: At the time, Venus and Serena were only 20 and 19 years old, respectively.

title: Williams sisters
text: Since then they have gone on to add another two Olympic gold medals in the 2008 Beijing Olympics and the 2012 London Olympics.

title: Williams sisters
text: Nearly a decade later, the duo would go on to win 4 consecutive grand slam doubles titles from 2009 Wimbledon through 2010 Roland Garros, which would catapult them to co-No.

title: Williams sisters
text: 1 doubles players on 7 June 2010.

title: Williams sisters
text: Two weeks later, on 21 June 2010, Serena would hold the No. 1 singles ranking and Venus would be right behind her at No. 2 in singles.

title: Williams sisters
text: Their most recent grand slam doubles titles came at the 2012 Wimbledon & 2016 Wimbledon events.

title: Williams sisters
text: They remain very close, often watching each other's matches in support, even after one of them has been knocked out of a tournament.

title: Fred McNair
text: Frederick V. McNair IV (born July 22, 1950 in Washington, D.C.) is a former professional tennis player from the United States who reached the World No. 1 doubles ranking in 1976.

title: Fred McNair
text: That year, he teamed up with Sherwood Stewart to capture the men's doubles titles at French Open, the German Open and the Masters.

title: Fred McNair
text: McNair was also a mixed doubles runner-up at the French Open in 1981, partnering Betty Stöve.

title: Fred McNair
text: In 1978, he was a member of the US team that won the Davis Cup.

title: Fred McNair
text: In nine years on the professional tour, McNair won 16 doubles titles.

title: Fred McNair
text: His career-high singles ranking was World No. 67.

title: Bahaedeen Ahmad Alshannik
text: Bahaedeen Ahmad Alshannik (born 18 July 1997) is a Jordanian male badminton player.

title: Bahaedeen Ahmad Alshannik
text: He was the mixed doubles runner-up at the Morocco International tournament in 2014 and 2015, and also men's doubles runner-up in 2015.

title: Bahaedeen Ahmad Alshannik
text: At the Egypt International tournament he became the runner-up in the men's doubles event.

title: Bahaedeen Ahmad Alshannik
text: He won her first international title at the 2017 Uganda International tournament in the mixed doubles event partnered with Domou Amro.

title: Bahaedeen Ahmad Alshannik
text: At the Cameroon, he won double title when he captured the men's singles and doubles event.

title: Jeff Tarango
text: Jeffrey Gail ("Jeff") Tarango (born November 20, 1968) is a retired American professional tennis player.

title: Jeff Tarango
text: He was a Top 10 doubles player and a runner-up at the 1999 French Open Men's Doubles tournament.

title: Jeff Tarango
text: At Wimbledon in 1995, he defaulted a match after a dispute with the umpire, and his wife assaulted the umpire once Tarango had left the court.

title: 1999 French Open – Women's Doubles
text: Martina Hingis and Jana Novotná were the defending champions, but they did not compete together this year.

title: 1999 French Open – Women's Doubles
text: Novotná instead partnered with Natasha Zvereva as the first seed, whereas Hingis partnered with Anna Kournikova as the second seed.

title: 1999 French Open – Women's Doubles
text: Novotná and Zvereva retired in their quarterfinal match against Lindsay Davenport and Mary Pierce, but Hingis and Kournikova reached the final where they lost to American sisters Serena and Venus Williams, 6–3, 6–7, 8–6.

title: 1999 French Open – Women's Doubles
text: This was the first Grand Slam for the Williams sisters and would be their first step towards completing a Career Golden Slam in doubles.

title: Anna Kournikova
text: Anna Sergeyevna Kournikova (Russian: А́нна Серге́евна Ку́рникова ; ] ; born 7 June 1981) is a Russian former professional tennis player.

title: Anna Kournikova
text: Her appearance and celebrity status made her one of the best known tennis stars worldwide.

title: Anna Kournikova
text: At the peak of her fame, fans looking for images of Kournikova made her name one of the most common search strings on Google Search.

title: Garbiñe Muguruza career statistics
text: This is a list of the main career statistics of Spanish professional tennis player, Garbiñe Muguruza.

title: Garbiñe Muguruza career statistics
text: To date, Muguruza has won five WTA singles titles – most significantly the 2016 French Open and the 2017 Wimbledon Championships– and five WTA doubles titles.

title: Garbiñe Muguruza career statistics
text: Other highlights of Muguruza's career thus far include reaching the final of the 2015 Wimbledon Championships, quarterfinal appearances at the French Open in 2014 and 2015; two runner-up finishes in doubles at the Madrid Open in 2014 and 2015 and a semi-final appearance in doubles at the 2014 French Open alongside Carla Suárez Navarro.
