text: Savarni's sons would be headed by Nirmoka, and among the demigods are the Sutapas.

title: Savarni Manu
text: Bali, the son of Virochana, is Indra, and Galava and Parashurama are among the seven sages.

title: Savarni Manu
text: In this age of Manu, the incarnation of the Supreme Personality of Godhead appears as Sarvabhauma, the son of Devaguhya and Sarasvati.

title: Savarni Manu
text: On the name of this Manu the only Ashram i.e. S S M Ashramam i.e Surya Savarnika Manavu Ashramam has been established at Garlavoddu, in India.

title: Payne baronets
text: The Payne Baronetcy, of St Christopher's in the West Indies, was a title in the Baronetage of Great Britain.

title: Payne baronets
text: It was created on 31 October 1737 for Charles Payne.

title: Payne baronets
text: According to some sources that title became extinct on the death of the second Baronet, Sir Gillis Payne, in 1801.

title: Payne baronets
text: Sir Gillis was in a relationship with a farmer's daughter, Maria Keeling.

title: Payne baronets
text: They apparently married in 1761 although several children had been born before this date.

title: Payne baronets
text: Peter Payne was the eldest son born after the marriage and would normally have succeeded in the title.

title: Payne baronets
text: However, he allowed his eldest brother John Payne to assume the title, although John was illegitimate.

title: Payne baronets
text: John died in 1803 when his son Charles assumed the title.

title: Payne baronets
text: However, in 1828 Peter Payne raised the question in the courts over who was the rightful baronet.

title: Payne baronets
text: The Court of Chancery declared that he was the rightful heir to his father, but this was overturned by the Lord Chancellor in 1829.

title: Payne baronets
text: Nonetheless, during his lifetime Sir Peter was universally acknowledged as a baronet.

title: Payne baronets
text: Most reference books on the British nobility and baronetage include the title, although they describe it as being in dispute between rival branches of the family.

title: Payne baronets
text: Charles Robert Salusbury Payne, the supposed sixth Baronet, appears to have discontinued the claim around 1900.

title: Fannie Lee Chaney
text: Fannie Lee Chaney (September 4, 1921 – May 22, 2007) was an American baker turned civil rights activist after her son James Chaney was murdered by the Ku Klux Klan during the 1964 Freedom Summer rides in Mississippi.

title: Conrad Black
text: Conrad Moffat Black, Lord Black of Crossharbour, KSG (born 25 August 1944) is a Canadian-born British former newspaper publisher and author.

title: Conrad Black
text: He is a non-affiliated life peer.

title: RAF Bomber Command Memorial
text: The Royal Air Force Bomber Command Memorial is a memorial in Green Park, London, commemorating the crews of RAF Bomber Command who embarked on missions during the Second World War.

title: RAF Bomber Command Memorial
text: The memorial, located on Piccadilly near Hyde Park Corner, was built to mark the sacrifice of 55,573 aircrew from Britain, Canada, Czechoslovakia, Poland and other countries of the Commonwealth, as well as civilians of all nations killed during raids.

title: Canada Memorial
text: The Canada Memorial in Green Park, London, United Kingdom, commemorates members of the Canadian Forces killed during the First and Second World Wars.

title: Canada Memorial
text: It was designed by the Canadian sculptor Pierre Granche, erected in 1992 and unveiled by Queen Elizabeth II in 1994.

title: Canada Memorial
text: The memorial was the result of lobbying and fund raising, much of it in Canada, by the former Canadian media tycoon Conrad Black.

title: Cenotaph War Memorial, Colombo
text: The Cenotaph War Memorial in Viharamahadevi Park, Colombo, Sri Lanka is dedicated to the military personal from Ceylon killed in action during the two world wars.

title: Cenotaph War Memorial, Colombo
text: It comprises a towering Cenotaph and Memorial Walls.

title: Cenotaph War Memorial, Colombo
text: The foundation stone was laid by Brigadier General Sir William Henry Manning, Governor of Ceylon on December 7, 1921 and was unveiled by him October 27, 1923 at the Galle Face Green and was known as the Victory tower.

title: Cenotaph War Memorial, Colombo
text: It was dismantled and re-erected at Victoria Park, during World War II after fears that the Japanese might use it as a marker to direct their artillery.

title: Cenotaph War Memorial, Colombo
text: The Cenotaph contains the names of those killed in the Great War, while the Memorial Wall behind it maintains the names of those killed in the Second World War.

title: Cenotaph War Memorial, Colombo
text: A single woman, Miss L. Midwood is listed among the dead of the Great war.

title: African and Caribbean War Memorial
text: The African and Caribbean War Memorial in Brixton, London, is the United Kingdom's national memorial to African and Caribbean service personnel who fought in the First and Second World Wars.

title: African and Caribbean War Memorial
text: It originated with a project for a memorial to Caribbean Royal Air Force veterans of World War II who arrived in Britain in 1948 on the MV "Empire Windrush"; this was an extension of the commemorative plaque and sculpture scheme run by the Nubian Jak Community Trust to highlight the historic contributions of Black and minority ethnic people in Britain.

title: African and Caribbean War Memorial
text: The memorial was originally to have been placed at Tilbury Docks, as part of the commemoration for the centenary of the outbreak of World War I. However, as the project began to evolve into a larger tribute that included both World Wars and commemorated servicemen and women from both Africa and the Caribbean, it was agreed by the memorial recipient – the Port of Tilbury – and the project organisers that a new, more accessible location needed to found.

title: African and Caribbean War Memorial
text: The memorial was ultimately permanently installed and unveiled on 22 June 2017 in Windrush Square, Brixton.

title: Peacekeeper Park
text: Peacekeeper Park is an urban park in Calgary, Alberta.

title: Peacekeeper Park
text: The park is located in the neighbourhood of North Glenmore, on the former grounds of Canadian Forces Base Calgary.

title: Peacekeeper Park
text: The park includes a memorial wall with the names of Canadian Forces members who have given their lives on peacekeeping and peace support missions with the United Nations, NATO and other organizations since the end of the Second World War, including the current mission in Afghanistan.

title: Portsmouth Naval Memorial
text: The Portsmouth Naval Memorial, sometimes known as Southsea Naval Memorial, is a war memorial in Portsmouth, Hampshire, England, on Southsea Common beside Clarence Esplanade, between Clarence Pier and Southsea Castle.

title: Portsmouth Naval Memorial
text: The memorial commemorates approximately 25,000 British and Commonwealth sailors who were lost in the World Wars, around 10,000 sailors in the First World War and 15,000 in the Second World War.

title: Portsmouth Naval Memorial
text: The memorial features a central obelisk, with names of the dead on bronze plaques arranged around the memorial according to the year of death.

title: CFB London
text: Canadian Forces Base London (also CFB London) is a former Canadian Forces Base that was located in London, Ontario, Canada.

title: CFB London
text: It was downsized and closed during defence budget cutbacks in the 1990s.

title: CFB London
text: Local Primary Reserve units were supported by Area Support Unit (ASU) London which was located in some of the remaining base buildings, but they are now supported by ASU Toronto.

title: CFB London
text: Much of this support is delivered by a Technical Services Platoon which remains stationed in London.

title: Armed Forces Memorial
text: The Armed Forces Memorial is a national memorial in the United Kingdom, dedicated to the 16,000 servicemen and women of the British Armed Forces killed on duty or through terrorist action since after the Second World War.

title: Armed Forces Memorial
text: It is within the National Memorial Arboretum in Staffordshire.

title: Parliamentary War Memorial
text: The Parliamentary War Memorial, also known as the Recording Angel Memorial, is a stone sculpture in Westminster Hall, unveiled in 1922, which commemorates the members of both Houses of Parliament of the United Kingdom who died in the First World War.

title: Parliamentary War Memorial
text: It names 22 members of the House of Commons, 20 members of the House of Lords, and 9 senior members of staff, together with another 94 sons of members and officers of the House of Commons, who lost their lives in the war.

title: Parliamentary War Memorial
text: (Sons of peers and of officers of the House of Lords are commemorated on the wooden panels of the House of Lords War Memorial in the Royal Gallery.)

title: Parliamentary War Memorial
text: Above the memorial is a large stained glass window which commemorates members and staff of both Houses who died in the Second World War.

title: WNP-1 and WNP-4
text: Washington Nuclear Project Nos. 1 and 4, abbreviated as WNP-1 and WNP-4 were two of the five nuclear power plants on which construction was started by the Washington Public Power Supply System (WPPSS) in order to meet projected electricity demand in the Pacific Northwest.

title: WNP-1 and WNP-4
text: WNP-1, WNP-2 and WNP-3 were part of the original 1968 plan, with WNP-4 (a twin to WNP-1 and located at the same site) and WNP-5 (a twin to WNP-3, in similar fashion) added in the early 1970s.

title: Railway Express Agency Building
text: The Railway Express Agency Building was a historic building located at 1804 Western Avenue in Mattoon, Illinois.

title: Railway Express Agency Building
text: The building was constructed in 1918 to serve as the Mattoon office of the Railway Express Agency.

title: Railway Express Agency Building
text: The Railway Express Agency provided rail express shipping services to Mattoon's citizens, allowing them to ship money and packages along Mattoon's two major railways, the Illinois Central Railroad and Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago and St. Louis (Big Four).

title: Railway Express Agency Building
text: The agency formed in 1917, when the federal government ordered that all existing express services consolidate into a single service; this measure ensured consistent shipping of goods during World War I.

title: Railway Express Agency Building
text: The agency shipped goods to and from Mattoon until 1964, when the Big Four went bankrupt; the building served as a freight depot until 1971.

title: WNP-3 and WNP-5
text: Washington Nuclear Project Nos. 3 and 5, abbreviated as WNP-3 and WNP-5 (collectively known as the Satsop Nuclear Power Plant) were two of the five nuclear power plants on which construction was started by the Washington Public Power Supply System (WPPSS) in order to meet projected electricity demand in the Pacific Northwest.

title: WNP-3 and WNP-5
text: WNP-1, WNP-2 and WNP-3 were part of the original 1968 plan, with WNP-4 (a twin to WNP-1 and located at the same site) and WNP-5 (a twin to WNP-3, in similar fashion) added in the early 1970s.

title: Energy Northwest
text: Energy Northwest (formerly Washington Public Power Supply System) is a United States public power joint operating agency formed by State law in 1957 to produce at-cost power for Northwest utilities.

title: Energy Northwest
text: Headquartered in Richland, Washington, the WPPSS became commonly known as "Whoops" due to over-commitment to nuclear power in the 1970s which brought about financial collapse and the second largest municipal bond default in U.S. history.

title: Energy Northwest
text: WPPSS was renamed Energy Northwest in November 1998.

title: Energy Northwest
text: Agency membership includes 28 public power utilities, including 23 of the state’s 24 public utility districts.

title: Road Safety Authority
text: The Road Safety Authority (Irish: "Údarás Um Shábháilteacht Ar Bhóithre" ) or RSA, is a state agency formed by the Irish Government to promote road safety.

title: Road Safety Authority
text: The agency has devolved control of much of the work of the Department of Transport.

title: Anti-Corruption Commission Seychelles
text: The Anti-Corruption Commission Seychelles (abbreviated ACCS) is an independent Seychellois government agency formed under the Anti-Corruption Act 2016.

title: Anti-Corruption Commission Seychelles
text: Formed in March 2016 after the National Assembly enacted the "Anti-Corruption Law No. 6 of 2016", the agency is charged with receiving complaints, investigating, detecting and preventing corruption-related practices in Seychelles.

title: Extraordinary State Commission
text: The Extraordinary State Commission was a Soviet government agency formed by the Council of People's Commissars on 2 November 1942, by a decree of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet.

title: Extraordinary State Commission
text: It was tasked with investigating World War II crimes against the Soviet Union and collecting documentation which would confirm material losses caused by Nazi Germany.

title: Extraordinary State Commission
text: Its full ceremonial name was: ""Extraordinary State Commission for Ascertaining and Investigating Crimes Perpetrated by the German-Fascist Invaders and their Accomplices"" (Russian: Чрезвычайная Государственная Комиссия , ChGK).

title: Extraordinary State Commission
text: The official aim of this agency included "punishing for the crimes of the German–fascist aggressors."

title: Extraordinary State Commission
text: According to its own data, 32,000 organization staff took part in the work of ChGK and around 7,000,000 Soviet citizens had participated in the collection of materials and evidence.

title: Director General of the European Space Agency
text: The Director General of the European Space Agency is the highest-ranked official of the European Space Agency (ESA), a space agency formed by the collaboration of prominent European nations.

title: WorkCover Authority of New South Wales
text: The WorkCover Authority of New South Wales or WorkCover NSW is a New South Wales Government agency established in 1989.

title: WorkCover Authority of New South Wales
text: The agency creates regulations to promote productive, healthy and safe workplaces for workers and employers in New South Wales.

title: WorkCover Authority of New South Wales
text: The agency formed part of the Safety, Return to Work and Support Division established pursuant to the "Safety, Return to Work and Support Board Act, 2012" (NSW) .

title: Virginia State Board of Censors
text: The Virginia State Board of Censors was a government agency formed on August 1, 1922 for the purpose of reviewing and licensing films for approval to be screened in the state of Virginia.

title: Virginia State Board of Censors
text: During the agency's existence its members examined over 52,000 films, over 2,000 of which required edits before approval was given; and another 157 films were rejected entirely, of which only 38 won subsequent approval.

title: Virginia State Board of Censors
text: The board disbanded in 1968 following a series of U.S. Supreme Court rulings which overturned censorship statutes across the country.

title: Central–Wan Chai Bypass
text: The Central–Wan Chai Bypass is a four-kilometre trunk road, currently under construction, running between Sheung Wan and Fortress Hill on Hong Kong Island.

title: Central–Wan Chai Bypass
text: The original design consists of a 2.3 km dual three-lane tunnel running under new reclamation areas which will be provided by Central and Wan Chai Reclamation project, and also connections to Connaught Road West flyover and Island Eastern Corridor.

title: Central–Wan Chai Bypass
text: When completed, it will substitute Connaught Road Central, Harcourt Road, Gloucester Road and Victoria Park Road to be part of Route 4.

title: Wan Chai District Council
text: Wan Chai District Council () is the district council for the Wan Chai District in Hong Kong.

title: Wan Chai District Council
text: It is one of 18 district councils.

title: Wan Chai District Council
text: Wan Chai District currently consists of 13 members, of which the district is divided into 13 constituencies, electing a total of 13 members.

title: Wan Chai District Council
text: The latest election was held on 22 November 2015.

title: Wan Chai
text: Wan Chai ( ) is a metropolitan area situated at the western part of the Wan Chai District on the northern shore of Hong Kong Island, in Hong Kong.

title: Wan Chai
text: Its other boundaries are Canal Road to the east, Arsenal Street to the west and Bowen Road to the south.

title: Wan Chai
text: The area north of Gloucester Road is often referred to as Wan Chai North.

title: Wan Chai
text: Wan Chai is one of the busiest commercial areas in Hong Kong with offices of many small and medium-sized companies.

title: Wan Chai
text: Wan Chai North features office towers, parks, hotels and an international conference and exhibition centre.

title: Wan Chai
text: As one of the first areas developed in Hong Kong, the locale is densely populated yet with noticeable residential zones facing urban decay.

title: Wan Chai
text: Arousing considerable public concern, the government has undertaken several urban renewal projects in recent years.

title: Wan Chai
text: There are many unique landmarks and skyscrapers within the area, most notably the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre (HKCEC), Central Plaza and Hopewell Centre.

title: Wan Chai Cargo Handling Basin
text: The Wan Chai Cargo Handling Basin () is situated in Wan Chai, Hong Kong Island, Hong Kong.

title: Wan Chai Cargo Handling Basin
text: A prime site along Victoria Harbour, it is adjacent to the Wan Chai Sports Ground and located between the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre and the Royal Hong Kong Yacht Club.

title: Wan Chai Cargo Handling Basin
text: The site has been earmarked under the Central and Wan Chai Reclamation project for the construction of a highway linking Central with Causeway Bay, aimed at easing traffic congestion along the northern coast of Hong Kong Island.

title: Central Harbourfront
text: The Central Harbourfront is a waterfront site in Central, Hong Kong.

title: Central Harbourfront
text: It is the result of Central and Wan Chai Reclamation, and it sits to the east of ifc skyscraper.

title: International Finance Center Seoul
text: International Finance Centre Seoul(서울국제금융센터), commonly known IFC Seoul(아이 에프 시 서울), is a mixed-use integrated commercial development in Seoul, South Korea.

title: International Finance Center Seoul
text: It is located in Yeouido-dong, Yeongdeungpo-gu, Seoul, South Korea.

title: International Finance Center Seoul
text: The IFC project is one of the first large-scale developments in Korea, led by an international consortium.

title: International Finance Center Seoul
text: It was officially launched in 2005, and is part of Seoul Metropolitan Government's plan to rejuvenate the Yeouido area as a regional financial hub.

title: Central Plaza (Hong Kong)
text: Central Plaza is a 78-storey, 374 m skyscraper completed in August 1992 at 18 Harbour Road, in Wan Chai on Hong Kong Island in Hong Kong.

title: Central Plaza (Hong Kong)
text: It is the third tallest tower in the city after 2 International Finance Centre in Central and the ICC in West Kowloon.

title: Central Plaza (Hong Kong)
text: It was the tallest building in Asia from 1992 to 1996, until the Shun Hing Square in neighbouring Shenzhen was built.

title: Central Plaza (Hong Kong)
text: Central Plaza surpassed the Bank of China Tower as the tallest building in Hong Kong until the completion of 2 IFC.

title: International Finance Centre (Hong Kong)
text: The International Finance Centre (abbr.

title: International Finance Centre (Hong Kong)
text: IFC, branded as "ifc") is a skyscraper and an integrated commercial development on the waterfront of Hong Kong's Central District.

title: Lung Wo Road
text: Lung Wo Road (Chinese:龍和道) is a road between Central and Wan Chai, Hong Kong.

title: Lung Wo Road
text: It is constructed in three phases as part of the Central and Wan Chai Reclamation.

title: Lung Wo Road
text: The first two phases are completed by 2010 and 2011 respectively and the third is expected to be completed in 2017.

title: Wan Chai Sports Ground
text: Wan Chai Sports Ground () is a stadium in Wan Chai North, Hong Kong Island, Hong Kong, with a seating capacity of 2,401.

title: Wan Chai Sports Ground
text: It is a government-run sports ground primarily used by local schools for sports days and other athletic activities.

title: Wan Chai Sports Ground
text: Situated by the Victoria Harbour, it is at a convenient location next to Hong Kong's Central business district, Wan Chai, and the shopping district of Causeway Bay.

title: White Crosses
text: White Crosses (in German: "Weiße Kreuze") is a memorial for those who died during the Cold War at the Berlin Wall.

title: White Crosses
text: It is located at the shore of the river Spree in Berlin next to the Reichstag building, which houses the German parliament.

title: White Crosses
text: Established by the private group "Berliner Bürger-Verein" on the 10th anniversary of the Berlin Wall in 1971 it was first located east of the Reichstag on a fence directly in front of the wall.

title: White Crosses
text: After the German reunification in 1990 it kept its location until construction of the new government buildings next to the Reichstag was started at the end of that century – Berlin was chosen to be the new capital of Germany.

title: Reichstag building
text: The Reichstag (German: "Reichstagsgebäude" ] ; officially: "Deutscher Bundestag - Plenarbereich Reichstagsgebäude" ] ) is a historic edifice in Berlin, Germany, constructed to house the Imperial Diet (German: "Reichstag"), of the German Empire.

title: Reichstag building
text: It was opened in 1894 and housed the Diet until 1933, when it was severely damaged after being set on fire.

title: Reichstag building
text: After World War II, the building fell into disuse; the parliament of the German Democratic Republic (the "Volkskammer") met in the "Palast der Republik" in East Berlin, while the parliament of the Federal Republic of Germany (the "Bundestag") met in the "Bundeshaus" in Bonn.

title: Paul Wallot
text: Paul Wallot (26 June 1841 Oppenheim am Rhein – 10 August 1912 Bad Schwalbach) was a German architect of Huguenot descent, best known for designing the Reichstag building in Berlin, erected between 1884 and 1894.

title: Paul Wallot
text: He also built the adjacent Palace of the President of the Reichstag, finished in 1904, and the former Saxon "Ständehaus" state diet building of 1906 at Brühl's Terrace in Dresden.

title: Politics of Berlin
text: Berlin is a city-state and the capital of the Federal Republic of Germany.

title: Politics of Berlin
text: The President of Germany, whose functions are primarily ceremonial under the German constitution, has his official residence in Schloss Bellevue.

title: Politics of Berlin
text: Berlin is the seat of the German executive, housed in the Chancellery (the "Bundeskanzleramt").

title: Politics of Berlin
text: Facing the Chancellery is the Bundestag, the German Parliament, housed in the renovated Reichstag building since the government's move to Berlin in 1998.

title: Politics of Berlin
text: The Bundesrat ("federal council", functioning as an upper house) represents the Federal States ("Bundesländer") of Germany and has its seat at the former Prussian House of Lords.

title: Marinus van der Lubbe
text: Marinus (Rinus) van der Lubbe (13 January 1909 – 10 January 1934) was a Dutch council communist tried, convicted and executed for setting fire to the German Reichstag building on 27 February 1933, an event known as the Reichstag fire.

title: Kroll Opera House
text: The Kroll Opera House (German: "Krolloper, Kroll-Oper" ) was an opera building in Berlin, Germany, located in the central Tiergarten district on the western edge of the "Königsplatz" square (today "Platz der Republik"), facing the Reichstag building.

title: Kroll Opera House
text: It was built in 1844 as an entertainment venue for the restaurant owner Joseph Kroll.

title: Kroll Opera House
text: During its eventful history it was redeveloped as an opera house in 1851 and was used by various owners and directors for opera, operetta and drama.

title: Kroll Opera House
text: It was later operated by the Prussian state opera and drama companies and served as the assembly hall of the German Reichstag parliament from 1933 until 1942.

title: Kroll Opera House
text: On 19 July 1940, the opera house was used to host the 1940 Field Marshal Ceremony.

title: Kroll Opera House
text: Severely damaged by bombing and the Battle of Berlin in World War II, it was finally demolished in 1951.

title: Memorial to the Murdered Members of the Reichstag
text: The Memorial to the Murdered Members of the Reichstag is a memorial in Berlin, Germany.

title: Memorial to the Murdered Members of the Reichstag
text: The memorial is located in front of the Reichstag building, and commemorates the 96 members of the parliament who died unnaturally between 1933 and 1945 (1948).

title: Memorial to the Murdered Members of the Reichstag
text: The idea of creating the monument started in the 1980s, and the memorial was erected in September 1992.

title: Memorial to the Murdered Members of the Reichstag
text: It was designed by Dieter Appelt, Klaus W. Eisenlohr, Justus Müller and Christian Zwirner.

title: Memorial to the Murdered Members of the Reichstag
text: The memorial is made of 96 cast iron plates, with the names, birth and death dates and places engraved on the edges.

title: Memorial to the Murdered Members of the Reichstag
text: It has been designed so that it can be extended if new names are discovered in the future.

title: Reichstag fire
text: The Reichstag fire (German: "Reichstagsbrand" , ) was an arson attack on the Reichstag building (home of the German parliament) in Berlin on 27 February 1933, just one month after Adolf Hitler had been sworn in as Chancellor of Germany.

title: Reichstag fire
text: The Nazis stated that Marinus van der Lubbe, a Dutch council communist, was found near the building.

title: Reichstag fire
text: The Nazis publicly blamed the fire on communist agitators in general, although in a German court in 1933, it was decided that Van Der Lubbe had acted alone, as he claimed to have done.

title: Reichstag fire
text: After the fire, the Reichstag Fire Decree was passed.

title: Reichstag fire
text: The fire was used as evidence by the Nazi Party that communists were plotting against the German government.

title: Reichstag fire
text: The event is seen as pivotal in the establishment of Nazi Germany.

title: Bundestag (Berlin U-Bahn)
text: Bundestag is a Berlin U-Bahn station located on the U55 .

title: Bundestag (Berlin U-Bahn)
text: The name of this station was changed in April 2006 from Reichstag to Bundestag after deputations from the Bundestag which sits in the Reichstag building.

title: Mikhail Minin
text: Mikhail Petrovich Minin (Russian: Михаил Петрович Минин ) (July 29, 1922 – January 10, 2008) was a Russian Soviet soldier who was the first to enter the Reichstag building on April 30, 1945 during the Battle of Berlin, and the first soldier to mount the flag on the Reichstag building at 10:40 pm.

title: Gorgeous George (album)
text: Gorgeous George is the third solo studio album by Scottish musician Edwyn Collins.

title: Gorgeous George (album)
text: The album was recorded at New River in London, with Collins acting as the producer.

title: I'm Not Following You
text: I'm Not Following You is an album by Scottish musician Edwyn Collins released in 1997.

title: Doctor Syntax (album)
text: Doctor Syntax is an album by Scottish musician Edwyn Collins.

title: Hellbent on Compromise
text: Hellbent on Compromise is an album by a Scottish musician Edwyn Collins.

title: Paul Quinn (singer)
text: Paul Walter Quinn (born 1959) is a Scottish musician who was the lead singer of cult 1980s band Bourgie Bourgie, and also released records with Jazzateers, Vince Clarke and Edwyn Collins and sang on an early track by the French Impressionists.

title: A Casual Introduction 1981/2001
text: A Casual Introduction 1981/2001 is an album by Scottish musician Edwyn Collins.

title: A Casual Introduction 1981/2001
text: It is a collection of both his solo work and also work of Orange Juice, the band he fronted from 1979 to the mid-80s.

title: Hope and Despair
text: Hope and Despair is the debut solo album by Scottish musician Edwyn Collins.

title: Edwyn Collins
text: Edwyn Stephen Collins (born 23 August 1959) is a Scottish musician, producer and record label owner from Edinburgh, Scotland.

title: Edwyn Collins
text: Collins was the lead singer for the 1980s post-punk band Orange Juice, which he co-founded.

title: Edwyn Collins
text: Following the group's split in 1985, Collins started a solo career.

title: Edwyn Collins
text: His 1994 single "A Girl Like You" was a worldwide hit.

title: Orange Juice (band)
text: Orange Juice was a Scottish post-punk band founded in the Glasgow suburb of Bearsden as the Nu-Sonics in 1976.

title: Orange Juice (band)
text: Edwyn Collins formed the Nu-Sonics (named after a cheap brand of guitar) with his school-mate Alan Duncan and was subsequently joined by James Kirk and Steven Daly, who left a band called The Machetes.

title: Orange Juice (band)
text: The band became Orange Juice in 1979.

title: Orange Juice (band)
text: They are best known for the hit "Rip It Up", which reached number 8 on the UK Singles Chart in February 1983, the band's only UK Top 40 hit.

title: Jimmie Ross
text: Jimmie Ross is an American rock guitarist and vocalist who is best known for being a member of Pittsburgh band the Jaggerz, known for their 1970 hit "The Rapper".

title: Jimmie Ross
text: During the band's initial existence of 1965-1976, the bassist shared the duties of lead vocalist with guitarist Donnie Iris.

title: Jimmie Ross
text: By the time the Jaggerz regrouped in 1989, Iris was well into his solo career, and Ross became the sole lead vocalist and remained bassist.

title: Jimmie Ross
text: He continues to hold both positions today.

title: Erie Bluffs State Park
text: Erie Bluffs State Park is a 587 acre Pennsylvania state park in Girard and Springfield Townships, Erie County, Pennsylvania in the United States.

title: Erie Bluffs State Park
text: The park is the largest undeveloped stretch of land overlooking Lake Erie in Pennsylvania.

title: Erie Bluffs State Park
text: Erie Bluffs State Park is just north of Pennsylvania Route 5 near Lake City and 12 mi west of Erie.

title: Erie Bluffs State Park
text: It is one of Pennsylvania's newest state parks.

title: Poe Valley State Park
text: Poe Valley State Park is a 620 acre Pennsylvania state park in Penn Township, Centre County, Pennsylvania in the United States.

title: Poe Valley State Park
text: The park is surrounded by Bald Eagle State Forest.

title: Poe Valley State Park
text: Poe Paddy State Park is 4 mi to the east.

title: Poe Valley State Park
text: The forests of the park surround the 25 acre Poe Lake.

title: Poe Valley State Park
text: Poe Valley State Park is in isolated Poe Valley which lies between Potters Mills on U.S. Route 322 and Millheim on Pennsylvania Route 45.

title: Poe Valley State Park
text: The park was closed during the 2008 and 2009 season while the lake was drained for dam repairs and the park facilities were upgraded.

title: Presque Isle State Park
text: Presque Isle State Park is a 3112 acre Pennsylvania state park on an arching, sandy peninsula that juts into Lake Erie, 4 mi west of the city of Erie, in Millcreek Township, Erie County, Pennsylvania, in the United States.

title: Presque Isle State Park
text: The peninsula sweeps northeastward, surrounding Presque Isle Bay along the park's southern coast.

title: Presque Isle State Park
text: It has 13 mi of roads, 21 mi of recreational trails, 13 beaches for swimming, and a marina.

title: Presque Isle State Park
text: Popular activities at the park include swimming, boating, hiking, biking, and birdwatching.

title: Sinnemahoning State Park
text: Sinnemahoning State Park is a 1910 acre Pennsylvania state park in Grove Township, Cameron County and Wharton Township, Potter County, Pennsylvania in the United States.

title: Sinnemahoning State Park
text: The park is surrounded by Elk State Forest and is mountainous with deep valleys.

title: Sinnemahoning State Park
text: The park is home to the rarely seen elk and bald eagle.

title: Sinnemahoning State Park
text: Sinnemahoning State Park is on Pennsylvania Route 872, eight miles (13 km) north of the village of Sinnamahoning.

title: Sinnemahoning State Park
text: In 1958, the park opened under the direction of the Pennsylvania Bureau of Forestry: it became a Pennsylvania State Park in 1962.

title: History of Presque Isle
text: The History of Presque Isle Pennsylvania began when Presque Isle was created by the wave action of Lake Erie over the course of the 11,000 years that have passed since the last ice age.

title: Maurice K. Goddard State Park
text: Maurice K. Goddard State Park is a 2856 acre Pennsylvania state park in Deer Creek, Mill Creek, New Vernon and Sandy Lake Townships, Mercer County, Pennsylvania in the United States.

title: Maurice K. Goddard State Park
text: It features wildlife, waterways and public recreational facilities.

title: Maurice K. Goddard State Park
text: Lake Wilhelm shares its shorelines with Maurice K. Goddard State Park and State Game Land No. 270.

title: Maurice K. Goddard State Park
text: The dam, constructed in 1971, creates a 1860 acre lake providing a resource for people and wildlife.

title: Maurice K. Goddard State Park
text: Many species of fish and amphibians make Lake Wilhelm their home.

title: Maurice K. Goddard State Park
text: A variety of outdoor activities are available in and around the Park vicinity.

title: Maurice K. Goddard State Park
text: The addition of the Goddard Classroom, at the Marina facility, provides the opportunity to present programs about nature, wildlife and ecology.

title: Maurice K. Goddard State Park
text: Special events and programs are held throughout the summer months.

title: Maurice K. Goddard State Park
text: Maurice K. Goddard State Park is just off exit 130 of Interstate 79 on Pennsylvania Route 358.

title: Gouldsboro State Park
text: Gouldsboro State Park is a 2880 acre Pennsylvania state park in Coolbaugh Township, Monroe County and Lehigh Township, Wayne County, Pennsylvania in the United States.

title: Gouldsboro State Park
text: The park includes the 250 acre Gouldsboro Lake.

title: Gouldsboro State Park
text: Gouldsboro State Park is located very close to Tobyhanna State Park and Pennsylvania State Game Lands 127 and 312.

title: Gouldsboro State Park
text: It is on Pennsylvania Route 507 near the small village of Gouldsboro.

title: French Creek State Park
text: French Creek State Park is a 7526 acre Pennsylvania state park in North Coventry and Warwick Townships in Chester County and Robeson and Union Townships in Berks County, Pennsylvania in the United States.

title: French Creek State Park
text: It straddles northern Chester County and southern Berks County along French Creek.

title: French Creek State Park
text: It is located in the Hopewell Big Woods.

title: French Creek State Park
text: The park is the home of two lakes: Hopewell Lake, a 68 acre warm water lake, and Scotts Run Lake, a 22 acre cold water lake.

title: French Creek State Park
text: The state record smallmouth bass was caught in Scotts Run Lake.

title: French Creek State Park
text: There are extensive forests, and almost 40 mi of hiking and equestrian trails.

title: French Creek State Park
text: The park is also friendly to mountain bikers, having some renowned technical trails.

title: French Creek State Park
text: Hopewell Furnace National Historic Site, which features a cold blast furnace restored to its 1830s appearance, is surrounded by the park.

title: French Creek State Park
text: The Six Penny Day Use Area and Group Camp are listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

title: French Creek State Park
text: French Creek State Park is located off of Pennsylvania Route 345 to the south of Birdsboro.

title: Allegheny Islands State Park
text: Allegheny Islands State Park is a 43 acre Pennsylvania state park in Harmar Township, Allegheny County, Pennsylvania in the United States.

title: Allegheny Islands State Park
text: The undeveloped park is composed of three alluvial islands located in the middle of the Allegheny River northeast of Pittsburgh.

title: Allegheny Islands State Park
text: The islands are just north of the boroughs of Oakmont and Plum, and southwest of Cheswick.

title: Allegheny Islands State Park
text: Bridges for the Pennsylvania Turnpike (Interstate 76) and the Bessemer and Lake Erie Railroad Branch of the Canadian National Railway cross the Allegheny River at the middle island.

title: Lake Erie Metropark
text: Lake Erie Metropark is a park in the Huron-Clinton system of metro parks.

title: Lake Erie Metropark
text: The park is a 1607 acre recreational facility located at the mouth of the Huron River on Lake Erie and consists of meadows, a marsh and lagoons.

title: Lake Erie Metropark
text: It has a three-mile (5 km) shoreline along the lake and is a popular bird-watching site.

title: Lake Erie Metropark
text: The Park has a wave action swimming pool, an 18-hole regulation golf course, the Marshlands Museum and Nature Center, boat launches and a marina.

title: Lake Erie Metropark
text: The children's play area, previously featuring a child-size town, is now under construction as a newer, more modern, playscape area is being built.

title: Chelonian Conservation and Biology
text: "Chelonian Conservation and Biology: International Journal of Turtle and Tortoise Research" is a peer-reviewed scientific journal covering research on freshwater turtles, marine turtles, and tortoises (Order Testudines).

title: Chelonian Conservation and Biology
text: It was established in 1993 by the Chelonian Research Foundation as the new scientific journal of the IUCN Species Survival Commission's Tortoise and Freshwater Turtle Specialist Group and the "International Bulletin of Chelonian Research".

title: Chelonian Conservation and Biology
text: The journal was first published with support from Conservation International, the Chelonian Institute, the Wildlife Conservation Society, the Florida Audubon Society, and the Species Survival Commission of the World Conservation Union.

title: Ecotropica
text: Ecotropica is the peer-reviewed international scientific journal of the European Society for Tropical Ecology, GTOE.

title: Ecotropica
text: The journal first appeared in 1995 and received an impact factor in 2011.

title: ACS Nano
text: ACS Nano is a monthly, peer-reviewed, scientific journal, first published in August 2007 by the American Chemical Society.

title: ACS Nano
text: The current editor in chief is Paul S. Weiss (University of California, Los Angeles).

title: ACS Nano
text: The journal publishes original research articles, reviews, perspectives, interviews with distinguished researchers, views on the future of nanoscience and nanotechnology.

title: Mathematics of Operations Research
text: Mathematics of Operations Research is a peer-reviewed scientific journal first published in February 1976.

title: Mathematics of Operations Research
text: It focuses on areas of mathematics relevant to the field of operations research such as continuous optimization, discrete optimization, game theory, machine learning, simulation methodology, and stochastic models.

title: Mathematics of Operations Research
text: The journal is published quarterly by INFORMS (Institute for Operations Research and the Management Sciences), which also publishes other journals including "Operations Research" and "Management Science".

title: Mathematics of Operations Research
text: "Mathematics of Operations Research" is indexed by the "Journal Citation Reports".

title: Mathematics of Operations Research
text: In 2014, it moved to "Issues in Advance", which publishes the articles online as they become available.

title: Mathematics of Operations Research
text: The H-index of the journal is 50.

title: Aliso
text: Aliso: A Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Botany is a peer-reviewed scientific journal that publishes original research on plant taxonomy and evolutionary botany with a worldwide scope, but with a particular focus on the floristics of the Western United States.

title: Aliso
text: "Aliso", first published in 1948, is the scientific journal of the Rancho Santa Ana Botanic Garden.

title: Aliso
text: The journal is named for the western sycamore, "Platanus racemosa", which was commonly called by its Spanish name "aliso".

title: Ceylon Journal of Science
text: The Ceylon Journal of Science (Biological Sciences) is a scientific journal that was established in 1958 and is published by the University of Peradeniya.

title: Ceylon Journal of Science
text: The journal covers all aspects of biology.

title: Ceylon Journal of Science
text: It was a successor to the "Ceylon Journal of Science", sections A, B, and C (covering botany, zoology, and fisheries, respectively).

title: Ceylon Journal of Science
text: The "Ceylon Journal of Science" was established in 1924 amalgamating the journals "Annals of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Peradeniya" (first published in 1901), the "Spolia Zeylanica" (first published in 1903), and the "Bulletin of the Ceylon Fisheries" (first published in 1923).

title: Nature (journal)
text: Nature is an English multidisciplinary scientific journal, first published on 4 November 1869.

title: Nature (journal)
text: It was ranked the world's most cited scientific journal by the Science Edition of the 2010 "Journal Citation Reports" and is ascribed an impact factor of approximately 38.1, making it one of the world's top academic journals.

title: Nature (journal)
text: It is one of the few remaining academic journals that publishes original research across a wide range of scientific fields.

title: Nature (journal)
text: "Nature" claims an online readership of about 3 million unique readers per month.

title: Nature (journal)
text: The journal has a weekly circulation of around 53,000 but studies have concluded that on average a single copy is shared by as many as eight people.

title: Laser & Photonics Reviews
text: Laser & Photonics Reviews is a bimonthly peer-reviewed scientific journal covering research on all aspects of optical science.

title: Laser & Photonics Reviews
text: It is published by Wiley-VCH and contains reviews and original papers/letters.

title: Laser & Photonics Reviews
text: The journal was established in 2007 by the founding editor-in-chief Theodor W. Hänsch (Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich).

title: Laser & Photonics Reviews
text: Since 2008, the editor-in-chief is Guido W. Fuchs (Wiley-VCH).

title: Laser & Photonics Reviews
text: Originally, the journal only published review articles.

title: Laser & Photonics Reviews
text: Since 2012, it also contains original papers and letters.

title: Laser & Photonics Reviews
text: According to the "Journal Citation Reports", the journal had a 2011 impact factor of 7.388, ranking it 2nd out of 79 journals in the category "Optics", 8th out of 125 journals in the category "Physics Applied", and 11th out of 69 journals in the category "Physics Condensed Matter".

title: Teri W. Odom
text: Teri W. Odom is an American chemist and materials scientist.

title: Teri W. Odom
text: She is the Associate Chair of the Chemistry Department, Charles E. and Emma H. Morrison Professor of Chemistry, and a Professor of Materials Science and Engineering at Northwestern University.

title: Teri W. Odom
text: Odom is a member of the editorial advisory board of ACS Nano, Chemical Physics Letters, Journal of Physical Chemistry, and Nano Letters.

title: Teri W. Odom
text: She is also currently the Executive Editor of ACS Photonics.

title: Scientific journal
text: In academic publishing, a scientific journal is a periodical publication intended to further the progress of science, usually by reporting new research.

title: Scientific journal
text: Articles in scientific journals are mostly written by active scientists such as students, researchers and professors instead of professional journalists.

title: Scientific journal
text: There are thousands of scientific journals in publication, and many more have been published at various points in the past (see list of scientific journals).

title: Scientific journal
text: Most journals are highly specialized, although some of the oldest journals such as "Nature" publish articles and scientific papers across a wide range of scientific fields.

title: Scientific journal
text: Scientific journals contain articles that have been peer reviewed, in an attempt to ensure that articles meet the journal's standards of quality, and scientific validity.

title: Scientific journal
text: Although scientific journals are superficially similar to professional magazines, they are actually quite different.

title: Scientific journal
text: Issues of a scientific journal are rarely read casually, as one would read a magazine.

title: Scientific journal
text: The publication of the results of research is an essential part of the scientific method.

title: Scientific journal
text: If they are describing experiments or calculations, they must supply enough details that an independent researcher could repeat the experiment or calculation to verify the results.

title: Scientific journal
text: Each such journal article becomes part of the permanent scientific record.

title: Richard Kuklinski
text: Richard Leonard Kuklinski (April 11, 1935 – March 5, 2006) was an American contract killer and serial killer who was convicted of murdering five people, though he likely killed at least several dozen more.

title: Richard Kuklinski
text: He was associated with members of the American Mafia, namely the DeCavalcante crime family of Newark, New Jersey, and the Five Families of New York City.

title: DeCavalcante crime family
text: The DeCavalcante crime family is an Italian-American organized crime family that operates in Elizabeth, New Jersey and surrounding areas in the state and is part of the nationwide criminal phenomenon known as the American Mafia (or Cosa Nostra).

title: DeCavalcante crime family
text: It operates on the other side of the Hudson River from the Five Families of New York, but it maintains strong relations with many of them, as well as with the Philadelphia crime family and the Patriarca crime family of New England.

title: DeCavalcante crime family
text: Its illicit activities include bookmaking, building, cement, and construction violations, bootlegging, corruption, drug trafficking, extortion, fencing, fraud, hijacking, illegal gambling, loan-sharking, money laundering, murder, pier thefts, pornography, prostitution, racketeering, and waste management violations.

title: DeCavalcante crime family
text: The DeCavalcantes are, in part, the inspiration for the fictional DiMeo crime family of HBO's dramatic series "The Sopranos".

title: DeCavalcante crime family
text: The DeCavalcante family was the subject of the CNBC program "Mob Money", which aired on June 23, 2010 and "The Real Sopranos" TV documentary (first airdate April 26, 2006) directed by Thomas Viner for the UK production company Class Films.

title: Sam DeCavalcante
text: Simone Rizzo "Sam" DeCavalcante (March 3, 1912 – February 7, 1997), known as "Sam the Plumber", was a member of the New Jersey Mafia.

title: Sam DeCavalcante
text: Claiming descent from the Italian royal family, DeCavalcante was nicknamed "The Count".

title: Sam DeCavalcante
text: The Kefauver hearings later named his crime family the DeCavalcante crime family since he was the boss of the family current to those hearings.

title: Joseph Miranda
text: Joseph "Joe" Miranda (born 1925) is an American mobster and member of the New Jersey-based DeCavalcante crime family.

title: Joseph Miranda
text: A longtime "soldier" to Simone "Sam the Plumber" DeCavalcante and later boss Giovanni Riggi, he became acting underboss for Girolamo "Jimmy" Palermo following the imprisonment of many high-ranking members in 2003.

title: John D'Amato
text: John "Johnny Boy" D'Amato (died January 1992) was a New Jersey mobster and former acting boss of the DeCavalcante crime family.

title: John D'Amato
text: After being recruited by Gambino crime family boss John Gotti to take over the family, he was suspected of engaging in homosexual activity and was murdered in January 1992.

title: Philip Abramo
text: Philip Abramo (born 1945), also known as "The King Of Wall Street", "Lou Metzer" is a caporegime in the New Jersey DeCavalcante crime family who was allegedly involved in security fraud and murder.

title: Philip Abramo
text: Abramo was a capo of the DeCavalcante family's crew in Miami, Florida.

title: Park Dietz
text: Park Dietz (born 1948) is a forensic psychiatrist who has consulted or testified in many of the highest profile US criminal cases including Joel Rifkin, Arthur Shawcross, Jeffrey Dahmer, The Unabomber, Richard Kuklinski, the Beltway sniper attacks, and Jared Lee Loughner.

title: Michael Welner
text: Michael Mark Welner, M.D., (born September 24, 1964, in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania) is an American forensic psychiatrist and Chairman of The Forensic Panel.

title: Michael Welner
text: Welner is best known for his work in sensitive and complex litigation.

title: Michael Welner
text: He has acted as lead forensic psychiatric examiner in numerous criminal or court proceedings of national and international prominence, including precedent-setting trials and higher court decisions.

title: Michael Welner
text: Welner is also known for a number of innovations in forensic science, forensic psychiatry and justice, including protocols for prospective peer review in forensic medicine consultation, research to standardize an evidence-based distinction of the worst crimes, The Depravity Standard, and recommendations for upgrading forensic science assessment.

title: Michael Welner
text: He has been featured in network television news coverage of forensic psychiatry issues, has authored publications for professional and public audiences, and has contributed to emerging legislation on mental health reform.

title: Frank Majuri
text: Francesco "Fat Frank" Majuri (April 18, 1909 – 1983) was a New Jersey mobster and the former consigliere of the DeCavalcante crime family.

title: Frank Majuri
text: His son is Charles "Big Ears" Majuri, a longtime recognized Captain in the Newark faction of the same crime family.

title: Jackie Aprile Sr.
text: Giacomo Michael "Jackie" Aprile Sr., played by Michael Rispoli, is a fictional character on the HBO original series "The Sopranos".

title: Jackie Aprile Sr.
text: He was the first acting boss of the DiMeo Crime Family, after longtime reputed boss Ercole 'Eckley' DiMeo was sent to prison in 1995.

title: Jackie Aprile Sr.
text: He is based on DeCavalcante crime family acting mob boss Giacomo "Jake" Amari.

title: Greatest Hits, Vol. 1 (Ray Stevens album)
text: Greatest Hits, Vol.

title: Greatest Hits, Vol. 1 (Ray Stevens album)
text: 1 is a collection of ten previously released singles by Ray Stevens, released in 1987.

title: Greatest Hits, Vol. 1 (Ray Stevens album)
text: Of the selections of songs, three were recorded for the record label of Monument Records ("Gitarzan," "Along Came Jones," and "Ahab the Arab,"), four for Barnaby Records ("Everything Is Beautiful," "Turn Your Radio On," "The Streak," "Misty"), one for RCA Records ("Shriner's Convention"), and two for MCA Records.

title: Greatest Hits, Vol. 1 (Ray Stevens album)
text: The version of "Gitarzan" is the album version that begins with cheering and applauding of an audience.

title: Greatest Hits, Vol. 1 (Ray Stevens album)
text: The version of "Ahab the Arab" on this compilation is not the original recording but a re-recording that Stevens made for his album "Gitarzan" during his career with Monument.

title: Shot Full of Love
text: Shot Full of Love is the fifth studio album by country music artist Billy Ray Cyrus.

title: Shot Full of Love
text: It features the single "Busy Man", which peaked at number 3 in early 1999, becoming Cyrus's first Top Ten country hit since "Somebody New" in 1993.

title: Shot Full of Love
text: The album's title song is a cover of a song originally recorded by Juice Newton in 1981, in 1983 by the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band, and a number 73-peaking single in 1990 for Jennifer McCarter and The McCarters.

title: Shot Full of Love
text: This was also his last studio album for the Mercury Records label.

title: Shot Full of Love
text: After that album's release, Billy Ray Cyrus left Mercury Records for Monument Records in 1999.

title: Greatest Hits (1983 Ray Stevens album)
text: Greatest Hits is a collection of ten previously released singles by Ray Stevens, released in 1983 by RCA Records.

title: Greatest Hits (1983 Ray Stevens album)
text: This collection contains three singles that were released by Monument Records, four by Barnaby Records, and two by RCA.

title: Greatest Hits (1983 Ray Stevens album)
text: One of the selections is not an original recording; "Ahab the Arab" is a re-recording of Stevens' 1962 hit for Mercury Records that was included on his album "Gitarzan", which was released by Monument in 1969.

title: Greatest Hits (1983 Ray Stevens album)
text: Additionally, there are two selections featured on this collection that are album versions; "Gitarzan" is the album version that begins with cheering and applauding with an audience; "Freddie Feelgood" is the version that contains audience noises and was first featured on the album "Gitarzan".

title: Pretty Paper (song)
text: "Pretty Paper" is a song written by country music singer-songwriter Willie Nelson in 1963.

title: Pretty Paper (song)
text: After being signed to Monument Records, Nelson played the song for producer Fred Foster.

title: Pretty Paper (song)
text: Foster pitched the song to Roy Orbison, who turned it into a hit.

title: Pretty Paper (song)
text: Nelson recorded his own version of the song in November 1964.

title: The Very Best of Ray Stevens
text: The Very Best of Ray Stevens is a collection of 12 previously released singles that were hits for novelty/country artist, Ray Stevens; it was released in December 1975 by Barnaby Records.

title: The Very Best of Ray Stevens
text: While this collection has more emphasis on Stevens' hits for Barnaby, it also contains three from the label of Monument Records ("Unwind," "Mr. Businessman," and "Gitarzan") and two from Mercury Records (Stevens' first label).

title: The Very Best of Ray Stevens
text: The version of "Mr. Businessman" is the single release. "

title: The Very Best of Ray Stevens
text: Gitarzan" is the album version that begins with an audience cheering and applauding. "

title: The Very Best of Ray Stevens
text: Ahab the Arab" is the original recording that was released by Mercury (Stevens had re-recorded the song for his album "Gitarzan" in 1969).

title: Hoover (singer)
text: Willis David Hoover was born in Jackson County, Missouri and raised in Lamoni, Iowa and Shenandoah, Iowa.

title: Hoover (singer)
text: After starting out as a coffee house folk singer as a teenager, Hoover moved to Nashville in the 1960s and became a songwriter.

title: Hoover (singer)
text: His songs were recorded by Tina Turner, Eddy Arnold and country music outlaws Tompall Glaser and Waylon Jennings.

title: Hoover (singer)
text: He won an ASCAP Award for music written for the motion picture, "...tick...tick...tick..." After losing or forgetting his first and middle names, Hoover became a recording artist for Monument Records, Epic Records, and Elektra Records in the late 1960s and early 1970s.

title: Hoover (singer)
text: His recordings for Elektra were released in 2003 by Kinky Friedman's Sphincter Records label.

title: Roy Orbison
text: Roy Kelton Orbison (April 23, 1936 – December 6, 1988) was an American singer-songwriter known for his distinctive, impassioned voice, complex song structures, and dark emotional ballads.

title: Roy Orbison
text: The combination led many critics to describe his music as operatic, nicknaming him "the Caruso of Rock" and "the Big O." Between 1960 and 1964, 22 of his songs placed on the "Billboard" Top 40, including "Only the Lonely" (1960), "Crying" (1961), "In Dreams" (1963), and "Oh, Pretty Woman" (1964).

title: Early Orbison
text: Early Orbison is an album recorded by Roy Orbison on the Monument Records label at their studios in Hendersonville, Tennessee and released in 1964.

title: Early Orbison
text: Essentially a compilation of songs from his first two Monument albums, it is most noteworthy for containing "Pretty One", the "B" side of Orbison's second Monument single, "Uptown".

title: Early Orbison
text: Many Orbison fans believe "Pretty One" would have been his first major hit had it been promoted as an "A" side.

title: Early Orbison
text: The second song of interest on this album is "Come Back to Me My Love" which Fred Foster, owner of Monument Records and producer of all of Orbison's earliest hits, says was the song which inspired production of the hit arrangement that later became "Only the Lonely".

title: Ray Stevens' Greatest Hits
text: Ray Stevens' Greatest Hits is a collection of songs that Ray Stevens previously recorded for Barnaby and Monument Records from 1968 to 1971.

title: Ray Stevens' Greatest Hits
text: This marks the first album appearance of Stevens' novelty hit single "Bridget the Midget (The Queen of the Blues)."

title: Ray Stevens' Greatest Hits
text: This collection contains two more singles from Barnaby while the rest are recordings for Monument (five singles and three album tracks). "

title: Ray Stevens' Greatest Hits
text: Gitarzan" is the album version that begins with noises of an audience.

title: Ray Stevens' Greatest Hits
text: "Harry the Hairy Ape" and "Ahab the Arab" are not the original recordings but re-recordings that were made for Monument.

title: Ray Stevens' Greatest Hits
text: "Mr. Businessman" is the album version.

title: Monument Records
text: Monument Records was an American record label in Washington, D.C. named for the Washington Monument, founded in 1958 by Fred Foster and Buddy Deane (a prominent Baltimore disc jockey at WTTG).

title: Monument Records
text: Buddy Deane soon left the company, and in the early 60's bought KOTN in Pine Bluff, Arkansas where he retired until his death.

title: Monument Records
text: Foster relocated to the Nashville suburb of Hendersonville, Tennessee.

title: Monument Records
text: Monument's releases include a variety of genres, including rock and roll, country, jazz, and rhythm and blues.

title: Br'er Rabbit
text: Br'er Rabbit (Brother Rabbit), also spelled Bre'r Rabbit or Brer Rabbit or Bruh Rabbit, is a central figure as Uncle Remus tells stories of the Southern United States.

title: Br'er Rabbit
text: Br'er Rabbit is a trickster who succeeds by his wits rather than by brawn, provoking authority figures and bending social mores as he sees fit.

title: Br'er Rabbit
text: The Walt Disney Company later adapted this character for its 1946 animated motion picture "Song of the South".

title: Mark Elliot (voice-over artist)
text: Mark Elliot (born September 24, 1939) is an American voice-over artist best known as the primary voice for Walt Disney Entertainment from 1983 to 2008.

title: Mark Elliot (voice-over artist)
text: He also provided voice overs for trailers of non-Disney films, logos, feature presentation bumpers and commercials.

title: Mark Elliot (voice-over artist)
text: He's well known for his voice overs in theatrical and home video trailers for films produced by The Walt Disney Studios from the 1980s to the 2000s.

title: Mark Elliot (voice-over artist)
text: He was also the voice of CBS and FOX throughout the 1980s and 1990s, and various theatrical trailers for such non-Disney animated movies as "All Dogs Go to Heaven", "The Seventh Brother", "Rover Dangerfield", "Rock-A-Doodle", "", "The Magic Voyage", "The Thief and the Cobbler", "Once Upon a Forest", "The Princess And The Goblin", "Andre", "Asterix Conquers America", "The Swan Princess", "The Pagemaster", "The Pebble and the Penguin", "Balto", "All Dogs Go to Heaven 2", "Tiny Heroes" ("Vacak 2 - az erdő hőse"), "Zeus and Roxanne", "The Fearless Four", "The Prince of Egypt", "The Adventures of Brer Rabbit", "", "House Arrest", and "".

title: Mark Elliot (voice-over artist)
text: In addition to his behind-the-scenes work, Elliott starred with four other notable voice artists in the 1997 short film "5 Men and a Limo".

title: Mark Elliot (voice-over artist)
text: One of his most well-known voice-overs for Disney is the catchphrase "And now, our feature presentation," which he says at the start of most animated Disney films on video on a "Feature Presentation" bumper.

title: Walt Disney World Dolphin
text: The Walt Disney World Dolphin is a resort hotel designed by architect Michael Graves located between Epcot and Disney's Hollywood Studios in the Walt Disney World Resort in Bay Lake, Florida, next to Disney's BoardWalk Resort area.

title: Walt Disney World Dolphin
text: It opened on June 1, 1990 and is joined to its sister hotel, the Walt Disney World Swan (also designed by Graves) by a palm-tree lined covered walkway crossing a lagoon.

title: Walt Disney World Dolphin
text: The Walt Disney World Swan and Dolphin is a joint venture between the Walt Disney Company, Tishman Hotel Corporation, MetLife and Starwood Hotels and Resorts.

title: Walt Disney World Dolphin
text: The land the resort occupies is owned by the Walt Disney Company, while the buildings themselves are leased by Disney to the Tishman Hotel Corporation and MetLife but operated by Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide under the Sheraton Hotels brand.

title: Walt Disney World Dolphin
text: The Walt Disney World Swan and Dolphin are a part of the Walt Disney Collection of resorts; because of this they are Disney branded and guests of the resort have access to special Disney benefits available to Disney Resort Hotel guests only.

title: Color motion picture film
text: Color motion picture film refers both to unexposed color photographic film in a format suitable for use in a motion picture camera, and to finished motion picture film, ready for use in a projector, which bears images in color.

title: Disney Comics
text: Disney Comics was a comic book publishing company operated by The Walt Disney Company which ran from 1990 to 1993.

title: Disney Comics
text: It was connected with W. D. Publications, Inc., which was a subsidiary of The Walt Disney Company that published "Disney Comics" during that time span.

title: Disney Comics
text: W. D. Publications, Inc. created Disney Comics in 1990 so that The Walt Disney Company would not have to rely on outside publishers such as Gladstone Publishing.

title: Disney Comics
text: In the USA, Disney only licensed their comic books to other publishers prior to 1990.

title: Disney Comics
text: Since the demise of the Disney Comics line, Disney has licensed out their properties to various US comics publishers, while continuing to publish comics in the since-defunct magazines "Disney Adventures" and "Disney Adventures Comic Zone", as well as numerous book projects, and has reentered the periodical comics market through their 2009 purchase of Marvel Entertainment.

title: Disney Comics
text: Marvel and Disney Publishing began jointly publishing "Disney/Pixar Presents" magazine in May 2011 but did not revive the Disney Comics imprint as Boom!

title: Disney Comics
text: Studios would continue to publish classic Disney character comics.

title: Walt Disney's Comics and Stories
text: Walt Disney's Comics and Stories, sometimes abbreviated WDC or WDC&S, is an anthology comic book series that has an assortment of Disney characters, including Donald Duck, Scrooge McDuck, Mickey Mouse, Chip 'n Dale, Lil Bad Wolf, Scamp, Bucky Bug, Grandma Duck, Brer Rabbit, Winnie the Pooh, and others.

title: The Adventures of Brer Rabbit
text: The Adventures of Brer Rabbit is a book, a play, and a film inspired by the Uncle Remus stories.

title: The Adventures of Brer Rabbit
text: The central character's actual name is Br'er Rabbit (short for Brother Rabbit), but in the title "Br'er" is simplified as "Brer".

title: Marvel Studios
text: Marvel Studios, LLC (originally known as Marvel Films from 1993 to 1996) is an American motion picture studio based at The Walt Disney Studios in Burbank, California and is a subsidiary of Walt Disney Studios, itself a wholly owned division of The Walt Disney Company, with film producer Kevin Feige serving as president.

title: Marvel Studios
text: Previously, the studio was a subsidiary of Marvel Entertainment until The Walt Disney Company reorganized the companies in August 2015.

title: The Walt Disney Company Italy
text: The Walt Disney Company Italia S.r.l. (formerly called The Walt Disney Company Italia S.p.A) is The Walt Disney Company's Italian division and one of The Walt Disney Company's European divisions.

title: The Walt Disney Company Italy
text: The company was founded on 8 May 1938 as Creazioni Walt Disney S.A.I.

title: The Walt Disney Company Italy
text: The company owns and operates Disney Channel Italy, Disney in English, and more.

title: The Walt Disney Company Italy
text: Comics are also published by the company as well.

title: Oswald the Lucky Rabbit
text: Oswald the Lucky Rabbit (also known as Oswald the Rabbit or Oswald Rabbit) is an anthropomorphic rabbit and animated cartoon character created by Ub Iwerks and Walt Disney for funny animal films distributed by Universal Studios in the 1920s and 1930s, serving as the Disney studio's first animated character to feature in their own series.

title: Oswald the Lucky Rabbit
text: 26 animated Oswald one-reelers were produced at Walt Disney Animation Studios (the Walt Disney Studio at the time).

title: Oswald the Lucky Rabbit
text: In 1928, Charles Mintz took the rights of Oswald from Walt Disney and claimed Oswald as an official Universal Studios character.

title: Oswald the Lucky Rabbit
text: In November of 1928, as a replacement to compete with Oswald the Lucky Rabbit, Walt Disney went on to create Mickey Mouse.

title: Abraham Weinberg
text: Abraham "Bo" Weinberg (January 7, 1900 – September 9, 1935) was a Jewish New York City mobster who became a hitman and chief lieutenant for the Prohibition-era gang boss Dutch Schultz.

title: Abraham Weinberg
text: As Schultz expanded his bootlegging operations into Manhattan during Prohibition, he recruited Abe Weinberg and his brother George into his gang.

title: Abraham Weinberg
text: Abe Weinberg would become one of Schultz's top gunmen during the Manhattan Bootleg Wars and was a later suspect in the high-profile gangland slayings of Jack "Legs" Diamond, Vincent "Mad Dog" Coll, and mob boss Salvatore Maranzano.

title: Mad Dog Coll
text: Vincent "Mad Dog" Coll (born Uinseann Ó Colla, July 20, 1908 – February 7, 1932) was an Irish American mob hitman in the 1920s and early 1930s in New York City.

title: Mad Dog Coll
text: Coll gained notoriety for the alleged accidental killing of a young child during a mob kidnap attempt.

title: George Hill Hodel
text: George Hill Hodel, Jr. (October 10, 1907 – May 16, 1999) was an American physician.

title: George Hill Hodel
text: After the 1947 murder of American woman Elizabeth Short, a.k.a. the Black Dahlia, police came to consider Hodel a suspect.

title: George Hill Hodel
text: He was never formally charged with the crime, and came to wider attention as a suspect after his death when his son Steve Hodel, a Los Angeles homicide detective, accused George Hodel of killing Short and committing several additional murders.

title: Civvies (TV series)
text: Civvies is a six-part thriller first broadcast on BBC1 on 22 September 1992.

title: Civvies (TV series)
text: The series was written by Lynda La Plante - her first writing contribution for the BBC, after being snatched in a "golden handcuffs" deal following the success of "Prime Suspect".

title: Civvies (TV series)
text: The series focuses on Frank Dillon (Jason Issacs), a former Army soldier who finds life outside the army tougher than being in it - and slowly falls under the power of east end gangster Barry Newman (Peter O'Toole), who is looking to hire a trained hitman.

title: Civvies (TV series)
text: The complete series was released on DVD on 3 June 2013 on Acorn Media UK.

title: Killing Lincoln (film)
text: Killing Lincoln is an American television film inspired by the 2011 book of the same name by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard.

title: Killing Lincoln (film)
text: The two-hour political docudrama was originally broadcast on National Geographic Channel on February 17, 2013.

title: Killing Lincoln (film)
text: Narrated and hosted by American actor Tom Hanks, the film stars Billy Campbell as United States President Abraham Lincoln and Jesse Johnson as John Wilkes Booth.

title: Killing Lincoln (film)
text: It was written and executive produced by Erik Jendresen ("Band of Brothers"), directed by Adrian Moat ("Gettysburg"), produced by Chris Cowen, Mark Herzog, Ridley Scott, Tony Scott, Mary Lisio, David Zucker, and Terri Weinberg.

title: What You Have Left
text: "What You Have Left" is the sixth episode of the American television drama series "The Killing", which aired on May 1, 2011 on AMC in the United States.

title: What You Have Left
text: The episode was written by Nic Pizzolatto and was directed by Agnieszka Holland.

title: What You Have Left
text: In the episode, the police further investigate Bennet Ahmed, which leads the Larsens to believe that he is a prime suspect.

title: What You Have Left
text: The mayoral candidates hold their televised debate, allowing the current mayor to bring up Richmond’s attachment to a murder suspect.

title: George Weinberg (mobster)
text: George Weinberg (1901 – January 29, 1939) was a New York mobster and, with brother Abraham Weinberg, an associate of Dutch Schultz as a mob accountant during the 1920s and 1930s.

title: George Weinberg (mobster)
text: In 1935, following the disappearance of his brother and the gangland murder of Schultz, he decided to become a government informant and testified against his former associates.

title: Abraham bar Hiyya
text: Abraham bar Ḥiyya ha-Nasi (1070 Barcelona, Catalonia – 1136 or 1145 Narbonne, France) was a Jewish mathematician, astronomer and philosopher, also known as Savasorda (from the Arabic صاحب الشرطة "Ṣāḥib al-Shurṭa" "Chief of the Police") or Abraham Judaeus.

title: Abraham bar Hiyya
text: He was born in Barcelona and scholars suspect he travelled to Narbonne where he is thought to have died.

title: Paul Genge
text: Paul Morgan Genge (29 March 1913 Brooklyn, New York – 13 May 1988 Los Angeles, California) was an actor from the 1950s through to the late 1970s.

title: Paul Genge
text: Genge is most famous for his role as the shotgun toting gray-haired mob hitman 'Mike' in the 1968 film "Bullitt" (his character is the passenger in the black 1968 Dodge Charger during the famous car chase that goes out of control and causes his death and the driver's).

title: Paul Genge
text: Other film roles include that of a payoff man in "The Outfit" (1973), a California Highway Patrol officer in 1967's "Hot Rods to Hell", Whitey, a communist suspect in "The FBI Story" (1959) and Lieutenant Hagerman in "North By Northwest" (1959).

title: Paul Genge
text: He also appeared on many television shows from the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s.

title: Paul Genge
text: He played in four episodes of "Perry Mason", starring Raymond Burr; in three of the roles he played a law-enforcement officer, such as San Francisco Inspector Wade in "The Case of the Poison Pen Pal" in 1962.

title: Paul Genge
text: In his final appearance in 1966 he played Bud in "The Case of the Sausalito Sunrise."

title: Paul Genge
text: Ironically, in that episode he and his comrade, in attempting to hijack goods from a truck driven by Paul Drake, are killed when their car loses control and rolls down the cliff, somewhat similar to the chase scene in "Bullitt".

title: Branko Tomović
text: Branko Tomović (Serbian Cyrillic: "Бранко Томовић"; born June 17, 1980) is a German-Serbian actor.

title: Branko Tomović
text: He was born in Münster, Germany, though his actual origin is from the Carpathians in Serbia.

title: Branko Tomović
text: His parents emigrated in the '70s from the Golubac Fortress area on the Danube and Branko was raised between Germany and Serbia before he studied acting at the prestigious Lee Strasberg Theatre Institute in New York City.

title: Branko Tomović
text: Tomović was first seen on the big screen in the lead role in the American Film Institute/Sundance drama "Remote Control", for which he received the OmU-Award at the Potsdam Film Festival.

title: Branko Tomović
text: Currently settled in London, with his dark, brooding looks he has appeared in striking roles on British Television.

title: Branko Tomović
text: He played the creepy main suspect Antoni Pricha, the Morgue Man, in Jack the Ripper thriller "Whitechapel", the pyromaniac Junky-Henchman Marek Lisowski in the final episodes of "A Touch of Frost" and Polish fighter pilot Miroslaw Feric in the World War II drama "The Untold Battle of Britain".

title: Branko Tomović
text: Tomovic has worked with internationally respected film directors as Ken Loach, Sönke Wortmann and Paul Greengrass.

title: Branko Tomović
text: He was named "One to Watch" by "Moviescope Magazine" in 2008 and recent film credits include The Bourne Ultimatum opposite Matt Damon (Dir.

title: Branko Tomović
text: Paul Greengrass), It's a Free World... (Dir.

title: Branko Tomović
text: Ken Loach), "The Wolf Man" (Dir.

title: Branko Tomović
text: Joe Johnston), "Pope Joan" (Dir.

title: Branko Tomović
text: Sönke Wortmann) and "Interview with a Hitman" (Dir.

title: Branko Tomović
text: Perry Bhandal).

title: Branko Tomović
text: In 2010, he won the 'Best Actor' Award at the San Francisco Short Film Festival and at The Accolade Film Awards for his performance as a Serbian soldier who is tormented by grief and guilt after being a witness of war crimes in the drama Inbetween.

title: Branko Tomović
text: He also stars opposite Debbie Harry in Jimmy Cauty's Road movie Believe the Magic and Steve Stone's ghost thriller Entity with Dervla Kirwan and Charlotte Riley.

title: Branko Tomović
text: Entity won two awards at the London Independent Film Festival 2013 and Best Film at the British Horror Film Festival where Branko was also nominated for Best Actor.

title: Branko Tomović
text: The British Filmmakers Alliance honoured him as Best International Actor for his role and he was also chosen as a Rising Star by Icon Magazine.

title: Branko Tomović
text: He is set to play the title character of Nikola Tesla in the upcoming bio-pic Tesla.

title: Branko Tomović
text: In 2014, he played Jack Bauer's right-hand man, the mysterious and dangerous Belcheck, next to Kiefer Sutherland in 24: Live Another Day.

title: Branko Tomović
text: He was also seen opposite Brad Pitt and Logan Lerman in David Ayer's WWII drama Fury.

title: Estádio José de Melo
text: Estádio José de Melo, sometimes called Stadium José de Melo, is a multi-use stadium located in Rio Branco, Brazil.

title: Estádio José de Melo
text: It is used mostly for football matches and hosts the home matches of Andirá Esporte Clube, Atlético Acreano, Independência Futebol Clube, Atlético Clube Juventus, Rio Branco Football Club and Associação Desportiva Vasco da Gama.

title: Estádio José de Melo
text: It also hosted the home matches of América-AC The stadium has a maximum capacity of 8,000 people and was built in 1929 (according to some sources, it was inaugurated in 1935).

title: Estádio José de Melo
text: The stadium is owned by Rio Branco Football Club and is named after the commissioner José Francisco de Melo, who is a former player and former president of Rio Branco Football Club.

title: Estádio José de Melo
text: He also donated the groundplot where the stadium was built.

title: Estadio Cincuentenario
text: The Estadio Cincuentenario is an indoor arena in Formosa, Argentina.

title: Estadio Cincuentenario
text: It hosts basketball, volleyball, futsal, boxing, handball and artistic events.

title: Estadio Cincuentenario
text: Club La Unión plays at this stadium its home matches for the Liga Nacional de Básquet, the top level of the Argentine basketball league system.

title: Estadio Cincuentenario
text: The same club also has a volleyball team that plays its home matches for the Liga Argentina de Voleibol – Serie A1 at the Cincuentenario as well.

title: FF Giza
text: Fótbóltsfelagið Giza (since 2012 Giza/Hoyvík) was a Faroese football club based in the capital Tórshavn.

title: FF Giza
text: The team plays its home matches on Niðari Vøllur (the Lower Field) in Gundadalur.

title: FF Giza
text: Earlier they played their home matches in Argir.

title: Estádio Municipal João Lamego Netto
text: Estádio Municipal João Lamego Netto, usually known as Lamegão, is a multi-purpose stadium in Ipatinga, Brazil.

title: Estádio Municipal João Lamego Netto
text: It is currently used mostly for football matches.

title: Estádio Municipal João Lamego Netto
text: Ideal futebol Clube usually play their home matches at the stadium.

title: Estádio Municipal João Lamego Netto
text: Social Futebol Clube, from the neighbor city Coronel Fabriciano, has its own stadium, but sometimes plays its home matches at Ipatingão, because of its larger capacity and better structure.

title: Estádio Municipal João Lamego Netto
text: The stadium has a current maximum capacity of 10,000 people and was built in 1982.

title: Ben Halfpenny
text: Benjamin Halfpenny (25 April 1906 – 15 June 1966) was an English professional rugby league footballer who played in the 1920s, and 1930s, playing at representative level for Great Britain (non-Test matches), and England, and at club level for Widnes, St. Helens, and Warrington, as a wing , or loose forward/lock , i.e. number 2 or 5, 3 or 4, 8 or 10, 11 or 12, or, 13.

title: Adelaide Football Club
text: The Adelaide Football Club, nicknamed the Crows, is a professional Australian rules football club that competes in the Australian Football League (AFL).

title: Adelaide Football Club
text: The club is based in Adelaide, South Australia, playing its home matches at Adelaide Oval.

title: Adelaide Football Club
text: The club has its training and administration base at Football Park in West Lakes, where it previously played home matches between 1991 and 2013.

title: Adelaide Football Club
text: The club song is "The Pride of South Australia", to the tune of the Marines' Hymn.

title: Arena Barueri
text: Arena Barueri is a multi-use stadium located in Barueri, São Paulo state, Brazil.

title: Arena Barueri
