text: It is used mostly for football matches and hosts the home matches of Sport Club Barueri, and hosted the matches of Grêmio Recreativo Barueri until the 2010 season.

title: Arena Barueri
text: The stadium has a maximum capacity of 31,452 people and was built in 2007.

title: Arena Barueri
text: It is owned by the City of Barueri.

title: Arena Barueri
text: During the reforming of Palestra Italia Stadium the Barueri Arena was being used for some home matches of Palmeiras.

title: Widnes Vikings
text: Widnes Vikings R.L.F.C. is an English professional rugby league club based in Widnes, Cheshire which currently plays in the Super League, the top tier of European rugby league.

title: Widnes Vikings
text: The club plays its home matches at the Select Security Stadium.

title: List of Glamorgan County Cricket Club grounds
text: Glamorgan County Cricket Club was established on 6 July 1888.

title: List of Glamorgan County Cricket Club grounds
text: The county entered the Minor Counties Championship in 1896 and competed in the competition until 1920, after which it was elevated to first-class status for the 1921 season, and has played first-class cricket since.

title: List of Glamorgan County Cricket Club grounds
text: Following their elevation to first-class status, Glamorgan alternated their home matches between Cardiff Arms Park in Cardiff and St Helen's in Swansea.

title: List of Glamorgan County Cricket Club grounds
text: It wasn't until 1966 that Glamorgan began playing at their current home ground, the SWALEC Stadium (known more commonly as Sophia Gardens) in Cardiff.

title: List of Glamorgan County Cricket Club grounds
text: Cardiff Arms Park played host to Glamorgan's first home fixture in first-class cricket against Sussex in 1921, as well as its first home List A fixture against Worcestershire in 1963.

title: List of Glamorgan County Cricket Club grounds
text: Forty years later Sophia Gardens played host to the clubs first Twenty20 fixture against Northamptonshire.

title: List of Glamorgan County Cricket Club grounds
text: Glamorgan have played home matches at nineteen grounds, but have played the majority of their home fixtures since 1966 at the SWALEC Stadium, which also holds Test, One Day International and Twenty20 International cricket matches.

title: Newington Youth F.C.
text: Newington Y.C. Football Club (also known as Newington Youth Club, Newington Y.C., Newington F.C. or simply Newington) is an intermediate-level Northern Irish football club playing in NIFL Premier Intermediate League.

title: Newington Youth F.C.
text: The club originates in the Newington area of Belfast, although owing to the lack of facilities for junior and intermediate clubs in north Belfast they have played home matches at Muckamore Park in Antrim, Brantwood FC on Skegoneill Avenue, Richardson Park in Dunmurry and The Cliff in Larne.

title: Newington Youth F.C.
text: In 2008, the club became involved in a partnership with IFA Premiership club Crusaders, with a view to securing funding for a new, shared ground in north Belfast.

title: Newington Youth F.C.
text: As part of the arrangement, Newington used Crusaders’ current ground Seaview for home matches in 2008–09, marking a return to home matches in the club's native north Belfast.

title: Newington Youth F.C.
text: For the 2013–14 season, the club's first season in NIFL Championship 2, Seaview will be the home venue once again.

title: 1997–98 Utah Jazz season
text: The 1997–98 NBA season was the Jazz's 24th season in the National Basketball Association, and 19th season in Salt Lake City, Utah.

title: 1997–98 Utah Jazz season
text: Without John Stockton for the first 18 games due to a knee injury, the Jazz slowly got off to an 11–7 start to the season.

title: 1997–98 Utah Jazz season
text: However, Stockton would eventually return as the Jazz won 31 of their final 36 games after the All-Star break, and finished first place in the Midwest Division with a 62–20 record.

title: 1997–98 Utah Jazz season
text: The Jazz's top scorer Karl Malone, who averaged 27.0 points per game, was part of a Jazz offense that had two other players, Stockton and Jeff Hornacek, averaging double-digits in points.

title: 1997–98 Utah Jazz season
text: Malone was the only member of the team to play in the 1998 NBA All-Star Game.

title: 2002–03 Utah Jazz season
text: The 2002–03 NBA season was the Jazz's 29th season in the National Basketball Association, and 24th season in Salt Lake City, Utah.

title: 2002–03 Utah Jazz season
text: During the offseason, the Jazz signed free agents Matt Harpring, Calbert Cheaney and Mark Jackson.

title: 2002–03 Utah Jazz season
text: The team finished third in the Midwest Division with a 47–35 record, and qualified for the playoffs for the twentieth straight season.

title: 2002–03 Utah Jazz season
text: However, the Jazz once again failed to make it out of the first round, losing to the Sacramento Kings in five games.

title: 2002–03 Utah Jazz season
text: This season also marked the end of the Stockton and Malone era.

title: 2002–03 Utah Jazz season
text: John Stockton and Karl Malone were both given a long standing ovation after Game 4 at the Delta Center, and another one after Game 5 at the ARCO Arena.

title: 2002–03 Utah Jazz season
text: Following the season, Stockton retired while Malone signed as a free agent with the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: 2002–03 Utah Jazz season
text: Also following the season, Cheaney signed with the Golden State Warriors and Jackson was released.

title: 2002–03 Utah Jazz season
text: The Jazz would not return to the playoffs until 2007.

title: 1999–2000 Utah Jazz season
text: The 1999–2000 NBA season was the Utah Jazz's 26th season in the National Basketball Association, and 21st season in Salt Lake City, Utah.

title: 1999–2000 Utah Jazz season
text: During the offseason, the Jazz signed free agent Olden Polynice, then later on signed Armen Gilliam in January.

title: 1999–2000 Utah Jazz season
text: The Jazz were now the oldest team in the NBA still led by John Stockton and Karl Malone, who were both selected for the 2000 NBA All-Star Game.

title: 1999–2000 Utah Jazz season
text: The Jazz would recapture the Midwest Division with a solid 55–27 record, qualifying for the playoffs for the 17th straight season.

title: 1999–2000 Utah Jazz season
text: In the playoffs, the Jazz defeated the Seattle SuperSonics three games to two in the Western Conference Quarterfinals, but would lose in five games to the Portland Trail Blazers in the semifinals for the second consecutive year.

title: 1999–2000 Utah Jazz season
text: Following the season, Jeff Hornacek retired after playing fourteen years in the NBA, Gilliam also retired while Howard Eisley was traded to the Dallas Mavericks, and Adam Keefe was dealt to the Golden State Warriors.

title: 2000–01 Utah Jazz season
text: The 2000–01 NBA season was the Jazz's 27th season in the National Basketball Association, and 22nd season in Salt Lake City, Utah.

title: 2000–01 Utah Jazz season
text: After the retirement of Jeff Hornacek, the Jazz signed free agents Danny Manning and John Starks, and acquired Donyell Marshall from the Golden State Warriors in an offseason four-team trade.

title: 2000–01 Utah Jazz season
text: The Jazz got off to a fast start winning 16 of their first 20 games, but struggled a bit down the stretch.

title: 2000–01 Utah Jazz season
text: They finished second in the Midwest Division with a 53–29 record, and qualified for the playoffs for the eighteenth straight season.

title: 2000–01 Utah Jazz season
text: On a more positive note, the Jazz equaled the Los Angeles Lakers' record of sixteen consecutive winning seasons, set between 1976–77 and 1991–92.

title: 2000–01 Utah Jazz season
text: The Jazz were ultimately to make it nineteen consecutive winning seasons before finishing with only 26 wins in 2004–05.

title: 1994–95 Utah Jazz season
text: The 1994–95 NBA season was the Jazz's 21st season in the National Basketball Association, and 16th season in Salt Lake City, Utah.

title: 1994–95 Utah Jazz season
text: During the offseason, the Jazz signed free agent Antoine Carr and acquired Adam Keefe from the Atlanta Hawks.

title: 1994–95 Utah Jazz season
text: In a year of milestones, John Stockton became the NBA's all-time assist leader passing Magic Johnson with 9,921 on his way to a record tying eighth straight assist title.

title: 1994–95 Utah Jazz season
text: Meanwhile, Karl Malone and Tom Chambers each passed the 20,000 point mark in their careers, as the Jazz posted a 14–1 record in January including a 14-game winning streak.

title: 1994–95 Utah Jazz season
text: At midseason, the team re-acquired former Jazz guard Blue Edwards from the Boston Celtics.

title: 1994–95 Utah Jazz season
text: The Jazz won their final seven games finishing second in the Midwest Division with a 60–22 record.

title: 1994–95 Utah Jazz season
text: Malone and Stockton were both selected for the 1995 NBA All-Star Game.

title: 1992–93 Utah Jazz season
text: The 1992–93 NBA season was the Jazz's 19th season in the National Basketball Association, and 14th season in Salt Lake City, Utah.

title: 1992–93 Utah Jazz season
text: During the offseason, the Jazz acquired Jay Humphries from the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: 1992–93 Utah Jazz season
text: Utah hosted the 1993 NBA All-Star Game, and their star players Karl Malone and John Stockton were named co-MVPs.

title: 1992–93 Utah Jazz season
text: Malone and Stockton continued to be among the best players in the NBA, as the Jazz won six of their first eight games on their way to a 24–10 start.

title: 1992–93 Utah Jazz season
text: However, they struggled down the stretch with a 6–8 record in February, including a five-game losing streak.

title: 1992–93 Utah Jazz season
text: Late in the season, the team signed free agent James Donaldson, who played in the final six games of the regular season.

title: 1992–93 Utah Jazz season
text: The Jazz went on to finish third in the Midwest Division with a 47–35 record.

title: 1992–93 Utah Jazz season
text: However, in the first round of the playoffs, they lost to the Seattle SuperSonics in five games after taking a 2–1 series lead.

title: 1992–93 Utah Jazz season
text: Following the season, Mark Eaton announced his retirement.

title: 2001–02 Utah Jazz season
text: The 2001–02 NBA season was the Jazz's 28th season in the National Basketball Association, and 23rd season in Salt Lake City, Utah.

title: 2001–02 Utah Jazz season
text: During the offseason, the Jazz signed free agent John Amaechi.

title: 2001–02 Utah Jazz season
text: John Stockton continued to set new standards with 15,000 career assists and 3,000 career steals, as Karl Malone scored his 34,000th career point.

title: 2001–02 Utah Jazz season
text: However, the Jazz began to show their age as they played mediocre basketball all season finishing fourth in the Midwest Division with a 44–38 record.

title: 2001–02 Utah Jazz season
text: The Jazz also beat the Los Angeles Lakers' record of sixteen consecutive winning seasons, set between 1976–77 and 1991–92.

title: 2001–02 Utah Jazz season
text: Malone was selected for the 2002 NBA All-Star Game, but did not play due to an injury.

title: 2001–02 Utah Jazz season
text: Rookie Andre Kirilenko was selected to the All-Rookie First Team.

title: 2001–02 Utah Jazz season
text: In the first round of the playoffs, they lost in four games to the Sacramento Kings.

title: 1995–96 Utah Jazz season
text: The 1995–96 NBA season was the Jazz's 22nd season in the National Basketball Association, and 17th season in Salt Lake City, Utah.

title: 1995–96 Utah Jazz season
text: During the offseason, the Jazz signed free agents Chris Morris and Greg Foster, then signed second-year guard Howard Eisley in December.

title: 1995–96 Utah Jazz season
text: John Stockton had another record breaking season leading the NBA in assists for the ninth straight season, while breaking Maurice Cheeks career record in steals.

title: 1995–96 Utah Jazz season
text: Meanwhile, Karl Malone moved into ninth place in all-time scoring as the Jazz finished second in the Midwest Division with a 55–27 record, with Stockton and Malone both being selected for the 1996 NBA All-Star Game.

title: John Starks (basketball)
text: John Levell Starks (born August 10, 1965) is an American retired professional basketball shooting guard.

title: John Starks (basketball)
text: Starks was listed at 6'5" and 190 pounds during his NBA playing career.

title: John Starks (basketball)
text: Although he was not drafted in the 1988 NBA draft after attending four colleges in his native Oklahoma, including Oklahoma State University, he gained fame while playing for the New York Knicks of the National Basketball Association in the 1990s.

title: 1993–94 Utah Jazz season
text: The 1993–94 NBA season was the Jazz's 20th season in the National Basketball Association, and 15th season in Salt Lake City, Utah.

title: 1993–94 Utah Jazz season
text: During the offseason, the Jazz signed unrestricted free agent All-Star forward Tom Chambers, and acquired Felton Spencer from the Minnesota Timberwolves.

title: 1993–94 Utah Jazz season
text: John Stockton led the league in assists for the seventh straight season, as Karl Malone joined the list in all-time points scored topping the 19,000 point mark.

title: 1993–94 Utah Jazz season
text: Both were selected for the 1994 NBA All-Star Game.

title: 1993–94 Utah Jazz season
text: At midseason, the Jazz traded Jeff Malone to the Philadelphia 76ers for Jeff Hornacek.

title: 1993–94 Utah Jazz season
text: With the addition of Hornacek, the Jazz went on to win ten consecutive games between February and March.

title: 1993–94 Utah Jazz season
text: They won nine of their final eleven games finishing third in the Midwest Division with a 53–29 record.

title: Leeuwarden
text: Leeuwarden (] , ] ), Stadsfries: "Liwwadden") is a city and municipality with a population of 108,249 in Friesland in the Netherlands.

title: Leeuwarden
text: It is the provincial capital of the States of Friesland.

title: Ivo den Bieman
text: Ivo den Bieman (born 4 February 1967 in Wamel, Gelderland) is a Dutch retired footballer who played the majority of his career in Scotland.

title: Ivo den Bieman
text: He moved to Scotland in 1990 to attend Aberdeen University having previously played for Dutch amateur side SV Leones.

title: Mitchell Elshot
text: Mitchell Elshot (born 14 April 1995, Amsterdam) is a Dutch retired footballer who played for Eerste Divisie club Almere City FC during the 2012-2013 football season.

title: Arturo ten Heuvel
text: Arturo ten Heuvel (born 20 December 1978) is a Dutch retired footballer who played for HFC Haarlem, FC Volendam, FC Den Bosch, KSV Roeselare, Katwijk and Ajax Zaterdag during the span of his playing career.

title: Arturo ten Heuvel
text: He is currently a youth coach, managing the D2 squad (under-13) at Almere City FC.

title: Foeke Booy
text: Foeke Booy (born 25 April 1962 in Leeuwarden) is a Dutch retired footballer and football manager.

title: Gerard Kerkum
text: Gerard Kerkum (born 17 December 1930) is a Dutch retired footballer and was twice chairman of Dutch football team Feyenoord Rotterdam.

title: Michel Kuipers
text: Michel Kuipers (born 26 June 1974) is a Dutch retired footballer who played as a goalkeeper.

title: Michel Kuipers
text: Prior to football he served with the Dutch Marine Corps.

title: Michel Kuipers
text: He became a football agent after finishing his playing career.

title: Reginald Faria
text: Reginald Faria (born November 1981 in Amsterdam, Netherlands) is a Dutch retired footballer who played for Dutch Eredivisie Club FC Volendam during 2003-2004 season.

title: Jeffrey Hoogervorst
text: Jeffrey Hoogervorst (born 23 October 1984) is a Dutch retired footballer who plays as a central defender.

title: Adilson Dos Santos
text: Adilson Ben David Dos Santos (born 15 May 1974) is a Dutch retired footballer.

title: GoCatch
text: goCatch is an Australian-based startup transportation network company that develops and operates a mobile app taxi cab ordering service of the same name.

title: GoCatch
text: It was founded by two Australian entrepreneurs, Andrew Campbell and Ned Moorfield in 2011.

title: GoCatch
text: The application is compatible with iOS, BlackBerry, Android and Windows Phone 7 platforms.

title: Milgram & Company Ltd.
text: Milgram & Company Ltd. is a Canadian integrated logistics services company specializing in customs brokerage, freight forwarding and North American transport.

title: Milgram & Company Ltd.
text: The company opened in Montreal, Quebec in 1951.

title: Milgram & Company Ltd.
text: In 2011, Milgram expanded into its new headquarters within a fully renovated facility built with green materials at 400 Wellington Street in close proximity to the Old Port of Montreal.

title: Milgram & Company Ltd.
text: That year, it was also named one of Canada's 50 best managed companies by the National Post, Deloitte and CIBC.

title: Milgram & Company Ltd.
text: Milgram also ranked number 1 in Les Affaires' "classement des 300 plus grandes PME québecoises" (300 Best Quebec SME's) in 2011 and ranked among the province's top 500 companies of any size.

title: Milgram & Company Ltd.
text: In 2010, the company was the first in Canada to launch a real-time business-to-business tracing service for iPhone and later released it for BlackBerry in 2011.

title: Milgram & Company Ltd.
text: Milgram has offices in Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver, Canada and is supported by a network of agents worldwide.

title: Quanta Computer
text: Quanta Computer Incorporated () () is a Taiwan-based manufacturer of notebook computers and other electronic hardware.

title: Quanta Computer
text: Its customers include Apple Inc., Dell, Hewlett-Packard Inc., Alienware, Amazon.com, Cisco, Fujitsu, Gericom, Lenovo, LG, Maxdata, MPC, BlackBerry Ltd, Sharp Corporation, Siemens AG, Sony, Sun Microsystems, Toshiba, Verizon Wireless, and Vizio.

title: Quanta Computer
text: It was founded by Barry Lam in 1988.

title: Quanta Computer
text: Lam continues to head the company.

title: Quanta Computer
text: Quanta has extended its businesses into enterprise network systems, home entertainment, mobile communication, automotive electronics, and digital home markets.

title: Quanta Computer
text: The company also designs, manufactures and markets GPS systems, including handheld GPS, in-car GPS, Bluetooth GPS and GPS with other positioning technologies.

title: BlackBerry DTEK60
text: BlackBerry DTEK60 is an Android smartphone co-developed and distributed by BlackBerry Limited, and manufactured by TCL.

title: BlackBerry DTEK60
text: Unveiled on October 25, 2016, it is BlackBerry's second device in the DTEK series after the BlackBerry DTEK50, and the third Android device after the BlackBerry Priv slider.

title: BlackBerry DTEK60
text: As with the Priv and the DTEK50, the DTEK60 Android operating system is customized with features inspired by those seen on BlackBerry's in-house operating systems, and with hardware and software security enhancements (such as the titular DTEK software).

title: BlackBerry DTEK60
text: The DTEK60 features a fingerprint sensor on the rear of the device.

title: BlackBerry DTEK50
text: BlackBerry DTEK50 is an Android smartphone co-developed and distributed by BlackBerry Limited, and manufactured by TCL, being a modified and rebranded variant of TCL's Alcatel Idol 4.

title: BlackBerry DTEK50
text: Unveiled during a press conference held on July 26, 2016, it is BlackBerry's second Android device after the BlackBerry Priv slider.

title: BlackBerry DTEK50
text: As with the Priv, the DTEK50's Android operating system is customized with features inspired by those seen on BlackBerry's in-house operating systems, and with hardware and software security enhancements (such as the titular DTEK software).

title: Serum Institute of India
text: Serum Institute of India is a manufacturer of immunobiological drugs including vaccines in India.

title: Serum Institute of India
text: The company is managed by the Poonawalla group which fully owned by Cyrus Poonawalla.

title: Serum Institute of India
text: The company was founded by Poonawalla in 1966.

title: Serum Institute of India
text: It is the world's largest vaccine producer by number of doses produced.

title: Serum Institute of India
text: The company is developing an intra-nasal swine flu vaccine.

title: Serum Institute of India
text: Co-developed with US-based Mass Biologics of the University of Massachusetts Medical School, it invented a fast-acting anti-rabies agent, Rabies Human Monoclonal Antibody (RMAb).

title: BlackBerry Limited
text: BlackBerry Limited is a Canadian-based multinational company specializing in enterprise software and the Internet of things.

title: BlackBerry Limited
text: Originally known as Research In Motion (RIM), it is best known to the general public as the former developer of the BlackBerry brand of smartphones, and tablets, it transitioned to an enterprise software and services company under CEO John S. Chen.

title: BlackBerry Limited
text: Its products are used worldwide by various businesses, car makers, and government agencies, and include the AtHoc crisis communications platform, the QNX real-time operating system, and BlackBerry UEM, an endpoint management platform.

title: BlackBerry Limited
text: BlackBerry was founded in 1984 as Research In Motion by Mike Lazaridis and Douglas Fregin.

title: BlackBerry Limited
text: In 1992, Lazaridis hired Jim Balsillie, and Lazaridis and Balsillie served as co-CEOs until January 22, 2012.

title: BlackBerry Limited
text: In November 2013, John S. Chen took over as CEO.

title: BlackBerry Limited
text: His initial strategy was to subcontract manufacturing to Foxconn, and to focus on software technology.

title: BlackBerry Limited
text: Currently, his strategy includes forming licensing partnerships with device manufacturers such as TCL Communication, and unifying BlackBerry’s software portfolio.

title: Lexicon Branding
text: Lexicon Branding, Inc., is an American marketing firm founded in 1982 by David Placek.

title: Lexicon Branding
text: It focuses on selecting brand names for companies and products.

title: Lexicon Branding
text: The company devised the brand names Pentium, BlackBerry, PowerBook, Zune, Swiffer, Febreze, Subaru Outback and Forester, Toyota Scion, DeskJet, Dasani, OnStar, Embassy Suites Hotels and Metreon, among others.

title: TuneIn
text: TuneIn is an audio streaming service delivering live news, radio, and sports, in addition to music, podcasts, and audiobooks, to an audience of over 60 million monthly active users worldwide.

title: TuneIn
text: The company is based in San Francisco, California.

title: TuneIn
text: Founded by Bill Moore in 2002 as RadioTime in Dallas, Texas, TuneIn has more than 100,000 broadcast radio stations and four million on-demand programs and podcasts from around the world.

title: TuneIn
text: TuneIn is available on the web at TuneIn.com, for a suite of mobile apps: iOS, Android, BlackBerry, Samsung, Windows Phone, and on over 200 connected devices, including Sonos, Bose, Amazon Echo, and Google Home connected speakers.

title: TuneIn
text: TuneIn service is also available in over 50 vehicle models, including the Tesla Model S. TuneIn raised over $47 million in venture funding from Institutional Venture Partners, Sequoia Capital, GV, General Catalyst Partners, and Icon Ventures.

title: Cardmobili
text: CardMobili is a European-based mobile application development company founded in 2009.

title: Cardmobili
text: The primary application of the company, also named CardMobili, provides a platform for managing customer loyalty programs via mobile phones.

title: Cardmobili
text: The application provides for digitizing and storing loyalty and membership cards, allowing their barcodes to be scanned directly from the device screen.

title: Cardmobili
text: It supports Android, iPhone, BlackBerry, Windows Phone 7, Windows Mobile, Nokia, Vodafone, and other brands.

title: Paris by Night (2012 film)
text: Paris by Night (French: "Une nuit" ) is a 2012 French crime film directed by Philippe Lefebvre.

title: 37th César Awards
text: The 37th César Awards ceremony, presented by the French Academy of Cinema Arts and Techniques (Académie des Arts et Techniques du Cinéma), was held on 24 February 2012, at the Théâtre du Châtelet in Paris.

title: 37th César Awards
text: The awards honoured the best films of 2011. "

title: 37th César Awards
text: The Artist" won six out of its ten nominations, including Best Film, Best Director (Michel Hazanavicius), Best Actress (Bérénice Bejo), and Best Cinematography (Guillaume Schiffman).

title: 37th César Awards
text: The ceremony was chaired by Guillaume Canet, with Antoine de Caunes as master of ceremonies.

title: 37th César Awards
text: Nominations were announced 27 January 2012.

title: 21st César Awards
text: The 21st César Awards ceremony, presented by the Académie des Arts et Techniques du Cinéma, honoured the best French films of 1995 and took place on 3 February 1996 at the Théâtre des Champs-Élysées in Paris.

title: 21st César Awards
text: The ceremony was chaired by Philippe Noiret and hosted by Antoine de Caunes. "

title: 21st César Awards
text: La Haine" won the award for Best Film.

title: Last Night (2010 film)
text: Last Night is a 2010 drama romance film written and directed by Massy Tadjedin.

title: Last Night (2010 film)
text: It stars Keira Knightley, Sam Worthington, Eva Mendes, and Guillaume Canet.

title: Last Night (2010 film)
text: The film's official trailer was released on November 6, 2010.

title: Last Night (2010 film)
text: It was released both in theaters and video-on-demand on May 6, 2011 in the United States.

title: Last Night (2010 film)
text: The film centers on Joanna (Keira Knightley) and Michael Reed (Sam Worthington), a successful and happy couple.

title: Last Night (2010 film)
text: They are moving along in their lives together until Joanna meets Laura (Eva Mendes), the stunningly beautiful colleague whom Michael never mentioned.

title: Last Night (2010 film)
text: While Michael is away with Laura on a business trip, Joanna runs into an old but never quite forgotten love, Alex (Guillaume Canet).

title: Last Night (2010 film)
text: As the night progresses and temptation increases, each must confront who they really are.

title: 12th Lumières Awards
text: The 12th Lumières Awards ceremony, presented by the Académie des Lumières, was held on 5 February 2007, at the Espace Pierre Cardin in Paris.

title: 12th Lumières Awards
text: The ceremony was chaired by Isabelle Mergault. "

title: 12th Lumières Awards
text: Tell No One" won the award for Best Film.

title: ARY Film Award for Best Film Jury
text: The ARY Film Award for Best Film Jury is one of the ARY Film Awards of Merit presented annually by the ARY Digital Network and Entertainment Channel to producers working in the film industry and is the only category in which every member is eligible to submit a nomination.

title: ARY Film Award for Best Film Jury
text: Best Film Jury is considered the most important of the ARY Film Awards, as it represents all the directing, acting, music composing, writing, editing and other efforts put forth into a drama.

title: ARY Film Award for Best Film Jury
text: This award is one of the two Best Film awards in ceremony which is awarded to relevant film only on the decision of ceremony Jury, while other being awarded on Viewers Voting's.

title: ARY Film Award for Best Film
text: The ARY Film Award for Best Film is one of the ARY Film Awards of Merit presented annually by the ARY Digital Network and Entertainment Channel to producers working in the film industry and is the only category in which every member is eligible to submit a nomination.

title: ARY Film Award for Best Film
text: Best Film is considered the most important of the ARY Film Awards, as it represents all the directing, acting, music composing, writing, editing and other efforts put forth into a drama.

title: ARY Film Award for Best Film
text: This award is one of the two Best Film awards in ceremony which is awarded to relevant film only on the decision of ceremony Jury, while other being awarded on Viewers Voting's.

title: The Judge (1984 film)
text: The Judge (French: "le juge" ) is a 1984 French crime drama film directed by Philippe Lefebvre.

title: Tell No One
text: Tell No One (French: "Ne le dis à personne" ) is a 2006 French thriller film directed by Guillaume Canet and based on the novel of the same name by Harlan Coben.

title: Tell No One
text: Written by Canet and Philippe Lefebvre and starring François Cluzet, the film won four categories at the 2007 César Awards in France: Best Director (Guillaume Canet), Best Actor (François Cluzet), Best Editing and Best Music Written for a Film.

title: 2nd Lumières Awards
text: The 2nd Lumières Awards ceremony, presented by the Académie des Lumières, was held on 13 February 1997.

title: 2nd Lumières Awards
text: The ceremony was chaired by Philippe Noiret. "

title: 2nd Lumières Awards
text: Ridicule" won three awards including Best Film, Best Actor and Best Actress.

title: Driven (Canadian magazine)
text: Driven was a Canadian men's lifestyle magazine, started in 2004 by publisher Michel Crépault based on a concept presented and developed by former editor-in-chief Michael La Fave and creative director Laurance Yap.

title: Driven (Canadian magazine)
text: "Driven" was published six times a year.

title: Driven (Canadian magazine)
text: It offered a combination of automotive, fashion, technology, travel and leisure content for affluent Canadian men featuring exotic locations and automobiles.

title: Driven (Canadian magazine)
text: The headquarters of the magazine was in Toronto.

title: Driven (Canadian magazine)
text: In 2007 the magazine became the best-selling men's magazine in Canada with a circulation of 150,000 copies.

title: Autostraddle
text: Autostraddle is an independently owned online magazine and social network for lesbian, bisexual, and queer women (cis and trans) as well as non-binary people.

title: Autostraddle
text: The website is a "politically progressive queer feminist media source" that features content covering LGBT and feminist news, politics, opinion, culture, arts and entertainment as well as lifestyle content such as DIY crafting, sex, relationships, fashion, food and technology.

title: Autostraddle
text: Autostraddle was founded by CEO, CFO and Editor-in-Chief Marie "Riese" Bernard and Design Director Alexandra Vega in March 2009.

title: Autostraddle
text: The senior editorial team consists of Riese Bernard, Laneia Jones, Rachel Kincaid, Yvonne Marquez, and Heather Hogan.

title: Autostraddle
text: Feminist Collections has highlighted Autostraddle's successful balance between serious, political and light-hearted articles.

title: Bust (magazine)
text: BUST is a women's lifestyle magazine that is published six times a year.

title: Bust (magazine)
text: The magazine is published by Debbie Stoller and Laurie Henzel.

title: Alternative fashion
text: Alternative fashion is fashion that, at least at one time, stood apart from mainstream commercial fashion.

title: Alternative fashion
text: Alternative fashion includes the fashions of specific subcultures such as emo, scene, Goth subculture, Hip hop, Heavy metal fashion, and Cyberpunk, Lolita fashion however it is not limited to these.

title: Alternative fashion
text: In general, alternative, or 'alt', fashion does not conform to widely popular style trends of the times that have widespread popularity.

title: Alternative fashion
text: It may exhibit itself as a fringe style – extremely attention-grabbing and more artistic than practical – but it can also develop from anti-fashion sentiments that focus on simplistic utilitarian drives (e.g.: grunge fashion, which was largely based around comfort and availability).

title: Mookychick
text: Mookychick is an independent daily online magazine and community with more than 100,000 readers a month and over 5,000 forum members.

title: Mookychick
text: "Mookychick" content includes analysis of current sociopolitical events, social and cultural trends, alternative fashion, movies, books, music and arts and crafts from a feminist perspective.

title: Mookychick
text: In contrast with feminist publications and communities such as "Jezebel", or "Bust", "Mookychick" explores gender issues from the perspective of the social outsider who feels they have been marginalised by their lifestyle choices.

title: Bitch (magazine)
text: Bitch is an independent, quarterly magazine published in Portland, Oregon.

title: Bitch (magazine)
text: Its tagline is "a feminist response to pop culture".

title: Bitch (magazine)
text: "Bitch" is published by the non-profit Bitch Media feminist media organization, dedicated to providing and encouraging an engaged, thoughtful feminist response to mainstream media and popular culture.

title: Bitch (magazine)
text: The magazine includes analysis of current political events, social and cultural trends, television shows, movies, books, music, advertising, and artwork from a feminist perspective.

title: Bitch (magazine)
text: It has about 80,000 readers.

title: Chrysalis (magazine)
text: Chrysalis: A Magazine of Women's Culture was a feminist publication produced from 1977 to 1980.

title: Chrysalis (magazine)
text: The self-published magazine was founded by Kirsten Grimstad and Susan Rennie at the Woman's Building in downtown Los Angeles.

title: Chrysalis (magazine)
text: "Chysalis" grew from Grimstad and Rennie's editorial work on the self-help resource books, The New Woman's Survival Catalog and The New Woman's Survival Sourcebook.

title: Chrysalis (magazine)
text: "Chrysalis" distinguished itself from other feminist publications through an organic integration of politics, literature, cultural studies, and art.

title: Chrysalis (magazine)
text: The magazine was produced through a collective process that grew out of the feminist practice of consciousness-raising.

title: Chrysalis (magazine)
text: Unusually broad in scope, "Chrysalis" did not substitute breadth for quality.

title: Chrysalis (magazine)
text: The authors, poets, essayists, and researchers contributing to the magazine reveals a veritable who's who of towering intellects of the feminist movement: black lesbian activist Audre Lorde; the magazine's poetry editor, Robin Morgan, who later served as editor of Ms. from 1990-1993: award winning poet Adrienne Rich; novelist Marge Percy; artist Judy Chicago; science fiction writer Joanna Russ; art critic Lucy Lippard, plus Mary Daly, Dolores Hayden, Andrea Dworkin, Marilyn Hacker, Arlene Raven, and Elizabeth Janeway.

title: Chrysalis (magazine)
text: Over a three-year span, the all volunteer staff produced ten issues before they were forced to disband in 1981 due to financial difficulties.

title: Fem (magazine)
text: Fem is a major feminist magazine and the first Latin American one.

title: Fem (magazine)
text: The idea for it was conceived in 1975 during a conference in Morelia, Michoacán, and it was established in the following year by Alaíde Foppa and Margarita García Flores.

title: Fem (magazine)
text: In 2005, its director, Esperanza Brito de Martí, reported that the print version was being discontinued due to high costs and from then on, the magazine would only be published online.

title: Fem (magazine)
text: The magazine focuses on social and political issues, art and cinema.

title: Fem (magazine)
text: It contains news, poetry and short stories.

title: Fem (magazine)
text: Topics range from domestic violence to health care, women in the student movement, AIDS, prostitution, and Chicanas.

title: Fem (magazine)
text: The headquarters is in Mexico City.

title: Fem (magazine)
text: The aspiration of the magazine was to bring a broad feminist perspective to Latin America, in hopes of inspiring grassroots feminist movements and achieving a recognition of the feminist ideology within the political and cultural spheres.

title: Down Shift Magazine
text: Down Shift Magazine is an American-English language automotive lifestyle magazine based out of the Tampa Bay metropolitan area of central Florida.

title: Down Shift Magazine
text: The publication is known for its focus on events, trends and movements which affect the automotive enthusiast culture.

title: Down Shift Magazine
text: The publication features a wide array of articles and content spanning cultural trends, travel, technical and automotive specific.

title: Down Shift Magazine
text: "Down Shift Magazine" is also known for its pictorials, featuring female models set against the backdrop of its featured vehicles.

title: Gába
text: Gába is a bilingual Sámi magazine that is published six times a year by the Sámi women's forum Sami Nisson Forum and that has funds earmarked for it in the annual budget of the Sami Parliament of Norway.

title: Gába
text: The magazine was published for the first time on International Women's Day (March 8) in 1996.

title: Gába
text: Although the main languages are Norwegian and Northern Sámi, articles are occasionally written in Southern Sámi, Lule Sámi and Swedish.

title: Gába
text: The articles mainly deal with the everyday life of the Sámi from a woman's perspective.

title: Gott, man lobet dich in der Stille, BWV 120
text: Gott, man lobet dich in der Stille (God, You are praised in the stillness), BWV 120 , is a sacred cantata by Johann Sebastian Bach.

title: Gott, man lobet dich in der Stille, BWV 120
text: He composed it in Leipzig for the occasion of "Ratswechsel ", the inauguration of a new town council in a church service, probably in 1742.

title: Gott, man lobet dich in der Stille, BWV 120
text: Parts of the cantata appeared in a wedding cantata (BWV 120a ) and a cantata (BWV 120b ) commemorating the Augsburg Confession in 1730.

title: Gott, man lobet dich in der Stille, BWV 120
text: Bach reworked the choral second movement for the "Symbolum Nicenum" of his Mass in B minor.

title: Carl Orff
text: Carl Heinrich Maria Orff (] ; (1895--)10 1895 – (1982--)29 1982 ) was a German composer, best known for his cantata "Carmina Burana" (1937).

title: Carl Orff
text: In addition to his career as a composer, Orff developed an influential approach toward music education for children.

title: Johann Abraham Peter Schulz
text: Johann Abraham Peter Schulz (31 March 1747, Lüneburg – 10 June 1800,Schwedt) was a German musician.

title: Johann Abraham Peter Schulz
text: He is best known as the composer of the melody for Matthias Claudius's poem "Der Mond ist aufgegangen" and the Christmas carol "Ihr Kinderlein kommet".

title: Der Mond ist aufgegangen
text: "Der Mond ist aufgegangen" (German for "The moon has risen") is a German lullaby and evening song by Matthias Claudius, one of the most popular in German literature.

title: Der Mond ist aufgegangen
text: Also known under the name Abendlied (German for "evening song") it was first released in "Musen-Almanach" in 1779, published by Johann Heinrich Voß.

title: Der Mond ist aufgegangen
text: The poem "" (German for "Now all forests rest") by Paul Gerhardt from 1647 was its model.

title: Der Mond ist aufgegangen
text: The exact dating is unclear; some believe that it was written in 1778 in Hamburg-Wandsbek, others that it originated earlier in Darmstadt.

title: Heino Gaze
text: Heino Gaze (20 February 1908 – 24 October 1967) was German composer.

title: Heino Gaze
text: In Germany he is best known as the composer of "La Le Lu (nur der Mann im Mond schaut zu)" sung by Heinz Rühmann in the film Wenn der Vater mit dem Sohne.

title: Heino Gaze
text: Probably most famous in America is his song "Kalkutta liegt am Ganges" which became a hit performed by Lawrence Welk under the title "Calcutta".

title: Heino Gaze
text: He worked on more than thirty film scores during his career.

title: Gott, man lobet dich in der Stille, BWV 120b
text: Gott, man lobet dich in der Stille (God, you are praised in the stillness), BWV 120b, is a cantata by Johann Sebastian Bach.

title: Gott, man lobet dich in der Stille, BWV 120b
text: He composed it in 1730 to commemorate the Augsburg Confession.

title: Nun komm, der Heiden Heiland
text: "Nun komm, der Heiden Heiland " (original: "Nu kom der Heyden heyland ", English: "Now come, Saviour of the heathens") is a Lutheran chorale of 1524 with words written by Martin Luther, based on "Veni redemptor gentium " by Ambrose.

title: Nun komm, der Heiden Heiland
text: It was printed in the Erfurt "Enchiridion" of 1524.

title: Nun komm, der Heiden Heiland
text: The chorale was used as the prominent hymn for the first Sunday of Advent for centuries.

title: Nun komm, der Heiden Heiland
text: It was used widely in organ settings by Protestant baroque composers, most notably Johann Sebastian Bach: he set it as the opening chorale prelude BWV 599 of Orgelbüchlein; and three times—as BWV 659 (one of his best known organ compositions), BWV 660 and BWV 661—in his Great Eighteen Chorale Preludes.

title: Nun komm, der Heiden Heiland
text: Bach used the hymn in his chorale cantata "Nun komm, der Heiden Heiland", BWV 62 (1724) and in the opening chorale fantasia of his earlier cantata "Nun komm, der Heiden Heiland", BWV 61 , BWV 61 (1714).

title: Nun komm, der Heiden Heiland
text: Max Reger composed a chorale prelude as No. 29 of his 52 Chorale Preludes, Op. 67 in 1902.

title: Chorale cantata (Bach)
text: There are 52 chorale cantatas by Johann Sebastian Bach surviving in at least one complete version.

title: Chorale cantata (Bach)
text: Around 40 of these were composed during his second year as Thomaskantor in Leipzig, which started after Trinity Sunday 4 June 1724, and form the backbone of his chorale cantata cycle.

title: Chorale cantata (Bach)
text: The eldest known cantata by Bach, an early version of "Christ lag in Todes Banden", BWV 4, presumably written in 1707, was a chorale cantata.

title: Chorale cantata (Bach)
text: The last chorale cantata he wrote in his second year in Leipzig was "Wie schön leuchtet der Morgenstern", BWV 1, first performed on Palm Sunday, 25 March 1725.

title: Chorale cantata (Bach)
text: In the ten years after that he wrote at least a dozen further chorale cantatas and other cantatas that were added to his chorale cantata cycle.

title: Festgesang
text: The Festgesang (Gutenberg cantata), also known as "Festgesang zur Eröffnung der am ersten Tage der vierten Säkularfeier der Erfindung der Buchdruckerkunst", was composed by Felix Mendelssohn in the first half of 1840 for performance in Leipzig at the celebrations to mark the putative quatercentenary of the invention of printing with movable type by Johannes Gutenberg.

title: Festgesang
text: It was first performed in the market-square at Leipzig on 24 June 1840.

title: Der Mond
text: Der Mond ("The Moon") is an opera in one act by Carl Orff based on a Grimm's fairy tale) with a libretto by the composer.

title: Der Mond
text: It was first performed on 5 February 1939 by the Bavarian State Opera in Munich under the direction of Clemens Krauss.

title: Der Mond
text: The composer describes it not as an opera but as "Ein kleines Welttheater" ("A little world theatre"); the performance lasts for about one hour and is often paired with Orff's "Die Kluge".

title: The F Word (2013 film)
text: The F Word (released in some countries as What If?)

title: The F Word (2013 film)
text: is a 2013 Canadian romantic comedy film directed by Michael Dowse and written by Elan Mastai, based on TJ Dawe and Michael Rinaldi's play "Toothpaste and Cigars".

title: The F Word (2013 film)
text: The film stars Daniel Radcliffe, Zoe Kazan, Megan Park, Adam Driver, Mackenzie Davis and Rafe Spall and follows a pair of best friends who begin to have feelings for each other.

title: Mackenzie Davis
text: Mackenzie Davis (born April 1, 1987) is a Canadian actress.

title: Mackenzie Davis
text: She made her film debut in "Smashed", and later appeared in "Breathe In", "That Awkward Moment", and "The F Word", the latter for which she received a Canadian Screen Award nomination.

title: The Right Kind of Wrong (film)
text: The Right Kind of Wrong is a 2013 Canadian romantic comedy film directed by Jeremiah S. Chechik, based on the 1987 novel "Sex and Sunsets" by Tim Sandlin.

title: The Right Kind of Wrong (film)
text: Its premiere was in the Gala Presentation section at the 2013 Toronto International Film Festival.

title: No Stranger Than Love
text: No Stranger Than Love is a 2015 Canadian romantic comedy film directed by Nick Wernham and written by Steve Adams.

title: No Stranger Than Love
text: The film stars Alison Brie, Justin Chatwin and Colin Hanks.

title: No Stranger Than Love
text: The film was released on June 17, 2016, in a limited release and through video on demand by Orion Pictures.

title: Love, Sex and Eating the Bones
text: Love, Sex and Eating the Bones is a 2003 Canadian romantic comedy film directed and screenwriter|written by Sudz Sutherland featuring a mostly African American and Black Canadian leading cast.

title: Love, Sex and Eating the Bones
text: It premiered and played twice at the 2003 Toronto International Film Festival, where it won the award for Best Canadian First Feature Film.

title: Gerontophilia (film)
text: Gerontophilia is a 2013 Canadian romantic comedy film directed by Bruce LaBruce and written by LaBruce and Daniel Allen Cox.

title: Gerontophilia (film)
text: It was screened in the Vanguard section at the 2013 Toronto International Film Festival.

title: Men with Brooms
text: Men with Brooms is a 2002 Canadian romantic comedy film, starring and directed by Paul Gross.

title: Men with Brooms
text: Centred on the sport of curling, the offbeat comedy tells the story of a reunited curling team from a small Canadian town as they work through their respective life issues and struggle to win the championship for the sake of their late coach.

title: Love at First Sight (1977 Canadian film)
text: Love at First Sight is a 1977 Canadian romantic comedy film directed by Rex Bromfield,

title: Lovesick (2016 film)
text: Lovesick is a Canadian romantic comedy film, released in 2016.

title: Lovesick (2016 film)
text: It was written and directed by Winnipeg filmmaker Tyson Caron, his directorial debut.

title: Dr. Cabbie
text: Dr. Cabbie is a 2014 Canadian romantic comedy film that stars Kunal Nayyar, Vinay Virmani, and Adrianne Palicki.

title: Dr. Cabbie
text: The film is directed by Jean-François Pouliot and co-produced by Bollywood actor, Salman Khan.

title: Dr. Cabbie
text: The story revolves around a newly arrived immigrant doctor in Canada who cannot get a job and is forced to become a taxi driver.

title: Dr. Cabbie
text: He becomes a local hero when he converts his taxi into a mobile medical clinic.

title: Dr. Cabbie
text: The film was released on DVD and Blu-ray from 23 December 2014.

title: Crusade for Citizenship
text: Crusade for Citizenship was the 1958 voter project organized by the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC).

title: Crusade for Citizenship
text: The aim of the project was to double the number of African-American voters in the southern United States for the 1958 and 1960 elections.

title: Crusade for Citizenship
text: Initially organized by Ella Baker as Associate Director then by Reverend John Tilley as the first Executive Director.

title: Crusade for Citizenship
text: The project was unsuccessful in achieving its objectives.

title: Barack Obama
text: Barack Hussein Obama II ( ; born August 4, 1961) is an American politician who served as the 44th President of the United States from 2009 to 2017.

title: Barack Obama
text: He is the first African American to have served as president.

title: Barack Obama
text: He previously served in the U.S. Senate representing Illinois from 2005 to 2008 and in the Illinois State Senate from 1997 to 2004.

title: Andrew McGuire
text: Andrew McGuire (born in 1945 in Oakland, California) is an American trauma prevention specialist and grassroots campaigner.

title: Andrew McGuire
text: He was the first Executive Director of Action Against Burns (Boston, 1973–75), founder and Executive Director of the Burn Council (San Francisco General Hospital, 1975–1981), which was renamed the Trauma Foundation, in 1981.

title: Andrew McGuire
text: He is currently the Executive Director of California OneCare, a campaign to establish a "Medicare for All" type health insurance for all residents of California.

title: Keith Michael Fiels
text: Keith Michael Fiels (born 1949) is an American librarian.

title: Keith Michael Fiels
text: He was appointed Executive Director of the American Library Association in July 2002.

title: Keith Michael Fiels
text: In September 2016, he announced his retirement from the position.

title: Keith Michael Fiels
text: He retired on July 31, 2017.

title: Keith Michael Fiels
text: Fiels has served as Executive Director longer than anyone else holding that title.

title: Keith Michael Fiels
text: Melvil Dewey (1879-1890, 1897-1898) and Carl Millam (1920-1948) served longer as the "Secretary" of the Association.

title: Keith Michael Fiels
text: David Clift served as Secretary from 1951-1958, and was the first Executive Director (1958-1972)

title: Sesame Workshop
text: Sesame Workshop (SW), formerly Children's Television Workshop (CTW), is an American non-profit organization which has been responsible for the production of several educational children's programs—including its first and best-known, "Sesame Street"—that have been televised internationally.

title: Sesame Workshop
text: Television producer Joan Ganz Cooney and foundation executive Lloyd Morrisett developed with the idea to form an organization to produce "Sesame Street", a television series which would help children, especially those from low-income families, prepare for school.

title: Sesame Workshop
text: They spent two years, from 1966 to 1968, researching, developing, and raising money for the new series.

title: Sesame Workshop
text: Cooney was named as the Workshop's first executive director, which was termed "one of the most important television developments of the decade".

title: Carl Anthony
text: Carl Anthony (born February 8, 1939) is an African American architect, regional planner, social justice activist, and author.

title: Carl Anthony
text: He is the founder and co-director of Breakthrough Communities, an Earth House Center project dedicated to building multiracial leadership for sustainable communities in California and the rest of the nation.

title: Carl Anthony
text: He is the former President of the Earth Island Institute, and is the co-founder and former Executive Director of its Urban Habitat Program, one of the first environmental justice organizations to address race and class issues.

title: Equality Ohio
text: Equality Ohio is a nonpartisan, nonprofit organization that advocates for full equality for the LGBTQ community.

title: Equality Ohio
text: It is the statewide authority advocating for LGBT families with over 30,000 members.

title: Equality Ohio
text: It is headquartered in Columbus, Ohio.

title: Equality Ohio
text: It was founded in 2005 following the passage of Ohio Issue 1, which banned state recognition of same-sex relationships.

title: Equality Ohio
text: Equality Ohio's first Executive Director, Lynne Bowman is one of the founders of Equality Ohio and served as its executive director for over 5 years.

title: Equality Ohio
text: Sue Doerfer, became Executive Director in December 2009 and announced her resignation in November 2010.

title: Equality Ohio
text: She was replaced by Ed Mullen, a former candidate for Illinois State Representative and civil rights lawyer from Chicago., Equality Ohio accepted the resignation of Ed Mullen, effective 29 June 2012.

title: Equality Ohio
text: Kim Welter then served as the Interim Executive Director, has served as the Director of Programs and Outreach at Equality Ohio and has five years of experience.

title: Equality Ohio
text: She joined the organization in 2008 after serving as the Executive Director of Equality Toledo for over 2 years.

title: Equality Ohio
text: In November 2012 the organization hired its fourth Executive Director, Elyzabeth Joy Holford.

title: Masorti Olami
text: Masorti Olami (also known as The World Council of Conservative/Masorti Synagogues) builds, renews and strengthens Jewish life throughout the world, with efforts that focus on existing and developing communities in Europe, Latin America, the Former Soviet Union, Africa, Asia and Australia.

title: Masorti Olami
text: More than 135 kehillot (communities) are affiliated with Masorti Olami in Argentina (through FEDECC), Australia, Brazil, China, the Czech Republic, France, Germany, Hungary, Israel, Japan, the Netherlands, Peru, Portugal, Russia, South Africa, Spain, Sweden, Ukraine, Uruguay, the United Kingdom and a more than 600 more in Canada and the United States of America.

title: Masorti Olami
text: All of its activities are conducted within the context of the overall Conservative Judaism movement, in close cooperation with its affiliated organizations in North America and Israel.

title: Bikes Not Bombs
text: Bikes Not Bombs is a Boston, Massachusetts based bicycle project which recycles donated bicycles, trains young people to fix their own bikes and become employable mechanics and sends thousands of bicycles to communities in countries such as Northern Uganda, Ghana, St. Kitts & Nevis, El Salvador, Sierra Leone and Guatemala.

title: Bikes Not Bombs
text: The organization was founded in 1984 by Carl Kurz, a bicycle mechanic and Michael Replogle, a Maryland-based transportation planner.

title: Bikes Not Bombs
text: Bikes Not Bombs provided bicycles and bicycle parts to Nicaragua in opposition to the Reagan administration's support for the Contra War, and in solidarity with the Nicaraguan people and in resistance to the U.S. trade embargo against Nicaragua in effect at the time.

title: Bikes Not Bombs
text: Mira Brown became involved with BNB's work while in Nicaragua and later became the organization's first Executive Director.

title: Developing Communities Project
text: The Developing Communities Project (DCP) is a faith-based organization in Chicago, Illinois.

title: Developing Communities Project
text: DCP was organized in 1984 as a branch of the Calumet Community Religious Conference (CCRC) in response to lay-offs and plant closings in Southeast Chicago in the 1970s and 1980s.

title: Developing Communities Project
text: In 1986, DCP was incorporated as a not-for-profit organization under the leadership of its first executive director Barack Obama.

title: Developing Communities Project
text: It continues to provide literacy, job training and leadership development programs, for which it has received multiple awards, such as the 2007 Chicago Community Organizing Award.

title: Jane's Addiction discography
text: The discography of Jane's Addiction, an American alternative rock band, consists of four studio albums, two live albums, four compilation albums, seventeen singles and ten music videos. Jane's Addiction was formed in Los Angeles, California in 1985.

title: Jane's Addiction discography
text: The band is composed of Perry Farrell (vocals), Dave Navarro (guitar), Eric Avery (bass) and Stephen Perkins (drums).

title: Jane's Addiction discography
text: After breaking up in 1991, Jane's Addiction briefly toured in 1997, reunited in 2001 and then parted ways in 2004.

title: Jane's Addiction discography
text: Jane's Addiction have since reunited again in 2008, with founding member Eric Avery returning on bass (Avery has since left again).

title: Jane's Addiction discography
text: The band's varied musical style have influences rooted in punk rock and heavy metal.

title: Christmas Time Has Come
text: Christmas Time Has Come was released on 12 November 2014, and is a Weeping Willows Christmas album.

title: Weeping Willows
text: Weeping Willows is a Swedish indie rock group that started in 1995.

title: Magnus Carlson
text: Magnus Carlson (born 3 August 1968) is a Swedish singer, composer and songwriter.

title: Magnus Carlson
text: He is a member of the Swedish indie rock group Weeping Willows, and has released several solo albums.

title: Magnus Carlson
text: In 2016 he participated in Så mycket bättre which was broadcast on TV4.

title: Johan Forsman
text: Johan Forsman or Johan Forsman Löwenström is a Swedish musician, singer, record producer, songwriter, music arranger and engineer based in Gothenburg, Sweden.

title: Johan Forsman
text: He was a member krautrock band Hybrizine in the late eighties and psychedelic rock band The Bad Karma in the early nineties.

title: Johan Forsman
text: Forsman has worked with musical acts such as the Soundtrack of our lives, Caesars, Weeping Willows, Håkan Hellström, Karin Dreijers early band Honey is Cool, Jens Lekman, Thåström, among others.

title: Johan Forsman
text: Johan Forsman is still active as a record producer/engineer and is currently a member of Tapefly.

title: Porno for Pyros (album)
text: Porno for Pyros is the eponymous debut album by Porno for Pyros, released on April 27, 1993 on the same label as Jane's Addiction, Warner Bros.

title: Porno for Pyros (album)
text: Records.

title: Porno for Pyros (album)
text: Jane's Addiction guitarist Dave Navarro and bassist Eric Avery, battling substance abuse issues, had left the band in 1991 in an attempt to stay clean, though the other half of the band wished to continue creating music.

title: Porno for Pyros (album)
text: The remaining members of Jane's Addiction, Perry Farrell and Stephen Perkins, were joined by guitarist Peter DiStefano and future Jane's Addiction bassist Martyn LeNoble, and continued under the new band name Porno for Pyros.

title: Porno for Pyros (album)
text: The band (and album) name is a reference to the 1992 Los Angeles riots, which are mentioned throughout the songs on the album as a recurring theme.

title: Stefan Sundström
text: Stefan Sundström is a Swedish singer/songwriter and troubadour.

title: Stefan Sundström
text: After dropping out of school, he started playing in small bands such as Trots, Läppstars and Apache, which later went on to become Weeping Willows.

title: Stefan Sundström
text: Sundström's music often refers to other important Swedish musicians like Evert Taube, Dan Andersson, Bellman, Alice Tegnér, Astrid Lindgren, Ulf Dageby and Cornelis Vreeswijk.

title: Perry Farrell
text: Perry Farrell (born Peretz Bernstein; March 29, 1959) is an American singer-songwriter and musician, best known as the frontman for the alternative rock band Jane's Addiction.

title: Perry Farrell
text: Farrell created the touring festival Lollapalooza as a farewell tour for Jane's Addiction in 1991; it has since evolved into an annual destination festival.

title: Perry Farrell
text: Farrell continues to produce Lollapalooza with partners William Morris Agency and C3.

title: Perry Farrell
text: Farrell has also led the alternative rock groups Porno for Pyros and Satellite Party.

title: Perry Farrell
text: He is the only person who has performed at all twelve Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festivals to date, having appeared under five different names (Perry Farrell, Jane's Addiction, DJ Peretz, Satellite Party, and with Hybrid).

title: Jane's Addiction
text: Jane's Addiction is an American rock band from Los Angeles, formed in 1985.

title: Jane's Addiction
text: The band consists of Perry Farrell (vocals), Dave Navarro (guitar), Stephen Perkins (drums) and Chris Chaney (bass).

title: Brian Virtue
text: Brian Virtue is an American Grammy-nominated music producer, engineer and mixer based in Los Angeles, California.

title: Brian Virtue
text: Virtue has worked with artists including Jane's Addiction, Thirty Seconds to Mars, Audioslave, Deftones, Puddle of Mudd, Chevelle, Hawthorne Heights and Crazy Town.

title: Brian Virtue
text: In the early 1990s, he began working in recording studios as an audio engineer which later developed into working as a producer.

title: Brian Virtue
text: Virtue worked with producer Bob Ezrin on Thirty Seconds to Mars' self-titled album in 2001 and 2002, and developed into more work with Ezrin on Jane's Addiction and with Rick Rubin on Audioslave.

title: Brian Virtue
text: In 2007, Virtue moved from Los Angeles to Nashville where he worked from his own studio, including recording Chevelle's "Sci-Fi Crimes".

title: Brian Virtue
text: Virtue also worked on the Jane's Addiction song "Superhero" which is the opening theme to the TV show Entourage.

title: Richelle Mead
text: Richelle Mead (born November 12, 1976) is a bestselling American fantasy author.

title: Richelle Mead
text: She is known for the "Georgina Kincaid" series, "Vampire Academy", "Bloodlines" and the "Dark Swan" series.

title: Sarah J. Maas
text: Sarah Janet Maas (born 5 March 1986) is a "New York Times" and "USA Today" bestselling American fantasy author.

title: Sarah J. Maas
text: Her debut novel, "Throne of Glass", was published in 2012 by Bloomsbury.

title: Maria V. Snyder
text: Maria V. Snyder is an American fantasy author best known for her "Study Series".

title: Maria V. Snyder
text: Her first novel, "Poison Study", was published on October 2005, and won the 2006 Compton Crook Award for Best First Novel.

title: Maria V. Snyder
text: the next two books in the series are "Magic Study" and "Fire Study".

title: Maria V. Snyder
text: Snyder then released another trilogy of books, the "Glass" series, following the character Opal Cowan from the "Study Series".

title: Maria V. Snyder
text: The books in the series are "Storm Glass", "Sea Glass" and "Spy Glass" respectively.

title: Maria V. Snyder
text: On 24 February, Snyder went back to the main characters of the "Study Series" and released the first book of he next trilogy, the "Soulfinder Series", the first book of which is "Shadow Study".

title: Maria V. Snyder
text: Aside from writing, her interests include "traveling, photography, making jewelry, and volleyball."

title: Red Queen (novel)
text: Red Queen is a young adult fantasy novel written by American writer Victoria Aveyard.

title: Red Queen (novel)
text: It was her first series and her first novel.

title: Red Queen (novel)
text: It was published in February 2015.

title: Red Queen (novel)
text: Its sequels are "Glass Sword" and "King's Cage".

title: Red Queen (novel)
text: Red Queen won the 2015 Goodreads Choice Award for Debut Goodreads Author and was nominated for the 2015 Goodreads Choice Award for Young Adult Fantasy & Science Fiction.

title: Elizabeth Haydon
text: Elizabeth Haydon (born 1965) is an American fantasy author.

title: Elizabeth Haydon
text: She has written two fantasy series set within the same universe, the fantasy/romance/whodunit fusion called The Symphony of Ages and the young adult series The Lost Journals of Ven Polypheme.

title: Elizabeth Haydon
text: Her WebSite is located at ElizabethHaydon.net.

title: The King of Elfland's Daughter
text: The King of Elfland's Daughter is a 1924 fantasy novel by British writer Lord Dunsany.

title: The King of Elfland's Daughter
text: It is widely recognized as one of the most influential and acclaimed works in all of fantasy literature.

title: The King of Elfland's Daughter
text: Although the novel faded into relative obscurity following its initial release, it found new longevity and wider critical acclaim when a paperback edition was released in 1969 as the second volume of the "Ballantine Adult Fantasy series".

title: The King of Elfland's Daughter
text: It has also been included in a more recent series of books reprinting the best of modern fantasy, the Fantasy Masterworks series.

title: The King of Elfland's Daughter
text: While seen as highly influential upon the genre as a whole, the novel was particularly formative in the (later-named) subgenres of fairytale fantasy and high fantasy.

title: Andre Norton Award
text: The Andre Norton Award for Young Adult Science Fiction and Fantasy is an annual award presented by the Science Fiction and Fantasy Writers of America (SFWA) to the author of the best young adult or middle grade science fiction or fantasy book published in the United States in the preceding year.

title: Andre Norton Award
text: It is named to honor prolific science fiction and fantasy author Andre Norton (1912–2005), and it was established by then SFWA president Catherine Asaro and the SFWA Young Adult Fiction committee and announced on February 20, 2005.

title: Andre Norton Award
text: Any published young adult or middle grade science fiction or fantasy novel is eligible for the prize, including graphic novels.

title: Andre Norton Award
text: There is no limit on word count.

title: Andre Norton Award
text: The award is presented along with the Nebula Awards and follows the same rules for nominations and voting; as the awards are separate, works may be simultaneously nominated for both the Andre Norton award and a Nebula Award.

title: Throne of Glass
text: Throne of Glass is a young adult high fantasy novel series by American author Sarah J. Maas, beginning with the inaugural entry of the same name.

title: Throne of Glass
text: The story follows the journey of Celaena Sardothien, a teenage assassin in a corrupted kingdom with a tyrannical ruler.

title: Throne of Glass
text: As the tale progresses, Celaena forms unexpected bonds and uncovers a conspiracy amidst her adventures.

title: Courtney Allison Moulton
text: Courtney Allison Moulton (born 1985/1986) is an American fantasy author.

title: Courtney Allison Moulton
text: She wrote the acclaimed and bestselling Angelfire (novel series) which was published by Katherine Tegen Books, an imprint of HarperCollins.

title: Sarah MacLean
text: Sarah MacLean (born December 17, 1978) is a New York Times bestselling American author of young adult novels and romance novels.

title: Sarah MacLean
text: Her first adult romance novel, "Nine Rules to Break When Romancing a Rake" debuted on the New York Times Bestseller List, where it stayed for four weeks.

title: Sarah MacLean
text: Since then, all of her adult romance novels have been on the New York Times and USA Today bestseller lists.

title: Sarah MacLean
text: Since February 2014, MacLean has written a monthly romance novel review column for The Washington Post.

title: Sarah MacLean
text: She is a two-time winner of the Romance Writers of America RITA Award for Best Historical Romance for "A Rogue by Any Other Name" in 2013 and "No Good Duke Goes Unpunished" in 2014.

title: Net register tonnage
text: Net register tonnage (NRT, nrt, n.r.t.) is a ship's cargo volume capacity expressed in "register tons", one of which equals to a volume of 100 cuft .

title: Net register tonnage
text: It is calculated by subtracting non-revenue-earning spaces i.e. spaces not available for carrying cargo, for example engine rooms, fuel tanks and crew quarters, from the ship's gross register tonnage.

title: Net register tonnage
text: Net register tonnage is not a measure of the weight of the ship or its cargo, and should not be confused with terms such as deadweight tonnage or displacement.

title: Olympic-class ocean liner
text: The "Olympic"-class ocean liners were a trio of British ocean liners built by the Harland & Wolff shipyard for the White Star Line during the early 20th century.

title: Olympic-class ocean liner
text: They were "Olympic" (1911), "Titanic" (1912), and "Britannic" (1915).

title: Olympic-class ocean liner
text: All three were designed to be the largest and most luxurious passenger ships in the world, designed to give White Star an advantage in the transatlantic passenger trade.

title: Olympic-class ocean liner
text: Two were lost early in their careers: "Titanic" sank in 1912 on its maiden voyage, after hitting an iceberg in the North Atlantic Ocean, and "Britannic" in 1916, after hitting a mine laid by the minelayer submarine "U-73" in a barrier off Kea in the Aegean Sea during World War I.

title: Olympic-class ocean liner
text: "Olympic", the lead vessel, had a career spanning 24 years and was retired in 1934 and sold for scrapping in 1935.

title: Nimrod (ship)
text: Nimrod was the ship Ernest Shackleton used in his 1908 Antarctic Nimrod Expedition for the South Pole.

title: Nimrod (ship)
text: It was a 41-year-old schooner of 334 gross register tons that had been used to hunt seals and whales.

title: Nimrod (ship)
text: Shackleton, who paid £5,000 for the ship, had it re-rigged as a barquentine.

title: Nimrod (ship)
text: It also had an auxiliary steam engine, but had a top speed of only six knots under this power.

title: Nimrod (ship)
text: In addition, the ship was so overloaded with supplies for the expedition that it could not carry enough coal to make passage to the Antarctic from New Zealand, and Shackleton had to arrange for the ship to be towed to the edge of the pack ice by tramp steamer "Koonya".

title: Nimrod (ship)
text: The New Zealand government paid half the cost of the tow; Sir James Mills, Chairman of the Union Steamship Company, paid the other half.

title: Nimrod (ship)
text: The "Koonya" was captained by Fredrick Pryce Evans during the tow.

title: Athenic-class ocean liner
text: The "Athenic"-class ocean liners were a three ship class of ocean liners built by the Harland & Wolff shipyard for the White Star Line in the early 20th century.

title: Gross register tonnage
text: Gross register tonnage (GRT, grt, g.r.t. "gt") a ship's total internal volume expressed in "register tons", each of which is equal to 100 cuft .

title: Gross register tonnage
text: Gross register tonnage uses the total permanently enclosed capacity of the vessel as its basis for volume.

title: Imperator-class ocean liner
text: The "Imperator" class ocean liners were a series of three ocean liners designed for the Hamburg America Line, commonly known as "HAPAG".

title: Imperator-class ocean liner
text: These three ships were commissioned by the chairman of HAPAG Albert Ballin.

title: Imperator-class ocean liner
text: Namely the "Imperator" (1912), the "Vaterland" (1913) and the largest, the "Bismarck" (1914).

title: Imperator-class ocean liner
text: These liners were over 50,000 tons, sported three funnels and had a length ranging from 906 ft (276 m) to 955.8 ft (291.3 m).

title: Imperator-class ocean liner
text: To this day, the "Vaterland" is the largest passenger ship operated by a German shipping company.

title: RMS Majestic (1914)
text: RMS "Majestic was a White Star ocean liner working on the North Atlantic run, originally launched in 1914 as the Hamburg America Line liner SS "Bismarck.

title: RMS Majestic (1914)
text: At 56,551 gross register tons, she was the largest ship in the world until completion of in 1935.

title: Titanic II
text: Titanic II is a planned ocean liner, to be built as a modern-day replica of the "Olympic"-class .

title: Titanic II
text: The new ship will have a gross tonnage (GT) of 56,000 while the original ship measured about 46,000 gross register tons (GRT).

title: Titanic II
text: The project was announced by Australian millionaire Clive Palmer in April 2012, as the flagship of a proposed cruise company Blue Star Line Pty. Ltd. of Brisbane, Australia.

title: Titanic II
text: The intended launch date was originally set in 2016, with the ship sailing from Southampton to New York within the same year.

title: Titanic II
text: However, construction of the ship has been delayed to 2018.

title: Titanic II
text: , construction is yet to commence.

title: Barbarossa-class ocean liner
text: The "Barbarossa" class was a class of ocean liners of North German Lloyd and the Hamburg America Line of the German Empire.

title: Barbarossa-class ocean liner
text: Of the ten ships built between 1896 and 1902, six were built by AG Vulcan Stettin, three were built by Blohm & Voss, and one was built by Schichau-Werke; all were built in Germany.

title: Barbarossa-class ocean liner
text: They averaged gross register tons (GRT) and featured twin screw propellers driven by quadruple-expansion steam engines.

title: MS Princess of Tasmania
text: MS Princess of Tasmania was an Australian-built roll-on/roll-off passenger ship.

title: MS Princess of Tasmania
text: She was built by the State Dockyard in Newcastle, New South Wales for the Australian National Line.

title: MS Princess of Tasmania
text: Laid down on 15 November 1957, she was launched on 15 December 1958.

title: MS Princess of Tasmania
text: As built, the ship had a tonnage value of gross register tons (GRT) , was 113.32 m long, had a beam of 17.73 m , and a draught of 4.74 m .

title: MS Princess of Tasmania
text: Two 9-cylinder Nydquist & Holm Polar M69TS diesels supplied 8600 hp to the propellers, allowing a maximum speed of 17.75 kn .

title: MS Princess of Tasmania
text: Up to 334 passengers and 142 vehicles could be carried.

title: MS Princess of Tasmania
text: "Princess of Tasmania" was given the IMO number: 5284986 .

title: MS Princess of Tasmania
text: The ship was the first RO/RO passenger ship in the southern hemisphere, and at the time of launch, the largest vessel built in Australia.

title: Shameless (season 5)
text: The fifth season of "Shameless", an American comedy-drama television series based on the award-winning British series of the same name by Paul Abbott, premiered on January 11, 2015 on the Showtime television network.

title: Shameless (season 5)
text: Executive producers are John Wells, Paul Abbott and Andrew Stearn, and producer Michael Hissrich.

title: Shameless (season 5)
text: Like all previous seasons, the season consisted of 12 episodes.

title: Shameless (season 3)
text: The third season of "Shameless", an American comedy-drama television series based on the award-winning British series of the same name by Paul Abbott, premiered on January 13, 2013, at Sunday 9:00 p.m. EST on the Showtime television network.

title: Shameless (season 3)
text: Executive producers are John Wells, Paul Abbott and Andrew Stearn, with producer Michael Hissrich.

title: Shameless (season 3)
text: The season concluded after 12 episodes on April 7, 2013.

title: Shameless (season 3)
text: The shows season premiere brought in 2.00 million viewers, becoming the show highest rated episode ever to-date.

title: Shameless (season 3)
text: The episode airing February 17, "The Sins of My Caretaker", received 1.31 million total viewers, its lowest rated episode of the season.

title: Shameless (season 3)
text: The season finale scored 1.82 million viewers.

title: Shameless (U.S. TV series)
text: Shameless is an American comedy-drama television series which airs on Showtime.

title: Shameless (U.S. TV series)
text: It is the remake of the British series of the same name.

title: Shameless (U.S. TV series)
text: Set in Chicago, the series is filmed in Los Angeles, with the exterior scenes shot in Chicago.

title: Axle Whitehead
text: Axle Whitehead (born 16 December 1980; Melbourne, Australia) is a former Australian Video Hits TV host and current singer, musician, and actor.

title: Axle Whitehead
text: In 2008, he released his first studio album "Losing Sleep" which debuted outside of the ARIA top 50.

title: Axle Whitehead
text: He also played Liam Murphy in Channel Seven's "Home and Away" and was the host of "The World's Strictest Parents".

title: Axle Whitehead
text: In 2015, Whitehead began playing the role of Davis, a musician, in the critically acclaimed Showtime series, "Shameless".

title: Shameless (season 4)
text: The fourth season episode 10 of "Shameless", an American comedy-drama television series based on the award-winning British series of the same name by Paul Abbott, premiered on January 12, 2014, at Sunday 9:00 p.m. EST on the Showtime television network.

title: Shameless (season 4)
text: Executive producers are John Wells, Paul Abbott and Andrew Stearn, with producer Michael Hissrich.

title: Shameless (season 4)
text: The season concluded after 12 episodes on April 6, 2014.

title: Shameless (season 4)
text: The shows season premiere brought in 1.69 million viewers, while the episode airing February 2, "Strangers on a Train", received 1.22 million total viewers, its lowest rated episode of the season.

title: Shameless (season 4)
text: The season finale scored 1.93 million viewers, becoming the show highest rated episode for the season.

title: Shameless (season 8)
text: The eighth season of "Shameless", an American comedy-drama television series based on the award-winning British series of the same name by Paul Abbott, was announced on December 19, 2016, a day after the seventh season finale.

title: Shameless (season 8)
text: The season will consist of a total of 12 episodes.

title: Shameless (season 8)
text: It is slated to premiere on November 5, 2017.

title: Shameless (season 6)
text: The sixth season of "Shameless", an American comedy-drama television series based on the award-winning British series of the same name by Paul Abbott, premiered on January 10, 2016, concluded April 3, 2016.

title: Shameless (season 6)
text: Executive producers are John Wells, Andrew Stearn, Nancy M. Pimental, Davey Holmes, Christopher Chulack, Krista Vernoff and producers Terri Murphy and Princess Nash.

title: Shameless (season 2)
text: The second season of "Shameless", an American comedy-drama television series based on the award-winning British series of the same name by Paul Abbott, premiered on January 8, 2012, at Sunday 9:00 p.m. EST on the Showtime television network.

title: Shameless (season 2)
text: Executive producers are John Wells, Paul Abbott and Andrew Stearn, with producer Michael Hissrich.

title: Shameless (season 2)
text: The season concluded after 12 episodes on April 1, 2012.

title: Shameless (season 2)
text: The shows season premiere brought in 1.58 million viewers, which was higher than the season 1 premiere.

title: Shameless (season 2)
text: The episode airing March 4, "Parenthood", received 1.6 million total viewers, its highest rated show of the season.

title: Shameless (season 2)
text: The season finale scored 1.45 million viewers.

title: Shameless (season 7)
text: The seventh season of "Shameless", based on the award-winning British series of the same name by Paul Abbott, is an American comedy-drama television series with executive producers John Wells, Christopher Chulack, Krista Vernoff, Etan Frankel, Nancy M. Pimental and Sheila Callaghan.

title: Shameless (season 7)
text: The season premiered on October 2, 2016, the first time the series has debuted in autumn.

title: Shameless (season 7)
text: Showtime premiered a free preview of the season premiere online on September 23, 2016, ahead of the October 2 broadcast.

title: Shameless (season 1)
text: The first season of "Shameless", an American comedy-drama television series based on the award-winning British series of the same name by Paul Abbott, premiered on January 9, 2011, at Sunday 10:00 p.m. EST on the Showtime television network.

title: Shameless (season 1)
text: Executive producers are John Wells, Paul Abbott and Andrew Stearn, with producer Michael Hissrich.

title: Shameless (season 1)
text: The season concluded after 12 episodes on March 27, 2011.

title: Shameless (season 1)
