text: The film captures the historical moment of advertising tactics in political campaigns as in the 1988 plebiscite, when the Chilean citizenry decided whether or not dictator Augusto Pinochet should stay in power for another eight years.

title: The Assassin of Rome
text: The Assassin of Rome (Italian: "Girolimoni, il mostro di Roma" ) is a 1972 Italian historical drama film directed by Damiano Damiani.

title: The Assassin of Rome
text: The film tells, with some historical licenses, the story of Gino Girolimoni, wrongfully accused of a series of child murders that occurred in Rome between 1924 and 1928.

title: Heroes in the Wind
text: Heroes in the Wind: From Kull to Conan; the Best of Robert E. Howard is a 2009 collection of dark fantasy and horror short stories written by Robert E. Howard, selected and with an introduction by John Clute.

title: Heroes in the Wind
text: Most of the stories were originally published in various fantasy magazines and feature Howard's heroes Kull, Bran Mak Morn and Conan, among others.

title: Heroes in the Wind
text: It was first published in paperback in September 2009 by Penguin Books in its Penguin Modern Classics series.

title: Conan: Adventures in an Age Undreamed Of
text: Robert E. Howard's Conan: Adventures in an Age Undreamed Of, or simply Conan: Adventures in an Age Undreamed Of, is a sword and sorcery British pen-and-paper role-playing game set in the world of Conan the Barbarian, the fictional Hyborian Age.

title: Conan: Adventures in an Age Undreamed Of
text: Both the character and the setting were first imagined by American author Robert E. Howard (1906-1936) as of 1932 and until his suicide in 1936.

title: Conan: Adventures in an Age Undreamed Of
text: Howard's original literary work has since spawned a vast franchise of novels, comic books, films, video games, board games, role-playing games, etc.

title: Conan: Adventures in an Age Undreamed Of
text: Following this tradition, "Conan: Adventures in an Age Undreamed Of" is the third officially licensed Conan role-playing game.

title: Conan: Adventures in an Age Undreamed Of
text: The two precedent games were "Conan Role-Playing Game" (1985-1988) and "" (2004-2010), although there also had been supplements for independent generic systems, like "GURPS Conan" (1988-1989).

title: Valeria (Conan the Barbarian)
text: Valeria is a pirate and adventuress (a member of "The Red Brotherhood" of pirates) in the fictional universe of Robert E. Howard's Conan the Barbarian stories.

title: Valeria (Conan the Barbarian)
text: She appears in Robert E. Howard's Conan novella "Red Nails", serialized in "Weird Tales" 28 1-3 (July, August/September & October 1936).

title: Valeria (Conan the Barbarian)
text: This was the last Conan story written by Howard, and published posthumously.

title: Valeria (Conan the Barbarian)
text: The name was also used for Conan's love interest in the 1982 film "Conan the Barbarian".

title: Optometry
text: Optometry is a health care profession which involves examining the eyes and applicable visual systems for defects or abnormalities as well as the medical diagnosis and management of eye disease.

title: Optometry
text: Traditionally, the field of optometry began with the primary focus of correcting refractive error through the use of spectacles.

title: Optometry
text: Modern day optometry, however, has evolved through time so that the education curriculum additionally includes intensive medical training in the diagnosis and management of ocular disease in countries where the profession is established and regulated.

title: Optometry
text: Optometrists (also known as Doctors of Optometry in the US and Canada for those holding the O.D. degree or Ophthalmic Opticians in the UK) are medical professionals who provide primary eyecare through comprehensive eye examinations to detect and treat various visual abnormalities and eye diseases.

title: Optometry
text: Being a regulated profession, an optometrist's scope of practice may differ depending on the location.

title: Optometry
text: Thus, disorders or diseases detected outside the treatment scope of optometry are referred out to relevant medical professionals for proper care, more commonly to ophthalmologists who are physicians that specialize in tertiary medical and surgical care of the eye.

title: Optometry
text: Optometrists typically work closely together with other eye care professionals such as ophthalmologists and opticians to deliver quality and efficient eyecare to the general public.

title: Lee Family Digital Archive
text: The Lee Family Digital Archive is a scholarly effort to collect, edit, and disseminate the papers of the Lee family of Virginia.

title: Lee Family Digital Archive
text: The Lees of Virginia included Richard Lee I, the immigrant founder of the family, who came to Virginia from England around 1640, and his descendants.

title: Lee Family Digital Archive
text: Some of the most famous Lees are Thomas Lee, the President of Virginia; Richard Henry Lee and Francis Lightfoot Lee, signers of the Declaration of Independence; Arthur Lee, the Penman of the Revolution; Light-Horse Harry Lee, the cavalry hero of the Continental army, three-time governor of Virginia, and the father of Robert E. Lee; Thomas Sim Lee, Revolutionary governor of Maryland; Richard Bland Lee, U.S. Senator; Charles Lee, U.S. Supreme Court justice; Richard Bland Lee II, a noted explorer; Robert E. Lee, the Confederate general who is by far the most famous of the family; William Henry Fitzhugh (Rooney) Lee, the son of Robert E. Lee and a U.S. Congressman from Virginia; and Fitzhugh Lee, Governor of Virginia and Civil War cavalry general.

title: Lee Family Digital Archive
text: President Zachary Taylor was a Lee descendant, on his mother's side.

title: Richard Ford
text: Richard Ford (born February 16, 1944) is an American novelist and short story writer.

title: Richard Ford
text: His best-known works are the novel "The Sportswriter" and its sequels, "Independence Day", "The Lay of the Land" and "Let Me Be Frank With You", and the short story collection "Rock Springs", which contains several widely anthologized stories.

title: Legacy of Robert E. Howard
text: Robert E. Howard's legacy extended after his death in 1936.

title: Legacy of Robert E. Howard
text: Howard's most famous character, Conan the Barbarian, has a pop-culture imprint that has been compared to such icons as Tarzan of the Apes, Count Dracula, Sherlock Holmes, and James Bond.

title: Legacy of Robert E. Howard
text: Howard's critical reputation suffered at first but over the decades works of Howard scholarship have been published.

title: Legacy of Robert E. Howard
text: The first professionally published example of this was L. Sprague de Camp's "Dark Valley Destiny" (1983) which was followed by other works, including Don Herron's "The Dark Barbarian" (1984) and Mark Finn's "" (2006).

title: Legacy of Robert E. Howard
text: Also in 2006, a charity, Robert E. Howard Foundation, was created to promote further scholarship.

title: Robert E. Howard
text: Robert Ervin Howard (January 22, 1906 – June 11, 1936) was an American author who wrote pulp fiction in a diverse range of genres.

title: Robert E. Howard
text: He is well known for his character Conan the Barbarian and is regarded as the father of the sword and sorcery subgenre.

title: Red Sonja (film)
text: Red Sonja is a 1985 Dutch-American sword and sorcery action film directed by Richard Fleischer.

title: Red Sonja (film)
text: The film introduces Brigitte Nielsen as the title character with Arnold Schwarzenegger, Sandahl Bergman, Ronald Lacey, Ernie Reyes, Jr., Paul L. Smith and Pat Roach in supporting roles.

title: Red Sonja (film)
text: The film features the sword-wielding Marvel Comics character Red Sonja, created by Roy Thomas, who first appeared in Marvel's "Conan the Barbarian" series (#23) in 1973.

title: Red Sonja (film)
text: The film's character of Red Sonja was based on Red Sonya of Rogatino, a character created by Robert E. Howard appearing in his short story "The Shadow of the Vulture" (1934).

title: Red Sonja (film)
text: The film acknowledges that it was "based on the character created by Robert E. Howard" in the introductory credits.

title: National Association for Chiropractic Medicine
text: The National Association for Chiropractic Medicine (NACM) was a minority chiropractic association founded in 1984 that described itself as a "consumer advocacy association of chiropractors".

title: National Association for Chiropractic Medicine
text: It openly rejected some of the more controversial aspects of chiropractic, including a basic concept of chiropractic, vertebral subluxations as the cause of all diseases.

title: National Association for Chiropractic Medicine
text: It also sought to "reform the chiropractic profession away from a philosophical scope of practice and towards an applied science scope of practice."

title: National Association for Chiropractic Medicine
text: It stated that it was "dedicated to bringing the scientific based practice of chiropractic into mainstream medicine" and that its members "confine their scope of practice to scientific parameters and seek to make legitimate the utilization of professional manipulative procedures in mainstream health care delivery."

title: National Association for Chiropractic Medicine
text: "While the NACM is focused on furthering the profession, its primary focus is on the rights and safety of the consumers."

title: National Association for Chiropractic Medicine
text: The NACM was the object of much controversy and criticism from the rest of the profession.

title: National Association for Chiropractic Medicine
text: It quietly dropped out of sight and its demise apparently occurred sometime between May 30, 2008 and March 6, 2010.

title: Bell UH-1 Iroquois
text: The Bell UH-1 Iroquois (nicknamed "Huey") is a utility military helicopter powered by a single turboshaft engine, with two-blade main and tail rotors.

title: Bell UH-1 Iroquois
text: The first member of the prolific Huey family, it was developed by Bell Helicopter to meet a United States Army's 1952 requirement for a medical evacuation and utility helicopter, and first flew in 1956.

title: Bell UH-1 Iroquois
text: The UH-1 was the first turbine-powered helicopter to enter production in 1960 for the United States military, and more than 16,000 have been built since.

title: Aérospatiale SA 321 Super Frelon
text: The Aérospatiale (formerly Sud Aviation) SA 321 Super Frelon ("Super Hornet") is a three-engined heavy transport helicopter produced by aerospace manufacturer Sud Aviation (later Aérospatiale) of France.

title: Aérospatiale SA 321 Super Frelon
text: It held the distinction of being the most powerful helicopter to be built in Europe at one point, as well as being the world's fastest helicopter.

title: Harbin Z-20
text: The Harbin Z-20 or Zhi-20 is a medium lift helicopter produced in the Northeast of China.

title: Harbin Z-20
text: Its first flight was on 23 December 2013.

title: Harbin Z-20
text: The helicopter has a maximum takeoff weight in the range of 10 tons, can drop troops at locations of up to 3,000 ft altitude, and could operate from the Chinese aircraft carrier Liaoning.

title: Harbin Z-20
text: It is thought to be comparable to the US made Sikorsky UH-60 Black Hawk helicopter, the civilian Sikorsky S-70C-2 variant of which has been used by the People's Liberation Army since 1984.

title: Harbin Z-20
text: Some sources suggest that the Z-20 is a copy of the Black Hawk and link the design to the Black Hawk that was abandoned by US special forces in Pakistan during the operation to kill Osama bin Laden on 1 May 2011.

title: Harbin Z-20
text: The sources say that Pakistan allowed Chinese officials to examine the Black Hawk wreckage.

title: Harbin Z-20
text: However, Aviation Week also points out that although some aspects of the design do appear similar, such as the tail wheel arrangement, there are also marked differences.

title: Harbin Z-20
text: For example, the Chinese Z-20 has a five blade rotor compared with the Black Hawks' four blades.

title: Kawasaki KH-4
text: The Kawasaki KH-4 was a light utility helicopter produced in Japan in the 1960s as a development of the Bell 47 that Kawasaki had been building under licence since 1952.

title: Kawasaki KH-4
text: The most visible difference between the KH-4 and its forerunner was its new and enlarged cabin.

title: Kawasaki KH-4
text: This was fully enclosed (although the side doors were removable) and provided seating for three passengers side-by-side on a bench seat behind the pilot's seat.

title: Kawasaki KH-4
text: The helicopter was provided with a new control system, revised instrumentation, and larger fuel tank.

title: Agusta-Bell AB.102
text: The Agusta AB.102 was an Italian helicopter produced in small numbers in the early 1960s.

title: Agusta-Bell AB.102
text: The aircraft was based on the mechanical components of a Bell 48 that Agusta incorporated into an all-new, streamlined fuselage.

title: Agusta-Bell AB.102
text: The first flight was on 3 February 1959 and the prototype was exhibited at that year's Paris Air Show in "faux" military colours.

title: Agusta-Bell AB.102
text: Only two production examples were built, operated by Elivie in a regular air service between Turin and Milan from 1961.

title: Agusta-Bell AB.102
text: However, the advent of turbine-powered helicopters in the 1960s soon rendered the AB.102 obsolete.

title: American Aircraft Penetrator
text: The American Aircraft Penetrator, now referred as the Aerocraft Stealth Star 204 SS, was a gunship helicopter modified from the Bell UH-1B Iroquois with tandem seating for the pilots and a troop-carrying compartment.

title: Eurocopter EC135
text: The Eurocopter EC135 (now Airbus Helicopters H135) is a twin-engine civil light utility helicopter produced by Airbus Helicopters (formerly known as Eurocopter).

title: Eurocopter EC135
text: It is capable of flight under instrument flight rules (IFR) and is outfitted with digital flight controls.

title: Eurocopter EC135
text: It entered service in 1996; over a thousand aircraft have been produced to date.

title: Eurocopter EC135
text: It is widely used by police and ambulance services and for executive transport; by 2013, more than 500 EC135s were providing helicopter emergency medical services across the world.

title: Eurocopter EC135
text: While the EC135 is primarily used by civil operators, a combat-capable military-orientated variant of the EC135, designated as the Eurocopter EC635, has also been produced.

title: Robinson R44
text: The Robinson R44 is a four-seat light helicopter produced by Robinson Helicopter Company since 1992.

title: Robinson R44
text: Based on the company's two-seat Robinson R22, the R44 features hydraulically assisted flight controls.

title: Robinson R44
text: It was first flown on 31 March 1990 and received FAA certification in December 1992, with the first delivery in February 1993.

title: AAI Penetrator
text: The American Aircraft International Penetrator was a military helicopter prototype conceived in 1990 as a gunship conversion of the Bell UH-1 Iroquois, aimed at ground insertion, close support and counter-insurgency roles.

title: Brantly B-2
text: The Brantly B-2 is an American two-seat light helicopter produced by the Brantly Helicopter Corporation.

title: Nam Cheong Station
text: Nam Cheong () is a MTR interchange station located at ground level beneath West Kowloon Highway, in Sham Shui Po, Hong Kong opposite the Fu Cheong Estate.

title: Nam Cheong Station
text: It is served by the Tung Chung Line and West Rail Line and provides cross-platform interchange between platform 1 (West Rail Line towards Tuen Mun) and platform 4 (Tung Chung Line towards Hong Kong).

title: Nam Cheong Station
text: The livery of Nam Cheong Station is pale yellow green.

title: Mei Foo Station
text: Mei Foo () is a Hong Kong MTR station located in Mei Foo Sun Chuen, Lai Chi Kok, New Kowloon.

title: Mei Foo Station
text: It is an interchange station between the Tsuen Wan Line and the West Rail Line, situated between Lai Chi Kok and Lai King stations on the Tsuen Wan Line and Nam Cheong Station and Tsuen Wan West stations on the West Rail Line.

title: Mei Foo Station
text: Mei Foo Station's livery is blue.

title: Yuen Long Station
text: Yuen Long () is an MTR station located in the northeastern part of Yuen Long Town, Yuen Long District, between Kam Sheung Road and Long Ping stations on the West Rail Line.

title: Yuen Long Station
text: It is an interchange between the West Rail Line and the Light Rail Yuen Long Stop.

title: West Rail Line
text: The West Rail Line () is one of the MTR lines in Hong Kong, indicated by the colour dark magenta.

title: West Rail Line
text: It was formerly known as the KCR West Rail (九廣西鐵 ).

title: West Rail Line
text: The line connects Hung Hom Station in Kowloon and Tuen Mun Station in Tuen Mun, 35.7 km away, in 37 minutes.

title: West Rail Line
text: The railway runs through the cities of Kowloon, Castle Peak and Tsuen Wan.

title: East Rail Line
text: The East Rail Line () is one of eleven railway lines of the Mass Transit Railway (MTR) system in Hong Kong.

title: East Rail Line
text: It used to be one of the three lines of the Kowloon–Canton Railway (KCR) network.

title: East Rail Line
text: It was known as the KCR British Section (九廣鐵路英段) from 1910 to 1996, and the KCR East Rail (九廣東鐵) from 1996 to 2007.

title: East Rail Line
text: The East Rail was the only railway line of the Kowloon-Canton Railway Corporation (KCRC) before the construction of "KCR West Rail" (now known as West Rail Line).

title: Canton Road Station
text: Canton Road Station (Trad.

title: Canton Road Station
text: Chinese: 廣東道站) was a planned railway station on the Kowloon Southern Link of West Rail Line between East Tsim Sha Tsui Station and Austin Station, beneath the shopping mall, Harbour City in Tsim Sha Tsui, by replacing the existing underground car park.

title: Canton Road Station
text: But it was never to be built because of the failed negotiations between the Kowloon-Canton Railway Corporation (KCRC), the former developer of the station, and The Wharf (Holdings) Limited, the owner of the Harbour City.

title: Austin Station (MTR)
text: Austin () is an underground MTR rapid transit station on the West Rail Line in Hong Kong, situated perpendicular to Wui Cheung Road and Austin Road West, and formerly adjacent to Jordan Road Ferry Pier Bus Terminus.

title: Austin Station (MTR)
text: It is the only intermediate station along the Kowloon Southern Link project, built to connect the West Rail Line and East Rail Line.

title: Austin Station (MTR)
text: Construction was finished in July 2009 and the station opened on 16 August 2009.

title: Tuen Mun South Extension
text: Tuen Mun South Extension is a proposed extension of the West Rail Line to the Tuen Mun South () station in the vicinities of Tuen Mun Ferry Pier.

title: Tuen Mun South Extension
text: This station will serve as the future West Rail Line westbound terminus if built.

title: Tuen Mun South Extension
text: The extension will extend southwards from the current western terminus Tuen Mun Station.

title: Tuen Mun South Extension
text: The journey time from Tuen Mun South to Tuen Mun is estimated to be approximately 4 minutes.

title: Tuen Mun South Extension
text: It is planned to run on viaduct, since if it were to continue underground the gradient would be too steep for the trains to run through.

title: Kowloon Southern Link
text: The Kowloon Southern Link is a section of the MTR West Rail Line, linking Nam Cheong Station and East Tsim Sha Tsui Station.

title: Kowloon Southern Link
text: The rail link is fully underground, lies along the south-west coastline of Kowloon Peninsula, east of rail tracks of the Tung Chung Line and Airport Express.

title: Kowloon Southern Link
text: Kowloon Southern Link has one underground intermediate station called Austin Station (formerly West Kowloon Station).

title: Kowloon Southern Link
text: It is located adjacent to the Canton Road Government Offices, close to Kowloon Station of Tung Chung Line and Airport Express.

title: Kowloon Southern Link
text: However, the structures do not provide a direct transfer between the two stations.

title: Harbour City (Hong Kong)
text: Harbour City is a large shopping mall in Tsim Sha Tsui, Hong Kong.

title: Harbour City (Hong Kong)
text: It is part of a series of office blocks and hotels.

title: Harbour City (Hong Kong)
text: It comprises several parts: Marco Polo Hong Kong Hotel, Ocean Terminal, Ocean Centre (with 1980s retro decor), the Gateway and the Pacific Club Kowloon.

title: Harbour City (Hong Kong)
text: The complex is located along the west side of Canton Road, stretching from the Star Ferry Pier in the south to China Hong Kong City in the north.

title: The Sound of Your Heart (TV series)
text: The Sound Of Your Heart (Hangul: 마음의 소리 / RR: Maeumui Sori) is a South Korean sitcom starring Lee Kwang-soo and Jung So-min.

title: The Sound of Your Heart (TV series)
text: The sitcom is based on the Webtoon "The Sound of Heart."

title: The Sound of Your Heart (TV series)
text: The first 10 episodes were aired as a web series on November 7, 2016 through Naver TV Cast on Mondays at 6:00 (KST), and the remaining 10 episodes aired from December 2016.

title: The Sound of Your Heart (TV series)
text: The web series hit 100 million views on Sohu TV and ranked No. 1 among Korean dramas on the site.

title: The Sound of Your Heart (TV series)
text: On Naver TV Cast, the web series has more than 40 million views in South Korea as of February 2017.

title: The Sound of Your Heart (TV series)
text: It is also now airing on Netflix.

title: Lina (South Korean singer)
text: Lee Ji-yeon (born February 18, 1984), better known by her stage name Lina is a South Korean singer and musical actress.

title: Lina (South Korean singer)
text: She debuted in 2002 as a member of South Korean R&B duo Isak N Jiyeon and disbanded in 2004.

title: Lina (South Korean singer)
text: She later re-debut as a member of South Korean girl group The Grace in 2005 and the group currently being inactive.

title: Lina (South Korean singer)
text: She currently active as a musical actress.

title: Unstoppable Marriage (TV series)
text: Unstoppable Marriage () is a South Korean sitcom that aired on KBS2 from November 5, 2007 to May 30, 2008, on Mondays to Fridays at 18:50 for 140 episodes.

title: Unstoppable Marriage (TV series)
text: It was adapted from the 2007 South Korean film of the same name.

title: Taeyang
text: Dong Young-bae (; born 18 May 1988), better known by his stage name Taeyang (meaning "sun" in Korean) and SOL (when performing in Japan), is a South Korean singer, songwriter and dancer.

title: Taeyang
text: After appearing in Jinusean's music video "A-yo," Taeyang began training under YG Entertainment at the age of 12.

title: Taeyang
text: Six years later, he made his debut in 2006 as a member of the South Korean boy band Big Bang.

title: Taeyang
text: While the quintet's debut was met with lukewarm receptions, their follow-ups cemented their popularity, becoming one of the best-selling digital group of all-time in Asia and one of the best-selling boy bands in the world.

title: Sunmin
text: Sunmin (Hangul: 선민, "Katakana": ソンミン, born August 4, 1987) is a South Korean singer who speaks and sings in Korean, Japanese, and English.

title: Sunmin
text: She debuted in 2006, with the single "Keep Holding You," a collaboration with the Japanese R&B singer Toshinobu Kubota.

title: Sunmin
text: Her career was initially focused on the Japanese market, but her work became focused in South Korea from 2009 to 2010.

title: Sunmin
text: She also contributed to original soundtracks of South Korean television series "Master of Study" and "Gloria (2010 TV series)".

title: Sunmin
text: In 2010 to 2011, she was in the main South Korean musical production of "Jekyll & Hyde" as Lucy.

title: Sunmin
text: In 2012 to 2013, she reprised her role as Lucy in the South Korean national tour.

title: Sunmin
text: In spring 2013, Sunmin played Josephine in the South Korean production of "Arsène Lupin", the musical.

title: The Producers (TV series)
text: The Producers (; lit.

title: The Producers (TV series)
text: Producer) is a 2015 South Korean sitcom starring Cha Tae-hyun, Gong Hyo-jin, Kim Soo-hyun, and IU.

title: The Producers (TV series)
text: It aired on KBS2 from 15 May 2015 to 20 June 2015 on Fridays and Saturdays at 21:15 for 12 episodes.

title: IU (singer)
text: Lee Ji-eun (Korean: 이지은 ; born May 16, 1993), better known by her stage name IU (Korean: 아이유 ), is a South Korean singer, songwriter and actress.

title: IU (singer)
text: While still in middle school, IU auditioned for various talent agencies with ambitions of becoming a singer.

title: IU (singer)
text: She signed with LOEN Entertainment in 2007 as a trainee and began her music career at the age of 15 with her debut album, "Lost and Found".

title: IU (singer)
text: Her follow-up albums, "Growing Up" and "IU...IM", brought her mainstream success, but it was through "Good Day" (Korean: 좋은 날 ), the lead single from her 2010 album "Real", that she achieved national stardom.

title: IU (singer)
text: "Good Day" spent five consecutive weeks at the top position of South Korea's Gaon Digital Chart and holds the record for spending the most number of weeks at No. 1 along with Psy's "Gangnam Style".

title: Kwon So-hyun
text: Kwon So-hyun (born August 30, 1994), is a South Korean singer and actress.

title: Kwon So-hyun
text: She was known as a member of the South Korean girl group 4Minute, under Cube Entertainment.

title: Kwon So-hyun
text: She is also a former member of the South Korean girl group, Orange.

title: Kwon So-hyun
text: Before June 15, 2016 (end of her contract with Cube), Sohyun left 4Minute and the record label along with members Nam Ji-hyun, Heo Ga-yoon, and Jeon Ji-yoon.

title: Han Sun-hwa
text: Han Sun-hwa (born October 6, 1990), is a South Korean singer and actress.

title: Han Sun-hwa
text: She is a former member of the South Korean girl group Secret.

title: Han Sun-hwa
text: She made her television debut in 2004 while participating in SBS's "Superstar Survival" as a finalist, and in 2009, she was a regular cast on a variety show called "Invincible Youth".

title: Han Sun-hwa
text: Aside from music, she also ventured into acting and made her debut in the 2010 drama, "More Charming By The Day".

title: Han Sun-hwa
text: She also acted in several dramas with supporting roles in "Ad Genius Lee Tae-baek", "God's Gift - 14 Days", and "Marriage, Not Dating".

title: Han Sun-hwa
text: In 2014 she finally starred as a lead actress on MBC's weekend drama "Rosy Lovers" as Baek Jang Mi co-starring with actor Lee Jang Woo.

title: Han Sun-hwa
text: CNN International Seoul listed Sunhwa as one of the nine rising "It" stars in Korean entertainment citing her as a "multi-tasking" artist.

title: Han Sun-hwa
text: Her portrayal of Kang Se-Ah in the 2014 TVN drama, "Marriage, Not Dating" earned her a nomination for "Best Youth Actress" at the 16th Seoul International Youth Film Festival.

title: Han Sun-hwa
text: In 2014, her portrayal of Jang-Mi from "Rosy Lovers" and Jenny from "God's Gift 14 Day"s won her two best new actress awards from MBC and SBS Drama Awards.

title: Han Sun-hwa
text: It was confirmed on September 26, 2016 that Sunhwa had not renewed her contract with TS Entertainment and will officially part ways in October.

title: Han Sun-hwa
text: On October 14, 2016 Sunhwa joined Huayi Brothers as an actress.

title: Shinsadong Tiger
text: Lee Ho-yang (Korean: 이호양 ), better known by his stage name Shinsadong Tiger (Korean: 신사동호랭이 "Shinsadong Horaengi") is a South Korean music producer and songwriter.

title: Shinsadong Tiger
text: Even after debuting in 2001 at the age of 18 (19 in Korean age), he has worked many odd jobs to fund his music career.

title: Shinsadong Tiger
text: He has become a prominent figure in the Korean pop music industry and is responsible for a number of popular songs.

title: Shinsadong Tiger
text: In 2010, he was named the "New Generation Producer" at the 18th Korean Culture Entertainment Awards, and in 2011 he was named as one of the most influential figures in the South Korean music industry by OSEN.

title: Shinsadong Tiger
text: Lee has recently started his own label, AB Entertainment, in which he has debuted his own girl group named EXID.

title: Want Ads
text: "Want Ads" was a million-selling Number 1 pop and R&B hit recorded by female group, Honey Cone for their third album "Sweet Replies" and also appears on their fourth album "Soulful Tapestry".

title: Want Ads
text: The song on the Detroit-based Hot Wax label was written by Greg Perry, General Norman Johnson and Barney Perkins.

title: Want Ads
text: It was produced by staff producer, Greg Perry, and features a young Ray Parker, Jr. ("Ghostbusters") on rhythm guitar.

title: Ray Parker Jr.
text: Ray Erskine Parker Jr. (born May 1, 1954) is an American guitarist, singer-songwriter, record producer, and actor, best known for writing and performing the theme song to the movie "Ghostbusters", for his solo music, and for performing with his band, Raydio, and with Barry White.

title: Sex and the Single Man
text: Sex and the Single Man is third solo album by guitarist/singer/songwriter Ray Parker Jr. released in 1985 on the Arista label.

title: Sex and the Single Man
text: The record includes the singles "Girls Are More Fun" and "One Sided Love Affair".

title: Ghostbusters (song)
text: "Ghostbusters" is a song written and recorded by Ray Parker Jr. as the theme to the film of the same name starring Bill Murray, Dan Aykroyd, Harold Ramis, and Ernie Hudson.

title: Ghostbusters (song)
text: Debuting at #68 on June 16, 1984, the song reached number one on the "Billboard" Hot 100 on August 11, 1984, staying there for three weeks, and at number two on the UK Singles Chart on September 16, 1984, staying there for three weeks.

title: Ghostbusters (song)
text: The song re-entered the UK Top 75 on November 2, 2008, at No. 49.

title: The Other Woman (Ray Parker Jr. album)
text: The Other Woman is the debut solo album by guitarist/singer/songwriter Ray Parker Jr. released in 1982 on the Arista label.

title: The Other Woman (Ray Parker Jr. album)
text: The album was remastered and expanded by Funky Town Grooves in June 2012 including 3 bonus tracks.

title: I Still Can't Get Over Loving You
text: "I Still Can't Get Over Loving You" is a 1983 song written and performed by Ray Parker, Jr..

title: I Still Can't Get Over Loving You
text: It was the lead single from his "Woman Out of Control" album of the same year, and it reached number 12 on the "Billboard" Hot 100 in early 1984.

title: I Still Can't Get Over Loving You
text: It was Parker's fifth Top 20 hit, the sixth being 1984's "Ghostbusters".

title: Dan Aykroyd
text: Daniel Edward Aykroyd {'1': ", '2': ", '3': ", '4': "} (born July 1, 1952) is a Canadian-American actor, comedian, producer, screenwriter, musician and businessman.

title: Dan Aykroyd
text: He was an original member of the "Not Ready for Prime Time Players" on "Saturday Night Live" (1975–1979).

title: Dan Aykroyd
text: A musical sketch he performed with John Belushi on "SNL", The Blues Brothers, turned into an actual performing band and then a highly successful 1980 film, also called "The Blues Brothers".

title: Woman Out of Control
text: Woman Out of Control is second solo album by Ray Parker Jr. It was released in 1983 on the Arista label.

title: Woman Out of Control
text: The record includes the single "I Still Can't Get Over Loving You" which reached number 12 on the "Billboard" Hot 100 in early 1984.

title: Woman Out of Control
text: The album was remastered and expanded by Funky Town Grooves in June 2012.

title: After Dark (Ray Parker Jr. album)
text: After Dark is the fourth album by guitarist/singer/songwriter Ray Parker Jr. released in 1987 for the new Geffen Records label.

title: After Dark (Ray Parker Jr. album)
text: The record company released the album on August 25, 1987.

title: After Dark (Ray Parker Jr. album)
text: It included the single "I Don't Think That Man Should Sleep Alone".

title: Saturday Night Live cast members
text: The following is a list of "Saturday Night Live" cast members, past and present.

title: Saturday Night Live cast members
text: The cast members of "Saturday Night Live" were originally referred to as the "Not Ready For Prime Time Players."

title: Lowell Smith
text: Lowell Herbert Smith (October 8, 1892—November 4, 1945) was a pioneer American airman who piloted the first airplane to receive a complete mid-air refueling (along with Lt. John P. Richter) on June 27, 1923, and later set an endurance record of 37 hours on August 28, both in a De Havilland DH-4B.

title: Lowell Smith
text: Smith also piloted the Douglas World Cruiser "Chicago", which along with one other made the first aerial circumnavigation in 1924.

title: Lowell Smith
text: Smith held 16 records for military aircraft in speed, endurance and distance.

title: Lowell Smith
text: He was awarded the best achievement in flight Mackay Trophy twice.

title: Lincoln J. Beachey
text: Lincoln J. Beachey (March 3, 1887 – March 14, 1915) was a pioneer American aviator and barnstormer.

title: Lincoln J. Beachey
text: He became famous and wealthy from flying exhibitions, staging aerial stunts, helping invent aerobatics, and setting aviation records.

title: List of British airships
text: Airship development in the United Kingdom lagged behind that of Germany and France.

title: List of British airships
text: The first British designed and built airship was constructed by Stanley Spencer, and on 22 September 1902 was flown 30 mi from Crystal Palace, London to Ruislip, carrying an advertisement for baby food.

title: List of British airships
text: A series of more practical airships was constructed by Ernest Willows, the "Willows Number 1" making its first flight near Cardiff on 5 August 1905.

title: List of British airships
text: The Royal Navy realised that airships similar to Ferdinand von Zeppelin's designs could be of great use and in 1909 ordered construction of a rigid airship.

title: List of British airships
text: This was completed in 1911 but was wrecked while leaving the hangar before it had flown.

title: List of British airships
text: Meanwhile, the British Army's School of Ballooning, later the Air Battalion Royal Engineers, acquired a small fleet of semi-rigid and non-rigid airships for observation purposes; they were taken over by the Royal Navy on the creation of the Royal Naval Air Service in 1914.

title: List of British airships
text: A large number of rigid and non-rigid airships were mainly used to counter the U-Boat campaign in World War I.

title: List of British airships
text: Interest in military airships declined at the end of the war, but some success in the commercial field inspired the Imperial Airship Scheme; however, the disastrous crash of the R101 in 1930 ended serious government and commercial interest in airships.

title: List of British airships
text: Since the 1970s, there have been persistent efforts to revive a British airship industry, using new designs, materials and technologies.

title: Zachary Lansdowne
text: Lieutenant Commander Zachary Lansdowne, USN (December 1, 1888 – September 3, 1925) was a United States Navy officer and early Naval aviator who contributed to the development of the Navy's first lighter-than-air craft.

title: Zachary Lansdowne
text: He earned the Navy Cross for his participation in the first transoceanic airship flight while assigned to the British "R34" in 1919.

title: Zachary Lansdowne
text: He later commanded the USS "Shenandoah" (ZR-1), which was the first rigid airship to complete a flight across North America.

title: Zachary Lansdowne
text: He was killed in the crash of the "Shenandoah".

title: Alys McKey Bryant
text: Alys McKey Bryant (1880–1954) was an American aviator.

title: Alys McKey Bryant
text: She was the first woman to fly on the Pacific Coast and in Canada, and one of the few female members of the Early Birds of Aviation—individuals who had solo piloted an aircraft prior to December 17, 1916.

title: Alys McKey Bryant
text: She cut short her brief career as a pilot after her husband, John Bryant, died while performing an air show in Victoria, Canada, in August 1913.

title: Alys McKey Bryant
text: During World War I she trained pilots.

title: Hilaire du Berrier
text: Hilaire du Berrier (1905 – October 12, 2002) was a pioneer American pilot, barnstormer, and spy.

title: Santos-Dumont number 6
text: The Santos-Dumont No. 6 was an airship designed and built by the Brazilian pioneer aviator Alberto Santos-Dumont.

title: Santos-Dumont number 6
text: In 1901 it was used by him to win the Deutsch de la Meurthe prize for a return from Parc Saint Cloud to the Eiffel Tower and back.

title: Santos-Dumont number 6
text: It is considered by many to be the first truly successful airship.

title: Ernest Willows
text: Ernest Thompson Willows (1886–1926) was a pioneer Welsh aviator and airship builder.

title: Ernest Willows
text: He became the first person in the United Kingdom to hold a pilots certificate for an airship when the Royal Aero Club awarded him "Airship Pilots Certificate No. 1".

title: Gelatine (airship)
text: Gelatine was an airship operated by the United States Army Signal Corps.

title: Gelatine (airship)
text: "Gelatine" was built by Thomas Scott Baldwin's company Baldwin's Airships, Balloons, Aeroplanes of New York City.

title: Gelatine (airship)
text: On the morning of September 19, 1905, the "Gelatine", piloted by Lincoln J. Beachey, ascended from the grounds of the Lewis and Clark Centennial Exposition on the shores of Guild's Lake in Portland, Oregon, landing 40 minutes later at the Vancouver Barracks in Vancouver, Washington.

title: Gelatine (airship)
text: The flight is considered as the first aerial crossing of the Columbia River and the first account of controlled powered flight in Washington.

title: Douglas Campbell (aviator)
text: Douglas Campbell (June 7, 1896 – December 16, 1990) was an American aviator and World War I flying ace.

title: Douglas Campbell (aviator)
text: He was the first American aviator flying in an American-trained air unit to achieve the status of ace.

title: 2009 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team
text: The 2009 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team represented the University of Notre Dame in the 2009 NCAA Division I FBS football season.

title: 2009 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team
text: The team was coached by Charlie Weis and played its home games at Notre Dame Stadium in South Bend, Indiana.

title: 2009 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team
text: Weis entered his fifth season as head coach with the expectation from the Notre Dame administration that his team would be in position to compete for a BCS Bowl berth.

title: 2009 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team
text: Notre Dame started the first part of the season 4-2, with close losses to Michigan and USC but ended the season with four straight losses, including a second loss to Navy loss in three years.

title: 2009 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team
text: Weis was fired as head coach the Monday after the Stanford loss at the end of the season.

title: 2009 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team
text: Although Notre Dame was bowl eligible with 6 wins, the University announced on December 4 that the Irish had chosen not to play in a bowl game.

title: 2009 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team
text: Irish athletic director Jack Swarbrick hired Cincinnati head coach Brian Kelly after a 10-day coaching search.

title: Notre Dame of Genio Edcor Inc.
text: Notre Dame of Genio Edcor, Inc. (Old name: "Notre Dame of Edcor" ) is a private, Catholic academic institution run by the Oblates of Notre Dame located in Alamada, Cotabato, Philippines.This school is a member of the Notre Dame Educational Association.

title: Notre Dame of Genio Edcor Inc.
text: Established in 1958,It has been one of the pioneering school under the Notre Dame Educational System run by the Oblates of Notre Dame in the province of North Cotabato, Philippines.

title: Notre Dame of Midsayap College
text: Notre Dame of Midsayap College (Tagalog: "Dalubhasaang Notre Dame ng Midsayap" or "Kolehiyong Notre Dame ng Midsayap") (colloquially known as "NDMC" or simply "Notre Dame") is a private, Catholic academic institution run by the Missionary Oblates of Mary Immaculate in Midsayap, Cotabato.

title: Notre Dame of Midsayap College
text: Established on 13 June 1941 making it as the "First Notre Dame School in Asia and in the Philippines", it was the first link in the long chain of Notre Dame Schools in the Philippines that form the Notre Dame Educational Association under the patronage of the Blessed Virgin Mary, the school Patroness and St. Eugene De Mazenod as the school's patron saint.

title: South of the Border with Disney
text: South of the Border with Disney is a 1942 Disney short documentary film.

title: South of the Border with Disney
text: It was shot in the same occasion "Saludos Amigos" was, when Walt Disney and a group of eighteen artists, musicians and writers went to South America looking for inspirations for a movie.

title: South of the Border with Disney
text: While "Saludos Amigos" is the result of this voyage, alternating animated shorts to the sequences from the travel that inspired them, "South of the Border with Disney" is more of a behind-the-scenes documentary showing only the travel and the genesis of cartoons not only for "Saludos Amigos" and "The Three Caballeros", but also some others used in later occasions.

title: South of the Border with Disney
text: The most notable example is a female Armadillo used for a 1943 Pluto cartoon, "Pluto and the Armadillo".

title: South of the Border with Disney
text: Film also includes some pencil test animation.

title: Notre Dame Fighting Irish football
text: The Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team is the intercollegiate football team representing the University of Notre Dame in Notre Dame, Indiana.

title: Notre Dame Fighting Irish football
text: The team is currently coached by Brian Kelly and plays its home games at the campus's Notre Dame Stadium, which has a capacity of 80,795 fans.

title: Notre Dame Fighting Irish football
text: Notre Dame is one of four schools that competes as an Independent at the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) Football Bowl Subdivision level; however, they play five games a year against opponents from the Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC), which Notre Dame is a member of in all other sports except ice hockey.

title: Notre Dame Shakespeare Festival
text: The Notre Dame Shakespeare Festival (formerly Summer Shakespeare) at the University of Notre Dame is an annual festival that seeks to combine professional productions of the works of William Shakespeare with community outreach and educational programs.

title: Notre Dame Shakespeare Festival
text: The Notre Dame Shakespeare Festival is a part of the University of Notre Dame's Shakespeare initiative entitled "Shakespeare at Notre Dame", a program that recognizes the centrality of the study of Shakespeare in humanistic pedagogy at the University.

title: Notre Dame Shakespeare Festival
text: Its fifteenth season (summer of 2014) was known as the 15/150, also celebrating the 450th birthday of William Shakespeare, and the 150th anniversary of the first full production of Shakespeare at the university in 1864 (Records indicate the first performance of Shakespeare at the University of Notre Dame took place in 1847, a collection of scenes also from "Henry IV)."

title: Notre Dame Shakespeare Festival
text: The anniversary season consisted of the Professional Company production of "Henry IV" (directed by Michael Goldberg), the Young Company performance of "The Merry Wives of Windsor" (directed by West Hyler), and the annual ShakeScenes shows featuring actors of all ages from South Bend and the surrounding community.

title: The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1996 film)
text: The Hunchback of Notre Dame is a 1996 American animated musical drama film produced by Walt Disney Feature Animation for Walt Disney Pictures.

title: The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1996 film)
text: The 34th Disney animated feature film, the film is based on Victor Hugo's novel of the same name.

title: The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1996 film)
text: The plot centers on Quasimodo, the deformed bell-ringer of Notre Dame, and his struggle to gain acceptance into society.

title: The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1996 film)
text: Directed by Kirk Wise and Gary Trousdale and produced by Don Hahn, the film's voice cast features Tom Hulce, Demi Moore, Tony Jay, Kevin Kline, Paul Kandel, Jason Alexander, Charles Kimbrough, David Ogden Stiers, and Mary Wickes in her final film role.

title: Notre Dame–Stanford football rivalry
text: The Notre Dame–Stanford football rivalry is an American college football rivalry between the Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team of the University of Notre Dame and Stanford Cardinal football team of Stanford University.

title: Notre Dame–Stanford football rivalry
text: As of 2016, the Notre Dame Fighting Irish and Stanford Cardinal have met 31 times, beginning in 1925 (though the modern series began in 1988).

title: Notre Dame–Stanford football rivalry
text: The Notre Dame–Stanford game has been played annually since 1997, with the teams meeting at Notre Dame Stadium earlier in the season (late September to mid-October) in even-numbered years, and at Stanford Stadium on the weekend following Thanksgiving in odd-numbered years since 1999.

title: Notre Dame–Stanford football rivalry
text: The game typically alternates positions in Notre Dame's schedule with its other Pac-12 opponent, USC.

title: Saludos Amigos
text: Saludos Amigos (Spanish for "Greetings, Friends") is a 1942 American live-action animated package film produced by Walt Disney and released by RKO Radio Pictures.

title: Saludos Amigos
text: It is the sixth Disney animated feature film and the first of the six package films produced by Walt Disney Productions in the 1940s.

title: Saludos Amigos
text: Set in Latin America, it is made up of four different segments; Donald Duck stars in two of them and Goofy stars in one.

title: Saludos Amigos
text: It also features the first appearance of José Carioca, the Brazilian cigar-smoking parrot.

title: Saludos Amigos
text: "Saludos Amigos" was popular enough that Walt Disney decided to make another film about Latin America, "The Three Caballeros", to be produced two years later.

title: Saludos Amigos
text: "Saludos Amigos" premiered in Rio de Janeiro on August 24, 1942.

title: Saludos Amigos
text: It was released in the United States on February 6, 1943.

title: Saludos Amigos
text: At 42 minutes, it is Disney's shortest animated feature to date.

title: Saludos Amigos
text: It garnered positive reviews and was theatrically reissued in 1949, when it was shown on a double bill with the first reissue of "Dumbo".

title: 2007 Navy vs. Notre Dame football game
text: The 2007 Navy vs. Notre Dame football game ended the longest all-time college football consecutive wins streak by one team over another.

title: 2007 Navy vs. Notre Dame football game
text: On November 3, 2007, the Navy Midshipmen defeated the Notre Dame Fighting Irish 46–44 in triple-overtime at Notre Dame's home field, Notre Dame Stadium in South Bend, Indiana.

title: 2007 Navy vs. Notre Dame football game
text: Notre Dame came into this annual game with 43 straight wins against Navy since the last loss against Heisman Trophy winner Roger Staubach in 1963.

title: 2007 Navy vs. Notre Dame football game
text: With the win, Navy improved to 5–4 and Notre Dame fell to 1–8 on the season.

title: Alexandru Drăghici
text: Alexandru Drăghici (] ; September 27, 1913 – December 12, 1993) was a Romanian communist activist and politician.

title: Alexandru Drăghici
text: He was Interior Minister in 1952 and from 1957 to 1965, and State Security Minister from 1952 to 1957.

title: Alexandru Drăghici
text: In these capacities, he exercised control over the "Securitate" secret police during a period of active repression against other Communist Party members, anti-communist resistance members and ordinary citizens.

title: Organización Primero de Marzo
text: The First Of March Organization (Organizacion Primero de Marzo) (OPM) was a clandestine movement created in Paraguay in the mid 70s to fight General Alfredo Stroessner’s dictatorship.

title: Organización Primero de Marzo
text: It was the most serious attempt at creating an armed resistance to the dictator’s repressive government.

title: Organización Primero de Marzo
text: Even though the organization was discovered before it was capable of attacking in the government in any way, the wave of repression which followed the discovery was enormous.

title: Organización Primero de Marzo
text: During that period of repression, several leaders of the organization were captured, tortured and then executed, but the violence also extended to many regions of the country, affecting several agrarian movements and agrarian workers that had nothing to do with the OPM.

title: Punk rock in Spain
text: In Spain, the punk rock scene emerged in 1978, when the country had just emerged from forty years of fascist dictatorship under General Franco, a state that “melded state repression with fundamentalist Catholic moralism”.

title: Punk rock in Spain
text: Even after Franco died in 1975, the country went through a “volatile political period”, in which the country had to try to relearn democratic values and install a constitution.

title: Punk rock in Spain
text: When punk emerged, it “did not appropriate socialism as its goal”; instead, it embraced “nihilism”, and focused on keeping the memories of past abuses alive, and accusing all of Spanish society of collaborating with the fascist regime.

title: History of Thailand (1932–1973)
text: The history of Thailand from 1932 to 1973 was dominated by military dictatorships which were in power for much of the period.

title: History of Thailand (1932–1973)
text: The main personalities of the period were the dictator Luang Phibunsongkhram (better known as Phibun), who allied the country with Japan during the Second World War, and the civilian politician Pridi Phanomyong, who founded Thammasat University and was briefly prime minister after the war.

title: History of Russia (1855–92)
text: In 1855 Alexander II began his reign as Tsar of Russia, and presided over a period of political and social reform, notably the emancipation of serfs in 1861 and the lifting of censorship.

title: History of Russia (1855–92)
text: His successor, Alexander III (1881-1894), pursued a policy of repression and restricted public expenditure, but continued land and labour reforms.

title: History of Russia (1855–92)
text: This was a period of population growth and significant industrialization; nevertheless Russia remained a largely rural country.

title: Dirty War
text: The "Dirty War" (Spanish: "Guerra Sucia" ), was the name used by the Argentine Military Government for a period of state terrorism in Argentina from roughly 1974 to 1983 (some sources date the beginning to 1969), during which military and security forces and right-wing death squads in the form of the Argentine Anticommunist Alliance (Triple A) hunted down and killed left-wing guerrillas, political dissidents, and anyone believed to be associated with socialism.

title: Dirty War
text: About 30,000 people disappeared, many of which were impossible to be formally reported due to the nature of the issue: state terrorism.

title: Dirty War
text: The targets were left-wing activists, guerrillas and militants, trade unionists, students, journalists and Marxists and Peronist guerrillas and their support network in the Montoneros believed to be 150,000-250,000-strong and 60,000-strong in the ERP, as well as alleged sympathizers.

title: Dirty War
text: Some 10,000 of the "disappeared" were guerrillas of the Montoneros (MPM) and the Marxist People's Revolutionary Army (ERP) although the lowest estimate is that the Montoneros and ERP had a combined strength of 5,000.

title: Dirty War
text: The "disappeared" included those thought to be a political or ideological threat to the military junta, even vaguely, and they were killed in an attempt by the junta to silence the opposition and break the determination of the guerrillas.

title: Dirty War
text: The worst repression reportedly occurred after the guerillas were largely defeated in 1977, when the church, labor unions, artists, intellectuals and university students and professors were targeted.

title: Dirty War
text: Although the Montoneros reported having carried out some 600 armed attacks in 1977, the guerrilla threat had greatly declined.

title: Dirty War
text: The junta justified this mass terror by exaggerating the guerrilla threat, and even staged attacks to be blamed on guerillas and used frozen dead bodies of guerilla fighters that had been kept in storage for this purpose.

title: Dirty War
text: In late 1979, Amnesty International accused the Videla military government of being responsible for the disappearance of 15,000 to 20,000 Argentine citizens since the 1976 coup.

title: Dirty War
text: That year, a special study by the New York City Bar concluded that around 10,000 Argentines had disappeared since the coup.

title: Dirty War
text: According to "Registro Unificado de Víctimas del Terrorismo de Estado" (Ruvte), 662 were disappeared under the presidency of Isabel Perón and 6,348 were disappeared during the military dictatorship.

title: Japanese dissidence during the early Shōwa period
text: Japanese dissidence during the early Shōwa period was dissidence by Japanese citizens of the Empire of Japan (1868–1947) during the Shōwa period, the reign of the Shōwa Emperor, Hirohito (1926–1989).

title: Japanese dissidence during the early Shōwa period
text: The early Shōwa period witnessed the rise of Japanese militarism, and Imperial Japan's full-scale invasion of China in the Second Sino-Japanese War (1937–1945), which escalated into a full-scale invasion of the Asia-Pacific during the Pacific theatre of World War II (1941–1945).

title: Japanese dissidence during the early Shōwa period
text: Throughout the period, there was political repression in Imperial Japan.

title: Stalinist repressions in Mongolia
text: The Stalinist repressions in Mongolia (Mongolian: Их Хэлмэгдүүлэлт , Ikh Khelmegdüülelt, ""Great Repression"") refers to a period of heightened political violence and persecution in the Mongolian People's Republic between 1937 and 1939.

title: Stalinist repressions in Mongolia
text: The repressions were part of the Stalinist purges (also known as the Great Purge) unfolding across the Soviet Union around the same period.

title: Stalinist repressions in Mongolia
text: Soviet NKVD advisors, under the nominal direction of Mongolia's "de facto" leader Khorloogiin Choibalsan, persecuted individuals and organizations perceived as threats to the Mongolian revolution and the growing Soviet influence in the country.

title: Stalinist repressions in Mongolia
text: As in the Soviet Union, methods of repression included show trials, torture, and imprisonment in remote forced labor camps.

title: Stalinist repressions in Mongolia
text: Estimates differ, but anywhere between 20,000 to 35,000 "enemies of the revolution" were executed, a figure representing three to five percent of Mongolia's total population at the time.

title: Stalinist repressions in Mongolia
text: Victims included those suspected of espousing lamaism, pan-Mongolist nationalism, and pro-Japanese sentiment with the Buddhist clergy, aristocrats, intelligentsia, political dissidents, and ethnic Buryats and Kazakhs suffering the greatest losses.

title: Augusto Pinochet
text: Augusto José Ramón Pinochet Ugarte (] or ] ; 25 November 1915 – 10 December 2006) was a Chilean general, politician and the dictator of Chile between 1973 and 1990; he remained the Commander-in-Chief of the Chilean Army until 1998.

title: Augusto Pinochet
text: He was also president of the Government Junta of Chile between 1973 and 1981.

title: Augusto Pinochet
text: His rule of Chile was a dictatorship.

title: Popular Unitary Action Movement
text: The Popular Unitary Action Movement or MAPU (Spanish: Movimiento de Acción Popular Unitario ) was a small leftist political party in Chile.

title: Popular Unitary Action Movement
text: It was part of the Popular Unity coalition during the government of Salvador Allende.

title: Popular Unitary Action Movement
text: MAPU was repressed during the dictatorship of Augusto Pinochet.

title: Popular Unitary Action Movement
text: In this period, some of its most radical members formed the Movimiento Juvenil Lautaro, whose leaders were political prisoners during the dictatorship and with the return to democracy.

title: Popular Unitary Action Movement
text: Another faction of the former members of the party joined the social democratic Party for Democracy in 1987.

title: Pantsuit Nation
text: Pantsuit Nation is a private Facebook group and Twitter hashtag used to rally camaraderie among Hillary Clinton supporters during her 2016 presidential campaign.

title: Pantsuit Nation
text: Though the group is not affiliated with a political party, its symbol—the pantsuit—was used as a metonym for Hillary Clinton's 2016 presidential campaign similar to how the color red was used for the campaign of her opponent, Donald Trump.

title: Pantsuit Nation
text: At the time of the November 2016 election, the group had 2.9 million members and had raised US $170,000 for the Clinton campaign.

title: Adam Parkhomenko
text: Adam Parkhomenko is a Democratic political strategist and organizer who served as National Field Director for the Democratic National Committee in 2016.

title: Adam Parkhomenko
text: He was the co-founder and executive director of Ready for Hillary, a super PAC established to persuade Hillary Clinton to run for the presidency of the United States in 2016.

title: Adam Parkhomenko
text: In the 2017 party election, Parkhomenko was a candidate for Vice Chair of the Democratic National Committee.

title: Vast right-wing conspiracy
text: "Vast right-wing conspiracy" is a conspiracy theory first described in a 1995 memo by political opposition researcher Chris Lehane and then referenced in 1998 by the then First Lady of the United States Hillary Clinton, in defense of her husband, President Bill Clinton, characterizing the continued allegations of scandal against her and her husband, including the Lewinsky scandal, as part of a long campaign by Clinton's political enemies.

title: Vast right-wing conspiracy
text: The term has been used since, including in a question posed to Bill Clinton in 2009 to describe verbal attacks on Barack Obama during his early presidency.

title: Vast right-wing conspiracy
text: Hillary Clinton mentioned it again during her 2016 presidential campaign.

title: Institute of Muslim Minority Affairs
text: The Institute of Muslim Minority Affairs is a London-based scholarly institution furthering the study of Muslims in non-Muslim nations.

title: Institute of Muslim Minority Affairs
text: It holds conferences and publishes books and journals.

title: Institute of Muslim Minority Affairs
text: Pakistani-born Dr. Saleha Mahmood Abedin, the mother of Hillary Clinton aide Huma Abedin, is Director of the Institute.

title: Institute of Muslim Minority Affairs
text: It was founded in 1978 by Dr. Syed Zainul Abedin, from India who was educated at Aligarh Muslim University and University of Pennsylvania.

title: Institute of Muslim Minority Affairs
text: Abdullah Omar Naseef, then president of the Muslim World League and president of King Abdulaziz University, provided backing to Abedin for the institute's formation.

title: Huma Abedin
text: Huma Mahmood Abedin (born July 28, 1976) is an American political staffer who was vice chair of Hillary Clinton's 2016 campaign for President of the United States.

title: Huma Abedin
text: Prior to that, Abedin was deputy chief of staff to Clinton, who was U.S. Secretary of State, from 2009 to 2013.

title: Huma Abedin
text: She was also the traveling chief of staff and former assistant for Clinton during Clinton's campaign for the Democratic nomination in the 2008 presidential election.

title: Tom Rasmussen
text: Tom Rasmussen is a retired member of the Seattle City Council, first elected in 2003.

title: Tom Rasmussen
text: Between September 2004 and December 2007 he was chair of the Housing, Human Services & Health Committee, vice chair of the Urban Development & Planning Committee, and a member of the Transportation Committee.

title: Tom Rasmussen
text: On January 7, 2008 Tom was sworn in for his second term on City Council.

title: Tom Rasmussen
text: From January 2008 through December 2009, he was chair of the Parks & Seattle Center Committee, the vice chair of the Culture, Civil Rights, Health and Personnel Committee, and the Labor Policy Committee.

title: Tom Rasmussen
text: He was also chair of the Transportation Committee, vice chair of the Economic Resiliency and Regional Relations, and a member of Parks and Seattle Center Committee.

title: Hillary 1984
text: Hillary 1984 is the title of the viral video that combines the footage of the 2008 presidential campaign web announcement by Hillary Clinton with the 1984 Super Bowl commercial by Apple Inc. for the launch of Macintosh.

title: Hillary 1984
text: The video shows the same blond female athlete from the 1984 Super Bowl commercial updated with an iPod.

title: Hillary 1984
text: The Big Brother image that she throws the sledgehammer at is replaced with Hillary Clinton announcing that she is running for president.

title: Hillary 1984
text: It ends with the original text replaced with, "On Jan. 14, the Democratic primary will begin.

title: Hillary 1984
text: And you'll see why 2008 won't be like 1984."

title: Hillary 1984
text: The Apple symbol is a morphed into an "O", which is followed by a logo for Barack Obama's presidential campaign website.

title: Hillary 1984
text: Barack Obama's presidential spokesman Bill Burton has said "Hillary 1984" was not created by the Obama campaign.

title: Hillary 1984
text: "It's somebody else's creation," he said.

title: Paul v. Clinton
text: Paul v. Clinton was a civil suit filed in 2004 held in Los Angeles County Superior Court.

title: Paul v. Clinton
text: The plaintiff, Peter F. Paul, alleged that President Bill Clinton and his wife, First Lady Hillary Clinton, deceived him into paying for the Gala Hollywood Farewell Salute to President Clinton, during Hillary Clinton's first Senate race in 2000, by making a promise that the President would work for Paul's company, Stan Lee Media, after his presidential term was over.

title: Paul v. Clinton
text: Paul alleged that the President broke his promise and stole his business partner, causing his business to crumble and, further, that his contributions to Hillary Clinton's campaign were falsely reported to the Federal Election Commission.

title: Paul v. Clinton
text: Besides the Clintons, three other individuals who were involved in fundraising for the gala, were named as defendants in the suit.

title: Clinton family
text: The Clinton family is a prominent American political family related to Bill Clinton, the 42nd President of the United States (1993–2001), and his wife Hillary Clinton, the 67th United States Secretary of State (2009–13), Senator from New York (2001–09) and the First Lady of the United States (1993–2001).

title: Clinton family
text: Their immediate family was the First Family of the United States from 1993 to 2001.

title: Clinton family
text: In 2016, Hillary Clinton became the first female presidential nominee from a major political party in United States history.

title: Clinton family
text: The Clintons (Bill and Hillary) are the first married couple to each be nominated for president.

title: Clinton family
text: She was defeated in the election by businessman Donald Trump.

title: Cheryl Mills
text: Cheryl D. Mills (born 1965) is an American lawyer and corporate executive.

title: Cheryl Mills
text: She first came into public prominence while serving as deputy White House Counsel for President Bill Clinton, whom she defended during his 1999 impeachment trial.

title: Cheryl Mills
text: She has worked for New York University as Senior Vice President, served as Senior Adviser and Counsel for Hillary Clinton's 2008 presidential campaign, and is considered a member of Hillary Clinton's group of core advisers, self-designated as "Hillaryland".

title: Cheryl Mills
text: She served as Counselor and Chief of Staff to Hillary Clinton during her whole tenure as United States Secretary of State.

title: Cheryl Mills
text: After leaving the State Department in January, 2013, she founded BlackIvy Group, which builds businesses in Africa.

title: Donald Evans (American football)
text: Donald Lee Evans (born March 14, 1964 in Raleigh, North Carolina) is a former American football defensive end who played eight seasons in the National Football League for the Los Angeles Rams, Philadelphia Eagles, Pittsburgh Steelers, and New York Jets.

title: Donald Evans (American football)
text: He attended high school in Raleigh at Athens Drive High School, graduating in 1982.

title: Dean Lowry
text: Dean Vincent Lowry (born June 9, 1994) is an American football defensive end for the Green Bay Packers of the National Football League (NFL).

title: Dean Lowry
text: He played high school football at Boylan Central Catholic High School in Rockford, Illinois before attending Northwestern and playing for their football team on a scholarship.

title: Dean Lowry
text: At Northwestern, he was a four-year starter at defensive end.

title: Dean Lowry
text: He was drafted after his senior year of college by the Green Bay Packers in the 2016 NFL Draft.

title: Jason Hall (American football)
text: Jason Hall (born October 31, 1983) is a former American football defensive end for the Buffalo Bill, Carolina Panthers, and Tennessee Titans in the National Football League.

title: Jason Hall (American football)
text: Hall attended high school at The McCallie School in Chattanooga, where he won the state title as a senior.

title: Jason Hall (American football)
text: He also won TSSAA's Division II-AAA Player of the Year honors and was Runner-Up for the 2002 American General Mr. Football Award.

title: Nauset Regional High School
text: Nauset Regional High School an NEASC accredited high school located in North Eastham, Massachusetts.

title: Nauset Regional High School
text: Nauset is inside the Cape Cod National Seashore, making it the only high school on the East Coast located within a National Park.

title: Nauset Regional High School
text: The open campus is situated about a half-mile from Nauset Light.

title: Nauset Regional High School
text: Nauset's colors are Black and Gold and the school's mascot is the Warrior.

title: Dennis Johnson (defensive end)
text: Dennis Alan Johnson (born December 4, 1979) is a former American football defensive end who played for the Arizona Cardinals and San Francisco 49ers of the National Football League (NFL).

title: Dennis Johnson (defensive end)
text: While playing his senior season for Harrodsburg High School, he was named the National Player of the Year by "Sports Illustrated" and 1997 National High School Defensive Player of the Year by "USA Today" and "The Sporting News".

title: Dennis Johnson (defensive end)
text: He attended the University of Kentucky, where he was a Third-Team All-American and All-Southeastern Conference (SEC) First-Team defender.

title: Dexter Nottage
text: Dexter Alexander Nottage (born November 14, 1970) is a former American football defensive end in the National Football League (NFL) for the Washington Redskins and the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: Dexter Nottage
text: He played college football at Florida A&M University and was selected in the sixth round of the 1994 NFL Draft.

title: Dexter Nottage
text: He played high school football at Hollywood Hills High School.

title: Walt Bowyer
text: Walter Nathaniel Bowyer Jr. (born September 8, 1960) is a former American football defensive end who played four seasons with the Denver Broncos of the National Football League (NFL).

title: Walt Bowyer
text: He was drafted by the Broncos in the tenth round of the 1983 NFL Draft.

title: Walt Bowyer
text: He played college football at Arizona State University and attended Wilkinsburg High School in Wilkinsburg, Pennsylvania.

title: Walt Bowyer
text: Bowyer was also a member of the Edmonton Eskimos of the Canadian Football League.

title: Mike DeVito
text: Michael Ralph DeVito (born June 10, 1984) is a former American football defensive end.

title: Mike DeVito
text: He played for the New York Jets of the National Football League (NFL) from 2007 to 2012, and then the Kansas City Chiefs from 2013 to 2015.

title: Mike DeVito
text: He played college football at The University of Maine.

title: Mike DeVito
text: DeVito attended high school at Nauset Regional High School in Eastham, Massachusetts.

title: Martin Baccaglio
text: Martin Hoppe "Marty" Baccaglio (born September 28, 1944) is a former American football defensive end.

title: Martin Baccaglio
text: He played college football at San José State University and in high school at Novato High School.

title: Martin Baccaglio
text: He played professionally in the American Football League for the San Diego Chargers in 1968 and for the Cincinnati Bengals 1968-1969.

title: Martin Baccaglio
text: He also played for the Bengals of the National Football League in 1970.

title: Tim Goad
text: Tim Goad (born February 28, 1966) is a former American football defensive tackle.

title: Tim Goad
text: He attended high school at Patrick County High School in Stuart, VA and was a member of the Cougar varsity football team.

title: Tim Goad
text: He played offensive tackle and defensive tackle for the team.

title: Tim Goad
text: After high school, he attended the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill, where he played on the defensive line.

title: Tim Goad
text: After college, Goad was drafted by the New England Patriots.

title: Tim Goad
text: He made his first professional appearance on September 4, 1988 in a 28–3 Patriots' victory.

title: Tim Goad
text: He played seven seasons in New England.

title: Tim Goad
text: In 1995, he played for the Cleveland Browns, and finished his career with the Baltimore Ravens in 1996.

title: Tim Goad
text: In 1998, Goad became the jackman for the NASCAR team Wood Brothers Racing, while also serving at Petty Enterprises and Kevin Harvick Incorporated, the latter in which he served as pit coach.

title: Tim Goad
text: He also worked as a professional bass fisherman.

title: Tim Goad
text: He currently resides in Pittsboro, NC C.I.D..

title: Samjhawan
text: "Samjhawan" is a romantic song from the 2014 Bollywood film "Humpty Sharma Ki Dulhania".

title: Samjhawan
text: Re-created by Sharib−Toshi, the song is sung by Arijit Singh and Shreya Ghoshal, with lyrics by Ahmad Anees and Kumaar.

title: Samjhawan
text: The song was originally composed by Jawad Ahmad and sung by Rahat Fateh Ali Khan for the Punjabi film "Virsa".

title: Samjhawan
text: An "unplugged" version of this song sung by the leading actress of the film, Alia Bhatt, was released on 2 July 2014.

title: Song of the sea
text: The Song of the Sea (Hebrew: שירת הים‎ ‎ , Shirat HaYam, also known as Az Yashir Moshe and Song of Moses) is a poem that appears in the Book of Exodus of the Hebrew Bible, at .

title: Song of the sea
text: It is followed in verses 20 and 21 by a much shorter song sung by Miriam and the other women.

title: Song of the sea
text: The Song of the Sea was reputedly sung by the Israelites after their crossing the Red Sea in safety, and celebrates the destruction of the Egyptian army during the crossing, and looks forward to the future conquest of Canaan.

title: Las Mañanitas
text: Las Mañanitas is a traditional Mexican birthday song sung in Mexico and other Latin American countries at birthday parties, usually early in the morning to awaken the birthday person, also before eating cake, and especially as part of the custom of serenading women.

title: Las Mañanitas
text: In Mexico, "Las Mañanitas" is sung to men and women of all ages.

title: Las Mañanitas
text: In some countries, such as Colombia, the song is only sung to girls, especially on their 15th birthdays.

title: Las Mañanitas
text: Perhaps the most famous rendition of "Las Mañanitas" is that sung by Pedro Infante to "Chachita" in the movie "Nosotros los pobres".

title: Apocalyptic (song)
text: "Apocalyptic" is a song by the American hard rock band Halestorm.

title: Apocalyptic (song)
text: It was released on January 12, 2015, as the lead single from the band's third studio album, "Into the Wild Life".

title: Apocalyptic (song)
text: The video for the song was released on January 28.

title: Halestorm
text: Halestorm is an American hard rock band from Red Lion, Pennsylvania, consisting of lead vocalist and guitarist Lzzy Hale, her brother drummer and percussionist Arejay Hale, guitarist Joe Hottinger, and bassist Josh Smith.

title: Halestorm
text: The group's self-titled debut album was released on April 28, 2009, through Atlantic Records.

title: Halestorm
text: Their second album "The Strange Case Of..." was released on April 10, 2012.

title: Halestorm
text: Its lead single "Love Bites (So Do I)" from that album won their first Grammy Award for Best Hard Rock/Metal Performance on February 10, 2013.

title: See the USA in Your Chevrolet
text: The song "See The U.S.A.

title: See the USA in Your Chevrolet
text: In Your Chevrolet" (title as filed for 1950 copyright) is a commercial jingle from c. 1949, with lyrics and music by Leo Corday (ASCAP) and Leon Carr (ASCAP), written for the Chevrolet Division of General Motors.

title: See the USA in Your Chevrolet
text: The song was the Chevrolet jingle sung on the show "Inside U.S.A. with Chevrolet" by Chevrolet's real-life husband-wife duo, Peter Lind Hayes and Mary Healy, years before it became associated with Dinah Shore through Chevrolet's decade-long sponsorship of her television shows.

title: See the USA in Your Chevrolet
text: Dinah Shore sang the song after 1952, and it became something of a signature song for her.

title: See the USA in Your Chevrolet
text: Later the song was also sung by male spokesman Pat Boone on his "Pat Boone-Chevy Showroom" (ABC) from 1957 through 1960.

title: See the USA in Your Chevrolet
text: When the games of the Los Angeles Dodgers were televised in the 1960s, commercials were aired with the song sung by John Roseboro and Don Drysdale, whose singing careers, announcer Vin Scully said, were "destined to go absolutely nowhere."

title: Famine Song
text: The Famine Song is a song sung by some Ulster loyalists in Northern Ireland and Scotland and is normally directed at Catholics and, in Scotland, Irish people, those of Irish descent or those with perceived affiliations to Ireland.

title: Famine Song
text: It is also sung by fans of Scottish football club Rangers due to rival Celtic's Irish roots.

title: Famine Song
text: Set to the tune of "The John B. Sails" popularised by Carl Sandburg, the lyrics of the song make reference to the 1840s' Great Famine of Ireland.

title: Famine Song
text: The song is often heard at loyalist marches in Northern Ireland despite many loyalists being descended from refugees fleeing famine in Scotland, and the Great Famine being an event that impacted the whole of Ireland.

title: Famine Song
text: The Famine Song has received criticism due to the racist and sectarian nature of its lyrics and, in some cases, those singing it have received criminal convictions.

title: Sarah (Thin Lizzy song)
text: "Sarah" is a pop song released in 1979 by Irish rock group Thin Lizzy, included on their album, "".

title: Sarah (Thin Lizzy song)
text: The song was written by the band's frontman Phil Lynott and guitarist Gary Moore about Lynott's newborn daughter.

title: Sarah (Thin Lizzy song)
text: The song was also issued as a single, and appeared on several compilation albums including "".

title: Sarah (Thin Lizzy song)
text: The song was never performed live by Thin Lizzy, but it was adopted as a live favourite by Lynott's post-Thin Lizzy project, Grand Slam, and featured on "Live in Sweden 1983", a recording of Lynott's solo band.

title: Oliver Twist (Vaughn De Leath song)
text: Oliver Twist is a 1921 song written by singer Vaughn De Leath (born Leonore von der Liethi), and performed by her as the first song sung by confirmed trans-Atlantic commercial radio broadcast.

title: Oliver Twist (Vaughn De Leath song)
text: In 1922 the song was one of the early major tie ups between silent pictures and music publishers, with De Leath's song being sung, and played instrumentally, during showings of the 1922 silent film "Oliver Twist" starring the child actor Jackie Coogan.

title: Girls' Generation (song)
text: Girls' Generation (Hangul: 소녀시대; RR: "Sonyeo Sidae") is a Korean song sung by several artists.

title: Girls' Generation (song)
text: The song was originally sung by Lee Seung-chul in 1989, released on his self-titled album "Lee Seung-chul: Part 2" (Korean: 이승철 1집 Part 2).

title: Girls' Generation (song)
text: It was covered by Maya in 2005 and girl group Girls' Generation in 2007, whose band name is derived from the song's.

title: Girls' Generation (song)
text: also performed the song at Superstar K in 2009 and it was released on "" which contains songs by the first Superstar K Top 10.

title: The River (1984 film)
text: The River is a 1984 American drama film directed by Mark Rydell, written by Robert Dillon and Julian Barry, and stars Mel Gibson, Sissy Spacek, and Scott Glenn.

title: The River (1984 film)
text: The film tells the story of a struggling farm family in the Tennessee valley trying to keep its farm from going under in the face of bank foreclosures and floods.

title: The River (1984 film)
text: The father faces the dilemma of having to work as a strikebreaker in a steel mill to keep his family farm from foreclosure.

title: The River (1984 film)
text: It was based on the true story of farmers who unknowingly took jobs as strikebreakers at a steel mill after their crops had been destroyed by rain.

title: Maverick (film)
text: Maverick is a 1994 American Western comedy film directed by Richard Donner and written by William Goldman, based on the 1950s television series of the same name created by Roy Huggins.

title: Maverick (film)
text: The film stars Mel Gibson as Bret Maverick, a card player and con artist collecting money to enter a high-stakes poker game.

title: Maverick (film)
text: He is joined in his adventure by Annabelle Bransford (Jodie Foster), another con artist, and lawman Marshall Zane Cooper (James Garner).

title: Maverick (film)
